LEAD: A CH-54 cargo helicopter, on loan from the Connecticut National Guard, carrying an outmoded Coast Guard HH-52 helicopter yesterday in a demonstration of lifting capability. The Sky Crane is part of an exhibition this week-end called ''Vietnam, the Helicopter War'' at the sea-air-space museum on board the carrier Intrepid at the foot of West 46th Street.

LEAD: A Senate subcommittee yesterday subpoenaed records of a financial adviser to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d in connection with a corruption investigation involving the Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx military contractor.

LEAD: Galina Heifetz, a violinist from Kiev who immigrated in 1979, gave a recital at Merkin Concert Hall Tuesday evening that was most notable for its inclusion of Arthur Honegger's bold, gritty sonata for unaccompanied violin, a work of 1940 that reflects the composer's lifelong veneration for Bach in its ways and means of treating the violin as a solo instrument.

LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3*ALASKA AIR GROUP (NYSE) Qtr to March 31 1987 1986 Revenue 141,375,000 98,786,000 Net loss b5,437,000 b4,849,000 b-After tax credits of $5,882,000 and $2,076,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

LEAD: Dan Ruff, a pitcher and second baseman for Fairfield Union High School in Lancaster, Ohio, is happy that he finally has broken the national high school career record for home runs. ''I was getting overanxious a lot and swinging at bad pitches,'' said the senior slugger after cracking homer No. 52, his 13th this season, in a 18-6 victory over Bloom-Carroll in which Ruff was also the winning pitcher.

LEAD: While the nation awaits the ''comprehensive proposals to enhance our competitiveness'' that President Reagan promised in his State of the Union Message last January, Ohio is beginning to reap the rewards of a four-year-old industrial strategy.

LEAD: Two lanes of a highway bridge to replace the one that collapsed into the Schoharie Creek last month is scheduled to open by December, Governor Cuomo announced today, and the new four-lane bridge is expected to be completed by the spring of 1988.

LEAD: Tennis Navratilova and Graf Gain: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova beat West Germany's Claudia Kohde-Kilsch, 6-2, 6-3, yesterday to reach the semifinals of the $150,000 Italian Open in Rome. The victory set up a match between Navratilova and Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina, who outclassed Aranxta Sanchez of Spain, 6-0, 6-0.

LEAD: Treasury bond prices climbed and yields dropped yesterday as the market continued to express relief that the $29 billion quarterly refunding was over and that the dollar held firm against the Japanese yen. Bill rates were essentially unchanged after the Federal Reserve moved directly to add reserves to the banking system.

LEAD: In Alice McDermott's critically acclaimed new novel, ''That Night,'' the narrator comments that ''even children know you cannot separate the tale from the teller.'' The narrator, because of what is going on in her own life, is obsessed with an event she witnessed one night more than 20 years ago, when she was 10 years old - a teen-age boy, unaware that his girlfriend is pregnant and that she has been sent away to relatives in another state, drives onto the lawn in front of the girl's house in a Long Island suburb in the 1960's, threatens her mother and gets into a fight with the neighbors.

LEAD: Security forces tonight killed eight attackers who rammed a bomb-laden earthmover into a County Armagh police station, the authorities said. They reported a bystander slain and three officers wounded.

LEAD: President Reagan signed a bill today designating the Santa Fe Trail, stretching 950 miles from Missouri to New Mexico, as the Santa Fe National Historic Trail. The measure grants administrative jurisdiction over the trail, an important trade and settlement route from about 1820 to 1880, to the Secretary of Interior.

LEAD: Alone at the dais and unaccompanied by any of his Warsaw Pact allies, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski today delivered a four-part plan for nuclear and conventional weapon disengagement covering four East European and five West European nations.

LEAD: The American Chamber Opera Company will present Purcell's ''Dido and Aeneas'' and the premiere of Alice Shield's ''Shaman,'' at 8 tonight at Tomi Theater, 23 West 73d Street (781-0857). Admission is $10.

LEAD: Philippe Bianconi, who won second prize in the 1985 Van Cliburn piano contest, played his first Carnegie Hall recital on Thursday evening as if he were still competing. The appearance, part of his reward, was pianistically impressive in many ways but left an incomplete picture of the young Frenchman as a musician.

LEAD: Michael K. Deaver, the former Presidential aide, refused to testify a second time before a Federal grand jury that is investigating his lobbying activities, a special prosecutor disclosed today.

LEAD: When the Caltex Petroleum Corporation decided to move its headquarters from Manhattan to the Dallas suburbs in 1982, Amy C. Tubens, a secretary, was apprehensive about leaving her home in Jackson Heights, Queens, to live here.

LEAD: JOHN HEGLE first took out a student loan during his freshman year at Southwest Missouri State University in Springfield. Eight loans and seven years later, Mr. Hegle, now armed with a master's degree in public administration, has joined the labor force $20,000 in debt.

LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating State Department employees in connection with security breaches at the American Embassy in Moscow, according to a letter that the F.B.I. Director, William H. Webster, sent to a senator today.

LEAD: A Company News report in Business Day yesterday, about Resorts International, incorrectly described an offer made by a group led by Marvin Davis. The $220 million bid that Resorts rejected was only for its Paradise Island operations. The revised plan, like the original one, offered $140 in cash and one share in a recapitalized Resorts for each of Resorts' class B shares, and $15 and three shares for each class A share.

LEAD: The Bronx Opera Company will present Donizetti's ''Elixir of Love'' tonight at 8 at Lehman College Theater, Bedford Park Boulevard West and Goulden Avenue, the Bronx (787-1356). Admission is $10 to $12.

LEAD: In his novel ''Hands of a Stranger,'' Robert Daley, a former deputy police commissioner for public affairs in New York City, brings the reader vividly into the often murky world of police precincts and courthouses, of deals and cutting corners. For television, the playwright Arthur Kopit has burrowed into the interior of that world, latching onto its peculiar personal tensions and never letting go.

LEAD: Two men were sentenced today to 25 years to life in prison for the contract slaying of a man whose death the authorities said was arranged by his wife. Jose Garcia, 19 years old, and Antonio Rivera, 21, both of New York City, were convicted last month in Nassau County Court of second-degree murder for their part in the shooting death of Daniel Lew, 35, as he left his Valley Stream cigar store last June.

LEAD: Britain still seemed on course for a June general election today after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party made a solid showing in 12,000 local elections throughout England, Wales and Scotland.
LEAD: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North made an unannounced appearance in Federal court today, apparently in a dispute over his willingness to cooperate with a grand jury.

LEAD: In July 1986 the world's population, which didn't top a billion until 1850, passed the five billion mark. The Population Institute, a public-interest group that seeks a better balance between population and world resources, warns that the five billion may be ten billion by 2028. All the more reason to lament the Reagan Administration's abandonment of family planning overseas out of misguided obeisance to the right to life movement.

LEAD: Shostakovich E minor Piano Trio (Op. 67) is a bleak work, written during the Second World War and filled with evocations of suffering and despair. The final movement, the work's most ambitious, is thought to be a statement by the composer about Nazi extermination camps. It weaves Jewish folk themes into what becomes a frightening, macabre dance with an ironic conclusion - the strings playing in the highest, most eerie register while the pianist executes a solemn chorale.

LEAD: ''But what about the terrorists?'' people ask my husband and me when we tell them we are moving to Paris from the idyllic college town of Princeton, N.J. LEAD: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center opened its latest round of concerts with an utterly haunting novelty, a nocturne for string quintet composed by Dvorak in 1870. It is a rapt, melodious slow movement of great concentration and small contrast; it went through several recyclings as a potential part of multimovement works before the composer decided to let it stand by itself - which, one supposes, is why it is so rarely heard.

LEAD: Executives at The Miami Herald, who have vigorously defended their newspaper's coverage of Gary Hart, were reticent today as the former Senator announced he was ending his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

LEAD: Three bridge and tunnel officers working in toll booths at the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel were overcome by carbon monoxide yesterday morning after problems developed in the ventilation system, officials said.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, appearing to step up Administration pressure on Japan, warned today that the Japanese economy was ''exceedingly vulnerable'' to a major reduction in its trading surplus.
LEAD: Divorce and remarriage will become legal in Argentina under legislation adopted at midnight Thursday by the Senate.

LEAD: Workers inspecting derailed railroad cars in the Columbia River Gorge, about 50 miles northeast of Portland, Ore. Twenty cars left the tracks Thursday afternoon; 13 burned and three were catapulted into the river. One of the cars contained 190 pounds of slightly radioactive material which was consumed by the fire.
LEAD: For the first time in the Iran-Iraq war, a Soviet ship has been attacked in the Persian Gulf, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: It was never clear that Gary Hart would be elected President or even that he would be the Democratic nominee in 1988. His downfall and political demise is a sad spectacle, nonetheless, and one that must leave many an American uneasy and disheartened.

The crate sat for days and days in a hangar at Kennedy International Airport, presumably to be sure it was not explosive or illegal.

LEAD: ACCORDING TO LEGEND, the Russian troops occupying Paris after the fall of Napoleon were unhappy with the off-handed treatment they received from the local tavern-keepers. LEAD: THERE IS A CRISIS IN NETWORK NEWSROOMS, although then again maybe there's not. Congress has wondered what's up. Is a network news division a public trust or, God forbid, a ''profit center,'' and whatever the answer, what are the implications? The discussion has been going on for months, in Washington and on Wall Street, in newspapers and in seminars, and on television itself.

LEAD: AS the first week of hearings on the Iran-contra affair drew to a close, new questions had been raised about Ronald Reagan's involvement. But the public still had not learned what the President knew and when he knew it.

LEAD: ''It was just above me and I could see the faces in the windows. There was some sputtering from the two engines on the right side. Then the plane disappeared into the trees and there was a big explosion with fire and smoke. The ground shuddered.'' - Czeslaw Buchalksi, after183 died in the crash of a Polish airliner.
LEAD: AT this time of year, when home landscapers are busy seeking out and planting the best small evergreens for their needs, the work of one man has special significance.

LEAD: THREE or four times a week Raeza Raein, a Washington businessman, goes to the Four Seasons Hotel in Georgetown for afternoon tea. ''A couple of times it's for business, a couple of times for pleasure,'' he said as he reclined in a fat armchair there one recent afternoon, a china teapot and a plate of pastries arrayed before him.
LEAD: A convict on parole from the Utah State Prison was held today for questioning in connection with what the authorities said was a plot to assassinate 10 prison officials.

LEAD: CREDIT reporting agencies have been keeping tabs on Americans' spending habits for years, selling the information to banks and other lenders. Now TRW Inc., the biggest of these watchdogs, has introduced a unique marketing twist: It wants consumers to pay $35 a year for a package of services centered on their credit reports, some of questionable value, others available for free.

LEAD: IT took only the opening theme of Mendelssohn's ''Variations Serieuses'' to establish that Gerald Robbins's evening of piano music at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday would be an event of substance. The balance of voices, the dignified movement, the kind of definition that subdued the encroaching loudness of this acoustical space - were qualities that carried through the rest of his pieces.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Dennis Rasmussen of the Yankees did not yield any home runs last night, something he has done frequently this season, especially with no one on base. But his offense let him down as he pitched a complete game at the Stadium.
LEAD: AN unexpected debut occurred Friday night at the New York State Theater when Michel Mesnier danced the ''Tema con Variazioni'' sequence of George Balanchine's ''Tchaikovsky Suite No. 3.''

LEAD: Canoeing around Ontario's near north one day in 1615, the French adventurer Samuel de Champlain found what he had long been searching for, a river that French fur traders could ply to paddle their pelts out from as far west as present-day Sault Ste. Marie. Some 300 years later well-heeled Pittsburghers - this time in search of nothing more esoteric than a patch of fresh air -discovered the same French River.

LEAD: THE GREAT DISAPPOINT-ment of this concert season was Leonard Bernstein's withdrawal of Charles Ives's Fourth Symphony from his Philharmonic programs. It is Ives's biggest and most difficult work; Leopold Stokowski gave the premiere with his American Symphony Orchestra in 1965 only after weeks of rehearsals and after failed attempts with other orchestras.

LEAD: The funeral of William J. Casey, the former Director of Central Intelligence who died Wednesday, was marked today by the controversy that continues to swirl around President Reagan's policy of aiding the rebels fighting the Government of Nicaragua.
LEAD: THE dollar continues to confound and confuse. Has it fallen too much or too little? Must it be stabilized or drop further?

LEAD: MY mother has come again for an extended stay. She comes now with a home health aide to care for her and tend to her needs, a hospital bed and other assorted paraphernalia of the aged and infirm. Most of the time she knows she is at my house but she does not always remember why, and there are times when she speaks of her visit as if she were in a hotel.

LEAD: MOST OF THE TIME IT IS INVISIBLE from earth, hurtling along at speeds over 2,000 miles an hour at altitudes up to 100,000 feet. The United States Air Force SR-71 is the world's fastest, technically most advanced spy plane, capable of seeing more from a greater distance than any other aircraft. And recent developments - the escalation of espionage between East and West, the curtailment of NASA's Space Shuttle program and the loss of several spy satellites through technical failures - have made this extraordinary plane more vital than ever.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: The air in Pittsburgh, a city once branded ''hell with the lid off,'' has for some time ceased to be a black joke without a punch line. Now, unlike the air in New York, Baltimore or Chicago, it even meets Federal standards for cleanliness, state officials have announced.
LEAD: Tom Chambers scored 38 points and Dale Ellis added 32 today to lead the SuperSonics to a 117-102 victory over Houston and a 3-1 lead in their four-of-seven-game playoff series.
LEAD: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of the letters it elicits.
LEAD: Patricia Anne Woods was married yesterday to Richard Esten Andersen at the Fourth Universalist Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Joyce Smith performed the ceremony.

LEAD: THE pieces of county-owned land listed last month by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke are either too small, too wet, too rocky or not really available for moderate-priced housing, according to officials in the communities where the land is situated.

LEAD: SQUEEZE disbanded in 1982. But the crowd that packed the Ritz on Wednesday for the last of the reunited band's three sold-out shows greeted the barrage of insidiously catchy songs as enthusiastically as if they were the latest pop hits. One had to wonder where all these people were in 1979-80, when ingenious pop-rock confections like ''Another Nail in My Heart'' and ''Pulling Mussels (from the Shell)'' were failing to win Squeeze the American mass audience the critics insisted the band deserved.
LEAD: More than 2,000 students were awarded degrees by Howard University at commencement ceremonies yesterday at the university's main campus in Washington.

LEAD: ONE day a few weeks ago, a large garbage container appeared on Columbus Avenue near 62d Street in Manhattan. The bin, provided for a nearby construction project, blocked the fire hydrant in front of a restaurant. Police Officer Edward Acevedo, who walks past the restaurant nearly every day as part of his duties as a member of the Community Patrol Officer Program in the 20th Precinct, called the Sanitation Department.

LEAD: Brian Propp, Philadelphia's version of a tight-lipped Jim McMahon, ran a calloused hand over his latest brush cut, removed his opaque wraparound sunglasses, and considered the spectacle of the black-shirted Flyers gliding through a practic session today.

LEAD: FOR SIX years, Governor Kean has tried to change New Jersey's automobile-insurance law to limit nuisance suits, but just when he appears to have his best chance, the changes he wants seem to have developed a language problem.
LEAD: Dorothy Kachmar, a mother of five from Punxsutawney, Pa., arrived in New York City recently with her daughter to visit Michael Hall and his 5-year-old girl.

LEAD: IT worked for Tupperware. So now hospitals are using the same idea: getting a group of women to gather in a home for games, prizes, refreshments and a sales pitch. But at the BodyCues women's home health care parties sponsored by the St. Elizabeth Medical Center in Dayton, Ohio, the pitch comes from doctors and nurses - and what is being sold is nothing less than the hospital itself.
LEAD: YOU LIVE AND LOVE And Other Stories. By Valentin Rasputin. Translated by Alan Myers. Foreword by Richard Lourie. 180 pp. New York: Vanguard Press. $16.95.
LEAD: REMEMBERING A STAR

LEAD: CALLING it the best budget of the 10 he has prepared, an ebullient Mayor Koch last week proposed a $22.7 billion municipal spending plan -$1.2 billion higher than this year's - for the fiscal year that begins in July.
LEAD: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of the letters it elicits.

LEAD: Elizabeth Zeltner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Zeltner of Pound Ridge, N.Y., was married last evening to Lawrence Brian Sorrel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Sorrel of Scarsdale, N.Y. Cantor Raymond Smolover officiated at the Pierre.

LEAD: CALL it a mini-spoken opera, a music monodrama or just a hybrid. Whatever the designation, ''Through Roses,'' with its cast of one actor (Harold Gould), one conductor (Paul Dunkel) and eight musicians (members of the New Orchestra of Westchester) represents a departure for East Coast Arts at Wildcliff, where it is playing through next Sunday.

LEAD: It appears to me that Susanne Batzdorff misunderstands the concept of martyrdom. Martyrdom is not the desire to die. Rather it is the belief that there is something more important even than one's own life, to wit, one's convictions, one's principles or what one perceives to be the truth.
LEAD: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of the letters it elicits.
LEAD: IN announcing his withdrawal from the 1988 Presidential campaign on Friday, Gary Hart said that elections should be decided on issues.

LEAD: When Representative Stewart B. McKinney, a 56-year-old Republican from Connecticut, died last week of an infection brought on by AIDS, his office issued a statement attributing the disease to blood transfusions received during heart bypass surgery in 1979. But some friends and associates of Mr. McKinney, who were concerned that people needing transfusions would be needlessly frightened, later disclosed that he had had homosexual relationships.
LEAD: Bonnie Tilkin was married last evening to Robert Saphir Alexander at the home of Albert Ross, the bride's uncle, in Tamarac, Fla. Rabbi Sheldon Harr performed the ceremony.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: FACE-TO-FACE with a record volume of empty offices, many of the nation's developers and builders are changing the way they do business. Smaller companies that were in the business just for the tax advantages have either left the field already or sold out at fire-sale prices. The larger, more diversified owners have reached far into their deep pockets and now are willing to cut major deals to finally fill some of their vacant buildings.
LEAD: Gary Hart's dizzy fall offered a searing look at scenes from a modern political marriage, painstakingly patched together in private only to be pulled apart in public.

LEAD: ONCE upon a time, motherhood was a sacred institution based on the combined arts and sciences of baking, laundering, polishing and mending, in addition to listening, advising, healing and nurturing. But as my musical hero Bob Dylan so aptly put it, ''The times, they are a-changing.''
LEAD: WITH ALL MY MIGHT An Autobiography. By Erskine Caldwell. Illustrated. 332 pp. Atlanta: Peachtree Publishers. $19.95.

LEAD: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 8 - Hugh Wolff is being widely credited for reviving the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, and tonight, in the first of five concert performances of Beethoven's ''Fidelio,'' he proved he is worth all the credit he's receiving. This was a passionately played and conducted, stalwartly sung and altogether convincing performance of one of the greatest operas in the repertory.

LEAD: Amanda McBroom, who achieved recognition in 1979 as the composer of the title song for ''The Rose,'' is one of the leading lights of the small but active Los Angeles cabaret scene. Ms. McBroom's music blends three different worlds. Original ballads like ''The Rose,'' ''Ship in a Bottle'' and ''From Where I Stand,'' have a pop-country melodic feel and the lyric precision of theater songs.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE HOUSTON ASTROS have activated Dickie Thon, a shortstop, and sent Bert Pena, another shortstop, to the club's minor league team in Tucson of the Pacific Coast League. Thon had been on a 20-day rehabilitation program at Tucson, where he hit .333 in 11 games. He walked out of the team's spring training camp because of blurred vision.

LEAD: FIVE HUNDRED SCORPIONS By Shelby Hearon. 306 pp. New York: Atheneum. $18.95.

LEAD: ABOUT seven years ago, Thomas J. Lipton Inc., the nation's largest tea producer, decided to branch out. After nearly a century of sticking to blends of black tea, it added Orange & Spice, Blackberry Brandy and other flavored teas to its product roster.

LEAD: Money spent on health accounts for 5 percent of the proposed city budget. According to the Office of Management and Budget, this year's allotment represents a $56.7 million increase over last year's.

LEAD: Police Officer Jerome Landry, who says he became a drug addict while working as an undercover agent, may return to the force despite a Police Department request that he be dismissed, the Police and Fire Commission ruled Thursday. Officer Landry told the commission last month that he became addicted because he had to use cocaine as part of his covert work.

LEAD: WHEN Borough President David N. Dinkins announced appointment of a Planning for Pedestrians Council in February, he said the council would make recommendations within a year. Last week, at its first public hearing, the council heard what dozens of New Yorkers, many representing community boards or citizens' action groups, think of the state of the sidewalks and intersections and what Julian Menken of Community Board 5 in central Manhattan called ''this bicycle infestation that we have.

LEAD: IN A LETTER TO ALEXANDER Woollcott half a century ago, Jerome Kern offered what may be the last word on the significance of Irving Berlin, who turns 99 tomorrow. ''Irving Berlin has no place in American music,'' wrote Kern. ''He is American music.'' And today that assessment still rings true, in spite of the fact Mr.

LEAD: For too long, say Board of Education officials, the city schools received too little from the city budget. But the picture began to brighten two years ago and looks brighter still this year. ''We've had a succession of good years and this was another in that succession,'' said Richard Riley, the spokesman for Schools Chancellor Nathan

LEAD: WHILE the recent Tax Act effectively axed many tax shelters, it hardly touched the tax breaks provided by life insurance. In particular, the single-premium policy has emerged as a popular tax-advantaged investment: You make a single payment up front - usually a minimum of $5,000, but in practice often $50,000 or $100,000 or more - that buys you a chunk of life insurance and an investment fund that appreciates tax-free as long as you keep the policy in force.

LEAD: THE Rev. Alphonse Stephenson, a diocesan priest who used to conduct the ''A Chorus Line'' orchestra on Broadway, has formed what is believed to be the first professional symphony orchestra in the nation specifically to raise funds for churches and nonprofit groups.

LEAD: With those corporate rites of spring - annual meetings - drawing to an end, shareholders may have been left with great expectations. Annual meetings, like annual reports, are meant to put the company's best foot forward. But shareholders who expect higher dividends may be disappointed.

LEAD: Analysts in and out of Government tore back to their calculators at last week's report of a drop of three-tenths of a percentage point in unemployment in April, to 6.2 percent, the lowest level in seven years.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A Brooklyn man was killed and three others were wounded by gunfire in a dispute over drugs in a hallway of a Bedford-Stuyvesant building, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: HOW FAR can you push a teapot? It would seem, from a group of works by Mayer Shacter, a California artist, at the Sheila Nussbaum Gallery here, that a teapot can be pushed to the point of disassembling the components. Of course, that implies that a sculptural form has been based on the concept of a teapot.
LEAD: When there was a knock on the door of his apartment in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, the former Haitian farmer would be gripped by fear, afraid it was the immigration agents.

LEAD: LIFE, after all, is not a one-way street. Living on Long Island had seemed to dictate that everything moved from the city to the suburbs. First we moved to the Island, and hardly looked back to Brooklyn.
LEAD: Dance of Life and Glaros scored similarly impressive victories while posting identical times in divisions of the Fort Marcy Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

LEAD: IN 1979 THE WORLD REMEMBERED - WITH EX-hibitions, congresses, publications - the Great Eruption of Mount Vesuvius that, in 79 A.D., buried the Roman towns of Herculaneum, Pompeii and Stabiae, on the Gulf of Naples, under volcanic ash, mud and lava. Next year will mark the 250th anniversary of the inauguration, at Herculaneum, of systematic excavation of those Vesuvian cities - a development of immense consequence not only for our knowledge of the ancient world but for the influence exerted over archeology, art and science, and over civilized consciousness, by the Vesuvian revelations.
LEAD: ALL hospitals in the state are required to have disaster plans. A building collapse and a radioactive alert forced hospitals in two cities to put their plans into practice.
LEAD: It was the last Saturday before Christmas in 1984 and the 20 or so passengers who were riding in subway car No. 7657 were wrapped up in private thoughts and conversations.

LEAD: AS a result of complaints -and officials say there have been many - the State Department of Motor Vehicles is beginning a statewide ''image-enhancer'' program to teach its gruff and put-upon driving inspectors how to be more sympathetic to people trying to pass their driving tests, the majority of whom are teen-agers.

LEAD: A Federal grand jury last week indicted a Conrail engineer on 16 counts of manslaughter, saying he showed ''wanton or reckless disregard for human life'' in driving through a stop signal and into the path of a speeding Amtrak train. In addition to the 16 passengers who died in the crash, 175 were injured.

LEAD: All the current hullabaloo about whether Edith Stein was killed because she was a Jew or because she was a Roman Catholic is irreligious and irrelevant (''A Martyr of Auschwitz,'' by Susanne M. Batzdorff, April 12). Of course, she died because of the Nazis' odium fidei! Jewish faith and Catholic faith are at their esoteric core the same faith: the faith of our common father, Abraham.

LEAD: Voters cast ballots today in the most fiercely contested election on this Mediterranean island since independence from Britain in 1964. All 65 seats in Parliament were at stake; results were not expected until Monday.

LEAD: ''UH-OH, CHUCK, THEY OUT TO get us!'' are the first words on the debut album by Public Enemy, ''Yo! Bum Rush the Show'' (Def Jam/Columbia BFC 40658, album and cassette) - the grittiest rap album so far this year and one of rap's fastest sellers. ''Us'' refers to Chuck D (whose last name is Ridenhour) and Flavor-Flav (William Drayton), Public Enemy's songwriters and rappers.

LEAD: The New Orleans Opera Guild Home was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Nancy Ellen Salathe and Thomas Denton Horan. Judge Lorain F. Wingerter of the Second City Court of New Orleans officiated.
LEAD: A man sought in the nearly fatal stabbing of a candidate for City Council president last week turned himself in this afternoon.

LEAD: THE VIEW FROM THE HOSPITAL After an emergency operation in a strange city, a convalescent man looks out at an ugly world that has never seemed so beautiful. This is from a story called ''The City'' in John Updike's new collection, ''Trust Me'' (Knopf).

LEAD: A group of academics, most of them professors at Queens College, have joined together in an unlikely real-estate venture that is teaching them a few things that are not readily available in the classroom. LEAD: Theresa Mary Levins was married yesterday to Patrick Dunne Walker at St. Mary Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Edward Flannery.

LEAD: Amelia O'Brien Parsons, a senior cataloguer in the arcade fine arts department of Sotheby's in New York, and Paul Stanley Bird, who expects to receive a J.D. degree May 24 from the Yale Law School, were married yesterday. LEAD: THE YACHTSMAN from Jamestown, R.I., who built his own sailboat for a race around the world won the Class II prize yesterday in the BOC Challenge competition. Mike Plant crossed the finish line in Newport, R.I., at 2:10 P.M., completing his 27,000-mile solo voyage in 157 days 11 hours 44 minutes 44 seconds.

LEAD: TWO hundred years ago, Canaan Parish's population of less than a hundred people was decimated. With the Revolutionary War ended, the Loyalists had fled, and many other families had moved to New York or Vermont in search of better farmland.

LEAD: HIS right knee was caked with blood and his tennis whites were covered in clay, a souvenir from the stadium court at Forest Hills. For Boris Becker, these were the signs of an honest night's work, the measure he uses to evaluate his performance. He, more than those around him - the hangers-on, news media and fans - appears to know his limitations, to understand that progress does not always result in victory and that inexperience is still his biggest adversary.

LEAD: JULIET SHAW has always loved duo piano, in which two pianists play musical works arranged for two pianos. In her living room in Norwalk stand twin grand pianos, and she is happiest when each is occupied by one of her two daughters, both accomplished pianists.

LEAD: A Polish airliner bound for New York crashed and burned here today after the pilot unsuccessfully tried to bring his faltering jet back to the airport less than an hour after takeoff. All 183 people aboard were killed.

Wuensch, the Deputy Police Commissioner for Management and Budget, said the ''first and most dramatic imperative'' would be to expand the Community Patrol Officer Program, the three-year-old initiative that puts officers back on foot patrol in neighborhoods.

LEAD: About 50 stunned, sobbing relatives and friends of the passengers on a New York-bound Polish jetliner that crashed near Warsaw gathered at Kennedy International Airport yesterday, only to learn that there was no hope for anyone aboard the ill-fated flight.

LEAD: JIMMY WITHERSPOON, a veteran blues singer, is singing the blues with more than theatrical emotion at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas between Ninth and Tenth Streets. He is fighting a throat problem that leaves his voice less rich, less resonant and free than it once was. But the effort gives his performances a sense of involvement that can be unusually strong, even with a restricted voice.

LEAD: IT has been a long time coming, but the people in Japan who don't smoke are starting to steam. Emboldened by the militancy of their American counterparts, they are insisting on, and winning, the right to smoke-free surroundings - not an easy battle in a male-dominated society where three in five men smoke.

LEAD: WHEN the Hudson River Valley Association celebrated its 20th birthday two years ago, the tourist association was nearly moribund. It was kept alive by erratic financial support from various hotels, restaurants and historic-sites organizations and by the volunteer staffs from the Sleepy Hollow Restorations and Boscobel, a 19th-century historic house in Garrison.

LEAD: IT'S TIME TO COME TO THE DEFENSE of the American moviegoing public, too often and too glibly characterized as a collective cretin with the taste of a 12-year-old and the brain of a gnat. In fact, the American moviegoing public is incredibly sophisticated. LEAD: THINGS are a bit different these days for Wang Yijung, and Union County is quite different from Beijing, but the master chef is starting to enjoy himself and to see that this part of America will be his universe for two years.

LEAD: St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church here is where the idea for the Orchestra of St. Peter by the Sea began to evolve just over a year ago, when its first concert sold out weeks beforehand to a standing-room-only audience of 400.

LEAD: Berlin is about to begin celebrating its 750th anniversary, and on both sides of the wall there will be a great outpouring of art, theater, music and so on, enough to keep things humming for the rest of the year. As usual, culture and politics will be cunningly intermingled in ways not always visible, for in this remarkable city you cannot play a sonata or exhibit a painting without touching a political chord.

I hold that she isn't a surrogate anything. I say she is the mother. As in real, actual, honest-to-God mother.

LEAD: SWIRLING onto the New York social scene like so many taffeta tornadoes are this spring's ball gowns, which seem to be setting a new standard for opulence. Few, and not far enough between, are the chairs that can accommodate these splendiferous garments, whose skirts drape or balloon over the edge of chairs like parachutes floating to rest.

LEAD: Since summer is nearly here, the sun and the swimming season cannot be far behind. For those women who haven't already found an attractive suit, there are many new ones to choose from. Sleek in fit, daring in shape and hot in shade, they will certainly light up any beach. One requisite, though, will be a superb figure.

LEAD: STANDING IN HIS PITEOUSLY FURNISHED Manhattan apartment not long ago, Gidon Kremer said he had changed his mind. The man Herbert von Karajan called ''the greatest violinist in the world'' was exhausted from his concert 13 hours before and still jet-lagged from a trans-Atlantic flight four days earlier.

LEAD: DESPITE having fallen nearly 40 percent since February 1985, the dollar continues to be overvalued. In fact, it will have to decline as much as 30 percent to eliminate the remaining trade deficit, create the conditions for cutting the Federal budget deficit and force Europe and Japan into more reasonable macroeconomic policies.

LEAD: GIVEN THE HEFTY PRICE of television sets, repair is often preferable to replacement. This is especially true of sets housed in elaborate consoles. Such sets, over the years, become familiar furniture whose loss would be tantamount to a domestic upheaval.

LEAD: I HAVE lusted, oft as not, over objects made of fiberglass and steel, with a bit of leather thrown in here and there. It is hard to say how some of them have escaped me, but the list is long, a whole litany of automobiles I have coveted but not possessed.
LEAD: LAST September, just before the World Series was to begin, The New York Post asked Mets star Howard Johnson about his biggest worry going into the pennant race.

LEAD: ON street corners of Manhattan, pedestrians dodge, squeeze and shove their way past sidewalk emporiums offering T-shirts, sunglasses, snack foods, cigarettes, jewelry, lipstick, even cotton candy. Nominally known as newsstands, the establishments pay pennies a day for rent.

LEAD: Twenty years ago the residences in the Hispanic section of the South End lay dilapidated and ruined, and the city was preparing to raze them in an urban renewal project. But about 200 Puerto Rican immigrants who had settled in the area refused to move.

LEAD: The ''cottages,'' as they are called locally, comprise a little low-rise oasis on Third Avenue between East 77th and East 78th Streets. Built in 1937, they occupy a prime potential development site, a full blockfront on the bustling avenue just outside the Upper East Side Historic District. Only two stories high, with a large garden, they are 50 years old this year.

LEAD: The additional $103 million for foster care would permit some innovations, including a computer to track vacancies in foster homes and a new unit to review adoptions. The largest chunk - $66 million - would be used to provide foster-family standing for relatives who take in children. There are 3,000 such families now, caring for 6,600 children who are related to them.

LEAD: At Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., 518 students were awarded degrees yesterday. LEAD: No, the Triple Crown has not lost stature; present day million-dollar bonuses have only distorted what has always been the true picture. Thoroughbred breeders and owners recognize that the 11 winners of the Triple Crown are the apex of the breed: superbly athletic, resilient to stress and of strong will and great heart.

The Rev. John A. Gilmore performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Milford,
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: STORMING THE MAGIC KINGDOM Wall Street, the Raiders, and the Battle for Disney. By John Taylor. Illustrated. 261 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.
LEAD: MY MOTHER tied a ribbon in my hair the day she took me to the public library for my first card. I wore my best dress and I was nervous.

LEAD: Beverly Miller and Peter Busch Orthwein were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York by the Rev. C.Hugh Hildesley. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul L. Miller of New Vernon, N.J. Mr. Orthwein is a son of Mrs. David D. Metcalfe and Adolphus Busch Orthwein, both of St.
LEAD: MARCH OF TIME'S SHOW BUSINESS - THE WAR YEARS Embassy Home Entertainment. 75 minutes. $24.95.

LEAD: Memorial services will be held Thursday for Representative Stewart B. McKinney, a Republican and nine-term Congressman from Connecticut who died of an AIDS-related infection. The service will be held at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport at 2 P.M. The McKinney family has also announced the formation of the S.B.

LEAD: NEARLY 50 years ago, I encountered my first fishing tournament and in the interim nothing has altered my original perception of them as a poor substitute for hoeing potatoes or other equally pleasurable pursuits.

LEAD: ONE of the many nice things about the Arena Players Repertory Theater is that aside from offering lightweight comedies and mysteries during its season, it also makes a point of presenting great American classic drama. It is currently offering Tennessee Williams's Pulitzer Prize-winning masterpiece, ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.
LEAD: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of the letters it elicits.

LEAD: Anne Tarver Hebner and Michael David Harris were married yesterday at St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church in Fairfield, Conn., by the Rev. Edward J. Scull. The bride, who is known as Tarver, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Hebner 3d of Southport, Conn. She is a graphics designer for the Carter Printing Company in Richmond.

LEAD: BEFORE he maneuvered the Chicago Cubs into first place in the National League East last week, Gene Michael hadn't managed a first-place team since June 11, 1981. The players' strike started the next day, insuring - as it turned out - the Yankees' presence in the postseason playoffs. Michael, however, did not make the playoffs.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE BIG NEWS IN VIENNA this season - culturally speaking, that is - has been the takeover of the ancient and honorable Burgtheater by a bunch of West German avant-gardists. Traditionalists are shaking their heads in dismay, but the theaters - the Burgtheater itself and the separate Akademietheater, under the same company's auspices - are full, and the press response has been enthusiastic.

LEAD: THE grass is growing; it may be necessary to mow more than once a week. Be sure mower blades are sharp and remember to set them to cut high, at least two inches or more since high cut encourages deep grass roots and makes the turf more drought resistant. Groom daffodils and tulips by snapping off faded flowers to prevent wasteful seed pods.

LEAD: Instead of seeking minority and bilingual teachers in foreign countries, the New York City Board of Education should establish a high school to prepare students to become teachers, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, Sandra Feldman, said yesterday.

LEAD: The Polish airline LOT made public this list of United States citizens and Polish residents of the United States who were killed in the crash of a Polish jetliner in Warsaw yesterday: U.S. CITIZENS BUKOWSKI, Bertha CLARK, Richard McConnel CWIK, Vincent Joseph CZECHOWSKI, Henry HANSON-ADRIAN, Kazimiera MALIN, Chester Stanley NESGODA, Richard Joseph NESGODA, Robert Leonard OBERBECK, Julianna OLSCHEWSKI, George PASZCUK, Bogdan PATRYLAK, Irene POCELAY, Martha Louise SOSNOWSKI, Adam SOSNOWSKI, Helena WIDERYNSKI, Elizabeth Grace WOJTAS-KOZIOL,

LEAD: Leslie Plesent, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Plesent of New York and Larchmont, N.Y., was married last evening to Jordan Charles Fox, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Fox of Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Harold Salzman performed the ceremony at the Seven Hills Inn in Lenox, Mass.

LEAD: Judith April Karp, director of public relations for the Philadelphia Orchestra, and Dr. Warren Scott Kurnick, a physician at the Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia, plan to be married June 27. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Justin Karp of Fairfax, Va., who have announced her engagement to a son of Harry Kurnick of Philadelphia and the late Sheryl

LEAD: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 1 A PERFECT SPY, by John le Carre. (Bantam, $4.95.) The tale of a British secret agent and his father, a flamboyant con man. 2 2 THE GOOD MOTHER, by Sue Miller. (Dell, $4.95.) A woman's attachment to her daughter becomes a consuming passion.

LEAD: IT HAS been easy and valid during the past decade to blame women's inability to reach senior management on corporate America's caste system - men at the top and women at the bottom or, more recently, at the middle management level. The reasons for women's failure to rise through the ranks more quickly are myriad and have been dissected ad nauseum - lack of drive, family considerations, lack of sponsors, the old-boy network.

LEAD: GENNADI Gerasimov, the Soviet spokesman, appeared at his Tuesday press briefing last week with a smug look and the collected works of Vladimir Ilyich Lenin. President Reagan, in a speech two days earlier to American newspaper publishers, had attributed to Lenin the menacing words that ''the road to America leads through Mexico.
LEAD: In the eyes of the authorities, the 30 young people gathered in the smoky back room of a bar called the South Railroad Station were plotting against the state.

LEAD: THE CONTINUED IMPOR-tance of LP's in the musical lives of serious record collectors has not only prompted the development of new turntables (as reported in last week's column) but also led to several noteworthy new designs of phono cartridges.
LEAD: MIAMI City of the Future. By T. D. Allman. 422 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $22.50.

LEAD: RESTAURANTS make statements about themselves. The West End Cafe says SoHo, not Carle Place. The ceilings are high enough to accommodate the full-size tree growing there. The decor is clean and modern: black and white tile floors, glass brick walls, neon signs, Art Deco light fixtures, brass railings and high-tech exposed water pipes.

LEAD: GEORGE ORWELL'S ''Nineteen Eighty-Four,'' published in 1949, portrayed a form of television as ''Big Brother,'' which beamed controlling messages to the public. Orwell may have misread the messages, but he pinpointed the messenger.

LEAD: James Thomas Kruger, a hard-line enforcer of apartheid who gained world notoriety for harshness as South Africa's Minister of Justice, died Friday at his home near Pretoria. He was 69 years old and had recently undergone heart surgery.

LEAD: More than 90 passengers on a ferryboat were feared to have drowned in the Yangtze River Friday when the ferry collided with a tugboat near the city of Nantong in Jiangsu Province, the official New China News Agency reported today.

LEAD: Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Betsy Bowman Phillips, a daughter of Melvin Burdette Phillips of Liberty, Ky., and the late Mrs. Phillips, to Edward Safford Mandel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Frank Mandel of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Lawrence J.
LEAD: People who believe their relatives might have been aboard the Polish airliner that crashed today can call (212) 944-8116 for information, a State Department spokeswoman announced.

LEAD: THE RETURN - SOME MIGHT even say the debut - of bistro-style cooking in the United States has restaurantgoers astir. But the puzzlement of the moment seems to be exactly how to define what it is.

LEAD: FOR the past week, Rita Reutter has been busy writing what she calls a ''very spiffy'' newspaper article to commemorate Older Americans Month. She is also busy writing other articles that involve the elderly, as well as putting out her monthly newspaper column.

LEAD: Israel's Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, who is also head of the Labor Party, threatened last week to try to break up the country's 31-month-old goverment over the issue of a proposed international peace conference on the Middle East. Mr. Peres, a former Prime Minister, favors the talks, whose participants would include Israel, Jordan, a Palestinian delegation, the United States and the Soviet Union.

LEAD: ''BARCELONA - NOW MORE than ever,'' say the bumper stickers all over this Catalan city, and if the tone smacks of boosterism, the reality in Barcelona is much more substantial. There is a sense of ever-mounting cultural energy in this city, as it looks toward the 1992 Olympics, and it is neatly balanced between a respect for

LEAD: A map purporting to show that the Vikings charted North America long before the arrival of Columbus, branded as a fraud in 1974, could turn out to be genuine after all, scientists at the University of California have concluded.
LEAD: West Berlin's all-night night life has kept it Germany's most truly cosmopolitan city.

LEAD: The American Civil Liberties Union has filed suit against this small Vermont town and its police chief on behalf of a local newspaper editor who contends the police are trying to intimidate him into editorial silence.

LEAD: Most of today's clustered condominiums are connected in such a way that barking, hammering and other din can permeate common walls, floating from living room to living room. But a 125-acre residential development planned for the Town of New Castle, N.Y., near Chappaqua, is trying to overcome this by having the condos attached at their garages.

LEAD: Because of a mechanical error, two arts-review headlines were reversed last Sunday on the bottom of page 76 in this section. The headlines that should have been transposed were ''Recital: Norma French Sings Grieg Program,'' and ''The Stage: 'Keeping Up.' ''

LEAD: FIVE years ago, when Melanie Snyder, an interior designer, went into business for herself, her New York apartment doubled as her office. Miss Snyder now has an office in White Plains, where she employs nine people, including her parents. She expects to reach $1 million in sales this year.
LEAD: INCREASINGLY these days, the average citizen is overcome with feelings of powerlessness.
LEAD: With a prayer and a shower of fireworks, campaigning ended today for legislative elections Monday that will restore a complete Government structure in the Philippines.

LEAD: The engagement of Gayle Debra Masri to Dr. Barry E. Fridling, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abe Fridling of Silver Spring, Md., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dorothy Cohn of Eastchester, N.Y., and Norman Masri of Weehawken, N.J.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: SAYING he would tell the Knicks tomorrow night whether he was interested in the team's coaching job. Coach Dick Motta of the Dallas Mavericks said he was definitely not interested in being hired as the team's general manager. ''I tried that once,'' Motta said, referring to a stint as coach and general manager in Chicago.

LEAD: The ''urban cohorts'' of Emperor Augustus probably encountered less trouble in dealing with the crowds in the Forum and with the litter bearers, charioteers and horseback riders all around than do the blue-uniformed men and women of Rome's municipal police in their current battles with the city's more than one million cars.

LEAD: To the Editor: I have just returned from a four-week European trip that included 12 to 14 border crossings, many in the Bregenz area where Germany, Switzerland and Austria meet. My experience may be of interest to readers of the items (Travel, April 5) about French visas and Swiss superhighway stickers.
LEAD: LAST month, a 10-year-old boy rode his skateboard out of the family driveway in Vernon and collided with a passing car.

LEAD: ''PARADE rest,'' barked the United States-trained officer to troops wearing United States Army issue uniforms and drilling in front of barracks built with United States military aid. Every West African nation has a patron, usually the former colonial power - Britain, France or Portugal. Liberia has the United
LEAD: A majority of Americans approve of Nancy Reagan's handling of her role as the wife of the President, the Gallup Poll reports.

LEAD: Yes, there are various fringe, ideological, political and religious movements and superpatriotic cults in Japan, as there are in the United States and other democracies where the freedom to be different is guaranteed (''A New Japanese Nationalism,'' by Ian Buruma, April 12). Yes, these aberrations invite a reporter's attention, especially when they are found in a country that has Japan's reputation for conformity, consensus and the pursuit of harmony.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. W. Herbert Smith Jr. of Clover, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Janet McArthur Smith to William Edwards Hunt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Hunt of Cambridge, Mass. The wedding is to be June 27.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: For many people, Minorca is the plain Jane of the Balearic Islands. Less visually spectacular and poorer than Majorca, not as hip or trendy as Ibiza, the island to miss if you can't see them all. All true perhaps, but therein lies its charm, and because it has not been totally swamped by tourism or overrun by foreign boutiques, it retains a naturalness and authenticity that is at once soothing and refreshing.

LEAD: IN ONE OF THE GALLERIES OF THE current Whitney biennial, the work of the photographers Mike and Doug Starn, better known as the Starn Twins, and the collaborative painters David McDermott and Peter McGough face each other from opposite walls. With this juxtaposition, - perhaps the most provocative and appropriate in the entire exhibition - the biennial's curators signal that the artists have a lot in common, and to some extent they are right.

LEAD: ABOUT 15 miles north of here, within viewing range of the great peaks of the North Cascades, a series of sleek, suburban office parks are rising among tall cedars and moisture-rotted homesteads. Virtually overnight, this 2,300-acre stretch of low-rise offices has posed a significant challenge to tenant-needy developers throughout the

LEAD: I DON'T remember exactly when I stopped thinking of my mother as just my mother and began to look at her as a real person - a person like other people, like my friends' mothers who talked and laughed and carried on in the regular world.

LEAD: IN this era of two-income families, going out to dinner is often a nonevent, a mere excuse to avoid cooking at the end of a working day; it is no longer always a special occasion. A clutch of pleasant restaurants have opened to meet our new need, establishments that are fun and informal with light-hearted atmospheres.

LEAD: President Reagan moved toward a major collision with Congress today when he threatened to veto any legislation that restricted his flexibility in arms control talks or provided what he considers to be inadequate levels of military spending.
LEAD: Marty McSorley's goal with 36 seconds to play tonight gave the Edmonton Oilers a 2-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings in Game 3 of their semifinal series.

LEAD: K. D. LANG comes on strong. She started her set Monday at the Bottom Line with a torchy ballad, leaning over the electric piano and emoting in throbbing, overwrought crescendoes that most country singers would save for peaks. Not Ms. Lang: she built from there.

LEAD: Seattle's array of seafood, which already boasts remarkable variety, has been graced with a new arrival recently. Tiny pink and spiny scallops from Puget Sound have appeared in fish markets and on restaurant menus. Because the entire animal is consumed right out of the shell, scallop lovers enjoy the full, sweet richness of their meat, and they must be served absolutely fresh, within 48 hours of being taken from the water, for there is no middle ground between that and spoilage.
LEAD: THE on-again, off-again controversy over whether to save the old Loew's Theater in Journal Square, Jersey City, is on again, but a final decision is said to be just weeks away.

LEAD: Peter Maas's distressing story of the victimization of Teresa Taylor, her young son and, ultimately, her entire family by a violent husband is, tragically, not an anomaly in our society (''Legacy of a Mother's Murder,'' April 12). The latest Federal Bureau of Investigation statistics indicate that 30 percent of the women murdered in this country are killed by their husbands, former husbands or boyfriends (usually after having suffered years of physical and emotional abuse).

LEAD: More than 50 tons of fish were killed when cyanide discharged from a textile factory polluted 25 miles of the Meijiang, a river in southern Guangdong Province, the official China Daily reported today.

LEAD: A Federal judge, warning that overcrowding at the Westchester County Jail could lead to a riot unless it is relieved, has ordered the county to reduce the number of inmates housed in its jail building.

LEAD: KEVIN KEELEY is well aware of what Little League baseball has done for Williamsport, Pa., putting it on the map as the home of the Little League World Series. Now Mr. Keeley is convinced that Little League baseball can be a key to revitalizing Bridgeport.

LEAD: A water truck crashed into a crowd of pedestrians and street vendors here Friday night, killing at least 17 people and injuring five others, witnesses said. The accident occurred in the densely populated Post Marchand slum neighborhood.

LEAD: THE collapse April 23 of an apartment complex under construction in Bridgeport in which 28 workers died is likely to cause tremors throughout the state's construction industry as regulators and professional organizations turn to some of the problems exposed by the disaster.

LEAD: A LONG a dirt road winding through Nicaragua's northern mountains, a patrol of Sandinista troops suddenly went on combat alert the other day after hearing a report that a rebel squad had just crossed the road less than a mile ahead.

LEAD: Vice President Bush today began outlining his major policy positions for the 1988 Presidential campaign with a strong statement on public ethics, saying democratic institutions required ''a high degree of trust.''

LEAD: Mother's Day remains the prototypical greeting card holiday, yet the cards have a strained quality. For instance, one card selected at random from the Mother's Day section of a shop on Fifth Avenue bears the photograph of a monarch butterfly landing in a flower garden. Etched on the pink background are the words, ''Mother, You're Especially Dear.

LEAD: Was there ever a liner that skimmed the Atlantic with more grace than the Normandie? Frank O. Braynard, a historian of passenger shipping, meticulously details the life of the proud French ship that linked Le Havre and New York between 1935 and 1939 in PICTURE HISTORY OF THE NORMANDIE (Dover, Paper, $9.95).

LEAD: ' I do not believe that the meaning of the Constitution was forever ''fixed'' at the Philadelphia Convention. Nor do I find the wisdom, foresight and sense of justice exhibited by the Framers particularly profound. To the contrary, the government they devised was defective from the start, requiring several amendments, a civil war and momentous social transformation to attain the system of constitutional government, and its respect for the individual freedoms and human rights, we hold as fundamental today.

LEAD: At the Central Nyack Congregational Church in Valley Cottage, N.Y., Helen Dorothy Wuster, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Robert C. Wuster of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Donald Kokinchak, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Kokinchak of Somers, N.Y. The bride's father, a retired Congregational minister, participated in the ceremony, which was performed by the Rev.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The saga of cable television in New York City might be the stuff of a network series - if it is ever concluded. In the latest cliffhanger, a state official announced last week that agreement with the city on plans for cable installation in the Bronx and Brooklyn was at hand; the next day, Mayor Koch announced tersely that the agreement was postponed.
LEAD: Some airline fares to Scandinavia have been reduced by about 50 percent, as Northwest Orient, Tower Air and the Government-owned Scandinavian Airlines System have engaged in a fare war.
LEAD: IF January at the Hudson River Museum seemed particularly bleak, and it did, May looks like it will be unusually fine.

LEAD: For the last 10 years, researchers have accumulated data suggesting a possible connection between drinking and breast cancer. Two studies published last week in the New England Journal of Medicine made the association seem especially strong. While past studies have spoken of the possible dangers of consuming more than three drinks a day, the new research indicates that women might be increasing their risk of getting cancer by having only several drinks a week.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Rice University presented degrees to 650 undergraduates and 320 graduate students in commencement exercises today.

LEAD: JAZZ IN NEWARK Eddie Daniels, the virtuoso jazz clarinetist who came to his instrument via the alto and tenor saxophones, will be featured Friday evening in the Terrace Room at Newark Symphony Hall.

LEAD: EDITOR TO AUTHOR: The Letters of Maxwell E. Perkins, edited by John Hall Wheelock. (Scribners, $10.95.) At Charles Scribner's Sons, the editor Maxwell E. Perkins shepherded into print the works of Wolfe, Fitzgerald, Hemingway and others. In reviewing this selection from his letters, Alfred A. Knopf said in The Book Review in 1950 that all the authors ''were devoted to Perkins and none ever wandered from his or her allegiance.

LEAD: THE football season ended several months ago, but for me it still lingers. Here is why. I am an avid New York Giant football fan. I have been one for many years and have witnessed many losing seasons. Despite their past ineptness, I still loved them.

The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's on his way to the 80's. 2 2 14 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $18.95.) The nightmarish experiences that befall a woman and her family after her appointment as Ambassador to Rumania.

LEAD: IN the aftermath of South Africa's whites-only elections last week the anti-apartheid movement was looking, with some anxiety, for indications of how its struggle might continue, and what the Government's reactions might be.

LEAD: The Justice Department has started a internal investigation into the legality and propriety of connections between Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and the Wedtech Corporation, and Congress is asking that it work quickly.

LEAD: The theater season, once again, is more notable for its revivals than for its originals. To name but two, Eliza Doolittle is being transformed on Broadway by haughty Henry Higgins from a squashed cabbage to something resembling a duchess, while down around Sheridan Square, the relationship of a pair of male lovers is transformed by AIDS.

LEAD: WE have reached a stage on Long Island where the average Long Islander can no longer afford to buy the average-price house in Nassau or Suffolk.

LEAD: At the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn Heights yesterday Susan Elizabeth Rehm, a vice president for corporate finance of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Manhattan, was married to Joseph Daniel Gatto, an investment banker for Goldman, Sachs & Company in Manhattan. The Rev. Frank A. Goodwin performed the Congregational ceremony.

LEAD: NIKON is a camera company best known as a supplier of professional equipment, including rugged camera bodies, crisp lenses and fuss-free accessories. My earliest image of what a ''real'' camera looked like was a bruised and battered Nikon F, slung over the shoulder of a news photographer. Its black pentaprism was badly dented, and bits of brass showed through on the edges where the paint had worn off.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL 3-17 The President ordered the N.S.C. to arrange support for the contras after Congress restricted aid in 1984, Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, will tell Congress tomorrow, according to people familiar with Mr. McFarlane's planned testimony.

LEAD: The police said today that three senior figures in the Irish Republican Army were among the eight guerrillas killed when policemen and soldiers intercepted a raid on a police station Friay night.
LEAD: A National Geographic production narrated by Martin Sheen. Written and produced by Nicolas Noxon. Vestron Video. 1986. 60 minutes. $29.95.

LEAD: Thank you for the article ''Blending Heritage and Change'' [ Long Islanders, April 12 ] . I am grateful for the sensitivity in portraying me personally and the grasp of Hadassah's philosophy and mission.
LEAD: Margaret Ann Drewes was married yesterday to Richard G. Pyle at the Douglaston (Queens) Community Church by the Rev. John Meyer.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II, a native of Poland, was shaken today when he was informed that a Polish jetliner had crashed near Warsaw, killing all aboard, a Vatican official reported. ''The Holy Father immediately retired to his private chapel to pray,'' the official said.

LEAD: In recent days, the Rumanian Embassy has brought to Washington a chorus of 40 Jewish boys and girls who sang Yiddish songs and a delegation of 12 religious leaders of various denominations. These were not so much a part of a cultural exchange or to discuss comparative religion as a question of trade policy.
LEAD: TAKE a map of Manhattan, overlay a one-story building as wide and long as Central Park, then extend it eight blocks south to the edge of Rockefeller Center.
LEAD: In the year after, their infielders make errors, their hitters do not always come up with the necessary hit, and worst of all for the Mets, they cannot elude the big injury.
LEAD: For centuries, the bullock cart has symbolized the face of traditional India and its ancient, village-based civilization to the outside world.

LEAD: A spokesman for the Sail America Foundation, sponsor of the America's Cup-winning yacht Stars & Stripes, said tonight that the group will seek arbitration concerning membership of the site selection committee for the next America's Cup.
LEAD: ''I THOUGHT there was a need,'' said Jane Greenstein of Roslyn Heights. ''Sometimes that's the key to an idea - recognizing a need and going for it.''

LEAD: It was appropriate, somehow, that so much of the drama of former Senator Gary Hart's decision to withdraw from the 1988 Presidential campaign unfolded in New Hampshire, which has for so many years played a special role in the quadrennial American political pageant.

LEAD: ONE morning in May 1937, back from a year's study at Clare College, Cambridge, I sat reading ''Gone With the Wind'' in the New York apartment of my former Yale roommate Chester Kerr, wondering what to try next in the job line. A hoped-for spot on Time magazine had fallen through. The phone rang, and the call was for me - from another Yale classmate, Henry McKnight, who was working at The Herald Tribune.
LEAD: A new group of generals are taking command of the Army in perhaps the most sweeping change since World War II, and the shift is causing concern throughout the officer corps.

LEAD: THE United States Postal Service added some excitement to the regular 22-cent flag stamp by introducing a new one showing the flag against a night sky illuminated by fireworks. The stamp was issued in Denver, Colo. in conjunction with the stamp show, Rompex '87. It goes on sale tomorrow at post offices.

LEAD: In other centuries, and even in this one, the Roman Church referred to Protestant groups as ''heretical conventicles,'' so unyielding was the schism over Rome's authority. A few decades of ecumenicism have cast it in a softer light. Last week the Pope himself visited a center of the Reformation, and he said the movement had brought spiritual renewal to the Roman Catholic

LEAD: Unlike Leonard Kriegel, I am both ''looking better'' and ''growing particularly stronger,'' since beginning, at age 36, to work out on exercise machines three months ago (''The Purpose of Lifting,'' About Men, April 12). Moreover, I am not ''simply continuing''; I am changing, gradually but steadily.

LEAD: ''If you raise the discount rate, you build confidence in the financial markets that the U.S. authorities will fight inflation and defend the dollar. I think that would bring interest rates down.'' Sam Nakagama, economist with Nakagama & Wallace.

LEAD: A FIVE-YEAR boom in the development of office parks by colleges and universities may be ending just as dozens of schools have decided that their surplus real estate could help solve long-term financial problems. And while American universities are struggling to get their projects off the ground, Japan's municipal and regional governments have launched a crash program to create 26 ''technopolis'' centers before the turn of the century.

LEAD: AFTER the gray skies of winter break and patches of blue burst out more frequently from whitening clouds then, in the first glorious sun-filled days of spring, the human spirit rises to greet the coming season of rebirth. The warmth and promise, so different from the chill before and the dulling heat to come, provide the most delicious time of the year.
LEAD: A WOMAN I know has put her mother into a nursing home in a town some distance away. I asked why she had not chosen a place near by.

LEAD: CELEBRATED ART LOVERS FROM ALL OVER the world habitually flocked to 1914 Rittenhouse Square in Philadelphia, for 35 years the home of the late Henry P. McIlhenny, former chairman of the board of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, world-renowned collector and host. His drawing room was filled with a stunning collection of paintings and Charles X furniture, the dining room overlooked a garden shaded by magnolia trees, and the grand ballroom was festooned with classical columns -all providing a rich setting for countless salons, luncheons, teas and dances.
LEAD: ANYONE who saw ''High Spirits'' on Broadway in 1964 got two shows for the price of one: a perfectly agreeable musical and an evening with Beatrice Lillie.
LEAD: Crimes reported to the police rose 6 percent in 1986, the biggest increase in seven years, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today.

LEAD: Jonalyn S. Schuon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Schuon of Huntington, L.I., was married yesterday to J.Ross Baughman, a son of Patricia Hill Baughman of Bradenton, Fla., and Charles T. Baughman of Savannah, Ga., and Dearborn, Mich. Mayor Clair Wolf of Ephrata, Pa., performed the ceremony at the Ephrata
LEAD: A bomb exploded today in the Syrian-controlled north Lebanon resort of Zgharta during a visit by President Amin Gemayel, killing one man and wounding 34 people, the police said.

LEAD: Gov. and Mrs. Robert P. Casey of Harrisburg, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Erin Marie Casey to John Leo Walsh 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walsh Jr. of Scranton, Pa. The couple plan to marry Aug. 1.
LEAD: Grandparents' rights notwithstanding, I am appalled by an omission in the Baby Taylor custody case.

LEAD: Ida Schenkman no longer writes bail bonds from her storefront office behind the Tombs jail on Baxter Street in Manhattan. Her name has disappeared from the Yellow Pages - along with all the other Baxter Street bondsmen. Their departure, and the failure of judges and defense lawyers to adjust to it, intensifies the jail crowding crisis.

LEAD: IN 1979, with an economy staggering from a decade of chaos during the Cultural Revolution, the leader of China, Deng Xiaoping, set an ambitious course of economic reform. His idea: to wrench China's stagnant economy from orthodox socialist central planning and management by embracing some economic ideas of the capitalist

LEAD: The wedding of Gwenne Marie Haggerty and James J. Dawson took place yesterday at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. John P. Moore performed the ceremony. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Haggerty of Summit and Sea Girt, N.J., graduated from Hollins College.
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 33 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

LEAD: JAMES BOND, THE INDEFECTIBLY-tailored British secret agent with a license to kill, celebrates his 25th anniversary as an international film star this year, and the observances will begin Wednesday at 9 P.M., when ABC broadcasts a television special called ''Happy Anniversary 007.'' (A Museum of Modern Art retrospective of Bond films and the newest James Bond film, ''The Living Daylights,'' will follow later this year.) As a literary figure, Bond came into the public eye in the first Ian Fleming account of his exploits, ''Casino Royale,'' in 1953.

LEAD: WHEN a woman gives birth, something happens that bonds her forever to that child. There is a primal, instinctive drive that makes mothers do crazy things to keep the children they bear - Mary Beth Whitehead is a good example of that. No matter what the courts decide, a woman who gives up her infant is affected for life by it.

LEAD: THE WORLD SEEMS DIVIDED BETWEEN PEO-ple for whom music is interesting mainly as accompaniment to some sacred or secular ritual and those for whom music itself is an experience needing little or no outside justification. However, it should be evident that ritual pervades every aspect of music and probably always has.
LEAD: ''ALL my life Mom never let me down. Whenever I needed her, she was always right there. It's so hard to believe she's really gone.''

LEAD: There were memorandums on how to ''paint . . . black'' such opponents as Edward M. Kennedy, George McGovern and Daniel Ellsberg. There was a proposal from Richard M. Nixon to try to uncover ''some of the real crooks on the highest court and in some of the other Federal courts.'' There were ideas - from William H.
