The Rev. Patrick O'Neill, president of St. Thomas University in Miami and the bride's cousin, performed the ceremony at St.
LEAD: My gratitude to you for publishing Peter Maas's article. To me, the callous attitude of officials was even more shocking than the murder. LUCILLE PURDY Westport, Conn.

LEAD: ''IT'S more, more, more,'' C. T. Roosevelt of Cambridge said of the almost uninterrupted rain and clouds that have dampened spirits in Boston since spring ostensibly arrived. ''I keep wishing I were a duck so I would think it's a beautiful day.''

LEAD: Lauren Elizabeth Bundschuh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Bundschuh Jr. of Rye and Millerton, N.Y., was married yesterday to Joseph Baker Coogan, a son of Dr. Philip S. Coogan and Carol Jean Gerlach, both of Johnson City, Tenn. Auxiliary Bishop Eugene A. Marino of Washington performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in
LEAD: EVANGELICALISM The Coming Generation. By James Davison Hunter. 302 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $19.95.

LEAD: DESERT FABULOSO. By Lisa Lovenheim. (Plume/ NAL, Paper, $7.95.) ''Desert Fabuloso'' would be a typical coming-of-age novel about the early development and spiritual education of Bradley Roberson 3d, but for the fact that the poor little rich boy is already a man. The task before Bradley is remedial: mastering and changing the unhappy, often nasty child that dominates him from within.
LEAD: British scientists have found the first evidence that genetic differences make some people more susceptible than others to infection with the virus that causes AIDS.

LEAD: HAROLD PINTER, A MASTER of subtle, evocative, multilayered drama, and John Travolta, who soared to stardom playing inarticulate hunks, might seem an unlikely team. But Mr. Travolta will be seen in a one-hour adaptation of Mr. Pinter's short play ''The Dumbwaiter,'' which is to be shown Tuesday night at 10 on ABC.

LEAD: Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, intends to tell Congress on Monday that President Reagan ordered the national security staff to arrange support for the Nicaraguan rebels after Congress restricted aid in 1984, according to officials and associates of Mr. McFarlane.

LEAD: There is an air of unreality in this small town in northern Vermont. Brightly colored autumn leaves cover lawns where daffodils are blooming. On Main Street, a three-sided shell of a building poses as a barber shop. Children in Halloween costumes roam the streets. A grocery store employee, asked for directions to the Post Office, responds: ''The real one or the fake one?
LEAD: THE CULTURE OF CRITICISM AND THE CRITICISM OF CULTURE By Giles Gunn. 216 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.
LEAD: THIS year marks a quarter of a century since Rachel Carson told her ''fable of tomorrow'' - a tomorrow in which a devastating blight had crept over a once happy, healthy and beautiful town.

LEAD: WHEN Main Streets, not shopping malls, were the centers of Long Island, luncheonettes were the places to meet friends and have freshly squeezed lemonade. There are still a few luncheonettes left on Long Island. Their decor is not 1987 but 1947, and so is the food.

LEAD: Temple won the featured race of the 49th annual Dad Vail Regatta today, capturing the Tom Conville Cup for varsity eights for the fifth straight year, tying the record for successive victories established by the Coast Guard Academy in the mid-70's.
LEAD: JUDGE JAMES D. SLOAN of Alabama was in Providence, R.I., last July to attend the 49th annual meeting of the National Council of Juvenile and Family Court Judges when he was arrested at a hotel.
LEAD: RAN Directed by Akira Kurosawa. CBS/Fox Video. 160 minutes. $79.98.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, Ronald Steel's affiliation was misstated in his book review April 26. He is a professor of international relations and journalism at the University of Southern California.

LEAD: An appellate court has ruled that California counties may not prevent the state from paroling prison inmates in their communities, ending the odyssey of a former convict who had been shunted among various hiding places since April 25 like a stateless man.
LEAD: An article about the Hearst Corporation on April 26 misstated The San Fransico Examiner's record on Pulitzer Prizes. It won its first Pulitzer in 1951, and its second this year.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Andrea Zalaznick, a research assistant for the Whitcom Investment Company in New York, was married yesterday to Eugene Braigen, research analyst for Veronis, Suhler & Associates, an investment bank specializing in the communications industry. Lois Kellerman, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony at the National Arts Club in New

LEAD: BACK in the mid-1950's, when he was racing through his economics Ph.D. in three years at Princeton, the last thing William G. Bowen thought about was eventually running that university. ''I set out to be a teacher and a scholar,'' he said.

LEAD: THE number of artists has long exceeded that of galleries willing and able to exhibit them. Still, the imbalance can never have been so dire as it was in the early 1970's, when the present art-education system introduced by American universities after World War II began bearing fruit in earnest - and when alternative spaces came to the rescue.
LEAD: MEMOIRS OF AN INVISIBLE MAN By H. F. Saint. 396 pp. New York: Atheneum. $18.95.

LEAD: CARMEN Opera by Bizet. With Maria Ewing, Barry McCauley, Marie McLaughlin and David Holloway. The London Philharmonic Orchestra and Glyndebourne Chorus, conducted by Bernard Haitink. Directed by Peter Hall. Home Vision. 175 minutes (two cassettes). $59.95.

LEAD: A Hanoi court sentenced one man to prison and gave two men suspended sentences for showing pornographic videos for profit, a Vietnamese radio broadcast said. The verdict last Monday from a Hanoi people's court was ''a warning knell'' to all those with videotapes and recorders that they must follow state regulations, the Hanoi radio said.

LEAD: SOON WE WILL know more about the Iran-contra affair. Witnesses before the special prosecutor's grand jury, and before the Congressional committees that began hearings last week, will expose the operations in much greater detail. They will delve into the un-derworld of arms dealers and financial brokers into which Lieut.

LEAD: It has been fashionable for some years now, perhaps since Paul Fussell wrote his splendid book about the history and nature of traveling abroad, to speak of the profoundly deep gulf that separates those of us who are brave enough to do so. (Not all are so brave: ''Never go abroad,'' warned old King Edward VII.

LEAD: THE clarion call has come once again from the Treasury Department: Congress must approve an increase in the public debt ceiling so the Government can continue to borrow to pay its bills. By Friday, if the increase is not approved, the Treasury will be in trouble. By May 28, the Treasury says, the Government will be in default.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: After listening to Richard V. Secord's detailed testimony in the first week of Congressional hearings into the Iran-contra affair, many committee members say they are outraged and amazed by how much the Reagan Administration delegated foreign policy to a small group of covert private operators.
LEAD: LIKE many other fathers, Ray Dandridge liked to bring his children to his place of work. His place of work was third base for the Newark Eagles.
LEAD: Elders blew cow horns, an Ashanti chorus sang praises, and a chief priest splashed libations over the coffin of the man from Great Barrington, Mass.
LEAD: TWO string quartets performing Friday evening provide a contrast between an up-and-coming group and a 15-year veteran that is disbanding.

LEAD: ANDREW DAVIS has moved from England to Russia in his choice of repertory for his third New York Philharmonic subscription concert, heard in Avery Fisher Hall Friday afternoon and scheduled to be repeated there Tuesday evening.

LEAD: Even in the interests of integration, a Federal judge in Brooklyn ruled last week, a private landlord may not set quotas to limit the number of apartments to be rented to minority group members .

LEAD: When voters lose jobs, elected officals tend to lose votes. So it was with Mayor Richard G. Hatcher of Gary, Ind., whose bid for a sixth term ended last week when he finished second in the Democratic mayoral primary. Mr. Hatcher, who gained national prominence in 1967 as one of the first blacks elected mayor of a major city, had been losing support in recent years as the steel industry, Gary's main employer, collapsed and his administration was unable to revive the city's economy.

LEAD: It is a historical truism that the dominant civilizations of history prospered, paradoxically, by an open absorption of alien cultures. Witness the character of history's greatest cities: Athens, Florence, Amsterdam, New York and, perhaps soon, Tokyo.

LEAD: Two 30-pound steel bars that help support a section of the outer roadway of the Williamsburg Bridge fell into the East River Friday, and city investigators have found three other sections of the roadway with similar structural problems.
LEAD: Dwight Gooden working out yesterday at Shea Stadium. He is scheduled to report to the Mets' Tidewater club this week. (NYT/Jim Wilson)
LEAD: Charges against the parents of a teen-age girl who turned them in for using drugs were dropped Friday after the couple proved they had successfully completed a counseling program.
LEAD: A listing accompanying an article Jan. 18 on Istanbul misstated the location of Hidiv Kasri, the summer palace of the last Khedive of Egypt. It is at Cubuklu, on the Asian side of the Bosporus.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Beginning May 22, much of Sacramento, Calif., will be taken over for four days by an invading force of trumpet and tuba players, drummers and banjo strummers, piano players and Red Hot Mamas from around the world. What began 13 years ago as a weekend jam session by local musicians has blossomed into the Sacramento Dixieland

LEAD: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger has sent President Reagan a report proposing four new tests that would violate the traditional interpretation of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: For 14 years homosexual and lesbian advocates in Massachusetts have been promoting, without success, the passage of a rights bill that would assure equal access to housing, employment and credit, regardless of sexual preference.
LEAD: Shipwrecks, long the inspiration of fear and fascination, are the focus of an exhibit, ''Shipwrecks and Disasters at Sea'' at the Mystic Seaport Museum in Connecticut.
LEAD: THE STORY OF ENGLISH FURNITURE Presented by Arthur Negus and Hugh Scully. Produced by Paul Smith and Robin Drake. Home Vision. Part I, 108 minutes; Part II, 107 minutes. $39.95 each.

LEAD: Mr. and Miss John DeWitt Widdemer of Gloversville, N.Y., and Canada Lake, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan DeWitt Widdemer, to Keith Eaton Harrington, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman W. Harrington of Oxford, Md. A July 18 wedding is planned. Miss Widdemer is a production coordinator at Sotheby's in New York.

LEAD: A GROWING dispute between the Board of Legislators and County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke reached the courts last week when two Democratic legislators sued Mr. O'Rourke for allegedly violating the County Charter by ignoring a Board resolution.

LEAD: THE SEVENTH SANCTUARY. By Daniel Easterman. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Daniel Easterman, the pseudonym for an English professor of Islamic studies, has crammed this thriller with enough murky mayhem to see Robert Ludlum through his next six epics. ''Raiders of the Lost Ark'' seems like ''Radio Days'' in comparison.

LEAD: THE TRIAL OF KLAUS Barbie is to open tomorrow in the French city of Lyons, and when it does, it will take an act of will to reconcile the frail 74-year-old man in the dock, whom one might imagine stooped over a flower bed in the garden of his retirement home, with the crimes he is accused of committing.

LEAD: A RECTANGULAR yellow sign nailed to a post at the Gulf gas station on Boston Avenue in Bridgeport alerts motorists that the station itself is for sale. On Main Street in Westport, stores and condominiums are rising on the site of an old Mobil station.

LEAD: A squadron of pupils from a Greenwich Village elementary school has enlisted in New York's war against waste, shouting their battle cry -''recycle'' - in their classrooms, playgrounds, neighborhoods and homes.

LEAD: The stir over the cause of Representative Stewart McKinney's death ought not distract from his achievements as a public servant. Mr. McKinney, who died last week at age 56, was a man of compassion. His constituency for 17 years was Connecticut's ''Gold Coast'' Fairfield County, and he was well to do himself.

LEAD: A users' guide to New York City parks on April 26 in The World of New York, part 2 of The Times Magazine, misstated the size of several city swimming pools. Only Hamilton Fish Pool in Manhattan and Astoria Pool in Queens now meet Olympic specifications. Also in that magazine, on the map of development projects in the city, site 14 was misidentified.

LEAD: A SPRINGTIME dinner, one that takes advantage of the season's fresh treasures, can be a pleasure to prepare and serve. After a winter of tired parsley, distressed zucchini and lettuces struggling to survive, it is a delight to shop for produce once again. The verdant selection beckons. Spring means freshness.

LEAD: TWENTY-SEVEN years ago Salvatore Ferragamo, a shoe designer in Florence, died leaving a widow, Wanda, and six children, the youngest 2 years old. Mrs. Ferragamo knew nothing about business. But a year and a half before, Mr. Ferragamo had insisted that their daughter Fiamma, the eldest child, who was then 16, come to work with him.

LEAD: After 12 years of enforced exile abroad, Clodomiro Almeyda, who was one of the best-known members of the leftist Government of Salvadore Allende, climbed the eastern slopes of the Andes on a mule and made his way through a snow-covered mountain pass to come home to Chile.

LEAD: WITH the ''potent art'' of a magician transforming monsters and melting spirits ''into air, into thin air'' - all on an enchanted island -''The Tempest'' is a magical play, through and through. In its modest way, the Theater for a New Audience, a Manhattan-based troupe, is making theatrical magic during the Stratford American Shakespeare Theater's three-week student season, which offers two performances this

LEAD: ''THAT'S what we're all here for, baby, the lowest common denominator,'' Lydia Lunch warbled enthusiastically in her role as master of ceremonies at the Ritz last Sunday. Was she talking about the singer in Big Stick, the first band on the bill? He wore what looked like a black plastic trash bag and a black mask with something like a black dustmop for a crest, and he sang about his mask at some length.

LEAD: Without calling a single witness, the defense in the criminal trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan is seeking victory mainly by assailing the integrity of the chief prosecutor.

LEAD: A prominent minister whose wife was nearly choked to death, and who himself later attempted suicide as the police prepared to question him about the incident, says he does not know who attacked her.

LEAD: ITS ORIGINS ARE SHROUDED in mystery, possibly even antiquity, but the anecdote in verse known as a limerick has long pleased those who delight in rhymes, both proper and bawdy, which can bring on a leer or maybe a grin and even have been deliciously naughty.
LEAD: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of the letters it elicits.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Page Boughton Merrill and Anthony Nicholas Brady plan to marry Sept. 12, Miss Merrill's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Barrant V. Merrill of Sun Valley, Idaho, and New York have announced. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Frederick Brady of Far Hills, N.J.
LEAD: Justine Hope Blau was married last evening to Jeffrey M. Klein at the Sara Delano Roosevelt Memorial House of Hunter College. Rabbi Clifford Kulwin performed the ceremony.
LEAD: THE ORTON DIARIES Edited by John Lahr. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95.
LEAD: STEVIE A Biography of Stevie Smith. By Jack Barbera and William McBrien. Illustrated. 378 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.
LEAD: Sixty law students at Columbia University will soon begin jobs as summer interns in an unusual human rights program.

LEAD: AFTER eight years of looking nervously over her shoulder, Krystyna Swiatek walked into the immigration legalization center here Tuesday and sighed with relief. LEAD: IGOR STRAVINSKY'S ''Histoire du Soldat'' has attracted a number of choreographers. Like Bartok's ''Miraculous Mandarin,'' it is a narrative score that seems to fascinate but elude those challenged. In ''Suite from 'Histoire Du Soldat,' '' performed by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday at the New York State Theater, Peter

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Atonement in Tenafly, N.J., yesterday Ellen Elizabeth Gibson, executive chef of the Silver Palate in Manhattan, and Christopher Silva White, a financial executive for the Bristol-Myers Company in New York, were married by the Rev. John P. Croneberger. The bride is the daughter of Mr.

LEAD: BOB OJEDA, the Mets' best pitcher in 1986, suggested that maybe the moon is aligned with Saturn. Dave Johnson, his manager, speculated that it might have something to do with the work force in Haiti. ''Maybe one shift likes pitchers and another shift doesn't,'' Johnson said. ''Maybe the shift that doesn't like pitchers comes in and winds the ball tighter.

LEAD: A SPRINGTIME dinner, one that takes advantage of the season's fresh treasures, can be a pleasure to prepare and serve. After a winter of tired parsley, distressed zucchini and lettuces struggling to survive, it is a delight to shop for produce once again. The verdant selection beckons. Spring means freshness.

LEAD: TWENTY-SEVEN years ago Salvatore Ferragamo, a shoe designer in Florence, died leaving a widow, Wanda, and six children, the youngest 2 years old. Mrs. Ferragamo knew nothing about business. But a year and a half before, Mr. Ferragamo had insisted that their daughter Fiamma, the eldest child, who was then 16, come to work with him.

LEAD: Mahmoud M. Atta, who was born in the Middle East and became an American citizen in Puerto Rico, was expelled from Venezuela last week and arrested in New York on charges of firebombing a bus in Israel last year.

LEAD: A DOZEN adults were running around a conference room at the Ramada Inn in Mystic. Soon some would be ''piloting'' imaginary airplanes across the carpet, and later all would be exchanging memories of giving birth, seeing rainbows, and other experiences.

LEAD: It is up to Democrats in the Senate to reaffirm their party's long-standing commitment to free trade by voting ''no'' to protectionist legislation. That is the only way they can atone for the irresponsible behavior of their Democratic colleagues in the House, who handed President Reagan an enormous political gift when they passed (with the help of 17 Republicans) the Gephardt amendment to the trade bill.

LEAD: The rhetoric heated up last week in the case against Michael K. Deaver, the former deputy White House chief of staff who is accused of lying to Congress and a Federal grand jury about his lobbying activities.
LEAD: To the Sport Editor:

LEAD: A THREE-ACRE rock garden at the New York Botanical Garden last Friday was renamed the T. H. Everett Memorial Rock Garden, in honor of Thomas H. Everett, the horticulturist, author, educator, former director of horticulture at the New York Botanical Garden and creator of the rock garden. Mr. Everett, who lived in Mount
LEAD: THE DREAMS OF DRAGONS Riddles of Natural History. By Lyall Watson. 178 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $15.95.

LEAD: STAGED READINGS Christopher Durang is the first celebrity to participate in a series of staged readings of theater works at the Westport Arts Center. The playwright will act in and direct his new satire, ''For Whom the Belle Tolls,'' at 8 P.M. Friday. The piece is billed as a sendup of the Tennessee
LEAD: Dear Prime Minister Nakasone:

LEAD: Bond prices bobbed and weaved on uncertainty over interest rates, trade relations with Japan and the dollar. Prices of Treasury securities plummeted as Japanese investors stayed out of the auction of 10-year notes, apparently fearful that the fall of the dollar against the yen would make the investments less attractive.

LEAD: Meile Rockefeller, the 31-year-old great-granddaughter of the man who built Rockefeller Center, is herself altering the cityscape. Her current project, however, in TriBeCa's ''dairy district,'' is far less grandiose than that of the late philanthropist, John D. Rockefeller Jr. Now nearing completion is the conversion of a former egg-packing and cheese-making plant, at 168 Duane Street near Hudson Street, into loft condominiums.

LEAD: Ramin, a 20-year-old Iranian seeking political asylum in Belgium, rolled up a sleeve of his sweater and pointed to a fresh scar on his left wrist. The jagged wound was inflicted in a suicide attempt last month, he said.

LEAD: At Christ Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Va., yesterday Diane Lyn Jensen was married to Capt. Dean Clement Berry, U.S.A. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Mark S. Anschutz, the rector, who was assisted by the Rev. James D. Ford, the chaplain of the House of Representatives and a Lutheran minister.

LEAD: AN inmate's complaint of ''bad air'' in the Federal prison office where he worked ignited a dispute that pitted the Federal Department of Labor against the Justice Department and its Bureau of Prisons.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Coast Guard seized almost a ton and a half of cocaine aboard a 28-foot fishing boat off the United States Virgin Islands Friday and arrested five Colombians, who were imprisoned here today.

LEAD: THE fateful day for West Midtown developers looms one year away -on Friday the 13th. A zoning bonus, set to expire on that date next May, has prompted a frenzy of demolition and digging north of Times Square.

LEAD: IF YOU CAN'T GET TICKETS FOR ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses,'' with its awesome and unsparing portrait of immediately pre-Revolutionary France, you can fall back for the moment on two new exhibitions in town that will give you fresh insights into France in the 18th century. If, on the other hand, you have already been to see ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses,'' you will have had an unforgettable evening in the theater.

LEAD: Imagine that the island of Manhattan is divided by a wall running down Fifth Avenue, with Times Square and Lincoln Center in the hands of a pro-Western government linked to a free republic entrenched west of the Mississippi River. A Communist regime, though, dominates the eastern half of the island; it also controls all of the United States east of the Mississippi.
LEAD: IT WAS the drink back in colonial days. But then the Boston Tea Party made it a symbol of British oppression. After that came expanding coffee imports.

LEAD: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More was the setting in New York yesterday for the wedding of Brooke Elizabeth Conaty to Thomas Joyce Farley. The Rev. Thomas J. Joyce performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Couples Sets Record: Fred Couples set a Byron Nelson Golf Classic 54-hole record total of 14-under-par 196 and took a two-shot lead yesterday over Bob Lohr and Ben Crenshaw. Couples, whose last victory was the Tournament Players Championship in 1984, had five birdies on the back nine and shot a six-under-par 64 over the rain-softened T.P.C.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: GONE TO SOLDIERS By Marge Piercy. 703 pp. New York: Summit Books. $19.95.
LEAD: THE most closely watched player in the world is the world champion, Gary Kasparov.

LEAD: 3 I.R.A. Leaders Died in Raid The police in Northern Ireland disclosed that three senior figures in the Irish Republican Army were among eight guerrillas killed Friday in an intercepted raid on the police.

LEAD: Late at night, flying home from delivering one of his major speeches, Mario M. Cuomo sometimes drops his ''I am the Governor'' tone, loosening his tie, sipping a vodka on the rocks, telling political war stories and doing impressions. (His Daniel Patrick Moynihan is great.) He is at his most vulnerable in moments like these - weary yet chatty as he sits in the dimly lighted cabin of his private 13-seat state plane - and so the questions asked at the news conferences and in the formal interviews are asked once again: Doesn't he really want to be President?
LEAD: South Korea has been a treasure-trove of purple amethyst, smoky topaz and white jade for centuries.

LEAD: THE puncturing of a social myth is not a lovely thing. When Dennis Levine was arrested a year ago this week, and then others and still others, and then Ivan Boesky - suddenly the whole idea that risk arbitrage could be practiced without inside information lay in doubt. And with it, the Reagan era myth that greed was good.

LEAD: 3 I.R.A. Leaders Died in Raid The police in Northern Ireland disclosed that three senior figures in the Irish Republican Army were among eight guerrillas killed Friday in an intercepted raid on the police.

LEAD: Late at night, flying home from delivering one of his major speeches, Mario M. Cuomo sometimes drops his ''I am the Governor'' tone, loosening his tie, sipping a vodka on the rocks, telling political war stories and doing impressions. (His Daniel Patrick Moynihan is great.) He is at his most vulnerable in moments like these - weary yet chatty as he sits in the dimly lighted cabin of his private 13-seat state plane - and so the questions asked at the news conferences and in the formal interviews are asked once again: Doesn't he really want to be President?

LEAD: WITH its new PS/2 series of computers, I.B.M. is beaming its spotlight on large corporations. Indeed, the new line would seem to be the opening act in a drama whose logical finale is a business environment in which everything is hooked up to, or at least able to communicate with, I.B.M.'s big mainframe computers.
LEAD: THE doors of Western Europe are slamming shut on the poor, the persecuted and the merely adventurous from Africa, Asia and the Arab world.

LEAD: ''THE FOREIGNER'' has made it from survival to success. After it opened off Broadway in 1984, the comedy by Larry Shue was on the verge of closing several times. Then, the proverbial show business ''angel'' materialized - in the guise of a Texas oilman who saved the sinking show with a $60,000 interest-free loan.
LEAD: PLAYTIME Starring Jacques Tati Embassy Home Entertainment 108 minutes. $29.95.

LEAD: Marla Susan Smith, a daughter of Martin G. Smith and Jeri B. Smith, both of New York, was married yesterday to Thomas Alan Berkenkamp, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred J. Berkenkamp of Kankakee, Ill. The Rev. Raymond Schulze, a Lutheran minister, and Cantor Mayer Becker officiated at the Westbury Hotel in
LEAD: TO the motorist drving along Interstate 10 west of New Orleans, the new high-rise looks as if it just flew in from Dallas, a mirrored monolith above the flatlands.

LEAD: IN another week it seems likely that bridge will hold the world record, and so earn a place in the Guinness Book of Records, for the greatest number of participants in a single competitive event. The Epson Worldwide Bridge Contest, which attracted 66,000 players when it was initiated almost a year ago, is expected to reach a six-figure participation.
LEAD: Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston was the setting for the wedding yesterday of Anne Crocker Phillips to Henry McFarlan Ogilby. The Rev. Spencer Morgan Rice, the rector, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: ''THE SLEEPING BEAUTY'' OF 1890 was created as a ''ballet-feerie'' for Russia's Imperial Theater in St. Petersburg. Yet, if ''ballet-feerie'' was a term applied to productions in which spectacle was dominant, ''The Sleeping Beauty'' was never conceived as empty spectacle. Meaning was present on every level.

LEAD: WHILE many of his fellow graduates will start the summer continuing their search for suitable employment, Brian Bosworth, who picked up a degree in management information from the University of Oklahoma yesterday, should have a simpler time securing a job worthy of his college-honed talents. The outspoken Sooner star is expected to announce tomorrow that he will try his hand in the National Football League, and given his record on the football field and in the classroom, he should have no problem finding a slot in a linebacker-training program.

LEAD: FOR his first competition since last summer, Edwin Moses, the world record-holder in the 400-meter hurdles, will participate in the Adidas-Princeton International track and field meet next Saturday . . . Rosa Mota, who won the women's division of the Boston Marathon, has entered the L'eggs Mini Marathon in Central Park May 30.

LEAD: In his contribution to the symposium, Zbigniew Brzezinski argues that, as long as the great powers continue to settle disputes through war, it is not possible to abolish nuclear weapons because, in case of war, the antagonists would be tempted to build them again - and possibly use them - and the knowledge of how to make these weapons cannot be erased.
LEAD: THE term ''mega,'' deriving from the Greek word for large or great, surely seems the appropriate prefix to use for some New York City development projects.

LEAD: AS THE CREATOR OF THE THEATER OF Cruelty, Antonin Artaud declared that cruelty was not exclusively a matter of ''bodily laceration.'' From the point of view of the mind, he said, it ''signifies rigor, implacable intention and decision, irreversible and absolute determination.'' That definition aptly applies to the essence of Christopher Hampton's brilliant adaptation of Choderlos de Laclos's novel, ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses.

LEAD: AFTER almost two years and three revisions, the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal has published its final version of the administrative code for rent-stabilized housing in New York City. The code, which took effect May 1, governs 943,000 apartments.
LEAD: South Korea has been a treasure-trove of purple amethyst, smoky topaz and white jade for centuries.

LEAD: THE puncturing of a social myth is not a lovely thing. And with it, the Reagan era myth that greed was good.

Dinkins, was announced yesterday by the Partnership for the Homeless, a network of more than 300 New York churches and synagogues providing emergency food and shelter.

LEAD: The Coast Guard seized almost a ton and a half of cocaine aboard a 28-foot fishing boat off the United States Virgin Islands Friday and arrested five Colombians, who were imprisoned here Saturday.

LEAD: Firefighters working to control fire near Sweet Home, Ore. A heat wave last week had helped the fire grow to 1,700 acres, before cooler, humid air yesterday helped crews as they worked to contain it.

LEAD: Beirut International Airport reopened today after being closed for 98 days, but higher insurance premiums that add $200 to the cost of a ticket may prohibit many Lebanese from using the airport.
LEAD: Attention in the credit markets this week will shift to economic data, which economists hope will provide some clues to the future performance of the dollar and interest rates.
LEAD: Juan Samuel and Lance Parrish belted homers, and Shane Rawley pitched seven scoreless innings for Philadelphia today as the Phillies defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 4-3.

LEAD: ''We sometimes lose sight of the potential risks in our haste to create new products,'' one investment banker said last week. ''What happened to Merrill is a warning signal.''
LEAD: ''What's in a name?'' William Shakespeare asks. ''Everything,'' says Domenico Manchisi, owner of Jerry's Shakespeare Pizza.

LEAD: Another Texas tradition has fallen. Starting Sept. 1, Texas drivers will no longer be able to hurtle down the road in their pickup trucks guzzling beer, though their passengers will.

LEAD: TAKE a girl of mixed blood, make her determined to climb out of desperate poverty, send her on the way to becoming an international film star and, lo and behold, you have ''Queenie,'' the latest television extravaganza in the absurd but good-for-a-giggle tradition of Judith Krantz and Sidney Sheldon.

LEAD: European delay in answering Mikhail Gorbachev's latest proposals for getting rid of all medium- and shorter-range missiles on the continent betrays a paralysis of will. Nothing is going to be learned or better understood by prolonging the debate.

LEAD: As usual, the Church of England's attendance this bright spring Sunday morning was somewhere below 3 percent of the population, anemically, alarmingly low in the view of the Bishop of Durham, who presided from the pulpit of St. Luke's Church.

LEAD: Each year Japan sends a fleet to U.S. waters to fish for salmon. In the process, porpoises become entangled and die in nylon nets that are invisible to their sonar. LEAD: Nancy Helen Liebermann, an associate at Linowes & Blocher, and Joseph Alexander Godles, a partner in Goldberg & Spector, both Washington law firms, were married yesterday in Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El.

LEAD: ''This is the end. Farewell,'' Capt. Zygmunt Pawlaczyk radioed seconds before his Ilyushin 62M jet slammed into a piney grove, killing him and the 182 other people it was to have carried to New York on Saturday.

LEAD: PART of Roger Craig's success with the San Francisco Giants has come from his unflagging refusal to see the glass half-empty. LEAD: Scientists have found a way to send enormous electric currents through newly discovered superconducting materials, overcoming the most important remaining technical barrier to applications ranging from high-speed computers to high-power magnets.

LEAD: The five-man office of the chief executive at the J. Walter Thompson Company, which lost two of its members, has been reconstituted. The chairman is still Don Johnston, who is also chairman and chief executive of the parent JWT Group.
LEAD: The Iowa Legislature approved a bill Saturday raising the speed limit to 65 miles an hour on most Interstate highways. Gov. Terry E. Branstad has said he would sign the measure.

LEAD: A dance by Lucinda Childs tends to send its performers hurtling serenely along like celestial atoms. The SoHo loft where she lives and works is as open, spacious and clear as her dances. But for all that simplicity, Ms. Childs is a choreographer with a strong interest in stage design and the way a dance interacts with the environment in which it unfolds.

LEAD: Al Mamoon, ridden by Patrick Valenzuela, led all the way today to win the $159,200 John Henry Handicap on the turf course at Hollywood Park.

LEAD: ByFLECTING the growing uncertainty about the boundaries of copyright law, the chief lawyer for the Copyright Office has asked the agency to re-examine its rules protecting certain computer technology.

LEAD: A 37-year-old man was found shot in his Staten Island apartment yesterday and died later at Staten Island Hospital, the police said. The victim, Edward Camera, had been shot twice in the head with a small-caliber gun. Mr. Camera was unconscious when he was discovered slumped on the floor of his second-floor apartment at 208 Atlantic Avenue in the Grant City section, the police said.

LEAD: President Reagan signed a bill on Friday designating the Santa Fe Trail, stretching 950 miles from Missouri to New Mexico, as the Santa Fe National Historic Trail. The measure grants administrative jurisdiction over the trail.
LEAD: The number of inmates in Federal and state prisons reached a record high last year, an agency of the Justice Department reported today.

LEAD: Robert M. Jacobson, the editor of Opera News magazine, died Saturday night at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Q. What are vitamins and how are they made? A. Vitamins are complex organic compounds that regulate the metabolism and functions of the body. LEAD: The sudden departure of Gary Hart from the campaign has, strangely enough, probably not altered the Democratic nomination or the Presidential outcome. Before his exit, Mr. Hart was clearly his party's front runner, just as Vice President Bush has had a handy lead in the Republican sweepstakes. In both cases, the polls have placed them around the 50 percent mark and found their competitors struggling to get into the double digits.

LEAD: THE cooking of the South - embracing as it does such foods as corn pone, turnip greens, hush puppies, spoon bread, country ham, grits and red-eye gravy -lends itself to caricature and stereotype and all the cliches of the marketplace. LEAD: YEARS ago I journeyed to Europe and took with me excess baggage. Among my material excesses were assorted electrical appliances I'd never use, high heels that made no sense on cobblestone streets, dozens of pleated skirts and sweaters of high school vintage, weighty guidebooks I abandoned in trains, jackets for all weathers, and all those innumerable items called accessories, as if they were accomplices in crime.

LEAD: Two former United States Customs officials were arrested today on Federal charges of robbing and killing a currency courier in 1982 shortly after he had declared to airport Customs agents here that he was carrying some $650,000 in cash and checks.
LEAD: The inner Cabinet failed again today to reach a decision on whether Israel should take part in an international peace conference on the Middle East.
LEAD: Representative Richard Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, said today he would introduce legislation aimed at ending the unsanctioned coloring of black-and-white motion picture classics.
LEAD: Senator Pete V. Domenici still finds himself answering to the title ''Mr. Chairman.''

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Some 20 percent of the nation's banks lost money in 1986 and many of the others suffered declining profits, a Federal Reserve study has indicated. In most cases the losses and lower profits were tied to bad loans in the energy and agriculture sectors, the study said.

LEAD: Klaus Barbie being escorted from court back to his cell yesterday in Lyons, France. The former Nazi Gestapo officer, asserting that he was a ''hostage, not a prisoner,'' said he would no longer take part in his trial for crimes against humanity. The move would prevent his accusers from confronting him face to face.

LEAD: A Senate subcommittee voted today to allow American companies for the first time to seek Federal court relief against foreign pirating of their patented manufacturing processes. The pirating is estimated to cost American industry billions of dollars annually.

LEAD: Fernando Bujones will join the Boston Ballet as principal guest dancer, Bruce Marks, artistic director of the company, announced yesterday. He also said that Carla Stallings, a soloist with American Ballet Theater, would be joining the Boston company as a principal dancer. Mr. Bujones, currently associate director of the ballet company of the Teatro Municipal in Rio de Janeiro, will perform with the Boston Ballet in its 1987-88 season, dancing lead roles in ''Giselle,'' ''Miss Julie,'' ''The Nutcracker'' and other ballets to be announced.

LEAD: In an effort to help state governments extend their taxable reach to the growing direct-marketing industry, a Congressional panel today began considering legislation to require mail-order retailers like L.L. Bean Inc. to collect sales taxes on out-of-state purchases.

LEAD: Three hundred and eighty miles away in Lyons, Klaus Barbie, the city's erstwhile Gestapo chief, finds himself at the center of the world's attention.

LEAD: NEW York City Ballet presented George Balanchine's ''Variations Pour une Porte et un Soupir'' on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater and, as usual, there were almost as many unhappy groans from the audience as there were on the taped score. Balanchine carefully set this trio for a man, a woman and her stage-covering, capelike black skirt to the measure of Pierre Henry's score for deep-voiced sighs and the higher-pitched creaks and groans of a door.

LEAD: A Federal judge has given tentative approval to a plan to pay an estimated 16,000 retirees up to $35 million to settle a class-action suit against the Federal Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation.

LEAD: Derrick McKey, the Southeastern Conference Player of the Year from Alabama, and Olden Polynice, the former Virginia center, were among nine underclassmen to apply to be eligible for the National Basketball Association draft June 22.

LEAD: When the West Dallas Housing Project was built it was, like most housing in Texas in 1952, unashamedly segregated: 1,500 units for whites, 1,500 for blacks and 500 for Hispanics. After ''desegregation'' it became all black, like the ghetto that surrounded it. Now, under an unusual three-way agreement, most residents are to be integrated into suburban apartment complexes and most of the project is to be torn down.

LEAD: In a move that stunned a Federal courtroom in Manhattan, Government prosecutors asked yesterday for the dismissal of insider-trading charges against three Wall Street professionals.

LEAD: Sales of new American-made cars dropped 28.5 percent in early May from the comparable period last year, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today. Sales of light trucks dropped 12.4 percent, the first decline in three months.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission asked for comment today on a proposal that would prohibit investors from covering short sales of over-the-counter stocks with securities bought from the underwriter or any participating firm in an underwriting syndicate.
LEAD: The European press has depicted the collapse of Gary Hart's Presidential campaign as the result of his personal failings and of fundamental flaws in the Presidential selection process.
LEAD: At one point, Robert C. McFarlane and Senator Daniel K. Inouye discussed the characteristics of Country 2, which has earlier been identified as Saudi Arabia. Here is that exchange.
LEAD: As a token of affection for the private school that his son, Bobby, attends in Burlington, Vt., Robert Brent decided to give each of the 25 students a novel gift: a share in the Boston Celtics.

LEAD: The British Petroleum Company controls about 95 percent of the common stock of the Standard Oil Company following expiration of its $7.9 billion tender offer for the shares it did not already own, British Petroleum said. Shackley, a former official of the Central Intelligence Agency. LEAD: This week in all four National Basketball Association conference semifinals and both Stanley Cup conference finals, six teams faced 3-1 deficits in the four-of-seven-game competitions. In major professional postseason competition, only 15 teams in such situations have rallied to win. LEAD: Vice President Bush began a push for New York Republican support last night with a speech at the largest political event in the state - the annual Nassau County Republican fund-raising dinner.

LEAD: THE glories of Nigerian juju music rang out anew when King Sunny Ade played his first New York concert in three years last Friday at the Beacon Theater. Mr. Ade's 17-man band has new members, including a synthesizer player, and he's willing to warm up a Western crowd with a few pop-length songs; now and then, he uses an English word amid the Yoruba lyrics.

LEAD: Rickey Henderson, who was to help fuel the Yankees' 9-1 victory over Texas yesterday with his bat, his legs and his glove, had led off the first inning with a home run. Willie Randolph had then walked and worked his way around to third on Ed Correa's wild pitch and errant pickoff throw. Don Mattingly was the next batter, but consistent with his seasonlong slump, he hit a weak bouncer back to the mound.

LEAD: After a long sleep, Manhattan's 42d Street redevelopment project stirs with life. First, Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch agreed on Carl Weisbrod, a fine choice to head the redevelopment. And now Federal District Judge Thomas Griesa has dismissed the last legal challenge, a suit claiming the project fails to meet air quality standards.

LEAD: A review of Vice President Bush's office records turned up a previously undisclosed meeting between a Bush aide and Felix Rodriguez, a one-time C.I.A. operative involved in the private support network for the Nicaraguan rebels, it was announced tonight.
LEAD: MCA Inc. has decided against selling 15 percent of its music-entertaiment gourp to the public, reversing last month's announcement that it might do so.

LEAD: A former United States Postal Service official has been charged with accepting bribes from the Wedtech Corporation and an internal investigation is examining the possibility that the Postal Service itself was cheated by the Bronx military contractor, the subject of other state and Federal inquiries.

LEAD: A Benefit Jazz Concert for Carol Britto, St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue and 54th Street (Information: 362-6580). A benefit concert this Sunday evening for Carol Britto, a pianist who is recovering from an illness, promises to be a summit of mainstream jazz talent. Ms. Britto, a student of Oscar Peterson, plays with a hard-swinging, expressive romanticism that has earned comparisons to Erroll Garner and Thelonious Monk as well as to her teacher.

LEAD: The Russians went to the South Bronx last night to play basketball, and on the way got a glimpse of opulence, poverty, traffic, iniquity and other features of the real New York. It was just what they had hoped to see.

LEAD: John McEnroe defeated Aaron Krickstein today to reach the quarterfinals of the Italian Open, but he did little to dispel doubts about his chances for attaining the most elusive prize of his career: the singles title at the French Open.

LEAD: ''Stardust'' will close after the Sunday matinee at the Biltmore Theater. The musical, conceived and directed by Albert Harris, moved from Off Broadway and will have run for 118 performances.

LEAD: An 83-year-old man shot his nurse to death in the belief that she was trying to poison him and was killed by the police after he fired three shots at officers, the authorities said today. The police shot Enrique Fuentes Wednesday night after they were summoned to an apartment complex by neighbors who had heard shots.

LEAD: THE Joan Miro retrospective at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum is a curious affair. Miro has long been recognized as a very special and unusually influential artist, and a large show of his work is always welcome. Even though Miro died in 1983 and there had been no Miro retrospective in New York since 1959, however, the art public has felt little or no need to think about him.

LEAD: A study of the new minimum academic requirements for freshman participation in intercollegiate athletics has found that 684 students who failed to qualify under the new standards, which took effect last fall, enrolled at Division I schools anyway. Of those, the study found, 424 had the required 2.0 grade-point average in their core high school courses but had failed to obtain the minimum score on their college admissions tests.

LEAD: ALMOST all of his works have dropped into obscurity, but for a while the Brazilian-born Antonio Carlos Gomes was a leading Italian opera composer. Gomes first came to know the works of Bellini and Donizetti and Verdi as a student in Rio de Janeiro in the 1850's and 1860's. He began composing operas of his own, and the success of his ''Joana de Flandres'' in 1863 won the 27-year-old Gomes a grant, sponsored by the Brazilian Government, to study at the Milan Conservatory.

LEAD: FRIDAY POLYRHYTHMIC SYMPHONY The music of the American composer Charles Ives (1874-1954) has always been controversial. An amateur musician, Ives wrote complex works using polytonality, polyrhythm and other devices considered radical at the time. Tonight at 8, the Cleveland Orchestra will perform the composer's rarely heard Fourth Symphony at Carnegie Hall.

LEAD: ANYONE who takes a little trouble can chart the ups and downs and the ins and outs of modernist predilections as they have evolved since the beginning of our century. Dealers, curators, collectors and writers on art find in those recombinings the occupation of a lifetime.

LEAD: FESTIVAL mania has struck New York. Every spring, the city's calendar is filled with street festivals, fairs and parades, but rarely do so many occur on a single weekend. LEAD: ON Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall, The Harmonie Ensemble offered an original-instrument performance of - believe it or not -Gershwin. Several of the composer's pieces have gone through a process not unlike what happened to certain Baroque works. ''Rhapsody in Blue,'' for instance, was written for piano and a small jazz orchestra, then expanded into the full-blown symphonic version known widely today; ''An American in Paris,'' went through a similar process.

LEAD: ''TONIGHT we're going to go through the whole spectrum of the music and then some,'' James Newton promised his audience at Carlos 1 on Tuesday. Was he boasting? LEAD: THE BEST PLACE TO meet a writer, it has been said, is on the page (or on the stage, or wherever else his work appears). I don't think the British playwright Joe Orton would have dissented. At all events, he once told an interviewer that, unlike Oscar Wilde, he thought that a writer should put his genius into his work, not into his life.

LEAD: IT ALL BEGAN ON A BAD DAY BACK in 1963. Tom Stoppard - sometime journalist, occasional drama critic and aspiring playwright - had gone to the BBC in search of a commission for a drama series, only to be turned down. He was driving dolefully away from the television studios when his agent, who had accompanied him, came up with an idea designed to revitalize his creative morale.

LEAD: FRED WALTERS can hardly wait for his six-shooter to arrive so that he can start blasting away at the hundreds of Canada geese expected at Byram Beach in Greenwich this summer. Not to kill them, mind you -just to scare them away.

LEAD: IN 1984, days after asking for a special investigation of his personal financial dealings, Edwin Meese 3d said there was little he would do differently, given the opportunity to change the past. LEAD: MOST LIKELY TO SUCCEED: Six Women From Harvard and What Became of Them. By Fran Schumer. (Random House, $17.95.) In the first half of ''Most Likely to Succeed'' Fran, the smart and sassy narrator, tries to re-create the turmoil, frustrations and fierce expectations that she and five other 'Cliffies endured in the early 1970's at Harvard University, in a male-dominated environment that simply intensified their ambivalence about their desires and goals; later in the book we find out what happened to them.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. G. Barry McMennamin of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Marilynn Breeze McMennamin to Gustavus Warfield Hobbs 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hobbs 3d of Manasota Key, Fla., and Stonington, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

LEAD: Mallory Greenberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Greenberg of Sands Point, L.I., and Jeffrey H. Lehman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Lehman of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., were married last evening. Rabbi Stephen Folberg performed the ceremony at the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel.

LEAD: At the Old Southeast Church in Brewster, N.Y., Betty Welsh Symington and Michael Jacob Sonnenfeld were married yesterday by the Rev. Robert L. Tate, rector of Christ Episcopal Church on Capitol Hill in Washington.

LEAD: Edward Swayduck, the former head of the lithographers union in New York City, died Thursday at the Hollywood (Fla.) Medical Center of complications from Parkinson's disease. He was 75 years old and lived in Hollywood.
LEAD: FORGET the gold that was discovered in Cobalt last year; the hottest commodity in Connecticut this summer is waterfront rentals. They are almost impossible to find and more costly than ever.

LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, in some of his toughest criticism of the United States and Western nations, charged today that recent attacks on his political leadership were a part of a campaign by ''foreign forces'' to undermine India's democracy.

LEAD: For years, the Swedish Government has been a vocal champion of peace and disarmament, a stand that is a source of national pride. But today Sweden finds itself embroiled in an arms-trading scandal that raises questions about its adherence to its stated principles and underlines the ''Swedish paradox'' of a pacifist country with a thriving weapons industry dependent on exports.

LEAD: One never can tell what will happen at the Paris Opera these days. LEAD: ''Protectionism is the ally of isolationism, and isolationism is the Dracula of American foreign policy.'' - William G. Hyland, former national security adviser. [ 34:5. ]

LEAD: The decision by South Korea's President Chun Doo Hwan to end negotiations with the opposition on a new system of government, and to proceed with a presidential election on the basis of the existing Constitution, could jeopardize South Korea's future and impair vital American interests in Asia.

LEAD: WALKING ROUND THE Italian Old Master drawings from the British royal collection that can be seen at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, through July 26, this visitor did not think all the time of the kings and queens of England, fascinating as many of them were. He thought of the private enthusiasts who had been given a chance of getting hold of fine drawings in large numbers and made haste to gobble them up.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH CHICKEN POACHED in wine with a julienne of vegetables sounds like nouvelle cuisine, it's an age-old method, and one I have been rethinking, transforming and enjoying for more than 35 years.

LEAD: Just as Ayako Okamoto of Japan was struggling uphill to a double bogey on the 15th hole at Navesink Country Club today, Colleen Walker of Bradenton, Fla., was playing downhill to a birdie 2 at the 17th.

LEAD: SUSAN RETHORST works with the kind of small, slippery phrases that identify the dance of Trisha Brown. In ''What She Knew,'' a new piece by Ms. Rethorst presented on Thursday at the Kitchen, those phrases are as discrete as words in conversation. And the ''words'' build up to a murmured conversation through which ideas, history and evocative imagery dart like quick, colorful little fish.

LEAD: At best, Erica Abeel's article ''Magnificent Obsession - A House in the Country'' (April 19) is a subtle treatment of the story, which needs to be told. That story tells that responsibility for the deteriorating quality of life in the city must be placed on the individuals who are presently obsessed with the great escape from New York.

LEAD: THE restaurant mortality rate being what it is, the 30-year-old Inn at Ridgefield is unusual. Even more remarkable is that its high performance remains as consistent as ever - even when it changes hands.
LEAD: The return of more than 40,000 Guatemalan Indians who fled to Mexico to escape military repression is proceeding slowly, according to Government officials and human-rights advocates.
LEAD: The garbage barge that nobody wants was towed into New York Harbor last night but was turned quickly around and anchored in Gravesend Bay off Brooklyn.
LEAD: Second-seeded Mats Wilander of Sweden, playing nearly flawless baseline tennis, crushed John McEnroe, 6-1, 6-3, today to advance to the final of the Italian Open.

LEAD: The Constitution Race, a trans-Atlantic regatta marking the 30th anniversary of the European Economic Community and the 200th anniversary of the signing of the United States Constitution, got off to a shaky start today.

LEAD: The Kentucky Derby was rerun today at Pimlico Race Course under the name of the Preakness Stakes, and Alysheba beat Bet Twice again. Alysheba's half-length victory made the son of Alydar eligible to become thoroughbred racing's first Triple Crown winner since Affirmed in 1978.

LEAD: ONE year ago this month, Sleepy Hollow Restorations, the Tarrytown-based historic site organization that owns four Westchester locations, named its first new president in 35 years, purchased Montgomery Place, a 443-acre estate on the Hudson River in Dutchess County for $3 million; and announced plans to play a more active role in the future of the entire Hudson Valley region.

LEAD: AMERICANS still spend more to prevent pregnancy than to pursue it, but that could soon change.
LEAD: A Guide to Italian Cooking with Giuliano Bugialli. Producer/director: Lee Kraft. Videocraft. 100 minutes. $49.95.

LEAD: I DON'T KNOW THAT LOVE IS SWEEPING THE country, but sex is surely taking the town. On stage, that is. Some of the sex is dramatically useful, some of it is just plain nutty fun, and some of it is deliberately distasteful. I guess that's a gamut, though the plays all seem to end up with their principal characters deeply troubled, momentarily deprived, or flat out dead.

LEAD: KITE COMPETITIONS A kaleidoscope of kites will take to the skies above Wildwood next weekend. The event, the East Coast Stunt Kite Flying Championship, is attracting about 100 entries from around the country, including Hawaii, where experts abound.

LEAD: The Government asked to dismiss insider trading charges against three Wall Street professionals, but the defendants' lawyers are fighting the request. LEAD: THERE were 27 people in line ahead of me. Men in work boots with strong hands. A widowed grandmother. A Wall Streeter in pinstripes reading a business section. It was a spring morning in the unemployment line.

LEAD: In what is perhaps the proper conclusion to the seemingly endless hockey season, the two teams that painstakingly compiled the best records over the 80-game regular season will duel for the Stanley Cup. LEAD: The Rev. J. Joseph Lynch, a Jesuit priest and longtime scholar of seismology, died of heart failure Thursday at the Murray-Weigel Infirmary at Fordham University. He was 92 years old and lived in the Bronx.
LEAD: PLAYING a one-night engagement last Monday at the Blue Note, the Widespread Jazz Orchestra showed that it has finally become the band it has been promising to be for the last decade.

LEAD: I realize that men have become more ''sensitive,'' but Ben Stein's article ''Life With Trixie'' gives sensitivity a bizarre name. We're all familiar with the adage about dog being man's best friend, but whoever heard of dog becoming man's preferred companion? It's embarrassing to hear Mr. Stein describe ''what it feels like to hold Trixie.

LEAD: FEADING Edmund Wilson on the subject of Rudyard Kipling, George Orwell was amazed to find how much of the Anglo-Indian mystique, ''so boringly familiar'' to the British, was ''barely intelligible to an American.''

LEAD: I AM growing gray, or rather platinum, before my time. Still straddling the middle of my 30's, I think of myself as permanently ''pre-middle age,'' save for those telltale signs that crown my head.

LEAD: WHEN SUMMER WEEKENDS come around, the people who own vacation homes give invitations. The rest of us accept them, put down the phone and say to each other, ''We'd better bring them something.''

LEAD: Testimony by Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, dominated not only last week's Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair, but also the attention of White House strategists. Highlights of the week's developments follow. * Mr. McFarlane said he had briefed the President ''dozens'' of times on the Administration's secret efforts to funnel private aid to Nicaraguan rebels.

LEAD: In New York City, it can be difficult to get a landlord to make repairs. Witness the case of J. Leonard Spodek, a Long Island resident who has been charged with failing to make court-ordered improvements in 29 of his 70 Manhattan and Brooklyn apartment buildings. Last year, Mr. Spodek served 45 days in jail on criminal and civil charges involving uncorrected building code violations.

LEAD: For the second time in three years, the ultimate prize in the National Basketball Association's draft lottery will be well worth the season of ineptitude endured by each team that qualified for the drawing.

LEAD: Granted, the ''power and lability of human sexuality'' is great, but so is the very real fear of death. If AIDS is to have an impact on future generations, it will be seen in a change in sexual behavior rather than in a massive death toll. STEPHEN J. LOMPERIS New York City
LEAD: EARLY each morning, Randy E. Percy goes to the fields.

LEAD: JUST after Jim Ray Hart, the third baseman for San Francisco, grounded out to end the seventh inning in the last game of the 1965 season, the phone rang in the press box at Candlestick Park. It was Herman Franks, the manager of the Giants and a man of few words, calling from the dugout. ''And?'' he rasped.
LEAD: EINSTEIN'S MONSTERS By Martin Amis. 149 pp. New York: Harmony Books. $12.95.

LEAD: A week ago, at 105 East 73rd Street, Manhattan was home to the world's most unusual bridge event: The Cavendish Invitational Charity Pairs. It is the only annual international event, at a permanent location, which assembles players from both sides of the Atlantic and on this occasion four from the Far East.

LEAD: Emotional economics and discredited protectionism drive Richard Gephardt's Presidential campaign. He appeals to popular frustration by blaming America's trade deficit on other countries. His remedy, adopted narrowly by the House and still uncertain in the Senate, would make matters worse.

LEAD: AS the spirit of the East Village creeps eastward into the region that runs from Avenues A to D, between Houston and 14th Streets, two distinct yet overlapping identities are emerging. One is Loisaida, indigenous and struggling; the other is Alphabet City, arty and affluent.
LEAD: A group of elected officials vowed yesterday to fight a plan to relocate the Museum of the American Indian from Manhattan to Washington.
LEAD: The shelf for researching bed and breakfast accommodations grows crowded.

LEAD: AMID THE THEATER PIECES recently created in the dance-theater genre, ''Cendrillon,'' by the French choreographer Maguy Marin, stands out for its richness of detail. When the Lyons Opera Ballet presented the American premiere of this magical doll's-eye view of ''Cinderella'' in January, its originality and psychological rightness came from this accumulated dramatic detail.

LEAD: INSTEAD of improving the breed, it's as if horse racing were trying to improve the greed. When the Belmont Stakes is run on June 6, the Triple Crown Challenge bonus will be worth either $5 million or $1 million, depending on Alysheba, now the winner of both the Preakness and the Kentucky Derby.

LEAD: It appears quite admirable of Roger Tilles to stress the seriousness of one of the issues confronting us on Long Island [ ''Arbitrary, Unilateral Caps on Water Use Will Hurt,'' Opinion Page, April 19 ] . However, one has to wonder where, as a developer who has constructed and proposes additional development in Nassau County, he and other builders have been while these issues were intensifying.

LEAD: THERE are actors' actors and dancers' dancers. There ought, perhaps, to be a category of performances about performing. Aikens of West Long Branch, N.J., and the late Judge Louis R. Aikins.

Whiteman of Shaker Heights, Ohio, who have announced her engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Gordon Brummer of Manhasset, L.I.

LEAD: THE ARRIVAL OF WARM WEATHER and weekend guests is an ideal time to take advantage of a microwave oven. This handy appliance does not heat up your kitchen, cooks rapidly and lets you make festive dishes quickly after a late return from tennis or the beach. And although microwave ovens are not appropriate for every recipe, many foods cook as well as, or better than, they would in a conventional oven, and in a fraction of the time.

LEAD: Sitting at a card table in the back room of an apartment in Flushing, Queens, Wang Bingzhang does not seem a likely figure to be plotting the introduction of democracy to China.

LEAD: IN THE CONTROVERSY OVER TV evangelism, no one seems to have noticed that the most influential preacher in America is not Jim Bakker or Jerry Falwell or John Cardinal O'Connor. Rather it is Bill Cosby. Every week his program and some others - ''Family Ties,'' ''Growing Pains,'' ''Mr. Belvedere'' and ''My Sister Sam'' - present vivid and appealing paradigms of love to vast audiences.

LEAD: WHEN THE COOK WANTS TO provide a bountiful table at minimal expense, expertise goes a long way. For those who find the idea of a dinner party for 20 daunting at any time, doing it on a shoestring becomes an even greater challenge. The trick is to shop carefully, taking advantage of seasonal foods, set the table stylishly and be prepared to spend more time than money.

LEAD: OUT ON THE EASTERN TIP OF Long Island, where I live, this time of year brings a tidal wave of fruits and vegetables. It starts in May, with the first sweet peas and tender asparagus, rising to a swell in midsummer with string beans, spinach and multicolored peppers. By August, the countryside has been inundated with zucchini, tomatoes, corn and yellow summer squash.

LEAD: After years of drifting politically toward Libya, the Mediterranean island nation of Malta is preparing to move closer to Europe, according to its new Prime Minister, Eddie Fenech Adami. Mr. Fenech Adami, who took office last week after his conservative Nationalist Party ended 16 years of Socialist rule by defeating the governing Labor Party, said he planned to renegotiate a treaty with Libya to elminate clauses on defense cooperation.

LEAD: Peruse the old-time photos of Adirondack sporting life and inevitably you come across this classic shot: the grizzled guide, his smooth-faced tweedy young client, and on the grass between them enough gaping speckled trout to keep a sushi chef busy for a month.

LEAD: THE first Earth Day in New Jersey - April 22, 1970 -served notice to government and industry that the environmental cause had, indeed, become a mass movement. All over the Garden State, campus organizations and citizens' groups launched cleanup campaigns, recycling projects, educational forums and public rallies.

LEAD: The sedate social clubs of upper-class New Orleans are abuzz this spring with an unusual issue for the time and the place: The rights of women, specifically Newcomb College women. The issue has caught on as the proposed Federal equal rights amendment never did.
LEAD: Federal and state agencies are at odds over the health hazards posed by thousands of miles of gravel roads made from asbestos-bearing serpentine rock.

LEAD: Soccer Title to Coventry City: Tottenham Hotspur's Gary Mabbutt put the ball into his own net six minutes into overtime to give Coventry City a 3-2 victory yesterday in the Football Association Cup final. It was the first F.A. Cup title won by Coventry in its 104-year history and the first-ever loss in a final for Tottenham, which shares the record of seven cup victories with Aston Villa.
LEAD: Any way you look at it, these are bad times for the Mets. And they worsened last night before 48,128 fans, the largest Shea Stadium crowd of the season.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Dr. Gould's muddy thoughts do little more than add to the general alarm. He fears the coming pandemic explosion yet rejects technology as our main ally. He sees its mechanism yet hints the answer is nontechnological.

LEAD: Chancellor Franz Vranitzky will make a symbolically important visit to Washington this week amid signs that political support for President Kurt Waldheim has eroded in Austria since the Justice Department listed Mr. Waldheim as being barred from entering the United States.

LEAD: New Jersey's Commissioner of Human Services suspended a physician and announced measures to improve medical services at the state's psychiatric hospitals after charges of negligence in the deaths of three patients last year.
LEAD: Large amounts of toxic metals in the waters of Long Island Sound can be traced to discharges from sewage treatment plants, a Federal study has found.

LEAD: Special Today: Entertaining/Magazine Part 2 * Strategies for easy summer get-togethers for busy people. * Take the Guests Out. It can be done with style. * Bring the Takeout In: A quick and effortless party. * Let the Guests Do the Cooking - it lightens the load.
LEAD: Nigel Mansell of Britain and Nelson Piquet of Brazil, Williams-Honda teammates, gained top positions today on the starting grid for the Belgian Grand Prix, which Mansell won last year.

LEAD: Passports Question:Is there any way you can obtain a passport without spending time at a passport office? - R. S., Hicksville, L.I. Answer:There are agencies that specialize in obtaining United States passports, visas and other documents. They use messengers to stand on line at passport offices and consulates and their fees depend on how quick a service is needed.
LEAD: HOW TO THINK LIKE A SCIENTIST Answering Questions by the Scientific Method. By Stephen P. Kramer. Illustrated by Felicia Bond. 44 pp. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell. $11.50. (Ages 8 to 12)
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Stephen Jay Gould is correct to stress that we humans are a part of nature, subject to its unrestricted, amoral patterns. Sadly, the AIDS tragedy reminds us of that humble reality. But let's not confuse our much-maligned love affair with technology with the power of medical science. The latter has provided our species with some control of our destiny.

LEAD: I read your article about a house in the country, and my husband would agree with you. He loves taking long walks in the woods to the river with our dog and he loves puttering around outside. And what am I doing? I am cleaning the house or shopping for food or discovering some form of wildlife in the kitchen, sometimes alive, sometimes not.

LEAD: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's open questioning of an understanding on medium-range missiles that was reached at the Iceland summit meeting has displeased senior White House and State Department officials, Administration officials said today.
LEAD: The Mets were told by their doctors last night that Sid Fernandez did not suffer cartilage damage in his left knee while pitching Friday night.

LEAD: AFTER five years of booming markets and unparalleled expansion, Wall Street's major securities firms have been transformed into sprawling global behemoths. But suddenly they are trying to reverse course out of a fear that leaner times lie ahead. That raises an unsettling question: Are Wall Street managers, already straining to control their bloated ranks, prepared to cope with a squeeze?

LEAD: BLOOMS AND TROPHIES The New York Botanical Garden's annual orchid show has been extended from three to five days but it is still the shortest show on the schedule, running this year from Thursday through next Monday under the glass dome of the Conservatory. It is the only show in which the plants are supplied by hobbyists, commercial growers and orchid societies worldwide.

LEAD: IT has been a few years since I last wandered around downtown Great Neck, a place I have never lived in but have often, if sporadically, visited, mostly to see friends whose children have now grown up and gone west - that is, to new apartment households in the city whence they came.

LEAD: WE WANT BURGERS AND WE want them now. We want them in all their cholesterolic glory, incinerated over an outdoor charcoal fire that gives them a nice dusting of ashes and a coating of benzopyrene, before we drown them in maroon barbecue sauce.
LEAD: Two days after seizing power in a coup, the army said today that it would restore democracy under a new constitution limiting the rights of ethnic Indians.

LEAD: The presidents of the nation's major private research universities were paid an average of $153,400 in 1986, nearly $50,000 more than their counterparts running the largest public universities, an administrators' group says.
LEAD: MARC and Kiki Ellenby have seen the future and it is filled with carambolas, millions of pounds of them.
LEAD: In another reflection of her wide popularity, President Corazon C. Aquino did very well last week in voting for the Philippine Senate.

LEAD: Why not compel everyone to be tested for AIDS as the basis for halting further spread of the virus? That's a natural first thought to anyone who ponders the deadly epidemic. But it's only a first thought. That some senior Administration officials argue for mandatory AIDS testing shows how late in the day they have arrived at step one.

LEAD: Prosecutors in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz last week presented what they said would be the most damaging evidence against him -Mr. Goetz's own videotaped statement about how and why he shot four youths in a Manhattan subway car on Dec. 22, 1984.

LEAD: SNYDER'S WALK. By Thomas B. Morgan. (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $17.95.) Ezra Pound described literature as news that stays news. Thomas B. Morgan's second novel is literature about how hard it is for news to stay news. Jacob C. Snyder, a magazine writer, sees reporting as an almost Arthurian quest for the truth.

LEAD: IN THE 20TH CENTURY THE ARTISTIC family has become almost obsolete. The notable exceptions are the Duchamps -Marcel, Jacques Villon, Raymond Duchamp-Villon and Suzanne Crotti - and the Giacomettis - the father, Giovanni; his second cousin, Augusto, and his three sons, Alberto, Diego and Bruno. Both families were raised in provincial settings: the Duchamps in Normandy, the Giacomettis in Italian Switzerland.
LEAD: YOU HAVE BEEN grievously misinformed about the love that dare not speak its name.

LEAD: THE drop in inflation that started in the early 1980's removed one of the main incentives to borrow. But Americans have continued their rapid pile-up of debt. Though the Federal Reserve reported that consumer borrowing fell in March for the first time since 1982, by one-tenth of 1 percent, analysts pointed out that the figure does not include home-equity loans, the fastest growing credit instruments.
LEAD: SOMETHING I cannot forgo is having time in the morning, in bed. I accomplish it, but with difficulty. Without this small pleasure, my nerves become jangled by late afternoon and my spirits sag.
LEAD: Dwight Gooden took another step last night, pitching four scoreless innings against a team of minor leaguers in the second live workout of his comeback.

LEAD: Fanny and Alexander Directed and written by Ingmar Bergman. Starring Pernilla Allwin, Bertil Guve, Ewa Froling, Erland Josephson, Jan Malmsjo, Gunn Wallgren. 1983. Embassy Home Entertainment. 197 minutes. $39.95.
LEAD: Eight Boston-area hospitals have filed suit to block new regulations that empower a state medical licensing agency to evaluate the performance of doctors.

LEAD: LIKE MANY PROFES-sional caterers, Chip Fisher doesn't stop entertaining during his weekends off. ''We usually have between six and a dozen people over for lunch or dinner at least once each weekend,'' said Mr. Fisher of his summer holidays at the house he and his wife rent near the beach in East Hampton, Long Island.

LEAD: THERE are certain dreads that must be universal among men: the dread of turning and running from the first danger on the battlefield, the dread that a desirable woman will look you straight in the eye and whisper, ''Not so long as you shall live,'' and the dread of the first scratch on your brand-new automobile.

LEAD: WHAT to serve at a large cocktail party? Spring vegetables are the answer at this time of year. Crudites - raw or blanched vegetables - are hardly new, but they are always popular, especially with the host or hostess who does not have to worry about taking sizzling trays out of the oven during the evening, or spending hours beforehand making complicated little things with puff pastry.

LEAD: RIVAL builders say that a major Pennsylvania developer who broke ground last December for two housing developments in this hill country west of Wilmington not only paid too much for farmland, but is also trying to lure away employees with wages that they cannot afford to pay.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo announced Friday that an extra $850 million had turned up in checks attached to 1986 income-tax returns. As a result, administration officials said, the array of new taxes and fees proposed only two weeks earlier to raise $1 billion a year to rebuild roads and bridges could be deferred for at least a year.

LEAD: THE way the Green Bay Packers' coach, Forrest Gregg, figures it, Donnie Humphrey's ideal playing weight would be 270 pounds, or about 25 pounds under the defensive lineman's listed weight last season. To help Humphrey trim down, the Packers sent him to a hospital nutrition program, but the 26-year-old player didn't cooperate, Gregg said, citing some weighty evidence.

LEAD: The 1990 World Soccer Cup competition will take place in 12 Italian cities from June 9 to July 8, with the final at the Olympic Stadium in Rome, the organizers announced today. The dates will have to be officially ratified by the Federation Internationale de Football Association, but this was considered a formality.
LEAD: WALTZING WITH A DICTATOR The Marcoses and the Making of American Policy. By Raymond Bonner. Illustrated. 533 pp. New York: Times Books. $19.95.
LEAD: PERHAPS a pivotal run that the Pittsburgh Pirates scored against San Diego one night last week epitomized the kind of season it has been for the pathetic Padres.
LEAD: STEREOTYPING the sexes can be useful in understanding people if you are wise enough to remember that exceptions are to be expected.

LEAD: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra case has granted immunity to a key figure in the case, Robert C. Dutton, and has questioned him before a grand jury, according to a Federal investigator and others with knowledge of the inquiry.

LEAD: THE Westchester County Office for the Aging has produced a nationally cited booklet that reinforces an old message. For years, parents have told their children about the importance of starting the day with a good breakfast. Now this six-page booklet, entitled ''The Forgotten Meal,'' is trying to deliver the same message to the elderly.
LEAD: Hobart defeated Ohio Wesleyan, 9-5, at Boswell Field today in a Division III lacrosse game that set a record for National Collegiate Athletic Association championships.

LEAD: When Julian Altman acquired a stolen Stradivarius violin in 1936, he put it right to work. In fact, he played it for a living in restaurants and at parties for nearly half a century. Not until he was on his deathbed in 1985 did Mr. Altman reveal his secret to his wife, Marcelle Hall. Ms. Hall said he told her he bought the violin from a friend for $100 shortly after it was stolen from a Carnegie Hall dressing room.

Hyland, who served as national security adviser to Presidents Nixon, Ford and Carter, told graduates at his alma mater Friday that the Reagan Administration should not permit its foreign policy to reflect a trend toward isolationism and protectionism. ''Protectionism is the ally of isolationism, and isolationism is the Dracula of American foreign policy,'' Mr.
