LEAD: The marriage of Alexandra Hope Simons, an associate at Sonnenblick-Goldman, a real-estate investment bank in Manhattan, and John Edward Lange, a legal consultant to the Manhattan law firm Rogers & Wells, took place yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in Washington. The Rev. Stephan E. Klingelhofer performed the ceremony.

LEAD: THE state is beginning to look for sites to build three major medium-security prisons, and while most municipalities are trying to keep them out, a small town in the eastern part of Connecticut is courting corrections officials.

LEAD: AFTER undergoing knee surgery this winter, Peter Baida, a hospital fund-raiser, hired a car service to take him to work for the month of February, rather than chance the icy Manhattan sidewalks. Taxis are not easily found during rush hour in Mr. Baida's neighborhood, but for a fee of $8, a sedan pulled up to his apartment building promptly each morning and deposited him several minutes later at his office entrance.

LEAD: WHEN she called a general election for June 11, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher made it clear she was not thinking of serving a few more years and retiring to her garden. ''This is only the third term we are asking for. There is quite a long way to go,'' she said, hinting that the year 2000 might be a nice time to step down.

LEAD: There were tremors along the elm-lined lawns of this courtly Detroit suburb this week as collectors, builders and ordinary homeowners dismantled one of the town's stateliest mansions, even stripping its oak floors and bronze door knockers.
LEAD: Inflation fears are growing despite the nation's industrial overcapacity, which has traditionally been seen as a form of insurance against price surges.
LEAD: THE ANGEL AND THE SOLDIER BOY Written and illustrated by Peter Collington. Unpaged. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $9.95. (All ages)

LEAD: Government officials and private citizens have been seeking ways of easing the plight of the homeless for many years. Yet solutions still elude the seekers and the number of homeless people seems to grow with each passing year.
LEAD: SCORNED AND RIDICULED FOR TWO decades, the made-for-TV movie now gives every indication of being ready to confound the smirkers.
LEAD: Herbert Mandel is missing the mark when he blames advocates of low-density housing on Long Island for the area's lack of affordable housing [ Letters to the Long Island Editor, April 19 ] .
LEAD: ''I THINK all police officers should be drug tested,'' Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said. It was, he said in June 1986, ''absolutely'' a priority of the force in New York City.
LEAD: IN THE COUNTRY OF LAST THINGS By Paul Auster. 188 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

LEAD: THE word ''personal'' is still very much a part of I.B.M.'s promotional campaign for its new line of microcomputers. But in a very real sense the machines are not personal computers at all, and this may well be the crux of their impact on the future of small computers.
LEAD: WE were standing - my husband and I - in a lot at the Cape Cod Fence Company, trying to choose a fence for a dog pen when I saw the wooden glider on the other side of the lot.

LEAD: A leading Beirut newspaper reported today that President Amin Gemayel, under pressure from his own Christian camp and with his Government threatened by the resignation of the Prime Minister, is expected to resign soon.

LEAD: The marriage of Stapley Wonham and David Merton Emberling took place yesterday at the Dingletown Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., with the Rev. Dr. Warren E. Ost, a Presbyterian minister, officiating. Diane Molleson was maid of honor, and James Warinsky was best man.

LEAD: Spring is the season when Boston, which is still a pedestrian's city, slips gratefully from galoshes to running shoes. It is the time to enjoy the texture of the 18th and 19th centuries, and even savor the finer parts of the 20th, a period through which the city has exported, by turns, revolution, culture and high technology.

LEAD: New York offers art, dance, danger, dirt, music, traffic and wildlife. It also offers falafel, calamari, sushi, cannoli, quiche, cheesecake, tempura, sausage, scungilli, yogurt on a stick, popcorn in a bucket, meatballs on a roll and all manner of things delicate and indelicate. LEAD: CONSISTENCY is the hallmark of a good restaurant, but it's not the word to describe Mamma Lombardi's in Holbrook.
LEAD: With a steadily rising surplus in state funds, Connecticut's General Assembly began approval this week of a $5.64 billion budget that will increase spending by a record 15 percent.

LEAD: This is a good week to explore modern dance at some of the city's vital smaller dance houses. Lisa Kraus and Dancers moves into Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue at Ninth Street, for five performances, Friday through next Sunday at 9 P.M. Ms. Kraus's dance tends to be yeasty, and she will present a wide-ranging program that includes new and recent works ranging from ''dancing to grand-scale classical music without the protection of tongue-in-cheek irony,'' as the choreographer puts it, to ''narrative dancing that relies primarily on the expressiveness of movement.

LEAD: The salvaging of the 18th-century British warship deBraak effectively ''mutilated'' the hull and has denied archeologists valuable data on life aboard the legendary ship, a leading preservationist has charged.

LEAD: One night, creeping through the bushes along the Texas side of the border, I began to laugh. I laughed until I had to stop and sit on the ground to control the sense of wild comedy that suddenly seized me.

LEAD: NANA VASCONCELOS has brought the spark of Brazilian percussion to all sorts of cross-cultural music in the last few years. Now, he's put together his own band, Bush Dance, and on Wednesday at S.O.B.'s it turned rhythms into melodies and tunes into grooves - heady, exhilarating, unpredictable music.

Locke 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Locke Jr. of New Hartford, N.Y., took place yesterday in New Canaan. The Rev. Roland Jones performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

LEAD: The final playoff to determine the United States entry in the 1987 world bridge team championships continued here quietly today after an extraordinary day of excitement and legal argument in the semifinal stage Friday.

LEAD: In this city renowned for its well-tended colonial history and rows of carefully restored antebellum mansions, the battle over historical preservation has moved for the first time into the 20th century.
LEAD: Racial hostilities led to the overthrow last week of the newly elected Government of Fiji.

Carey Jr. of Sands Point, L.I., and North Palm Beach, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Ann Carey, to Charles Bernard LaLone, a son of Marie T. LaLone of Locust Valley, L.I., and Bernard H. LaLone Jr. of Locust Valley and Palm Beach, Fla.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: Athletes should not be role models; fathers and mothers should be role models. E. P. HUMPHREY Jr. Wynnewood, Pa.

LEAD: HE was still feeling the pain, but Eric Davis, the Cincinnati Reds' star outfielder who hurt his left shoulder making a diving catch against the Cardinals in St. Louis Friday night, had some good news yesterday morning. According to a Reds spokesman, a second round of X-rays confirmed that there had been no fracture to the shoulder, indicating that Davis should be able to return to the lineup within a few days.

LEAD: PLAYING THE BASS IN YOUR own improvising ensemble can put you in the driver's seat, just as a certain rent-a-car agency claims to do. Of course, not every bassist wants to drive or is capable of handling a careering vehicle. Not every band wants to be driven, by the bassist or by anyone else. But the bass has special capabilities, and its role in the jazz ensemble has developed in a special manner.

LEAD: BETWEEN THE CIVIL War and World War II, sculptors decorated the gardens of Europe and America with grandiose urns, fanciful fountains, heroic statuary and a wealth of weighty furniture. Nobody knows how many of these figures and furnishings have survived the elements, wartime scrap drives and property subdivisions of the 1950's.

LEAD: AS POPULAR as exotic fruits have become, they are still small potatoes at many supermarket cash registers. Mr. Kemp of Super Valu, for example, says they account for just 1 percent of total fruit sales at his stores.

LEAD: THE AMERICAN FAMILY: THE POSTWAR YEARS 1946-1948 Part of the series ''The March of Time: American Lifestyles 1939-1950.'' Executive producer Louis de Rochemont. Narrated by Westbrook van Voorhis. Embassy Home Entertainment. 90 minutes. $24.95.

LEAD: THE official announcement isn't due until tomorrow, but according to a report in The Daily News, an arbitrator has decided that the Nets have to pay Otis Birdsong his full $500,000 salary next season but don't have to fork over some $280,000 the team had withheld from his salary for this past season.
LEAD: A music review headline in this section last Sunday appeared in similar versions on two adjoining articles.

LEAD: A quiet change under way in American political life - the creation of a new center - may be more momentous in the long run than such attention-seizing matters as Gary Hart's evening with Donna Rice or President Reagan's Iran-contra problems.
LEAD: Edwin Moses had one of his closer calls this sunny afternoon at Princeton University's Palmer Stadium in the Adidas/Princeton Invitational track meet.
LEAD: Legislative candidates backed by President Corazon C. Aquino consolidated their lead today, and their opponents appeared uncertain on how to press a threatened protest.

LEAD: TAKEOUT IS A 1987 WAY OF LIFE FOR many people too busy to cook for themselves. It can also be an inventive and spontaneous way of entertaining. These days takeout shops are making more sophisticated dishes and creating more varieties of ethnic and homespun American foods than ever before, and with such a wide array, elegant meals can be assembled almost in the time it takes to arrange the food on party plates.

LEAD: WHEN the Chase Manhattan Bank mailed hundreds of thousands of letters to homeowners in the New York area a few weeks ago, offering them bargain rates on home-equity loans, or what used to be known as second mortgages, the bank was joining in an increasingly popular promotion.
LEAD: Dr. Sidney Cohen, a leading authority on marijuana, LSD and other mood altering drugs, died of heart failure at his Los Angeles home on May 8. He was 76 years old.

LEAD: The Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company opened its $13.7 million repair yard today to trains on the Harlem line. The 63,000-square-foot center in Putnam County, 52 miles north of Grand Central Terminal in New York City, was built on the site of a smaller diesel repair shop made obsolete with the introduction of electric trains on the Upper Harlem line in June 1984.
LEAD: One month ago today, Willi Smith, 39, who designed inventive low-priced sports clothes that became street classics, died of AIDS at Mount Sinai Hospital.
LEAD: Jack Clark drove in three runs with a homer and a double, and Curt Ford also had a home run, leading the Cardinals to a 6-5 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

LEAD: RECOGNIZING the need for regional political cooperation in the drive to make the nation's waterways safe for swimming and fishing, members of Congress from Connecticut, New York and Rhode Island have formed a Congressional Long Island Sound Caucus.

LEAD: CAMEO delivered a hyperkinetic hour of music Sunday at Radio City Music Hall - strutting, conga-lining, hip-swiveling, rapping and singing over a pile-driver funk beat. Larry Blackmon has led Cameo through 10 years and 12 albums, gradually dropping band members so the current group is simply three male singers - himself, Tomi Jenkins and Nathan Leftenant.

LEAD: Elizabeth Ann Maloney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Maloney of Easton, Conn., and James Patrick Dowd, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mathew J. Dowd of West Brighton, S.I., were married yesterday at Notre Dame of Easton Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Robert J. Hyl performed the ceremony. Mary Ellen Maloney was her sister's maid of honor.

LEAD: Texas, cowboy-and-pickup-truck division, continues to undergo deflation: As of Sept. 1, drinking at the wheel will no longer be permitted. The Legislature made the decision by voice vote, without opposition.

LEAD: CAST-IRON FURNITURE RE-splendent with intricate patterns of ferns, grape vines, morning glories or ivy epitomized the 19th-century Iron Age, when burgeoning industrialization made ornate, mass-produced furniture plentiful and well-priced for the growing middle class. Those interested in buying outdoor furniture and ornaments today are again gravitating toward these decorative designs.

LEAD: AT a time when most American cities are trying to figure out what to do with hundreds of thousands of square feet of office space no one seems to need, New Yorkers are facing a generation of skyscraper parks laid out not by the square foot but by the block. Never before have so many gigantic projects been planned simultaneously, underscoring the unrelenting expansion of the city's financial services industry, which seems to devour almost every inch of space that comes on the market.

LEAD: For the last five months, tax investigators have searched streets by night and subpoenaed garages' customer lists seeking to track down New York residents who violate the law by registering their cars outside the state.

LEAD: THE 15-month-old son of Marques Johnson, the Los Angeles Clippers forward, died yesterday after having fallen into the family swimming pool, club officials said. The child, Marques Kevin Johnson Jr., died of cardiac arrest. The youngster was admitted to U.C.L.A. Medical Center Friday night.
LEAD: Thousands of students battled policemen today in the sixth day of demonstrations demanding the ouster of President Chun Doo Hwan, witnesses said.

LEAD: THE tragic end of a civilization that peopled New Jersey as early as 10,000 B.C. is recounted in ''The Lenape: Archaeology, History, and Ethnography,'' by Herbert C. Kraft (New Jersey Historical Society, 230 Broadway, Newark, N.J., $26.70 postpaid).

LEAD: Evan Inlaw, a junior majoring in psychology at Fordham University, found that working as a counselor at the Fresh Air Fund's Camp Hidden Valley meant putting to use all of what he has learned. ''You have to use a lot of psychology,'' he said.

LEAD: THE name Bulova has a secure place in the affections of northern Queens. The watch company built itself a home with Art Deco touches in Jackson Heights 35 years ago and manufactured fine watches there for years.

LEAD: IT did not take very long for the trial of Klaus Barbie to become as much a contest among lawyers as a lesson in history. Mr. Barbie, whose trial opened here last week, was the wartime chief of the Gestapo in this region of France. As the trial's main exhibit, he did offer a kind of presence here for the first two days - the gray, pallid, strangely smiling and apparently unrepentant presence of an old Nazi.

LEAD: The turn-of-the-century structure that once housed two of America's great retailing institutions - J.P. McCreery's and, more recently, the flagship store of Ohrbach's - is destined for renovation and conversion into 430,000 square feet of offices and stores.

LEAD: The marriage of Leslie Carol Fielden, an associate in the New York law firm Solinger Grosz & Goldwasser, and Jeffry Bruce Seidel, a manager in the tax department at the Touche Ross Financial Services Center in New York, took place last evening at Federal Hall in Manhattan. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony.

LEAD: IT IS CURIOUS THAT MY ENTHUSIASM for the picnic is so deep-seated, for I have over the years enjoyed but also endured that dining-out-of-doors under the pleasantest yet, at times, the vilest conditions conceivable.

LEAD: TWO postal cards are scheduled for release in the next eight days. The first, to be released Friday, commemorates the 150th anniversary of the self-scouring steel plow. The second, to be released May 25, will mark the 200th anniversary of the Constitutional Convention.

LEAD: The engagement of Judith Ellen Frisch to John J. Monaghan has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Alan J. Frisch of New York, parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Monaghan Jr. of Cumberland, R.I. An August wedding is planned. Ms. Frisch, an associate in the Boston office of the law firm LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae, graduated cum laude from Barnard College and the Boston University School of Law.

LEAD: COMMUNITIES in the county are being urged by the Federal Government to use a new rent-subsidy system that could make more housing available to homeless and low-income people but that would require them to pay more than the 30 percent of their income they are paying now in rent.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Bach's ''Art of the Fugue'' is one of the great works from the Baroque, a summation of Bach's thinking on contrapuntal writing and a heroic piece of music. Extant manuscripts give no indication what instrument or instruments were intended to perform the work, and so, over the years, harpsichordists, chamber groups and full-blown symphony orchestras have been among those to tackle the piece.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., yesterday Brooke Bayard Baldridge, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dickson Bouton Baldridge of Wilmington, N.C., was married to Daniel Gregory Pelizza, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Pelizza of Wallingford, Conn. The Rev. M.Jennings Matheson performed the ceremony, assisted by Kempton Dunn Baldridge, a seminarian at the Berkeley Divinity School of Yale

LEAD: At a time that millions of Americans cannot afford homes of their own, in a world in which land is a limited resource, it is appalling that owners of second homes may still deduct mortgage interest from their taxable incomes.

LEAD: MOZART AND BEETHOVEN found the piano a major merchandising tool in their struggle for audience recognition. For Haydn it was more a faithful companion - a trusted appliance for the daily business of making music. Haydn's last sonatas, and a few of the earlier ones, do seek a public forum, but for him, the instrument was principally his private conduit for ideas.

LEAD: HARD-HIT in the 1970's by the closing of steel mills and rubber factories, this blue-collar borough about 10 miles west of Philadelphia has suddenly found itself in the midst of a building boom traced to the development of interstate highways.
LEAD: A review of the New York City Ballet last Sunday misidentified the ballerina in ''Variations pour une porte et un soupir.'' She was Maria Calegari, not Darci Kistler.
LEAD: WHAT drives the marketers is the dream of finding the next kiwi, the Horatio Alger of exotic fruit.

LEAD: CONNECTICUT has not experienced a catastrophe in recent memory. We've had terrible floods, blizzards, hurricanes and tornadoes. As tragic as the collapses of L'Ambiance Plaza apartment complex in Bridgeport and the Mianus River bridge in Greenwich were, they were not catastrophes as defined by widespread devastation and great loss of life.

LEAD: THE HUMAN SEASON. By Sarah Rossiter. (Little, Brown, $16.95.) Prep school novels about a boy's coming of age are familiar and usually written by men, but this first novel by Sarah Rossiter updates the genre while retaining the stock characters. Dunster, a New England boys' boarding school, seems to be a place time forgot, replete with tie-and-jacket code, compulsory chapel and bully-boy students who sir and madam everyone.

LEAD: Visitors to Central Park relaxing on the grass near Bethesda Terrace in the sunny and mild weather yesterday. The terrace, originally completed in 1864, reopened after a $4.5 million, four-year restoration. The reopening coincided with the annual ''You Gotta Have Park'' festivities this weekend. (NYT/Angel

LEAD: I HAD WORN my hair in a conservative pageboy for years, but now in the springtime, this middle-aged woman's fancy turned to thoughts of a new hair style. For the last seven years or so, I've looked the part of the college instructor that I am - classic in coiffeur and dress, correct. Then, in a moment of madness, I walked into the beauty salon for my first ''perm'' since high school.

LEAD: Kristie Karen Bryant, an account executive with Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Humphrey Inc., a New York advertising agency, and Richard Wayne Kornhauser, a vice president of Ted Bates Advertising in New York, were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Hattiesburg, Miss. The Rev. Joseph Rowland performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The engagement of Sara Gilchrist Johnston to Alexander John Skene Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Skene of Norwood, Mass., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. James Gilchrist Johnston of West Boothbay Harbor, Me. The couple plan to marry July 25. Miss Johnston is a graduate of the University of Oregon and she studied at the Boston Architectural Center.
LEAD: State health authorities have refused to let New York City officials give needles and syringes to drug users as part of a test project to stem the spread of AIDS.

LEAD: James Worthy scored 27 points and Michael Cooper sank three free throws in the final 1 minute 42 seconds today as the Los Angeles Lakers held off the Seattle SuperSonics, 92-87, in Game 1 of the Western Conference finals.

LEAD: Amy Ellen Gewirtz and Michael Francis McGahan, both lawyers, plan to marry June 28, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Gewirtz of Southport, Conn., and New York have announced. Mr. McGahan is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis McGahan of Larchmont, N.Y.

LEAD: Some Sunday mornings in the country, when work does not call, we set out the margarine, the strawberry jam and the apple butter, and on occasion the Portuguese marmalade. We pour coffee and then we start slicing our loaf of massa sovada, Portuguese sweet bread, and dropping the slices into the toaster.

LEAD: A hiker can follow the Appalachian Trail for 2,000 miles, between Georgia and Maine, and the route is well known for its ''through hikers,'' the several hundred people who hike its full length each year. But as it passes through the heart of New England, the trail takes in 300 sometimes bucolic, sometimes breathtaking miles of Vermont and New

LEAD: American officials say they will continue to explore the idea of an international conference on Middle East peace, even though they regard the prospects as poor because of a political deadlock in Israel over the proposal.
LEAD: ED BERGER had a 50th birthday not long ago, and he rearranged his priorities or, as he put it, had a ''mental reorganization and liberation.''

LEAD: THAT EYE, THE SKY. By Tim Winton. (Atheneum, $14.95.) If you don't know Australian slang you might stop reading this novel after coming upon words like ''ute'' (pickup truck or van), ''crook'' (sick or broken), ''bowser'' (gasoline pump), ''plonk'' (red wine) and ''dag'' (sloppy or slovenly person).

LEAD: AFTER seven of its teen-age students and two teachers were killed in the worst climbing accident in the history of Mount Hood, the Oregon Episcopal School in Portland suspended its wilderness education program to take stock.

LEAD: ON the wide-open spaces of Albuquerque's west side of the Rio Grande, developers are facing a challenge from the past: Public awareness of the city's rich archeology is raising preservation issue sthat could interfere with growth.

LEAD: Vice President Bush, while insisting that he was not breaking with President Reagan, said today that one of the ''highest priorities'' in the next decade should be helping families finance a college education.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.
LEAD: THE wide selection of American wines at three relatively new area restaurants give patrons an excellent opportunity to become acquainted with a variety of domestic products.

LEAD: As the Agriculture Department told Congress it was looking for better ways to protect consumers from food poisoning, one of its processing plant inspectors declared that Government labels on beef, pork and poultry products should read: ''Eat at Your Own Risk.''
LEAD: Five Lionni Classics The Animal Fables of Leo Lionni Random House 30 minutes. $14.95.
LEAD: LAWRENCE E. BATHGATE 2D, LAW-yer, land investor, multimillionaire, inveterate schmoozer, and fund-raiser for Vice President Bush, is on the phone, dealing in the currency of politics.

LEAD: WHEN THE ENGLISH QUIBBLE about plans for new public buildings in London, the arguments are esthetic. But when the French do battle over proposals to add something new to Paris, it sometimes seems as if the entire Government may tumble.
LEAD: WITH a burst of spring shows at galleries in northern New Jersey, interesting work in all craft media is proliferating.

LEAD: The testimony had not even begun. City Councilman Michael DeMarco was explaining the rules for the public hearing in the Bronx on New York City's proposed $22.7 billion budget: The speaking time would be five minutes for elected officials and heads of agencies, two minutes for everyone else.

I was surprised to recognize her familiar script under photos of a skinny girl in laced shoes, shapeless frocks and oversized hair bows, and

LEAD: TO open a bookshop is one of the archetypal romances or escapes, like sailing around the world or living off the land. The peculiar appeal of a bookshop is that you don't have to know anything about books - your customers will educate you.
LEAD: Eriya Jokasi was 38 years old, unemployed and a widow with seven children when she secretly gave birth to a baby in a cornfield and, using a heavy rock, killed it.
LEAD: ''THIS is the heart of Asia,'' said a poet reciting Pushtoon verse at a recent mammoth celebration of the Soviet-backed government here. ''When Afghanistan trembles, all of Asia moves.''

LEAD: EASY IS A LOVELY WORD. AMONG ITS DICTIONARY DEFINI-tions one finds even nicer words: ''free from constraint,'' ''comfortable,'' ''carefree,'' ''unhurried.'' All evocative of what a summer should be. And how a host or hostess should feel about summer entertaining. But the reality is that most of us look on a summer party as a chore - the beach beckons, the hammock lures, the dolce far niente of warm months takes over and sociability goes on hold until fall.

LEAD: Lawyers, real-estate agents, notaries public, travel agents and even some driving instructors have put up signs in recent weeks offering to help illegal aliens sort their way through the complexities of the new immigration law.

LEAD: DOES IT MATTER THAT STRAVINSKY WAS A Russian? If that question strikes you as too obvious to deserve serious consideration, you probably haven't kept up with the hot debate being waged in scholarly circles over two seemingly irreconcilable methods of appraising music. The argument originally was joined over the narrow musicological question of whether ''The Rite of Spring'' is essentially a tonal or a nontonal work, but has taken on the fervor of a dialectical struggle between Greek philosophers over the nature of the Sublime.
LEAD: New York State's farm economy improved last year, with farmers' net income up 35 percent, according to agricultural officials. But farmers still made less than in the early 1980's.
LEAD: Richard M. Nixon has denied charges in a new book that he approved the decision by Ferdinand E. Marcos to impose martial law on the Philippines in 1972.
LEAD: Massachusetts has become the first state in the nation to outlaw alachlor, the nation's most widely used agricultural herbicide, which is suspected of causing cancer.

LEAD: A tentative decision by executives of the American Cancer Society last month to move the 74-year-old agency from New York has stirred dissatisfaction at the society's headquarters in Manhattan and touched its officials around the country.

LEAD: The Mayor of Norwalk, William A. Collins, writes in favor of reforming our nominating procedures [ ''The Struggle to Control Nominations,'' March 29 ] . He suggests that a direct primary will cure two ills of the current system: patronage and issueless contests for nomination.

LEAD: At the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday, Colleen Deborah Green, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Edward Green of Amston, Conn., and New York, was married to Franklin Charles Everett, a son of Charlotte Sonja Everett of Arosa, Switzerland, and San Diego, and the late William Greenough Everett.

LEAD: Lazar Mojsov became head of the collective presidency, Yugoslavia's highest Government body, the official Tanyug press agency reported Friday. Mr. Mojsov, a former Foreign Minister, replaced Sinan Hasani, who served for the last year under a rotation system. Mr. Mojsov is the ninth head of the collective presidency since the death of Tito in May 1980.

LEAD: Tenant Rights in a Sale Question: I am the leaseholder on a town house in a rent-stabilized complex that includes five apartments and three town houses. Access to the units is from an interior courtyard connected to the street by an enclosed passageway. All units are served by a common heating hot-water system.
LEAD: Two years ago, Roger Mears was a driver in the Indy 500. But next weekend he won't be at Indianapolis, where his younger brother, Rick, starts the 500 from the outside of the front row.
LEAD: FROM THE GRAND-stands, they saw bleacher bums sprawling in the sun beyond the outfield, neighbors watching from nearby rooftops, and, beyond these sights, the boundless Midwestern sky.

LEAD: IN ITS first full month of operation last month, the Showboat Hotel-Casino led all of its Atlantic City competitors in slot-machine revenue and trailed only Caesars in total revenue.

LEAD: AS winner of the Mary Mulligan Award, given by the Abby Whiteside Foundation, John Kamitsuka, a pianist, appeared in recital at Alice Tully Hall Tuesday evening. He walked out on crutches, the result of a torn Achilles' tendon. The injury seemed not to bother the pianist, but did prevent him from using the soft pedal.

LEAD: OUTDOOR furniture of good quality is designed to withstand exposure to all kinds of weather, but pieces will last longer and look better if they are given regular preventive maintenance.

LEAD: JUST about everything can be planted in the garden this week except in northern cool regions where there still could be danger of late frost. Before planting out seedlings, started indoors, adjust them to the outside for the day, but take them in at night; put them outdoors overnight the day before they are transplanted to the garden.

LEAD: SOME rock singers try everything; some specialize. Chris Isaak, the singer who came to the Bottom Line Tuesday, has narrowed his specialty to a subsection of a subgenre - rockabilly-tinged, minor-key songs about deceitful lovers. It's a surprise when he breaks into a major key; it's a shock when he straps on an accordion to sing the Louis Jordan hit ''Caledonia Boogie.
LEAD: CHARLES FOURIER The Visionary and His World. By Jonathan Beecher. Illustrated. 601 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $49.50.

LEAD: ''WE'RE not missionaries running the Constitution up for everybody to salute and give honor to it,'' said Richard Petrow of Manhattan and Southampton. ''We're looking at it as a very real document drafted by politicians in Philadelphia. And it's not perfect; yet it's been around for 200 years, and it certainly contributes something important.

LEAD: It was curious to sit in Washington Square United Methodist Church Wednesday night, along with 30 or 40 other devoted listeners, and hear the music of a man who routinely fills Avery Fisher Hall and Carnegie Hall. Even more curious to remember how utterly charming he can be in either circumstance, and to wonder bemusedly about the inherent schizophrenia of having a public and private persona.

LEAD: Valerie Gayle Campbell, who is to join the New York law firm Brown & Wood as an associate in September, was married yesterday to Eric Abrahamson, a teaching fellow and a doctoral candidate in management at the New York University Graduate School of Business Administration. The Rev. Richard Edens, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Fearrington House in Pittsboro, N

LEAD: Susan Louise Green, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alanson Wood Green Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married at Christ Episcopal Church there yesterday to Edward Dean Willett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Edward Willett of Mount Sinai, L.I. The Rev. John Bishop officiated.

LEAD: ''The Sunday Rock was the rock everybody passed on their way into the park, on their way into the Adirondack wilderness back in the old days. Once they passed that rock, Sunday could be Wednesday, Tuesday could be Saturday. You lost account of time. It didn't matter, because once you were in the woods, you were on a different time, in a different frame of mind, everything.

LEAD: The night air was humid and heavy and the politics were rich. A butler served iced tea as reporters gathered on the white-columned veranda of the Louisiana Governor's Mansion, swatting bugs and awaiting the emergence of the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Gov. Edwin W. Edwards.

LEAD: When the technological uncertainties of President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative were combined with the complexities of the budget process in Congress last week, it was hard to tell what was being shot down by whom.

LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 30 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

LEAD: For the first time in more than three years, conservatives lost their tight control of the United States Commission on Civil Rights last week. By a vote of 5 to 3, the panel decided not to issue a draft statement charging that the Supreme Court was ''wrong'' to uphold a California affirmative action plan.
LEAD: ''Womanizer'' achieved more fame, but another word apparently vital to the spirit of Gary Hart's weekend with Donna Rice was ''blonde.''

LEAD: THE pants suit has been with us for a while, and shows little sign of going away. Why should it? While much attention is riveted on the ups and downs of skirts, the pants suit, either carefully tailored or in soft dressmaker styling, continues to provide a casual, down-to-earth elegance appropriate for a range of activities.

LEAD: PEOPLE WHO CLAIM THEY HAVE NEVER had a disaster while entertaining either have maids and butlers or serve sliced white bread and salmon out of a can. Otherwise, it can only be assumed that they are flirting dangerously with falsehood.

LEAD: ALASKA BASICALLY BACH FESTIVAL Anchorage, June 9-19. Serge Luca is among the guest artists in a five-concert series that is part of an educational project. Michael Palme is music director. FAIRBANKS SUMMER ARTS FESTIVAL July 26-Aug. 8. This farthest north arts festival in North America has workshops as well as concerts on the University of Alaska-Fairbanks campus.

LEAD: IF it were in, say, Toledo or Phoenix, it would be a major cultural attraction to which residents would make frequent visits. But Audubon Terrace - a magnificent assemblage at 155th Street and Broadway of a church and other structures that once housed five museums - is unknown to most New Yorkers, and now the second of its founding institutions is about to pull up stakes for another location.

LEAD: ABOUT 130 people gathered - or, by the look of it, scattered - in Alice Tully Hall Thursday evening for one of the most enjoyable string quartet concerts this listener can recall from recent seasons. The occasion was a visit by the Quartetto della Scala (four principal string players from the orchestra of La Scala, Milan), brought over by the Banco Popolare di Milano.

LEAD: At the First Presbyterian Church in Hopewell, N.J., yesterday Pamela Etter Mack, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Duncan Mack of Ringoes, N.J., and Chatham, Mass., was married to John Walker Mauer, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Alton Mauer of Pasadena, Tex. The Rev. Catherine Snyder performed the ceremony.

LEAD: In his article ''Life With Trixie'' (About Men, April 19), Ben J. Stein has articulated what those of us who love our dogs have always known. The best therapists have four legs, wet noses and eyes that see nothing but us! BARBARA P. HOWELL Family Counselor Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

LEAD: Cable's worthy film fare this week is topped by two premieres of 1986 films - Eugene Corr's ''Desert Bloom'' and Federico Fellini's ''Ginger and Fred.'' There's also a Fellini bonus of ''Variety Lights,'' ''The White Sheik'' and ''La Strada.''
LEAD: Mayor Don Fraser has fined himself a week's pay, taking responsibility for loafing by city sewer workers.

LEAD: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 9 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's on his way to the 80's. 2 1 THE HAUNTED MESA, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $18.95.) Unraveling the mystery of Indian cliff dwellers who disappeared centuries ago.

LEAD: JAN HODENFIELD remembers six years ago when a town house in Park Slope could be bought for less than $200,000 and Seventh Avenue was mostly bodegas, cobblers and neighborhood bars. Today, brownstones cost $750,000 and a Benetton clothing store opened on the avenue in October.

LEAD: SELLING HITLER, by Robert Harris. (Penguin, $4.95.) This account of the splashiest hoax of the 1980's - the ''discovery'' of 60 volumes of bogus Hitler diaries, later shown to be crude forgeries - is ''thorough and mordantly funny,'' James M. Markham said in The Book Review in 1986. But there are serious lessons amid the humor, he said.
LEAD: ANY day now, a plywood construction shell around the first floor of a Broadway apartment building at 105th Street will be torn down, revealing a new mahogany-and-marble restaurant.
LEAD: New York supporters of Gary Hart are being wooed by other Presidential contenders but for the most part, they are staying on the sidelines at least for now.
LEAD: The World Trade Club of Westchester is sponsor ing a seminar on a new system of international tariffs that will become effective Jan. 1 and change duty rates on world markets.
LEAD: BEST INTENTIONS The Education and Killing of Edmund Perry. By Robert Sam Anson. 221 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

LEAD: FOR months, members of the Newington High School Class of '87 had looked forward to graduating at the Hartford Civic Center on June 18. LEAD: ONLY six months ago, Brazil's majority party seemed proud to count President Jose Sarney among its members, using the popularity of his economic policies to score a stunning victory in crucial gubernatorial and Assembly elections.

LEAD: For exotic fruits, these are the glory days. Increasingly, shoppers who were once content with bananas and oranges are now purchasing fruits they can barely pronounce and never heard of until recently - exotics like the star-shaped carambola, the prickly lychee and the grapefruit-like pummelo.

LEAD: In 1971, a vest-pocket retreat known as Greenacre Park was carved out of the East 51st Street block between Second and Third Avenues. It has trees, a waterfall and a sculptured fountain, and it has become a neighborhood delight. But in recent years, high-rise development in the area has threatened to throw shadows over this midblock oasis.

LEAD: LAST January, Norwalk adopted a sweeping new zoning ordinance requiring developers to sell a percentage of all new condominium units at no more than $125,000. So far, six applications for such projects have been received at City Hall, while four lawsuits oppose the ordinance.

LEAD: Peter Finch's classic line shouted during his Academy Award performance in ''Network'' best captures the frustrated feelings of outer borough New Yorkers who have been living without cable television: ''We're mad as hell, and we're not going to take it any more!''

LEAD: Firefighters have halted the eastward spread of a huge forest fire that has burned in northeastern China for 10 days and has killed 160 people, the official New Chine News Agency reported today.

LEAD: Eddie Daniels is coming into the Village Vanguard with a quartet on Tuesday in an unusual glow of encomiums. He was the No. 1 clarinetist in Down Beat's readers' poll last year, and he also gained a Grammy nomination as the best jazz instrumental soloist. His reviews have called him ''the most gifted and intensely beautiful clarinetist now recording'' and declare that he is ''bringing [ the clarinet ] to a new stage in its evolution.

Lincolndale, N.Y. $310,000 Lovell Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 157-year-old clapboard farmhouse; eat-in kitchen, den, barn, horse property, 10.39 acres; taxes $5,081.
LEAD: At the New Orleans Botanical Garden yesterday Brooke Dorothy Slater was married to Mark Edwin Mouton in a ceremony performed by Rabbi David Goldstein.

LEAD: The Catholic University of America presented degrees to 614 undergraduates and 709 graduate students in commencement ceremonies at the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception in Washington yesterday. Edouard Saouma, the Director General of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, addressed the graduating class and was awarded an honorary Doctor of Science degree.

LEAD: WHEN THE NA-tional Association for the Advancement of Colored People examined racial discrimination in the music business recently, its report concentrated on offstage employment opportunities. For all the visibility and profitability of black performers, the report said, blacks are ''grossly underrepresented'' in the business itself: in record companies, concert promotion, management.

LEAD: HIS FRIEND WAS SO SHORT THAT when she was seated at Washington's Kennedy Center her feet barely reached the floor. Could he, she asked, devise some sort of stool on which to rest her feet? One day while driving to work it came to him. You can't walk into a theater with a stool under your arm. But what about a book?

LEAD: IN THE 1960's, when Americans still looked to the future with unbounded optimism, analysts such as Daniel Bell and, later on, popularizers such as Alvin Toffler, confidently predicted an imminent and historic transition from a dirty and dank industrial era to a lean, clean information age - the post-industrial economy.
LEAD: THERE are times when what is needed is the argumentative, stubborn antigambit attitude made famous by Wilhelm Steinitz, who dominated the game from 1866 to 1894.

LEAD: Three days of reportedly sharp talks between Soviet leaders and Prime Minister Jacques Chirac of France did not bridge the gap between the two countries on disarmament issues, a Soviet spokesman said today.

LEAD: Richard McConnell Clark, chairman of the Department of Theatre Arts at Ithaca College in Ithaca, N.Y., was among the 183 people killed in the crash of a LOT Polish airlines plane near Warsaw on May 9 while en route to New York, the college reported Thursday. He was 51 years old and lived in Ithaca.

LEAD: Some of the most intriguing trails in the Adirondack Mountains lead to the many crafts studios and shops nestled among the peaks and valleys. They range from rustic workshops hidden down dirt roads to the spacious new Adirondack North Country Crafts Center in Lake Placid. Besides the predictable woodcarvers and guideboat builders, you can find paper makers, clothing designers, silversmiths and potters among the artisans.

LEAD: As evidence accumulates that President Reagan was active in getting aid for the Nicaraguan rebels from foreign nations and private donors, his defenders began arguing this week that Mr. Reagan has sweeping power to disregard legislation barring such Government aid.

LEAD: THE disclosures came in bits and pieces last week, buried in the impassive, often disjointed testimony of Robert C. McFarlane, President Reagan's former national security adviser. But they added up to a new picture of the President's role in the Iran-contra affair, a picture very different from that drawn by the Tower Commission last February.

LEAD: A safety crisis is brewing in the American airline industry, many aviation experts say, citing warning signs that flight disasters could be imminent.

LEAD: FOR nearly half of the 50 years that the Ossining Choral Society has performed in the county, the man at the podium has been the pianist and conductor Vladimir Havsky. So there is a special feeling attached to his final concert as music director at 3:30 P.M. today in the Ossining High School auditorium.
LEAD: The Soviet Union today announced the successful test launching of its most powerful rocket, one capable of putting a 100-ton space shuttle into orbit.

LEAD: AFTER spending 14 acclaimed years as athletic director at North Dakota State, A. L. (Abe) Sponberg probably deserved a rest. What he got was a new job as athletic director at the University of Wisconsin. Sponberg, who replaces Elroy Hirsch, called the Wisconsin post ''the ultimate challenge.'' . .
LEAD: IN 1935, THE BRITISH NOVEL-ist and critic J. B. Priestley traveled to what was then still a relatively exotic region: Arizona.

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: I will do spring cleaning by cleaning out closets and maybe throwing out junk. I have nine closets. I wonder which has the most memorabilia.

LEAD: SUMMER'S MOST INNOVATIVE TABLE accessories are not what they seem. Tumblers look as if they are sculpted from stone, paper plates appear as marble, and ceramic dishes boast a quarry-like array of mineral patterns. Even when objects are clearly for the table, they often allude to architecture more than dining.

LEAD: SUMMER IS A SEASON FOR RELAX-ation and excitement - lazy picnics and high-style adventure. The two can be combined in a sports outing for half- a-dozen people or so. There's a sense of exhilaration in being on a raft trip or aloft in a hot-air balloon. Or in just paddling your way to a leisurely picnic on a river bank.

LEAD: I continue to be surprised that New Yorkers have never heard of the eastern part of Connecticut. LEAD: TENNIS >Wilander Wins Final: Mats Wilander of Sweden, showing why he is considered the world's top clay court player, trounced Martin Jaite of Argentina, 6-3, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday and won the Italian Open men's tennis championship at the Foro Italico in Rome. Wilander, the second-seeded player, did not drop a set during the weeklong tourney and dominated the 11th-seeded Jaite with a virtually errorless baseline game and emerged as a favorite for the French Open, beginning in a week.

LEAD: IF Janacek's ''Glagolitic Mass'' had a Latin text rather than the old Slavonic translation of the traditional liturgy, it might join the requiems of Verdi and Brahms as a staple of the great Romantic chorus-and-orchestra repertory. But it would not be itself, since Janacek's involvement in the rhythms of language was a powerful factor in his compositional life.

LEAD: An obituary of Wilbur J. Cohen yesterday misstated his college background. Mr. Cohen, former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, graduated from the University of Wisconsin, not Michigan.

LEAD: Two century-old towers - once the hub of a trolley system that sent its spokes throughout New York City -will be preserved and incorporated into a developer's plan for a shopping center in Woodside, Queens, according to an agreement announced yesterday by Borough President Claire Shulman of Queens.

LEAD: In a move intended to reduce flight delays and increase airport capacity, the Federal Aviation Administration has lifted its five-year-old freeze that prevented airports from installing more electronic guidance systems that allow pilots to land in conditions of low visibility, officials said yesterday.
LEAD: When Herman A. Schaefer retired two years ago as chief financial officer of Pepsico Inc., he planned to get involved in a few ventures and take life a little easier.

LEAD: Turn on the police scanner, Scoop, we're going to the Stanley Cup finals. You never know where violence might break out when the Philadelphia Flyers are involved.

LEAD: THE idea of a perfectly flat-surfaced color picture tube was tested, and reluctantly rejected as being far too complex, in the 1950's when color television was young. Now, using an advanced design that was originally developed for use in military avionics, Zenith has returned to ''flat technology'' with a new color monitor for computers.

LEAD: TBWA Advertising, which has never had an automotive account, has been named agency for the Acura Tri-State Dealers' Association, which is expected to bill $5.5 million.
LEAD: Wayne Gretzky, the Edmonton center, received two honors at the annual National Hockey League awards ceremony today. For the third straight year, Gretzky was named the N.H.L. Player of the Year.

LEAD: To ease the burden of high interest rates, New York City is making its first use of muncipal bond insurance. The insured bonds, with principal and interest payments guaranteed by two separate firms, are part of a $451.9 million financing announced yesterday. Proceeds of the financing will be used to refund outstanding bonds, producing budget savings of $3.7 million in the current year, $16.2 million next year and $33 million over the life of the new bonds.
LEAD: New York City health inspectors, in their second day of testing garbage aboard the barge, Mobro, said they found no evidence of hazardous or toxic material.

LEAD: PLANS for a sumptuous New York City Ballet production of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' were revealed. Mikhail Baryshnikov danced with a swarm of tiny student-performers. Mayor Koch arrived with a medallion. And the New York State Theater was filled with cheers, standing ovations and cascades of balloons and flowers.

LEAD: Aides to Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger are looking favorably on the Soviet suggestion that top defense officials from the two countries meet to discuss the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty.

LEAD: ''I intend to keep them and win the American League pennant,'' said Eddie Chiles, the majority owner of the Texas Rangers, in announcing that he would no longer accept offers to buy his team. ''It's a closed chapter.'' Chiles had been considering offers because his Western Company has been foundering from problems in the energy business.

LEAD: Robert W. Owen, a ''foot soldier'' in the secret operation to help the Nicaraguan rebels, detailed today how he and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North used the State Department's humanitarian-aid program to supply weapons to the rebels.

LEAD: Federal agents smashed through the door of a mobile home Monday to rescue two terrified adolescent models and arrest a man who the authorities believe kidnapped them and killed their chaperones.

LEAD: A 10-year-old controversy about building a million-kilowatt, pumped-storage generating plant at Prattsville in the Catskill Mountains ended today when the New York Power Authority announced it was giving up the project.

LEAD: Elizabeth Black, widow of Justice Hugo Black of the Supreme Court, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Sunday at Sibley Hospital here, her son, Fred J. DeMeritte, said Monday. She was 79 years old. She married Justice Black in 1957. His first wife had died in 1951. He died in 1971, just after retiring from the Court.
LEAD: JIM GIFFORD, the wine maker at Domaine Mumm, said Monday that he will return to the Finger Lakes region of New York in July as wine maker and president of Glenora Wine Cellars.

LEAD: A Soviet spokesman said today that a Middle East peace conference must be more than an ''umbrella'' for face-to-face negotiations between Israel and Jordan, and that the Palestine Liberation Organization should determine who would represent Palestinian interests at such a meeting.
LEAD: * Coca-Cola Bottling Co., Charlotte, N.C., said William H. Dougherty Jr. had resigned as vice chairman and chief financial officer to ''pursue outside business investments.''

LEAD: Senate Republicans are mounting an offensive to force the Reagan Administration to abandon its support for the Government of Mozambique and instead back an anti-Communist insurgent group with ties to South Africa.

LEAD: Dwight Muhammad Qawi will remain the International Boxing Federation's No. 1-ranked cruiserweight, despite a 10-round majority-decision loss in Las Vegas, Nev., last week, I.B.F. President Robert W. Lee said yesterday. Qawi, a former World Boxing Association cruiserweight and World Boxing Council light-heavyweight champion, lost to Ossie Ocasio last Friday when two judges favored Ocasio and one called the fight a draw.

LEAD: NEBRASKANS living in New York miss the sweeping prairies, lush sunsets and college linebackers who can hit, and many do not think much of the subways and the skyscrapers and - frankly - the rudeness. But the Nebraskans recently had two tons of food from home to comfort them.

LEAD: A program announced three years ago to modernize New York City's 17 vocational high schools is so far behind schedule that it is likely to produce out-of-date schools, according to a civic group that monitors the school system.

LEAD: A dispatch on Monday from South Bend, Ind., about commencement exercises at the University of Notre Dame, omitted two recipients of honorary degrees. They were Joan Kroc, philanthropist, and Carlos Chagas, president of the Pontifical Academy of Sciences.
LEAD: The stock market was battered yesterday by rumors that Citicorp would restructure its portfolio of loans to developing nations and by fears of higher interest rates.

The rest, it said, would be financed by the high-yielding securities known as ''junk bonds.

LEAD: MAGUY MARIN'S choreographically magical ''Cendrillon'' (''Cinderella'') returned to the City Center Theater yesterday afternoon. Thanks to technological magic, the production by the Lyon Opera Ballet also returned to France, for the company's reopening in New York was televised by TF1, one of the French networks.

LEAD: The Marine Midland Bank has begun charging its upstate customers a 75-cent fee for using automated teller machines at other banks. Marine Midland is a member of the New York Cash Exchange, and its customers can gain access to their accounts through the automated teller machines of dozens of banks in several states.

LEAD: The Advanced Micro Devices Corporation has disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it is seeking an award of $1 billion in monetary damages in its dispute with the Intel Corporation over the right to manufacture important new chips. Advanced Micro's filing said that it would alternately seek $100 million in damages plus the right to make the chips.

LEAD: The Senate Banking Committee today approved a bill that would significantly ease the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act by reducing a company's responsibility to police its employees on foreign bribery matters and permitting certain ''nominal'' payments to foreign government officials.
LEAD: William H. Webster, F.B.I. director, won Senate confirmation last night as the new Director of Central Intelligence. Page A15. (NYT)
LEAD: With Klaus Barbie's trial in its second week, the former Gestapo official's name has been invoked in a dispute within France's governing conservative coalition.
LEAD: Four Japanese, including an employee at a United States air base, were arrested Tuesday night and charged with passing technical documents of American military aircraft to a Soviet official.

LEAD: AS Alfred Steffen lay on an operating room table in Pittsburgh last year, his body rejected the heart that had just been transplanted. Dr. Bartley P. Griffith of Presbyterian-University Hospital gave Mr. Steffen's wife, Joy, a choice: let her husband die or permit doctors to implant an artificial heart until a second human heart could be found.
LEAD: Whether or not the Epson Worldwide Bridge Contest played Saturday set a participation record for any competitive activity will not be clear for some time to come.

LEAD: President Reagan plans to nominate H. Lawrence Garrett 3d, general counsel to the Defense Department, as Under Secretary of the Navy, the White House announced today.

LEAD: United Airlines, the nation's largest air carrier, said yesterday that it would raise fares across the nation by $15 for one-way first-class flights and by $10 for one-way unrestricted coach flights, effective June 3.

LEAD: Mayor Koch has named an educator and administrator, Luis A. Miranda, as his special adviser for Hispanic affairs. The $70,000-a-year position was previously held by John Cinque-Sacarello, who has been named to the Housing Authority. Mr. Miranda, 32 years old, of Manhattan, worked for the Board of Education until 1984, when he became a director of the National Action Council for Minorities in Engineering.

LEAD: A grand jury has indicted nine building maintenance supervisors and inspectors for the New York City Board of Education on charges that they joined in a bribe-taking conspiracy that was planned 10 years ago.

LEAD: The PTL television network is trying to bolster its image within the cable television industry by dropping PTL from its formal name and distancing itself from the troubled television ministry, network officials said today.

LEAD: The State Human Services Department violated a drug counselor's civil rights by discharging her after she used the hallucinogenic substance peyote in Indian religious ceremonies, a Federal judge has ruled.

LEAD: George Steinbrenner, the Yankee owner, testified for nearly four hours yesterday at a hearing of a players' union grievance that owners conspired to restrict the movement of free agents and hold down salaries. Donald Fehr, the union's executive director, said that Steinbrenner provided no new or substantial information during the closed session.

LEAD: ''One Challenge: Eight Visions,'' an art exhibition sponsored by the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, will open tomorrow at the society, 205 East 42d Street. Eight artists who have the disease are represented in the show, which will be up through August.

LEAD: In what a Congressional investigator has concluded may be a violation of Federal law, White House officials have been using three political appointees in positions unrelated to those they were hired to fill or to the agency that pays their salaries.

LEAD: Herbert Friedmann, an ornithologist and director emeritus of the Los Angeles County Museum of Natural History, died Thursday at Saddleback Hospital in Laguna Hills, Calif. He was 87 years old.
LEAD: An article yesterday about the new immigration law discussed implications for the employment of child-care helpers in American households.

LEAD: The AVX Corporation, a manufacturer of ceramic capacitors, is offering $75 million of 8 1/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2012 at par through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.
LEAD: A police officer raiding a crack house in Brooklyn early yesterday killed a man who confronted him wielding a knife, the police said.

LEAD: Andy Yoder, atop ladder, and a friend, John Parcher, working on the installation of Mr. Yoder's sculpture ''Motorcross,'' at Kenmare Square at Lafayette and Spring Streets. The work, made of plywood and fiberglass roofing panels, is 16 feet high and 1 foot wide. The sculpture is on view through Aug.
LEAD: Offensively the Boston Celtics' game plan never changes. It is geared to getting the ball inside to their big and talented front line of Larry Bird, Kevin McHale and Robert Parish.

LEAD: Prime Minister Timoci Bavadra being greeted by his wife, Adi Kuini, after he and his 11 Cabinet members were freed unharmed by the army. He objected to a call for new elections by the Governor General, Ratu Sir Penaia Ganilau, and said, ''I'm still Prime Minister.'' Page A6. (AP)

LEAD: Nostalgia, which usually sells briskly among people who have been deprived or robbed of something pleasurable, is up for sale again in the pages of the Official 1987 Gift Catalog of Major League Baseball.

LEAD: A new study concludes that desegregation plans have significantly improved the racial balance in public schools, but it says some of this progress has been offset by declines in white enrollment over the same period.

LEAD: When Bobby Rahal won the Indianapolis 500 last year with a record average speed of 170.72 miles an hour, he beat Kevin Cogan, the runner-up, by only 1.44 seconds. But the narrowest margin of victory was the 16 one hundredths of a second that separated Gordon Johncock and Rick Mears in 1982. LEAD: Interest rates rose moderately at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $50 million of the 91-day paper at an average rate of 7.144 percent, up from 6.9367 percent last week. Paper due in 182 days sold at an average rate of 7.282 percent, up from 7.1175 percent.
LEAD: GEORGE A. KOOPMAN likes to think of his nascent commercial space launching business not as a daring, high-technology endeavor but as the outer space version of United Parcel Service.

LEAD: Mario Firmenich, the best-known leader of the leftist guerrillas who fought the Argentine Government in the early and middle 1970's, was found guilty today in a 1974 kidnapping-murder case and sentenced to life in prison.

LEAD: At Southern Methodist University, where the football program has been suspended for the 1987 season by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for repeated recruiting violations, the sale of T-shirts that poke fun at the school's plight has been banned.

LEAD: The Koch administration has abandoned its plans to erect dormitory-style shelters for homeless individuals and will instead put up five buildings modeled on single-room-occupancy hotels, city officials said yesterday.

LEAD: IN the interval between ''Beverly Hills Cop'' and ''Beverly Hills Cop II,'' Axel Foley, the brash young police detective from Detroit, has been on at least one fishing trip with Billy Rosewood (Judge Reinhold), John Taggart (John Ashton) and Andrew Bogomil (Ronny Cox), his friends on the Beverly Hills force.

LEAD: FROM baseball fields and tennis clubs to homes and restaurants, something tall, cold and thirst-quenching could be the most sought-after food during the coming months. But what shall it be? Aside from carbonated soft drinks, there are many choices, with varying merits and demerits when thirst, nutrition and health matters are considered: iced coffee (regular or decaffeinated), iced tea (regular or herbal), fruit juice, fruit drinks, milk, beer, wine coolers, mineral water and bottled or tap water.

LEAD: RUN-D.M.C. and the Beastie Boys, the country's two most popular rap music acts, have announced a 40-city summerlong tour tentatively scheduled to begin in Honolulu on June 13 and to culminate at Madison Square Garden on Aug. 17. The ''Together Forever'' tour will be one of the few in pop music history to give top billing to black and white acts of equal stature.

LEAD: HERE is nothing like a tag sale to force you to confront the hard choices in life. To junk the class notes from Introduction to Psychology and give away the trunk that houses them; to stare with hard, unromantic eyes at the cake plate your husband's great-aunt gave you as a wedding present and tote it out to the car; to look upon a size 8 suit and accept for all time that the body it fits is no longer yours - these things mark milestones, besides providing much-needed closet space.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company increased its cash rebates on two light-truck lines and extended all of its incentives by one week, to June 15. LEAD: THE Microscopic Septet throws free-jazz tone clusters, swing-era saxophone riffs, rhythm-and-blues honking and Dixieland and be-bop colorings into a style-pulverizing blender, then adds a leavening of humor. LEAD: Jan Morris could have written a book about New York as it is today. She actually contemplated it, but the place changes swiftly, and she realized it would be out of date by the time it got to the reader. Instead, she wrote ''Manhattan '45,'' a lively social history of the core of the city as it was at the end of World War II and on the brink of a confident, prosperous golden age.

LEAD: Back in the old days of television, a playful Peeping Tom named Allen Funt ran a show called ''Candid Camera.'' He delighted in setting people up with lost wallets containing fake money, or doors that would not open, or talking mailboxes, and he let the cameras roll.

LEAD: The Senate, in the first attempt to change the new immigration law, tentatively approved legislation today that would delay the enforcement of sanctions against employers who hire illegal aliens.

LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company today introduced three new computer systems for technical users and announced shipping dates and prices for its long-awaited HP 3000 Series 930 and 950 business computers, ending months of frustration for users and Wall Street speculation. The machines all use the company's new internal architecture based on reduced instruction set computing.

LEAD: Senator Daniel K. Inouye, a Hawaii Democrat who heads the Senate commitee investigating the Iran-contra affair, has generally opposed President Reagan's efforts to provide aid to the Nicaraguan rebels. But in a procedural move this week, Mr. Inouye gave the Administration substantial help on the issue.

LEAD: An article on Wednesday about plans to preserve two century-old clock towers in Queens misidentified the president of the Sunnyside Foundation, a community planning organization. He is Frank Havlecek.

LEAD: BRYAN HUNT is a stylish and astute sculptor. His elegantly flowing bronzes, true to their material and engaged in the kind of dialogue with tradition that was unthinkable in the 60's and 70's, are hip enough to raise eyebrows and challenge some of the strictest modernist taboos. No matter how clunky and derivative individual pieces may seem, there is something in almost all of them that cannot be dismissed.
LEAD: Judy Niemack, a singer, will lead a trio tonight and tomorrow at Gregory's, 1149 First Avenue, at 63d Street (371-2220). There is a $6 cover and a two-drink minimum.

LEAD: Federal prosecutors here are preparing a case against eight self-described revolutionaries on a charge rarely seen in recent years: seditious conspiracy, which is plotting to overthrow the Government of the United States by force.

LEAD: Rutgers, the state university of New Jersey, held its 221st commencement in New Brunswick yesterday, conferring 8,900 degrees. Among those receiving honorary degrees were the author Philip Roth and Stephen Jay Gould, professor of zoology at Harvard University and curator of invertebrate paleontology at Harvard's Museum of Comparative Zoology.

LEAD: Fur designers tend to emphasize the practical aspects of their wares: they talk about the warmth of mink, the lightness of sable and the flattery of golden fox to most skin tones. Inherently, furs are so rich the designers feel no need to call attention to such obvious qualities as luxury and opulence.
LEAD: The rating on $3.5 billion of outstanding debt issued by the BCI Holdings Corporation is under review for possible upgrading, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced late Wednesday.

LEAD: President Reagan thinks that if he keeps resisting higher Federal taxes, he'll force more cuts in Federal spending. What he's really doing is forcing the Administration to cook up more budget gimmicks. The latest one is a gamble called a national lottery.

LEAD: The New York Philharmonic, conducted by Giuseppe Sinopoli, will perform works by Ravel, Berlioz and Strauss tomorrow at 8 P.M. in Avery Fisher Hall. Rosalind Plowright, a soprano, is guest soloist for Berlioz's ''Mort de Cleopatre.'' Tickets are $27.50. Information: 874-2424.

LEAD: The Cannon Group Inc., under pressure from an ongoing inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission, today reported a loss of $60.4 million for 1986 and made large downward adjustments for past quarters that cut shareholders' equity to $54.5 million as of Jan. 3, 1987.
LEAD: Tinsley H. Irvin, president of Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., a leading insurance broker, was elected yesterday to the additional post of chief executive.

LEAD: Richard Kirshenbaum, 26 years old, and Jonathan H. Bond, 29, who as freelancers were responsible for the moderately controversal print campaign that has been running for Kenneth Cole shoes, have started Kirshenbaum & Bond, with the shoemaker as their first client.

LEAD: Braathen Safe, the Norwegian Airline, which is part of the Braathens Group, said that it had ordered 31 medium-sized planes under a contract worth about $730 million. The privately owned airline ordered 25 737-500's and six Boeing 737-400's. Boeing is using Braathen as the launching customer for its new 737-500, which is a plane for short hauls and carries 124 passengers.

LEAD: A military spokesman said today that a compromise had been achieved under which the provisional military Government will be retained until new elections can be held in about five and a half months.

LEAD: MORDECAI SHEHORI demonstrated in his piano recital Wednesday at Merkin Recital Hall that he is a rarity among performers today - a distinctive player with strong, serious, compelling musical ideas and the physical capacity to realize them on stage. His playing is by no means technically flawless, and at several moments during the concert he pressed fast tempos beyond manageability or played so quietly that notes became inaudible.

LEAD: THE bright balloons and paper streamers flying outside the American Museum of Natural History Tuesday night were a tip-off. Inside the Theodore Roosevelt Rotunda, there was no doubt at all. This wasn't a conventional benefit dinner. A popcorn stand was on the left, waiters were offering miniature pizzas and the huge space was ringed with displays of exotica - electric fish, poison dart frogs, the skull of a saber-toothed cat and flesh-eating beetles working on an owl skeleton (not the most popular exhibit).

LEAD: Tow truck operators demonstrating yesterday outside City Hall. More than 250 drivers took part in the rally to show opposition to a bill, later passed unanimously by the City Council, intended to prevent tow truck drivers from racing to crash sites, sometimes causing accidents on the way. The measure would require that trucks be assigned by police dispatchers on a rotation system from a prepared list.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 How ships would defend themselves against attack would have to be reported to Congress by the Administration before the Navy vessels start escorting Kuwaiti tankers, under a bill approved in the Senate by a vote of 91 to 5. The question is why the Stark let down her guard and why, once hit, damage and casualties were so heavy.

LEAD: John H. Alexander, a longtime law partner of Mudge Rose Guthrie Alexander & Ferdon and a specialist in Federal tax law, died of a heart attack Wednesday while at a business lunch. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: A city supervisor has dropped a proposal to close what is known as ''the crookedest street in the world'' to traffic for safety, but he wants a police officer stationed there to control the flow of automobiles. City officials said a poll showed there was no strong sentiment among residents to close the street, Lombard.

He was a charter member in 1957 and was chairman from 1969 to 1972, when he was sacked for criticizing the Nixon civil rights record.

LEAD: FRANCIS BACON'S latest exhibition, at the Marlborough Gallery (40 West 57th Street), is an impressive dose of more of the same: writhing figures, often violently truncated, isolated by their own evident anxiety and by fields of solid ''abstract'' color, most often a strong orange-red. This exhibition focuses on the artist's triptychs of the 1980's - in all there are five of the large three-panel works to be seen here, through July 31.

LEAD: The human form is the subject of an exhibition that will run through October at the Storm King Art Center, Old Pleasant Hill, Mountainville, N.Y. LEAD: WHEN JACK TELNACK was growing up in Dearborn, Mich., he would often go with his friends to the Ford Motor Company test track. They would scramble up the tall, brown masonry wall around the track and watch the cars of several years into the future come roaring past.

The towers were designed for use if a high-altitude nuclear explosion crippled primary communications systems. The Air Force said the two Maine sites would have the ''least environmental impact'' of any of the dozens of sites studied.

LEAD: Neatly timed to get viewers through the normal summer drought of quality programming, ''The Jewel in the Crown'' is being revived on public television's ''Masterpiece Theater.'' The 14-part series reopens with a special two-hour episode Sunday at 9 on Channels 13 and 49. Based on the Paul Scott novels known collectively as ''The Raj Quartet,'' this British mini-series, made for Granada TV, has been justifiably showered with international awards.
LEAD: Pamela Kirkpatrick Sutherland and Philip Abram Lipman plan to marry Sept. 19, her mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. Timoleon Andreadis of Huntington, L.I., have announced.

LEAD: ALMOST 27 years after graduating from high school, Adrienne James entered college as a part-time student. She financed her education at New York University with an amalgam of loans, grants and scholarships. ''Every way that I could, I got money,'' Ms. James said. The 51-year-old New Yorker, who just received a bachelor's degree in literary studies, estimates that she paid out of pocket only a few hundred dollars of each semester's $2,000 tuition bill.
LEAD: A decade-old alleged bribery conspiracy among public school maintenance employees was further unraveled last week with the indictment of nine supervisors and inspectors.

LEAD: HE failed to meet the amateur eligibility requirements for the 1984 Winter Olympics, but Ingmar Stenmark, the Swedish skier, will be allowed to compete in next year's Games, according to a Swedish member of the International Ski Federation. Stenmark helped his chances by transferring his earnings trust fund to an account maintained by the Swedish Ski Federation.

LEAD: THIS is the time to keep pruning shears out. Shrubs that have been established for some time become too large for their spaces and should be disciplined by cutting them back. Cut back to near ground level and do not leave ugly stubs. This type of rejuvenation done promptly will invigorate shrubs and allow them sufficient time to form flowers for next spring.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''The only good thing about this summit is that it's in Venice - and Venice is sinking.'' This gloomy assessment by an official helping to prepare next month's meeting of the leaders of the seven main industrialized democracies is somewhat off the mark. Because of Italy's corrective action, Venice is no longer sinking, but because of the political paralysis of the summit leaders, the world economy is.

LEAD: As a devoted fan of many forms of auto racing I think that auto racing is a dangerous sport by nature. On occasion, as recent events in Nascar and Cart have shown, it can become too dangerous. What is necessary is to identify the safety problems that exist and take corrective action.

LEAD: ''YOU HAVE TO BE PASSION-ate,'' says Rocco Landesman, reflecting on the status of his peers, the younger generation of independent theatrical producers. ''Getting a show on is such an overwhelming task that unless you can't live without doing it, you'll never get it done.'' While today's emerging producers are as determined as any who came before them, they frequently must fight harder and more imaginatively to bring new plays to an often beleaguered commercial stage, where it can be difficult to build the foundation for an enduring career.
LEAD: Slow Motion for VCR's The video cassette recorders will be whirring away at this week's annual Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago, but VCR sales may be starting to slow, or even flatten.

LEAD: FIFTEEN rainbows, and only one keeper. Matt Charlevoix thought the fishing had been pretty bad.

LEAD: The cost of New York's long-delayed plan to clean up PCB contamination in the Hudson River by dredging its bed has risen to $40 million, up from previous estimates of $27.6 million, the State Department of Environmental Conservation said.

LEAD: Unvarnished blues, Chicago and bayou style, will rock New York clubs this week. Saturday night at 9:15 and 11:30 at the Lone Star Cafe, 61 Fifth Avenue, at 13th Street, Rockin' Dopsie and the Cajun Twisters will play zydeco - the accordion-and-washboard-powered bayou dance music that's part Cajun, part Caribbean, part blues and part rhythm-and-blues.

LEAD: Dr. Marjorie Lauren Eskay, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Eskay of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Dr. Marc Andrew Auerbach, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Auerbach of York, Pa., were married yesterday at the Mansion Club in Phoenix. Rabbi Maynard Bell performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Three employees of a Wendy's restaurant were shot to death before the restaurant opened for business this morning and were not found until another employee arrived for the lunch-time shift, the police said. Ott Cefkin, a police spokesman, said it was not known if the fast-food restaurant had been robbed or how the killer or killers had gained entry.

LEAD: Federal prosecutors dropped charges against two men in the shooting of a defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug case because a Government informant decided not to testify, people close to the case said yesterday.
