LEAD: PERSONALITIES FROM AMER-ica and Western Europe grabbed most of the press and public attention during the second and final week of the 40th Anniversary Cannes International Film Festival, but the Russians supplied more drama, and even more human interest. Elizabeth Taylor and George Hamilton, both displaying the kind of deep tans that give dermatologists nightmares, were here early in the week.

LEAD: CITICORP'S decision last week to allocate $3 billion to its loan-loss reserves raised many questions about how banks deal with problem loans and how such problems affect the banks' profits and financial stability. The following addresses some of the key points. Q. What is a loan loss reserve? A. It is money put aside by a bank when it believes that certain loans will not be repaid.

LEAD: Officials at the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear power plant triggered the plant's first nuclear reaction today. They said the plant, which is nine years behind schedule, will be tested for two months before generating electricity.

LEAD: ''THE INORDINATE APPETITE for mushrooms is considered to be a French disease,'' observed an anonymous author in the 17th century. The same statement could be made about Americans in the 20th century, who recently seem to have developed their own inordinate appetite for all kinds of wild mushrooms, partly because improved modern shipping allows cooks to use such exotic produce within hours of its being picked.

LEAD: THE International Team Trials in Memphis a week ago generated much excitement and some deja vu. The scenario closely resembled the 1985 trials in the same location, for victory went to the same team of six stars: Chip Martel of Davis, Calif., Lew Stansby, Castro Valley, Calif., Peter Pender, Forestville, Calif., Hugh Ross, Oakland, Calif., Bob Wolff and Bob Hamman, both of Dallas.

LEAD: The marriage of Patricia Laurie Bayer, a vice president in the taxable fixed income department at the First Boston Corporation in New York, to Kent George Troup, national sales manager in New York for the Temcor Corporation, took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Abba Bayer, parents of the bride, in East Hampton, L.I.

LEAD: More than midway through their 12-year project, the restorers of the Sistine Chapel frescoes seem to have dampened a debate over the use of solvents to strip away old varnish and five centuries' accumulation of soot.
LEAD: SPRING is the season for rhubarb, a vegetable that is usually used as a fruit. For that reason in Colonial days it was known as pie plant.

LEAD: The Beekman Country Club, a 27-hole public golf course in East Fishkill, N.Y., is about to develop a loyal following. Time Equities and Empire State Land Company are in contract to buy the golf course as well as adjoining tracts - 563 acres in all - for a vast residential development.

LEAD: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 10 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's on his way to the 80's. 2 2 2 THE HAUNTED MESA, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $18.95.) Unraveling the mystery of Indian cliff dwellers who vanished centuries ago.

LEAD: WHAT'S IT LIKE out today?'' ''Yucky.'' You reach for your raincoat and begin a search for your overshoes (which you used to call rubbers before that word became a euphemism for condoms), because you know that yucky means ''inclement'' (a word most often meaning ''stormy,'' based on the opposite of the Latin clemens, ''lenient, mild'').

LEAD: In a happy, sometimes boisterous celebration of the United States' chancy, uncertain origins and its present-day power and unity, the major phase of the Constitution's bicentennial got off to a rousing start Friday night and today.

LEAD: ON the green in Waterford, youngsters carded freshly sheared wool to get out the clumps, wound yarn on a wood device called a niddy noddy and tackled a variety of other tasks. Sheep waited to be sheared, a young goat frolicked under a tree and visitors came by the busload.

LEAD: Holly Jean McHale, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. McHale of Greenwich, Conn., and St. John's Island, Fla., and Jonathan Thomas Biggins, a son of Mrs. Robert A. Biggins of Wayne, Pa., and the late Mr. Biggins, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Michael in Greenwich by Msgr.
LEAD: To the Editor: Just to make sure that I never go to Casa de Campo (Letters, April 26), could you please let me know where it is? BARBARA WRIGHT Hebron, Conn.

LEAD: Pardon Mon Affaire Directed by Yves Robert. Starring Jean Rochefort, Claude Brasseur, Guy Bedos, Victor Lanoux. 1977. French with English subtitles. Embassy Home Entertainment. 105 minutes. $29.95.

LEAD: It is a quiet place, ignored on most maps, home to a few songbirds and a thousand memories. A couple of weathered signs might steer the extremely curious traveler from the middle of Guernsey, a small southeastern Wyoming community, south past the Sunrise School and just across the North Platte River.

LEAD: REPRESENTATIVE Gerry E. Studds, Democrat of Massachusetts, is mailing the United States Surgeon General's report on AIDS to each of the 268,000 households in his district and urging other members of Congress to follow suit.

LEAD: Justice John P. Collins swept motions aside, grappled with ambiguity in the law and resolved a legal dilemma over the objections of defense lawyers yesterday, all with one apparent overriding objective: moving the fraud trial of Raymond J. Donovan and his co-defendants forward.
LEAD: DODGE CITY With Errol Flynn and Olivia de Havilland. Directed by Michael Curtiz. 1939. Playhouse Video. 104 minutes. $19.98.

LEAD: THROUGHOUT the scientific establishment, inside the halls of Congress and in corporate suites across America, concern is mounting about the inadequacy of laboratory equipment and facilities in the nation's universities.

LEAD: WHEN all taxes and commuting expenses are figured in, homeownership costs about the same in New York City as it does in the suburbs, according to a new study that tested the common belief that it costs more in the city.

LEAD: MEN THINK first about how they look, then they worry about how they feel,'' says Richard Lane, a proprietor of Latham House, the Manhattan and Long Island clothier. Mr. Lane, who makes it his business to know such things, may be right in predicting that, come summer, men will opt increasingly for elegance over comfort, regardless of how high the mercury soars.

LEAD: Jean Swofford and Marc S. Firestone, associates at the Washington law firm of Arnold & Porter, were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Va., by the Rev. Nicholas T. Cooke 3d.

LEAD: Joe Niekro won the 216th game of his major league career tonight, and it might have been more special than any of the others: It put the Yankee pitcher and his 48-year-old brother Phil into the baseball record book.

LEAD: Dominick Blum has maintained from the beginning that although it was his car that struck and killed a black man fleeing a group of white youths in Howard Beach one night last December, he was only a passing motorist. Last week a Queens grand jury said it had ''failed to find sufficient evidence'' to indict him.

LEAD: Elizabeth Hette Kahn, the daughter of Judge and Mrs. Armand David Kahn of Atlanta, was married last evening to William Ashby Jump 3d, the son of Mr. Jump Jr. of San Antonio and the late Dorothy Walsh Tenney of Port Washington, L.I. Rabbi Alvin Sugarman, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Jack S. Boozer, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at The Temple in
LEAD: AFTER almost a decade as just another faceless tenant in a Manhattan office tower, Banco de Bilbao bought its own piece of Manhattan a few months ago.

LEAD: THE Sacramento Kings will have a pair of Hall of Famers on their bench next season. Willis Reed, the former all-star player and head coach, will join the Kings Tuesday as an assistant coach to Bill Russell, who last month signed on with Sacramento for seven years. Although he has no guarantee in writing in the three-year contract he signed with the Kings, it is expected that Reed will move up as the Kings' head coach in a year or two when Russell is expected to become the club's president and general manager.

LEAD: An article May 17 about Yorktown's Indian Hill incorrectly identified the Town Historian, Doris E. Auser, and an inaccurate publication date was given for Robert Bolton Jr.'s ''History of the County of Westchester,'' which was printed in 1848.

LEAD: The train's P.A. system crackled to life just after dawn. A sleepy voice mumbled, ''We're going to stop for just a minute up here to drop off someone from the sleeping car who's visiting the Izaak Walton Inn, coming up on your left.''

LEAD: ALBERTO GIACOMETTI'S lesser known works -lighting fixtures and furnishings, which he produced to earn a living just before and after World War II -were once again at center stage two weeks ago on the day after one of his bronzes brought the record price at auction of $3.63 million for a sculpture.

LEAD: ''I REMEMBER, when I was 15, in the middle of World War II, I would ride up to New Rochelle on my bike,'' said Cynthia Ozick, who grew up nearby in the northeast Bronx. ''Because of gas rationing there were very few cars. I would ride right down the middle and look at the houses behind the picket fences and smell the flowers and the blossoming trees.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL 3-15 2,3.5,q>Some C.I.A. officers have recanted previous statements and are now acknowledging to the agency's internal investigators possibly improper contacts with the contras and their private supporters, Administration officials said. 1 The Soviet Union will halt whaling as its last fleet heads home from its final hunting season in the Antarctic, Moscow announced.

LEAD: The marriage of Julie Ellen Schmerler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Schmerler of Tenafly, N.J., and Mark Goehausen Harrison, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Smith Harrison of Wilmington, Del., took place last evening at the Westbury Hotel in New York. Rabbi Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Anne Marshall Sheerin and Carl Sumner Shoup plan to marry Aug. 15, the parents of the bride-to-be, the Rev. and Mrs. Charles W. Sheerin Jr. of Albany, have announced. The future bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul S. Shoup of Charlottesville, Va.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: If these Palestinian students really want to have freedom, they should develop responsible leadership to negotiate with the Israelis in accordance with the Camp David accords. The Palestine Liberation Organization, which seems to control the activities of these students by demagoguery or by arm-twisting, wants to frustrate any chance of rapprochement.

LEAD: Because of a producer's change in plans, a picture caption on the theater page of the Arts and Leisure section today gives an incorrect title and opening date for a new musical at the American Jewish Theater of the 92d Street Y. ''The Bar Mitzvah Boy'' (formerly titled ''Song for a Saturday'') will open on June 10.

LEAD: Richard F. Kahn, one of the country's leading bridge players, died yesterday of complications resulting from Parkinson's disease and heart problems at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: LIKE millions of other tourists, they saw ''A Chorus Line,'' went to the top of the Empire State Building, toured the Metropolitan Museum of Art and ate at culinary meccas that ranged from Chinatown to John's Pizzeria in Greenwich Village.
LEAD: YOU CAN'T GET LOST IN CAPE TOWN By Zoe Wicomb. 185 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $10.95; Paper, $6.95.

LEAD: THERE are people who say it never happens to them. They are people who flirt with the truth. Or maybe they just have serious memory lapses, or are born under an extraordinarily benign star. Because it isn't possible to believe that there truly are beings, particularly New York beings, who don't have to have a lot of things done twice.

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in Locust Valley, L.I., yesterday Nancy Carpenter Lenahan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Patrick Lenahan of Locust Valley, was married to John Britton Gourley Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gourley of East Norriton, Pa. The Rev. William Guido performed the ceremony.
LEAD: ''While we may not be in a recession, the economy is not very buoyant.''
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: It seems to me that Dylan Thomas was advising not so much the manner of one's going as how to be - ungenteel - while going.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.
LEAD: Contracts between a fiscally sound New York City and its municipal unions expire June 30, and, for the first time in a long time, the unions are out for important gains.

LEAD: OEDIPUS ON ICE While some English teachers encourage exceptional students to become writers, others infuriate them into taking up writing as a revenge. Alfred Kazin describes his case in ''An Apple for My Teacher'' (Algonquin), edited by Louis D. Rubin Jr.

LEAD: A Test for Gorbachev A Russian nationalist organization has emerged in Moscow, putting Mikhail S. Gorbachev's calls for openness to something of a test. Page 10.

LEAD: TAKING CARE OF ALL the fine art piled up in this country is more than just a practical matter. It is a problem that involves the ways that Italians look at God and country, the rest of the world and themselves.

LEAD: Six hundred dusty miles out of St. Joseph, Mo., pioneers crossed a low rise on the plains of eastern Wyoming and came across a welcome sight. There in a saucer-shaped valley was a lonely outpost known as Fort Laramie, a cluster of rough-hewn buildings in a vast and forbidding wilderness.

LEAD: If it can put politics aside for a few minutes, Europe will be celebrating the 40th anniversary of the Marshall Plan on June 6, but it's not likely to remember the little band of valiant men who helped put that European recovery program together.

LEAD: PARNASSUS is a new-music group that trafficks in serious contemporary composition. Anthony Korf and his first-rate musicians define the ''uptown'' sensibility: They champion intelligently crafted, earnestly complex scores by composers who owe a direct spiritual and, often as not, academic allegiance to older modernist masters.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Avram J. Goldberg of Boston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Beth Goldberg, to Michael Winter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Winter of Malden, Mass. The couple plan to be married June 28.

LEAD: The Community Church of Douglaston, Queens, was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Jennifer Ann Hoadley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philemon Hoadley of Douglaston Manor, Queens, to Philip Shaw, a son of Margaret Shaw of Cincinnati and Stuart Shaw of London. The Rev. John Meyer performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Mozambique calls itself a ''people's republic'' but with civil war and famine threatening the lives of an estimated one-third of the country's 13 million people, the former Portuguese colony has warmed to the West in recent years. Hoping to encourage moderate political tendencies in southern Africa, Britain and the United States have sent economic aid to Mozambique's Government.

LEAD: Fordham University awarded 3,000 undergraduate and graduate degrees at yesterday's commencement exercises. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York spoke to the graduates and their families at the ceremony held on the Bronx campus.
LEAD: A ''CEMETERY'' sprang up in the middle of a Bedford Hills schoolyard last week in the first of what sponsors hope will be many such schoolyard appearances around the county.
LEAD: MORE DIE OF HEARTBREAK By Saul Bellow. 335 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

LEAD: BY ORGANIZING ''CONTEMPO-rary Japanese Art in America,'' the Japan Society has provided a valuable service. With the quality of someof the Japanese artists currently living in the United

LEAD: In a major step toward NATO consensus, Chancellor Helmut Kohl has reluctantly decided to abandon resistance to any United States-Soviet pact that would abolish short-range missiles, according to high Western officials and political figures.

LEAD: Having long enjoyed water rates that were among the lowest for major American cities, New Yorkers are about to see the first in a series of increases that by 1996 will almost triple the typical homeowner's water bill.
LEAD: THE BELLES LETTRES PAPERS By Charles Simmons. 175 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $12.95.
LEAD: Bob Ojeda underwent one hour of surgery on his left elbow yesterday, and his surgeon told the Mets that the operation had been ''a complete success.''

LEAD: AT a time when some college athletes have apparently been looking to supplement their athletic scholarships by taking money from agents and college boosters, Tracy Ham, a quarterback who led Georgia Southern to two Division I-AA championships, has decided that his scholarship was more than enough compensation for his four years of playing football.

LEAD: THE lifeguard is an endangered species. So say waterfront directors and swimming-pool operators who have been hard-pressed to fill positions in time for this Memorial Day weekend, the official opening of many beaches and pools in the area.

LEAD: Cathy Morse, who has only one victory in nearly a decade on the women's golf tour, birdied the 15th and 17th holes today for a 5-under-par 67 and a one-shot lead over Laurie Rinker after three rounds of the Mazda L.P.G.A. Championship.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: HAMMER By Armand Hammer with Neil Lyndon. Illustrated. 544 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $22.95.
LEAD: LEO DUROCHER and Ron Hunt had not snapped at each other across a diamond in 14 years, but it all came back to them quickly.
LEAD: The Detroit Pistons, trailing the Eastern Conference final series by 2-0, returned to what Isiah Thomas called ''my house'' today and trounced the Boston Celtics, 122-104.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Belfer of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rachelle Lisa Belfer, to Anthony Edward Malkin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter L. Malkin of Greenwich, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: A toll-free number has been set up for people wishing to donate money or other items to victims of the Saragosa tornado, the American Red Cross said today. The number is (800) 453-9000. People wishing information about the victims can call (512) 928-4271, the Red Cross said.
LEAD: The Soviet Union has announced that it is halting commercial whaling, and its last whaling fleet is heading home from its final season in the Antarctic.

LEAD: INCREASING numbers of high school students appear to be saying no to alcohol and drugs, at least on graduation night, according to the sponsors of Project Graduation, which provides an alcohol- and drug-free celebration for students.

LEAD: An article last Sunday about negotiations on an international conference on Middle East peace misidentified the group whose meeting the Israeli Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, was planning to attend. It was the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, not the American-Israeli Political Action Committee.
LEAD: Contempt Written and directed by Jean-Luc Godard. With Brigitte Bardot, Michelle Picolli and Jack Palance. 1963. Embassy Home Entertainment. 102 minutes. $29.95.
LEAD: An article May 10 about the Westchester Jewish Community Services Divorce Counseling Program misidentified the district supervisor at the program's Hartsdale office. She is Edythe Kurz.

LEAD: A DECADE ago, when there had been no major commercial building in New York City for four years running, when the city was losing tens of thousands of jobs a year to the suburbs and was tottering on the brink of bankruptcy, New York City, with Albany's approval, decided to launch a series of giveaways to real-estate developers in hopes of spurring them into activity.

LEAD: AT THE MARIAN GOODMAN GAL-lery, 24 West 57th Street, there can be seen through June 4 an exhibition, that is not like any other. In the big room, there are exactly two paintings, on the theme of Isis and Osiris. One measures roughly 11 feet by 18 feet. The other is a little larger. They are huge, therefore, and they are also dense and dark and, at first sight, cryptic.

LEAD: TODAY as many as 40 million people from around the world will watch, either in person or on television, a colorful display of expensively engineered metal in an orchestra of high engine notes. They will see the banging of car bodies and scraping of walls as 33 drivers maneuver their cars around the Indianapolis Motor
LEAD: NOBODY in the Philippines expected the leftist candidates to win big in their first attempt at electoral politics this month. But few people thought they would lose as badly as they did.

LEAD: Two years ago, at the height of his popularity, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi seemed to move effortlessly from triumph to triumph. But even then, skeptics noted that his leadership had yet to be tested by adversity. Today Mr. Gandhi faces such tests from many quarters.
LEAD: Chicago would like to be considered the nation's premier center for conventions and trade shows, but old Chicago problems like corrupt politicians and bad management keep getting in the way.
LEAD: I hope that prospective lifeguards will read the May 3 article ''Lifeguard Shortage Seen'' and come forward and fill the positions.

LEAD: A Federal judge in Massachusetts last week ordered a fundamentalist church to pass back the contents of its collection plate. LEAD: Elizabeth Mary Ryan and John Tylko Jr. were married yesterday at St. Agatha's Roman Catholic Church in Milton, Mass., by the Rev. Francis Turke. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Ryan of Milton and Mr. and Mrs. Tylko of Binghamton, N.Y.

LEAD: HOMER LEE is the Woody Allen of Long Island restaurateurs. Never content with past successes and winning formulas, he's always trying to create something new. His latest venture, Maison de Lee, in Woodbury, combines French and Oriental cooking.

LEAD: When members of the New York City Council voted recently to increase the salaries of other top New York City officials, they couldn't resist throwing in a hefty raise for themselves. Do they deserve it? The basic salary of a City Council member is now $47,500. But the true pay adds up to thousands more.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday on advertisments on Connecticut Transit buses to promote condoms in preventing AIDS misattributed remarks describing the bus system's initial objections to the ads.

LEAD: CLASSMATES vividly remember their first glimpse of Paul A. Bilzerian at Harvard Business School's opening session in 1975. ''Everybody was wearing jackets and ties,'' said Mark Filippell, an investment banker and former classmate. ''It was the first day and no one knew what to expect, and this guy sticks his head in five minutes late.

LEAD: COUNTRY MUSIC LEFT HOME long ago. It took its heritage -Celtic ballads and fiddle tunes, backwoods hymn-singing and square-dancing, Western swing's echoes of jazz and blues, hints of Cajun and Tex-Mex music, the twangs of down-home singers and guitarists - and moved out of the South and West, reaching listeners and performers from Canada to Great Britain to Nigeria.

LEAD: AFTER several rounds of tough sparring in a Federal courtroom in Manhattan, what would have been the first trial in the insider trading scandal was temporarily called off last week, leaving both sides to claim a measure of victory.
LEAD: In the summer of 1967, as riots erupted in city after city around the country, a group of national leaders gathered here to find ways to respond to the violence and its causes.

LEAD: MOSSY CADE, a defensive back with the Packers, was found guilty in Green Bay yesterday of two charges that he sexually assaulted a 44-year-old woman related to him by marriage. Cade was acquitted on a third count. The woman had accused Cade of assaulting her at his home in November 1985. Cade, who was allowed to remain free on bond, faces a maximum penalty of 10 years in jail on each count when he is sentenced June 29.

Public debate over the Whitney Museum's expansion plans has opened with a focus on whether razing a row of adjoining brownstones would clear the way for piecemeal dismemberment of historic districts in New York City.

LEAD: Wreckage of a house destroyed Friday in a huge explosion being loaded onto a truck yesterday as investigators tried to determine cause.

LEAD: TUCKED into a Congressional spending bill last year was a $2.28 million tree contract: a nursery in Oregon would ship up to 2.5 million cuttings of hybrid poplars to the Himalayan kingdom of Nepal, which is plagued by depleted forests.

LEAD: City Councilwoman Carol Greitzer of Manhattan has introduced a resolution condemning a state plan to cross-check computerized rent rolls against income-tax returns. The state hopes to find out whether rent regulation allows large numbers of renters to pay substantially less rent than they can afford.

LEAD: Andrea Braverman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Monte Braverman of Tenafly, N.J., and Snowmass Village, Colo., was married last evening to Lewis Stephen Gross, the son of Mrs. Irwin K. Chapman of Closter, N.J., and Maurice Gross of Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbis Maurice Davis and Jack Bemporad, assisted by Cantor Nathaniel Benjamin, performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

LEAD: ILLUSTRATING ROCKWELL A former New Rochelle resident -Norman Rockwell, illustrator of the popular Saturday Evening Post magazine covers of the 1940's and 1950's - is the subject of a musical-in-progress to be performed at 8 P.M. Friday and Saturday in Port Chester's Capitol Theater, at 149 Westchester Avenue.

LEAD: PAULA HAS BEEN A PROSTI-tute. She has stood on street corners hawking cocaine just to be able to afford it herself. She has been a vagabond, a truant and a criminal, but in her 15 years she has barely been a child .

LEAD: The Mets shook down fond memories of the old Brooklyn Dodgers in Shea Stadium yesterday in their annual reunion and salute to the past. But they had the devil's own time shaking down any fond memories of themselves from last year, which is something they have been struggling to do all season.
LEAD: YELENA, the young, bored wife of a pompous, aging and ailing professor, has a sudden, all-consuming desire to play the piano.

LEAD: To the Editor: Having just returned from two months at Fort Union National Monument (I was working for the National Park Service, through their volunteer-in-the-parks program), I was excited to see ''In New Mexico, the Other Las Vegas'' (Travel, April 12). Fort Union is near Las Vegas and, as the article suggests, is well worth a visit.
LEAD: THERE is a crisis in the educational process of our nation. This is most evident in the percentage of illiteracy in our population, which is higher than in some Third World nations.

LEAD: LIKE little children, the Giants stared at their Super Bowl rings, smiling at the dazzle of the diamonds. In the blue stone, a miniature replica of the Vince Lombardi Trophy sparkled - a three-quarter-carat diamond in the shape of the football atop the trophy, nine other diamonds forming the base of the trophy.
LEAD: A map May 10 accompanying an article about Ontario reversed the identifications of Lake Michigan and Lake Superior.
LEAD: THE FORTUNE TELLER By Marsha Norman. 387 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

LEAD: The sunken pirate ship Whydah, which left jewels the size of eggs and streaks of gold dust in the sands off Cape Cod, has been, not surprisingly, the subject of a court dispute. The winner is the man who found it.

LEAD: Philip M. Boffey's article ''Dr. Marks' Crusade'' (April 26) describes the shaking up of Sloan-Kettering in terms worthy of turn-around experts such as Lee Iacocca. However, Sloan-Kettering is a nonprofit research organization, not a Fortune 500 corporation. It relies solely on private donations and Government and privately financed grants for its survival.

LEAD: Kathleen A. Yockey and Capt. Kurt P. Wangenheim, U.S.A., were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Chapel of the Most Holy Trinity at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y. The Rev. Robert T. Drummond performed the ceremony.

LEAD: After tearfully reading ''Falling Away, Here at Home'' [ Opinion Page, April 26 ] , I wanted Julia Aldrich to know how her strength, courage and quiet words touched me and, I am sure, many other readers.

LEAD: Three mothers came to the settlement house at the public housing project on Madison Street one day last week to register their children for a chance to spend a couple of weeks away from New York City this summer and see that a world exists beyond the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

Whittier of San Clemente, and Harry Burnett Boadwee, the son of Mrs. Cecil B. Boadwee of Jackson, Miss., and the late Mr. Boadwee, were married by the Rev. James Farley. The bride, who will keep her name, and the bridegroom are graduates of Stanford University, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa.

LEAD: The economy grew at a 4.4 percent annual rate in the first quarter, better than the previous estimate of 4.3 percent, and far better than the 1.1 percent rate of the fourth quarter of 1986. But most analysts say they expect smaller increases for the rest of the year, with a final growth rate for 1987 of around 4 percent.

LEAD: CAR STEREOS ARE A NO-torious incitement to crime. In many cities, a car parked overnight at the curb is likely to have its radio removed, with incidental damage to doors and dashboard. Even broad daylight offers little protection in some neighborhoods.

LEAD: The Communist Party leadership suffered a painful setback this week when the Academy of Sciences turned down the draft of a program intended to lead Hungary out of economic crisis toward long-term economic and social development.

LEAD: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., Darcy Lynn Chappel, the daughter of Barry Hyde Chappel of Rowayton, Conn., and Mrs. Davis Stirling Margold of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Sanders Ahl, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Watkins Ahl Jr. of Rowayton. The Rev. Jenny Matheson performed the ceremony.

LEAD: ''We watch it on television at home,'' said Melvin Schottenstein, a lawyer active in civic affairs in this Middle Western city, ''but when I come downtown to work, no one mentions it. I guess everyone has already made up his or her mind.''

LEAD: JUDGING BY ITS FASHION, COLOR and ornament, as William Shakespeare might have put it, the ''Comedy of Errors'' now previewing at the Vivian Beaumont Theater would seem to be quite the merry demolition of the Bard. After all, this is the vaudeville version of ''The Comedy of Errors'' -the production that transforms Shakespeare's town of Ephesus into a circus's winter quarters, where characters polish their acts while performing their lines.

LEAD: DANCERS HAVE LONG BEEN fond of the fairy tales of Hans Christian Andersen, for many of the 19th-century Danish writer's fantastic plots seem suitable for choreographic treatment. Three were recently brought to theatrical life in Boston, when the Boston Ballet presented ''Tales of Hans Christian Andersen,'' a new full-evening work, collaboratively choreographed by Bruce Marks and Bruce Wells, that retold ''The Ice Maiden,'' ''The Steadfast Tin Soldier'' and ''The Wild Swans.
LEAD: They Race Terriers, Don't They?

LEAD: The trial of Raymond J. Donovan, the former Secretary of Labor, and seven other men had lumbered along for more than eight months with spectators and defendants appearing to doze in the sultry Bronx courtroom. The jurors even applauded a witness after he finished three weeks on the stand.

LEAD: It was 1982, and the Welbilt Electronic Die Corporation, with the help of a series of letters, telephone calls and meetings organized by White House aides, had overcome Army opposition and won a $27.7 million contract to make small engines.

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of SS. John and Paul in Larchmont, N.Y., yesterday Patricia Anne Kelleher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Breslin Kelleher of Larchmont, was married to James P. Cassidy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Cassidy of Harrison, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph Martin performed the ceremony.

LEAD: HOLLYWOOD, which has conceived so many wonderful stories over the years, is spinning another beauty about the cable television industry. According to the studios, cable is fast becoming an unrestrained monopoly, intent on gouging consumers and, yes, the companies that make films and other programming.
LEAD: Egypt has received a boost in its struggle to cope with its economic problems, in the form of a long-sought debt rescheduling by the Paris Club of Western creditor nations.

LEAD: DANCING ON CORAL. By Glenda Adams. (Viking, $16.95.) Lark Watter is an unintentionally disagreeable heroine, and that's not good news. A scheming, kvetching twit with an opinion about everything, Lark longs for life away from her native Sydney and gets her wish. After her boyfriend immigrates to the United States, she makes two friends at the university: the wealthy Donna Bird, daughter of a Columbia University art professor, and Tom Brown, a political activist.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. James P. Schadt of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauren Cardy Schadt, to Charles D. Baker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Baker of Boston and Rockport, Mass. A September wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Editor: On April 12 you featured Las Vegas, N.M. The article was packed immediately because we were leaving for Albuquerque, Santa Fe and Taos the next day.
LEAD: FOR more than a decade, Long Island's supply of office space expanded rapidly as developers sought to meet a growing demand for high-quality, relatively low-priced offices close to Manhattan.

LEAD: THE 10:40 was clattering into the East River tunnel, and I was snuggling my knees up against the next seat for the serious business of my long day, the crossword puzzle. LEAD: THE epitaph on her tombstone read: ''She never said 'no.' '' And it was true.
LEAD: One hundred forty high school seniors have been chosen 1987 Presidential Scholars, Education Secretary William J. Bennett announced this week.

LEAD: CRITICS of a Congressional proposal to prohibit the use of tin-based paints by pleasure-craft owners, but not the sale of such paints, say the ban would be virtually impossible to monitor.

LEAD: CITICORP'S decision to take a $3 billion reserve against its third world loan portfolio is in every way welcome, as a sign of rationality at our largest bank and as a signal that the private lenders are prepared to make a real contribution to clearing out the channels of the world's trading system, which have been clogged much too long with garbage debts.

LEAD: Some Central Intelligence Agency officers have recanted previous statements and are telling the agency's investigators about contacts with the contras and their private supporters that may have been improper, according to Reagan Administration officials.

LEAD: Danylo Shumuk, left, speaking with journalists at Schiphol Airport near Amsterdam yesterday before leaving for Canada, where he will live. The Ukrainian nationalist, 73 years old, was granted a Soviet exit visa last week. He has spent more than 42 years in prison and internal exile in the Soviet Union and Poland.

LEAD: MICHAEL A. LoGRANDE, the Acting Suffolk County Executive, won the overwhelming support of the Suffolk Republican organization last week for nomination to a full four-year term as County Executive.
LEAD: LOBSTER FESTIVAL IN MYSTIC The fourth annual Lobster Weekend, which opened yesterday at Mystic Seaport in Mystic, Conn., continues today and tomorrow.

LEAD: Elizabeth Brooks Naff, an assistant research analyst in the Boston office of Alex Brown & Sons, the stock brokerage, and Michael Scott Fulton, an account executive for Prudential-Bache Securities, also in Boston, were married yesterday. The Rev. George Coxe Bland Jr. performed the ceremony at the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church in Fairfield,
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: A BENCHMARK event emphasized the new realities in the Middle East last Sunday when the Israeli Foreign Minister met secretly with the Soviet Ambassador in Washington to solicit the Kremlin's thinking on the Arab-Israeli peace process.

LEAD: New concerns about growing sectarian tension in northern India were fueled this week after at least 63 people were killed and hundreds were injured or arrested in rioting between Hindus and Moslems in the capital and nearby Meerut.

LEAD: LEN CARIOU and Jo Sullivan, two veterans of the Broadway musical theater, make an appealing odd couple in their joint cabaret act, ''Center Stage: From Loesser to Sondheim,'' which is playing at Michael's Pub (211 East 55th Street) through June 6.

LEAD: HE was the favorite to win the 110-meter hurdles at the Big Ten track and field championships, but when the meet began at Iowa yesterday, Purdue's acclaimed athlete, Rod Woodson, was not among the competitors. On Friday, Woodson, a star defensive back who was a first-round draft choice of the Pittsburgh Steelers, was disqualified from the championships by the Big Ten commissioner, Wayne Duke.

LEAD: DON NELSON, who has been frequently mentioned as a candidate to become the Knicks' general manager or head coach, said he is leaving the Milwaukee Bucks after 11 years as their head coach. He cited differences with Herbert Kohl, the Bucks' owner.

LEAD: It has been called ''inclusionary zoning'' because instead of keeping low-income families out of a neighborhood it makes it easier for them to stay in. Last week the New York City Board of Estimate approved a change in the city's zoning resolution to do just that.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: To the Editor: Each season we read with interest your Caribbean roundup. We would like to take this opportunity to call your attention to the Anguilla section on April 12, and to advise that the Government of Anguilla has established its own Tourist Information Office for the United States and Ontario.
LEAD: THE REST OF THE WORLD may see Japan as a nation of workaholics, but not Juzo Itami.
LEAD: A GOOD ENOUGH PARENT A Book on Child-Rearing. By Bruno Bettelheim. 377 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.
LEAD: THE BURDEN OF CONSCIENCE French Jewish Leadership During the Holocaust. By Richard I. Cohen. Illustrated. 237 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. $27.50.

LEAD: KITTENS. The classifieds were full of advertisements for adorable, cuddly, fluffy, baby cats. As I skimmed past the columns of kittens, looking for good deals on household items, I realized the best deal was staring right at me. My daughter's birthday was just weeks away and we still had not decided on a gift.
LEAD: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, a leader of the anti-Vietnamese Cambodian resistance, has shaken the delicate balance of diplomacy in Indochina with a surprise one-year resignation.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Soviet Union's only Yiddish musical theater will embark on its first North American tour this month, performing in New York June 6, 7 and 8. The troupe will arrive in New York today and move on directly to the West Coast.

LEAD: Andrew Wyeth's ''Helga Pictures,'' which begin their two-and-a-half-year, six-stop national run today at the National Gallery of Art, are not that disturbing in themselves. LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday on an application by male legislators for membership in the Connecticut Order of Women Legislators misidentified State Representative William L. Wollenberg of Farmington. He is a Republican.

LEAD: Before the British founded their favorite summer resort of Darjeeling in the lush green Himalayan foothills in 1835, the region surrounding the town on top of a 7,000-ridge was known as the abode of Indra, the rain god - dorje ling, or the place of thunderbolts.

LEAD: SOMETIMES THE CHEMISTRY between playwright and director is so crucial that it becomes almost impossible to separate the work of one from the other. Graig Lucas and Norman Rene enjoy that kind of collaboration.
LEAD: On a sunny morning last January, Maria Azucena Ferrey was leaning against a jeep waiting for an anti-Sandinista protest march to begin.
LEAD: THE essence of chess is time, a point Bobby Fischer always used to be fond of emphasizing.

LEAD: THE PERFECT WAR: Technowar in Vietnam. By James William Gibson. (Atlantic Monthly, $24.95.) Early in this argumentative book, the author writes: ''If you are setting up an ambush, you must first pick a place where men are likely to walk. . . . You then position your mines and grenades and automatic weapons to achieve overlapping or intersecting 'fields of fire.

LEAD: Bombings by terrorist groups rose from 5 in 1985 to 15 last year, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today, while the total number of bombings nationwide was 709, killing 14 people and injuring 185.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: THE journalistic ethics involved in the articles that ended Gary Hart's bid for the Presidency may be debated for years; however, if Chad Peterman had been assigned to the story, Mr. Hart's candidacy might have been salvaged.

LEAD: Diane Alexandra Oelsner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W.James Oelsner of St. Thomas, V.I., Centre Island, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Carter Todd Peyton Jenkins, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Peyton Jenkins of Richmond and Palm Beach. The Rev. Robert Bryan and the Rev. Ralph Warren performed the ceremony at Bethesda by the Sea Episcopal Church in Palm

LEAD: A griffin - a mythical animal that is half eagle and half lion - still looks down from the facade of the Griffin, an 18-story building in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, as it has since 1931. But inside the Art Deco structure, at 101 Lafayette Avenue near South Oxford Street, kitchens are being remodeled and new tenants are arriving as the result of a co-op conversion that was declared effective this month.

LEAD: A 31-year-old Waco man, Edward Lyon Jr., has turned himself in to the police, pleaded guilty to a slaying and been sentenced to life in prison - all in one day. Negotiations with his attorney accounted for the speedy disposition of the case on Thursday, said District Attorney John Miller. Mr. Lyon admitted stabbing William Long of Texarkana to death on April 22.

LEAD: ALBERTINA BLOOM, of course, never thought of herself as a little person, although she was not very tall. Nor did the people who knew her, including her students - especially her students. To them she was a giant because of what she gave them - concern, encouragement, inspiration, love.

LEAD: LEONARD CONTARDO, a guidance counselor at Yardville Elementary School here and a New Jersey teacher for 30 years, believes that children go to school carrying ''more emotional baggage than ever before.''

LEAD: SOAP OPERA USED to lean heavily on hospital miseries. As soon as a promising young pianist entered the plot you knew a doctor would soon be giving him some bad news: ''I'm afraid you have a rare brain disease, Jeff, that completely destroys the patient's ability to carry a tune.''

LEAD: IT is unfair to compare restaurant chains with individually owned and operated eating places. But some chain restaurants are worth recommending. Typical is J. B. Winberie in Great Neck (37 Cutter Mill Road, 482-2181).
LEAD: Apparently, the idea has been around for some time, but happily I managed to avoid it until the ad appeared in the paper: surrogate staffs for surrogate bosses.

LEAD: AN AMERICAN WOMAN. By Kati Marton. (Norton, $15.95.) Anna Bator was born in Hungary. When she was 6 years old, her parents were arrested as spies. They were allowed to emigrate after their release, and Anna was raised in America. She grew into a cosmopolitan woman, became a successful television correspondent, married and had a child, but was not happy.

LEAD: AS New York City adds people and continues to reverse its population losses of the 60's and 70's, it does so at the expense of overcrowding in rental apartments, according to a study that will be made public this week by the City Planning Commission.

LEAD: WHEN he was alive and robustly effective as the senior Senator from Oklahoma, Robert Kerr used to rise heavily to his feet in the Senate chamber and declare that ''I am against all monopolies'' - slight pause - ''that I'm not a part of.'' America has never approved or allowed monopolies - except, as with utilities, under the restraint of public agencies.

LEAD: FOR the first time in more than a month, both houses of the Legislature were back at work last week, and as the two-year session heads toward its final six months many major issues targeted for action over the last year and a half are still unresolved.
LEAD: A strike by heavy-equipment operators and mechanics has halted both new construction and repairs on most highway and bridge projects in Connecticut.
LEAD: A report last Sunday on a consultation service used in child custody cases misstated its name. It is the Family Divorce Consultation Center.

LEAD: IT WAS LOUIS SULLIVAN'S SAD FATE not only to have been insufficiently appreciated in his time - he died in 1924, broke and without work - but also to have been misunderstood later on. For even when there was no doubt about his status as one of the greatest architects America has ever produced, Sullivan was too often thought of as having had one crucial flaw: he was a brilliant modern polemicist who filled his buildings with lavish ornament.

LEAD: Boxing Johnson Loses Title: Leslie Stewart of Trinidad and Tobago, the hometown favorite, knocked down Marvin Johnson, the defending champion, twice in the first round and went on to win the World Boxing Association light-heavyweight title yesterday. The scheduled 15-round fight, held in Port-of-Spain, Trinidad, was stopped after the eighth round.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: To hear her critics tell it, W. Ann Reynolds runs the 19 campuses of California State University with an iron fist inside a steel glove. Dr. Reynolds, chancellor of the 335,000-student system since 1982, was accused earlier this year of verbal brutality in her treatment of Richard Butwell, who died of a heart attack two weeks after she suggested he resign as president of the Dominguez Hills campus.
LEAD: Under rainy, funereal skies, dazed residents of this tiny West Texas town trickled back to a community that barely exists after a devastating tornado Friday night.
LEAD: In Massachusetts, anyone can help a woman give birth at home - anyone except registered nurses who have been specially trained as midwives.

LEAD: After hard bargaining last week, descendants of the early Melanesian inhabitants of Fiji came up with a deal that was intended to send the army of the Pacific island country back to the barracks. However, Lieut. Col. Sitiveni Rabuka, who led a bloodless coup on May 14, retained important authority in an interim Government led by the Governor General and nominal head of state, Ratu Sir

The Rev. H.Scott Matheney, a Presbyterian minister who is a Columbia chaplain, officiated.

LEAD: One of the Reagan Administration's wiser foreign policies supports the nominally Marxist but increasingly pragmatic Government of Mozambique. Still, some right-wing extremists would prefer backing the Mozambican insurgency financed by South Africa. The nomination of a new U.S. ambassador to Mozambique offers them an opportunity to press their case.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: There are some sections of New York in which the only way you can tell the season is by the temperature. Looking out a window provides no clue when you're looking at a rubble-strewn vacant lot. There are fewer dismal vistas these days, thanks to Operation GreenThumb, now entering its 10th year of bringing life and color to blighted neighborhoods.

LEAD: ON a recent evening at Shea Stadium, Dave Johnson sounded like a shell-shocked manager, and well he might be. The man is unaccustomed to the sort of adversity the Mets have encountered this season.

LEAD: I suppose I should admit it: I shoot more black-and-white film than I do color. This makes me a bit of a dinosaur, since 95 percent of the pictures now taken in the United States are color pictures. But despite color's universal appeal, there remain a few diehards to whom the tones of black and white are as beautiful as any colors.

LEAD: Grecian Flight, who won the Black-Eyed Susan at Pimlico just nine days ago, continued the dominance of New York-breds in major races for 3-year-old fillies by posting a 1 3/4-length upset victory over Fiesta Gal in the Acorn Stakes yesterday at Belmont.

Cummiskey of Greenwich and Guilford, Conn., and Mr. Jenkins 2d of Marblehead, Mass. The wedding is to be in

LEAD: For the space of an evening last summer I sat in an ancient part of a modern city and watched a progression of stilt-fighters, fire-eaters, jugglers, acrobats, fireworks, trumpets, drums, horses and a costumed cast of thousands. The Ommegang takes place in Brussels every year in early July. This year July 2 is the regular night for the pageant, but this time there is an extra performance.
LEAD: WHAT was originally proposed as a $14.1 million sports complex at the University of Connecticut apparently will be built for almost twice that amount, to the chagrin of many state lawmakers.

LEAD: Martin Steadman, Governor Cuomo's chief spokesman and one of his closest advisers, will leave the administration early in July. Administration officials said his replacement was expected to be Gary Fryer, who is second in command of the press office.

LEAD: Fearful of losing its allocation of low-cost Federal power, the Vermont Legislature has passed a bill that allows the Vermont Department of Public Service to buy electricity from any source and to sell that power to any customer.

LEAD: A parade of secondary figures -expediters, contributors and one beneficiary of aid to the Nicaraguan rebels - testified at last week's Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair. Highlights of the week's developments follow.

LEAD: THE old roads that wind through the tree-lined villages and small farmsteads of central New Jersey are still marked as scenic routes on some maps, but with the growth of the area in recent years, the principal view seems to consist of the bumper and brake lights of the car in front.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Summer Music listings in Arts and Leisure last Sunday misidentified a group that will perform at the Summer Evenings at Sarah Lawrence, which will take place June 11-28. It is the Bowdoin Trio.

LEAD: In those years of wealth and privilege before World War II, Lionel de Rothschild, of the banking family, spared no expense in creating his masterpiece, a rhododendron garden in Hampshire, some 100 miles southwest of London. He bought the Georgian Exbury House, the ancestral home of the Mitford sisters near Southampton, in 1919.

LEAD: ROLLING downhill in the battered blue Volvo to Port Jefferson past the harbor. . . For a minute I feel things open up - there's a flash of Monterey, Calif., in the corner of my memory; memories of last summer's vacation, the land opening out over the water. I'm quickly easing my way uphill, and the first specks of pale green spot the open sky at the hill's top - spring!

LEAD: THE continued decline of the dollar may be causing shudders on Wall Street, but in the hotels, restaurants and tourist attractions of Midtown Manhattan it is a source of joy. New York City, while seeming to be ever more expensive for its own residents, is becoming something of a bargain for foreign visitors, and they are flocking here in near-record numbers.

LEAD: William Safire's article ''The PAWs That Refresh'' (On Language, April 26), on allusion catching, does indeed remind us of one of the few delightful pastimes that is low calorie, tax free and harmless to the environment. When he wanders from citation into literary criticism, however, he spoils the fun.

LEAD: FEDERAL officials said there was no reason for alarm when the Government last week reported three cases of health care workers infected with the AIDS virus after brief exposure to the blood of infected patients. The cases, they said, underscored the need for strict adherence to infection-control procedures previously issued by the

LEAD: I LIVE in a community in northern New Jersey where it is all but impossible to buy a decent house for less than $200,000, and where rentals - when obtainable at all - command minimum prices of $1,000 a month.
LEAD: On this tiny, elbow-shaped island, isolated 30 miles out at sea, there are no stop lights, one town, and 340 licensed real estate brokers.

LEAD: A Government plan to bury a nuclear waste byproduct 30 miles southeast of here will be blocked for at least two years under a court settlement between a citizens' group and the Federal Energy Department.

LEAD: Six young Soviet Jews will be allowed to study for the rabbinate in the United States with the understanding that they will return to lead Soviet synagogues, according to the head of a delegation of Orthodox rabbis who returned last week from the Soviet Union.

The engaged couple both graduated from the Emory University School of Dentistry; she is a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, and he of Hobart College.

LEAD: THERE ARE THOSE WHO argue that the hippest radio station ever to beam music and chatter over the American airwaves operated out of a tiny studio overlooking the Pacific Ocean in this sleepy Mexican resort town, 15 miles south of the United States border.

But to a developer it is really a collection of sites crying out for development: old, low buildings, with no residential tenants, that are not landmarks - and are right in the middle of the fashionable West

LEAD: JUNE LAVELLE has been managing the Fulton-Carroll incubator since the Industrial Council of Northwest Chicago opened it in 1981. At first, the rent included a receptionist/secretary (Ms. Lavelle), meeting rooms and loading docks. Council members volunteered help when tenants had management problems.
LEAD: Blue Velvet Written and directed by David Lynch. With Kyle Maclachlan, Isabella Rossellini, Dennis Hopper, Laura Dern. 1986. Lorimar Home Video. 120 minutes. $79.95.

LEAD: THE two missiles fired by an Iraqi pilot last Sunday spread havoc far beyond the fiery destruction aboard the United States frigate Stark, where 37 crew members were killed. Also severely damaged in the attack were longstanding assumptions about the American Navy's global responsibilities and capabilities and about the Reagan Administration's military plans for the Persian Gulf region.
LEAD: BLACK AND GOLD By Anthony Sampson. 280 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $18.95.

LEAD: The risks of cancer in the nation's food supply are unknowable by most measures, but the National Academy of Sciences said last week that the Government could reduce them greatly by reorganizing its ''crazy quilt'' of laws and regulations governing pesticides.

LEAD: Only one American in four says President Reagan is telling the truth when he denies knowing that money from arms sales to Iran went to help the Nicaraguan rebels, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

LEAD: OF THE 1,583 New Jersey public schoolteachers to receive Governor Kean's teacher-recognition honor this year, more than 1,300 are members of the New Jersey Education Association, a bargaining organization with 124,000 members statewide.

LEAD: Several years ago, I informally presided over a dinner party of seven in the San Francisco area (''The Returns Are In,'' by Frank J. Prial, Wine, April 26). I did not know the wine (it had been selected by committee vote), and it was probably not far off (and after a stiff rum punch and a mild case of sunstroke, could I really tell?), but it seemed off enough to force a snap decision: ''I'm sorry, but I must ask to try another bottle of this.
LEAD: Drivers and mechanics at the Shortline Bus System approved a new contract today by a 2-to-1 ratio, ending a two-week strike that affected 10,000 riders in three states, officials said.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Massed amateur American choruses are not everyone's cup of tea, especially those used to the surer, more solid English choral tradition or, on the rare occasions when they can be encountered in this country, large professional choruses. Still, amateur choruses can make up in fervor what they lack in tonal focus, and when they are well conducted in the right repertory, the results can be pretty exciting.

LEAD: LOOKING for this spring's newest fashion fad? It's all there in black and white (occasionally blue and white). Stripes of those colors are most definitely in. The proof is on jackets, pants, blouses, sweatshirts, T-shirts, beach tops, socks, hats -garments, indeed, of every stripe.

LEAD: Lawyers for Bernhard H. Goetz began his defense last week, trying to persuade jurors that he acted in self-defense when he shot four youths with an unregistered gun in a Manhattan subway car in 1984. Before they did, however, one of the men shot by Mr. Goetz was cited for contempt of court and sentenced to six months in jail after he refused to answer some questions posed during two hours of cross-examination.

LEAD: MOST rain gutters and downspouts can be repaired when they are leaking or sagging, but if there are many leaks, or if the gutters are badly corroded, rotting or split, it is best to replace them.
LEAD: SKINNY ISLAND More Tales of Manhattan. By Louis Auchincloss. 230 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.

LEAD: The inspirational character that led the Seattle SuperSonics to this unexpected juncture of the season is still there. The tenacious defense, brilliant individual performances and admirable resiliency have not changed. Only the opponent has, but that has made all the difference.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: POWER SITS AT ANOTHER TABLE: And Other Observations on the Business of Power. By Earl Shorris. (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) It is now possible to have a power lunch alone. All one has to do is carry along this sometimes funny and frequently chilling little tome and digest its contents along with the steak tartare, or whatever it is power lunchers eat.
LEAD: To try to capture a larger portion of the leisure market, car rental companies have been reducing weekly rates in some popular vacation destinations.
LEAD: From his home in the center of this quiet farm and fishing town on Martha's Vineyard, John S. Alley can hear the Navy dropping bombs.

LEAD: I AM the son of a soldier. I was born and raised on war stories. The best were repeated time and again, until they became so familiar that my brother and I practically had them numbered and categorized, and my mother was able to correct them for certain inaccuracies or exaggerations that slipped in with the passage of time.
LEAD: A three-day meeting of Russian and American municipal officials has been been dominated by protests against Soviet policies on the emigration of Jews.

LEAD: Harvey Goldberg, a historian and political advocate, died of cancer Wednesday in Madison, Wis. He was 65 years old.

LEAD: THROUGHOUT most of the regular season, it is the southern half of the county that gets most of the concert business, but in the weeks before summer programs get under way, Tarrytown and points north are often the musical places to be.

LEAD: THE fashion arbiters have decided low-heeled shoes will be in style soon. While I've never been one to follow the seasonal whimsies of these standard-setters, this latest missive is quite exciting. And the best part of it is that I've been in the vanguard of this style for years.

LEAD: A C.P.I. LEASE CLAUSE Question: I have a small retail business in Queens. My landlord is prepared to give me a new lease for 10 years at $325 per month with a 5 percent annual increase. However, she also wants to add an inflation clause that would be based on the Consumer Price Index. I would like to renew my lease but before I do I would like to know if a C.P.I.

LEAD: Susan Chin, an architect, and Charles Edwin McKinney, the director of Riverside Park for the City Parks Department, were married yesterday at Riverside Church. The Rev. Dr. Eugene E. Laubach, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The marriage of Olwen Ebright Weatherhead, a lawyer, and David Orrick Modell, director of marketing for the Cleveland Browns football team, took place yesterday in Cleveland Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Martha Shiverick, sister of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Fairmount Presbyterian Church. She was assisted by the Rev.

LEAD: The Supreme Court held last week that a Reconstruction-era law designed to prevent and redress discrimination against blacks is not limited to them. The two unanimous decisions involved Jewish and Arab-American plaintiffs, but the Court said the law applied to any people subjected to intentional discrimination because of ''their ancestry or ethnic characteristics.
LEAD: BROADTAIL is one of the furs, like Persian lamb, enjoying a revival this season. Long considered a ''mature'' fur, it is being transformed into a youthful style by various designers.

LEAD: As barbed-wire fences rapidly seal off undeveloped properties throughout this huge city, only a few hundred wooden shacks and concrete-block houses hurriedly built on muddy hillsides still stand as testimony to the largest urban squatter movement in Brazilian history.

LEAD: Robin Lynn Smith, a producer for NBC News in Washington, and William Madden Plante, the CBS News senior White House correspondent, known as Bill Plante, were married yesterday at the Woodrow Wilson House in Washington. Judge Kenneth W. Starr of the Federal Court of Appeals in Washington performed the ceremony.

LEAD: FOR weeks the world watched a barge of unwelcome New York garbage get shunted about, a dramatic symbol of the garbage crisis facing many communities.

LEAD: In some circumstances a mile is a long way. In the 1920's, at the entrance to San Francisco Bay, in a channel of savage tidal currents, ocean waves and rushing winds, within 12 miles of a major earthquake fault, a mile seemed unbridgeably long.

LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 45 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

LEAD: California, which led the country in requiring stringent smog controls for automobiles in the 1960's, has taken another big step toward cleaning up its polluted air. In what environmentalists hope will prove the impetus for a nationwide movement, state officials said last week that they would promote the replacement of gasoline with methanol, a form of alcohol that is abundant and less polluting.

LEAD: Marchers in the sixth annual Turkish-American Day Parade yesterday in Manhattan. The parade moved down Avenue of the Americas to 47th Street and on to Dag Hammarskjold Plaza for a rally. (NYT/Fred R. Conrad)

LEAD: The Iraqi attack on the frigate Stark last Sunday night was not the first such incident, Navy officers have asserted, describing a similar but less disastrous episode in 1985 when the destroyer John Hancock appeared to have been an Iraqi target in the Persian Gulf.

LEAD: Facing the possible end of its baseball season twice within eight hours, Rider College defeated Dartmouth this afternoon and Fordham this evening to move within a game of the Northeast regional championship in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's baseball tournament.
LEAD: Two adults and a 6-year-old girl died today when an early morning fire ripped through the first floor of their two-story row house here, officials said.

LEAD: THE irony of his racing life is hardly lost on Bobby Rahal, the slender Indianapolis 500 champion who will defend his title today.
LEAD: THREE residents of Windham are gaining prominence as leaders of the largest veterans' groups in the state.
LEAD: At a time when hospitals in the Boston area urgently need more nurses, Boston University has announced that its School of Nursing is likely to close next fall because of a shortage of students.

LEAD: Floyd Bannister retired the first 17 batters en route to a two-hitter, ending a personal 11-game losing streak against Boston as the Chicago White Sox scored a 9-1 victory over the Red Sox today.
LEAD: For the first time, a big American bank has acknowledged what many people thought was obvious: that some developing countries are not going to pay back all the money they owe.

LEAD: In the conventional view of early human development, evolution occurred steadily and gradually over millions of years. But the discovery last summer of a skeleton in the Olduvai Gorge of Tanzania has raised speculation that an abrupt speed-up in human evolution took place about 1.6 million years ago.

LEAD: In her article ''The Palestinian Campus'' (April 19), Lisa Wolfe comments several times on the ''basic academic freedoms'' that the Israeli Government bestows on Bir Zeit University. An incident on April 13 gives an example of the privileged existence that Bir Zeit students enjoy. Students were marching in protest of the killing of a boy in Ramallah when Israeli soldiers arrived to stop the march.

LEAD: The Federal Election Commission says Representative Jack F. Kemp, Republican of upstate New York, will receive Federal matching funds for his 1988 Presidential race. Matching funds are disbursed to candidates in the primaries who agree to abide by Federal spending limits for each state and who raise $100,000 in 20 states in contributions of $250 or less.

LEAD: The Week in Business last week misstated the month in which producer prices rose seven-tenths of 1 percent. It was April. If April's figure holds for 12 months, producer prices will rise at an annual compound rate of 8.9 percent.

LEAD: Ever heard of digital audio tape recordings? Most people haven't, and never will if the recorded music industry has its way. Music makers acknowledge the spectacular potential of this new technology, but argue that its unconstrained use poses a ''unique threat'' to their industry. They want Congress to require manufacturers to add a computer chip that would prevent owners of digital recorders from copying compact disc recordings.

LEAD: Joan Carol Hoffman, a senior graphics designer at Fortune magazine in New York, and Christopher Ellis Green, a photograph editor and researcher at Fortune, were married at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park yesterday. Acting Justice Richard L. Price of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

LEAD: A Superior Court judge is expected to rule soon on whether the University of California must arrange a way for small-scale farmers to benefit from university research that is supported by public funds.

LEAD: SINCExh the Challenger exploded in January 1986, killing its crew of seven, the nation's space program has been pervaded with an air of pessimism and gloom. But there are still those who dream of colonizing the Moon and Mars and mining the riches of the asteroids.

LEAD: Claire Porter and Lisa Kraus, two choreographers who can make incisive comments on the world around them, are both presenting works this week. Unfortunately, audiences at staged productions all too rarely have the opportunity to test the validity of that maxim. For good theatrical reasons, they must be kept literally in the dark.

You will find some of the finest Italian food in the entire state as well as most of New England at Pasta

LEAD: William W. Turnbull, who was president of the Educational Testing Service in a period of ferment over its role and influence, died of heart failure Thursday during heart bypass surgery at Presbyterian Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 67 years old and was a resident of Princeton, N.J.

LEAD: New York City's moratorium on the demolition or alteration of single-room occupancy buildings is meant to preserve inexpensive housing. Owners of long-vacant large S.R.O.'s can get exemptions, but only if they file applications with the city by Friday.

LEAD: Nancy Reagan told the graduating class of the Georgetown University School of Medicine today that there is no excuse for drug abuse in the medical profession. She asked the new physicians to watch for drug problems among their patients and their colleagues.

LEAD: Connecticut College, in New London, held its 69th commencement yesterday, conferring 468 degrees. The commencement speaker, Marion Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, discussed national priorities in providing for children.

LEAD: Perspective was always a problem for me in art classes. Sometimes I would capture it successfully, but just as often there would be a false, unsatisfying depth to a drawing or a painting that would leave me keenly frustrated. I would shrug my shoulders and mumble something about the Egyptians and Picasso having had the same problem.

LEAD: SIMONE DE BEAUVOIR: A Life . . . a Love Story. By Claude Francis and Fernande Gontier. Translated by Lisa Nesselson. (St. Martin's, $18.95.) This is a lucid, appealingly human account of the life of the French feminist and lover of Jean-Paul Sartre. The authors, Claude Francis and Fernande Gontier, who have written critical works on Simone de Beauvoir, Proust and others, found their point of departure in the more than 1,400 pages of love letters from de Beauvoir to the Chicago writer Nelson Algren.

LEAD: WE were married in October and the first ''Happy Hanukkah'' card arrived in mid-December. I can still remember opening the envelope and staring at the card for quite some time. So many thoughts crossed my mind. ''They're trying to convert me,'' I remember thinking. ''They'll never accept me. . . .what the heck is Hanukkah, anyway?

Conant of Weston, Mass., were married by the Rev.

LEAD: My first day in Cairo I was offered 10,000 camels, 2 donkeys, a horse and 20 shekels to marry a rather charming Egyptian named Sharif. Actually, the two women I was traveling with were offered the booty as they were the only ''family'' Sharif could find to bargain with. He read my palm - ''Let me see your hand, no, no, the clean one'' - in an alley cafe, four chipped Formica tables tilted toward the drain.
LEAD: ''Those are the pro-Goetz people over there - we're anti-Goetz,'' a man explained to passers-by as he distributed fliers for a lunchtime rally in lower Manhattan last week.
LEAD: AGRICULTURE has always been a big deal in Arkansas.

LEAD: EIGHTY YEARS AGO, THIS PENNSYLVA-nia rose garden was planted as a laboratory by Edwin Rosenbluth, a Philadelphia chemist who became well-known as a manufacturer of garden spray. It has matured and changed over the years, and the present owners, Dr. Joseph Kassab, a retired surgeon, and his wife, Betty, have been conducting experiments of their own.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: SCOTT MILLER proudly displayed his company's new headquarters on 60th Street just off Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, and the contrast with days past could not have been more striking. Where once the Sawyer/Miller Group Inc.'s 30 employees had toiled in cramped, windowless rooms, the new offices - replete with sleek black furniture and fresh maroon carpeting -abound with light, space and air.

LEAD: TOMORROW is the first anniversary of the death of Chester Bowles. He is remembered fondly in Connecticut, in Essex where the family lived and in Hartford where he served briefly as Governor and throughout the state for the achievements of his diplomatic career.

LEAD: THE Palestine Liberation Organization, now reunited under Yasir Arafat, is pressing for an Arab summit meeting to discuss strategy toward a proposed international conference on the Arab-Israeli conflict.
LEAD: The marriage of Kathryn A. Frazer and B. V. Brooks took place last evening at the Albertson Memorial Spiritualist Church in Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Melvin O. Smith performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The past impresses itself on every visitor to Rome, just as the sky-scraping present spellbinds a visitor to Manhattan. Artists have come to Italy in a constant stream to paint and sketch the ancient ruins and monuments of the capital, while engravers have reproduced these images to create fine period prints.

LEAD: ROCK-AND-ROLL IS MORE than 30 years old, and its roots reach back further than that. It's a tradition now, not just rude teen-aged rebellion. But with its deliberate formal limitations - rock is simple, danceable, hummable music - there is a crisis of originality in rock. What is original may not be rock any more; what is stereotypically rock may seem boring.
LEAD: AN empty nest on Memorial Day! With four participating children in our family, we've stood at attention for a lot of village parades.
LEAD: THE man at the wheel of the pace car in today's race at Indianapolis has had, if you'll excuse the expression, a checkered career.

LEAD: WHEN the city of Chicago and eight equity partners teamed up in March 1986 to open a business incubator called Enterprise Place, the building was filled within a month. Today, with tenants ranging from a gospel music recording company to a distributor of wild mushrooms, the operation is one of the country's oldest mixed incubators.
LEAD: Jerry Mumphrey's double into the left-field corner scored Ryne Sandberg from first base in the 16th inning today, giving the Chicago Cubs a 7-6 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

LEAD: Avon, Conn. $255,000 61 Harris Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 36-year-old brick colonial; crown moldings, 1.5 acres; taxes $2,335. Bristol, Conn. $82,000 186 Stevens Street 2-bedroom, 1 bath, older ranch; close to shopping, 0.75 acre; taxes $1,098.

LEAD: Martha Ann Deane and Christopher Forest Benton were married yesterday in a Quaker ceremony performed by the Rev. Daniel Whitley at the home of the bride's maternal grandfather, Howell Taylor, in Chester, N.Y. The bride, who is known as Marcy, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Deane of Roslyn, L.I.

LEAD: The jury ended its first week of deliberations Friday in the manslaughter trial stemming from Hollywood's worst movie set disaster. On Tuesday the jurors will continue hearing a stenographer read back testimony from eight months ago. John Landis, director of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie,'' and four associates are charged in the 1982 deaths of the actor Vic Morrow and two children when a helicopter crashed on them amid special effects explosions.
LEAD: WHILE London may be the source of Broadway's biggest hit musicals, it is Connecticut that has supplied the New York theater season's most acclaimed dramatic offerings - new and old.

LEAD: Lt. Col. Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho, who was lionized as the hero of Portugal's 1974 revolution, now faces imprisonment as a terrorist. Colonel Saraiva de Carvalho, a two-time presidential candidate, was convicted last week of leading a left-wing terrorist group linked to dozens of bombings and bank robberies and the deaths of 13 people.

LEAD: WHEN the University of California surveyed high school students about their interest in agriculture school, it did not like what it heard. The students described agriculture as a blue-collar occupation, tedious and insecure. ''All you hear about are people going broke,'' one commented. ''That's not the kind of future I want.
LEAD: GRADUATION time - the grand finale of the school year. It's a heady time, a strong brew of final exams, proms, plans, and pomp and circumstance.

What is vital for a leader is the ability to be flexible, accept suggestions, acknowledge errors and change procedures when necessary to accomplish a goal.

Actually, none of this takes a great leap of imagination.

LEAD: If you drew the short straw and are in charge of the family-reunion arrangements, I sure hope it's for the 1988 season. Your leverage for this year is pretty much used up. And depending upon the site you've chosen, you may be barely in time for '88.

LEAD: WHEN WAS the last time you bought and drank one of the great names of wine, a Chateau Mouton-Rothschild, say, or a Chateau Latour, or a Romanee-Conti? Newcomers to wine may find it hard to believe, but 20 years ago these were readily accessible to anyone prepared to spend a dollar or two more than usual for a bottle.

LEAD: AN auction of manuscripts and United States postal history will be held on Saturday at the Hilton Hotel in Danbury, Conn. Richard C. Frajola, Inc. will stage the auction which features an outstanding selection of stampless covers, an important collection of Minnesota Territory usages and selected rarities bearing the 1847 and 1851 issues.

LEAD: I WAS sitting down to breakfast and the newspaper one Sunday morning when the telephone rang. The voice on the line was a voice from the past. My high school girlfriend was up from Pennsylvania, visiting her parents in Rockville Centre, and she wanted to know if I had time to get together.

LEAD: TWAIN'S SOUVENIRS When Mark Twain and his Hartford neighbor, Harriet Beecher Stowe, traveled abroad, they bought the tourist souvenirs now on exhibit in the basement gallery of the Twain House at 77 Forest Avenue. The exhibition is a collection of some 40 items picked up around the world by Twains and his family, the Stowes and their relatives, the Beechers and the Days, all of whom inhabited Nook Farm, as the compound was called, and by Charles Dudley Warner, Twain's collaborator on the writing of ''The Gilded Age.

So much, in fact, that all five starters have been inducted into the Holy Cross College Athletic Hall of Fame, as has the coach, Al (Doggie) Julian, who received an honorary induction last year.

LEAD: The playwright John Guare and Adele Chatfield-Taylor, director of the design-arts program of the National Endowment for the Arts, who are husband and wife, addressed those attending the 123d commencement of Vassar College yesterday in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. Some 570 graduates received degrees in a colorful ceremony that included the faculty in full academic regalia and the traditional 150-foot Daisy Chain, a century-old Vassar tradition.

LEAD: This place in the Cyclades has palms and flat-roofed villas painted glaring white and 360 small white churches, some domed in primary colors. It has white windmills by a deep blue sea and a whiteish pelican called Petros as a mascot.

LEAD: Jack Clark's second-inning grand slam knocked out Mike Scott and led the St. Louis Cardinals to an 8-2 victory over the Houston Astros today.

LEAD: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou said tonight that he would call a referendum on the future of the United States military bases in Greece before his term of office ends in 1989.
