LEAD: The marriage of Polly Jacquelin Hoppin, a candidate for a doctorate in environmental and occupational health policy at the Johns Hopkins University School of Public Health, to Robert Mason Thomas Jr., an associate at the law firm of Covington & Burling in Washington, took place yesterday in Sherborn, Mass.

LEAD: Penelope Farrington Stone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Boething Stone of New York and Darien, Conn., and Steven Jeffrey Campbell, a son of James Mulford Campbell of Yellow Springs, Ohio, and Mrs. Robin Crane Wing of Readfield, Me., were married yesterday. The Rev. Susan J. Ingham, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the summit of Cadillac Mountain in Acadia National Park on Mount Desert Island in Maine.

LEAD: Leo Castelli outlasted Gone West to win the Peter Pan Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday, a race that earned the top two finishers a trip to the Belmont Stakes and made Gone West look especially impressive in defeat.

LEAD: Just as some Handel oratorios fairly burst with concealed operatic tendencies, Benjamin Britten's ''Rape of Lucretia'' resembles an oratorio dressed up for the stage. The Brooklyn College Conservatory of Music offered a student production of the Britten chamber opera at the school on Saturday afternoon - in a performance that, despite the unresolved musical problems, reinforced the work's creative ambivalence.

LEAD: Managers of New York's 13-month-old Javits Convention Center deserve credit for responding swiftly to disclosures of payroll discrepancies involving electricians who work on exhibits at the center.
LEAD: Dr. Hans H. Neumann, a public health physician and writer, died Saturday at Norwalk Hospital in Connecticut after suffering a heart attack at his home in Wilton. He was 75 years old.

LEAD: Coming Up Short It's not that Carl Larsen is an especially impatient sort, but as the executive director of the Kentucky Harness Racing Commission, he's come to the conclusion that many of the sport's fans and potential fans are. They would enjoy harness racing more, he figures, and more of them would come to the track, if the races didn't take so darned long - as much as two minutes for the average trotter or pacer to cover a mile, the standardbred distance standard.

LEAD: New York City's biggest handicap in attracting or keeping electricity-hungry businesses is the ruinously high cost of power, compared with that above the city line or across state borders. Higher taxes explain some of the discrepancy. New York takes 22 cents of every Con Edison dollar. New Jersey utilities pay only 14 cents.

LEAD: ''You got to do what's honest and right and what the rules say. I told my team that people forget the scores of basketball games; they don't ever forget what you're made of.'' -Cleveland Stroud, coach at Rockdale County High School in Georgia. [ 1:3. ]

LEAD: When industry supplicants go to Albany to beg for legislative handouts, they generally tell such heart-rending economic sob stories that the lawmakers have to get out their handkerchiefs to wipe away the tears. When a delegation representing the state's thoroughbred breeders made such a trip a few weeks ago, it was the breeders who had to pull out their bandanas - to wipe the smiles off their faces.

LEAD: Until it was acquired by Charles H. Keating Jr. early in 1984, the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., was a quiet little institution suffering like many others through a downturn in the traditional business of home lending.

LEAD: The Central Intelligence Agency has been beset with anxieties that William H. Webster, recently confirmed as Director of Central Intelligence, will be bringing with him hordes of officials from the Federal Bureau of Investigation to run the agency. Mr. Webster was director of the F.B.I., and the two agencies have different cultures and on occasion have had sharp disagreements.
LEAD: Commencement ceremonies were held in two parts yesterday at the State University of New York at Binghamton.
LEAD: The nation's new immigration law is placing added burdens on business people in the New York City region.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo addressed 4,000 graduates of the University of Massachusetts today, and aside from a few choruses of ''Run! Run!'' that went up from one section of the audience, the tenor of the event suggested that he had convinced the public that he was not seeking the Democratic nomination for President.

LEAD: The former chancellor of the State University of New York accused Secretary of Education William J. Bennett yesterday of a ''cynical'' and ''disingenuous'' approach to public policy affecting American higher education.

LEAD: A panel appointed by Mayor Koch has drafted a broad, five-year plan to combat the AIDS epidemic by expanding care for the sick, promoting research and seeking to prevent the spread of the deadly disease.

At a big after-hours event here Saturday night, more than 1,000 booksellers and publishing-industry employees celebrated until the early hours at a party tied to a forthcoming book about Elvis

LEAD: ABC will present ''Cracked Up,'' a drama about a teen-age track star's addiction to crack, a potent form of cocaine, Tuesday night at 9. One of the most surprising aspects of the film is that it was produced by Aaron Spelling, who is best known as a purveyor of glamorous escapism.
LEAD: After a relatively quiet decade, Richie Moran is back at the lectern, commanding attention.
LEAD: The Federal Election Commission, established as a watchdog over the election process after the Watergate scandal of the 1970's, has evolved into an agency widely viewed as ineffectual.
LEAD: Morgan Freeman just can't seem to be bad.

LEAD: Members of the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair say they want to recall Richard V. Secord, a retired Air Force officer who became an arms dealer, to clear up discrepancies between his version of events and those of later witnesses.

LEAD: At the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., Cindy Louis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Louis of North Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Ronald A. Freydberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph M. Freydberg of Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Morris Friedman performed the ceremony. The bride is a graduate of Syracuse University.

LEAD: Lou Piniella, the Yankee manager, held a closed-door meeting with his players before today's game to discuss a possible theft in the clubhouse Saturday and a string of apparent thefts dating to spring training.
LEAD: For 15 students who graduated yesterday from the College of New Rochelle's lower Manhattan campus, there will be no panicking over job interviews or last-minute writing of resumes.

LEAD: Hoping to use their home ice to advantage and tie their Stanley Cup series with Edmonton at two games apiece, the Flyers instead fell prey to the Oilers' exuberant offense and were defeated, 4-1, in a testily played game at the Spectrum tonight.
LEAD: With about half of its members destined to be a freshman class, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission is likely to take on a new tone in coming months.

King of Parsippany, N.J., took place yesterday at the Stronghold Mansion in Bernardsville, N.J. Rabbi Stephen Listfield, assisted by Cantor Kurt Silberman, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The nuances that make for the success or failure of a team are often rooted in actions that have little to do with conditioning, practice, or even skill. And they do not always occur between the time the athletes report for training camp and the end of their season. Sometimes, a reassuring conversation between two teammates during the off season can make the difference between months of conflict or months of contentment.

LEAD: Works by Bach, Mozart, Brahms, Samuel Barber and Carlos Chavez are to open this year's Waterloo Festival in Waterloo Village, N.J., the weekend of June 19-21. For the first time in its 12 seasons, the festival will offer adjunct concerts at Richardson Hall at Princeton University.

LEAD: The Emir of Kuwait, which is seeking both United States and Soviet protection for its oil tankers, has said the growing Gulf War threat to shipping should be a matter of ''international concern.''
LEAD: The chief of Syrian military intelligence in Lebanon denied today that he said Moslem kidnappers had sold a French hostage to Libya, Beirut radio stations reported.

LEAD: Television has been doing exceptionally well by stage plays recently. There have been first-rate adaptations of Hugh Whitemore's ''Pack of Lies'' and Simon Gray's ''Quartermaine's Terms.'' Now, at 9 o'clock tonight on Channel 13, there is John Guare's ''House of Blue Leaves'' in the Lincoln Center Theater production that won several Tony Awards last year and moved to Broadway.

LEAD: Timoci Bavadra, who was deposed as Prime Minister in a coup 10 days ago, refused today to work with an interim Government backed by the military.

Snow, in Darien, Conn.
LEAD: THE malpractice crisis swirling about the legal profession will not soon subside, according to lawyers and insurance experts.

LEAD: Under a row of sycamore trees just across the river from the Palace of Justice here, Yves Girerd, 55 years old, tended a market stand where he sells chickens and ducks every day and gave a somewhat ambivalent and skeptical view of the trial of Klaus Barbie, the wartime head of the Gestapo in this city.
LEAD: About 7 in 10 young adults paroled from prison were arrested again at least once for serious crimes within six years, the Department of Justice said today.

Goldburg and Cantor Ellen S. Math officiating.

LEAD: Ellen Frankfort, the feminist author, died early yesterday at Long Island's Southampton Hospital. She was 50 years old and lived in Sag Harbor, L.I.

LEAD: Jane Geddes, winner of the 1986 United States Women's Open championship only 40 miles from here at Dayton's NCR Club, gained her second major tournament victory today when she birdied the 16th and 17th holes to win the Mazda L.P.G.A. Championship by a shot over Betsy King.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A Polish citizen jumped from a Canadian tour boat Saturday into the roiling waters just below Niagara Falls, swam to the United States side of the river and apparently asked for asylum.
LEAD: Chi Chi Rodriguez shot a three-under-par 69 and held off a challenge by Bruce Crampton for a three-shot victory today in the $250,000 Silver Pages Classic.

LEAD: The ardor of the wealthy people who gave money for a plane and military supplies to the White House contra cause is a reflection of the broader attempt by hard-liners to take foreign policy out of functioning international relations.

LEAD: EVENTS - like his fastball -are moving at a fast pace, sometimes faster than Willie Banks would prefer. The recent past, the times he would spend playing stickball in the neighborhood schoolyard, seems like an eternity ago, among the few carefree moments in a difficult childhood. Then, Banks pretended to be Reggie Jackson, hitting sponge balls over the schoolyard fence that he and his brothers would have to scale in order to get in.

LEAD: Marlene Fay Sable, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Sable of West Roxbury, Mass., was married last evening to Merrick Lloyd Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Cohen of Englewood, N.J. Rabbi Marc Cooper performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Natick, Mass.

LEAD: The seven-nation industrial summit conference that President Reagan will attend next month in Venice is likely to prove unusually modest in its achievements despite the long agenda of issues, analysts and officials report.

LEAD: Former Gov. Pierre S. du Pont 4th of Delaware is by far the wealthiest of the Presidential contenders, according to financial disclosure documents. He leads the Republican candidates with assets in excess of $6.3 million and probably greater than twice that much.
LEAD: Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, sought the other night to deliver a funny response to a glowing introduction, but not many people laughed.

LEAD: Michele MacDonald was married yesterday to Thomas A. Witkin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Witkin of Harrison, N.Y., at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. MacDonald, in New Milford, Conn. The Rev. A.Russell Ayre, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Several weeks ago, in preparation for the public hearings on the Iran-contra affair, lawyers for the Congressional committees spent a full day taking a sworn deposition from Adolfo Calero, the contra leader.

LEAD: Confident that the financial and other problems that rocked it in the 1970's and early 1980's have been solved, Yale University's new president, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., has begun laying out priorities for what he calls a ''new era in Yale's history.''

LEAD: If you don't especially like the sound of an Irish tenor - clear, reedy, sweet, penetrating and somewhat nasal - you surely wouldn't have liked Frank Patterson's recital Friday night in Carnegie Hall, because all the traditional characteristics are quite marked in his singing. If, like this listener, you have an affection for the style and the songs that go with it, a visit to his next local appearance is warmly recommended.

LEAD: Nana Kwabena Oppong, a former cabdriver from the Bronx and the new king of the Ashanti people in the United States, at a weekend festival at the Roosevelt Hotel attended by more than 500 Ghanaians. Page 23. (NYT/Peter Freed)

LEAD: New orders for American-made machine tools fell 20.9 percent in April from their March level, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association said in a report to be released today. The association reported that orders declined 32.8 percent from April 1986.
LEAD: One arrived late. Another sent a stand-in. Seven, including the men from New York and New Jersey, who pleaded other commitments, were not represented at all.
LEAD: The tired Boston Celtics were solidly trounced today, 145-119, by the younger and quicker Detroit Pistons.

LEAD: Susan Shapiro, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Theodore Shapiro of Manhattan, and Daniel Berman, a son of Arthur Berman of Haworth, N.J., and the late Mildred Berman, were married last evening at the St. Regis-Sheraton in New York by Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg.

LEAD: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the Arab countries of the Persian Gulf should provide bases and other support for aircraft that would patrol the waterway, protecting oil tankers and their naval escorts.
LEAD: Somehow, the inferiority complex common to Northeastern teams in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's baseball tournament had seemed to vanish from the Fordham dugout.
LEAD: BY now the story of what Cus D'Amato wrought with Mike Tyson is boxing lore.

LEAD: James J. Delaney, the former Queens Congressman whose three decades in Washington catapulted him into the chairmanship of the powerful House Rules Committee, died yesterday at his son's home in Tenafly, N.J. He was 86 years old and had been a resident of Key Biscayne, Fla., since his retirement in 1978.

LEAD: New York City is in the midst of a drive to regulate gypsy cabs and other nonmedallion vehicles, an effort officials say will enhance the industry's image and could make it easier to find a taxi - although not necessarily a yellow one.

LEAD: Seven honorary degrees were awarded yesterday at the commencement of Mount Holyoke College in South Hadley, Mass. Among those receiving honorary degrees were: Maya Angelou, the poet, playwright, composer and performer; the commencement speaker, Dolores Hayden, a professor in the urban planning program of the Graduate School of Architecture and Urban Planning at the University of California at Los Angeles, and David Baltimore, the director of the Whitehead Institute for

LEAD: YOU will have heard - if you bother to listen - anglers prating about how catching fish is really less important than the quest itself, than feeling the wind in their hair or listening to a lovely stream's sweet song.

LEAD: Summer is upon us, and post-Memorial Day thoughts are turning to vacations, tennis, the beach, swimming pools and the inevitable stock market rally. The inevitable stock market rally? Laszlo Birinyi, the statistical guru at Salomon Brothers, says that there is always a summer rally. He also says the ''rally'' has the same relevance to real life as current airline schedules.

LEAD: Every diplomatic effort has its logic, and the next logical step in the process of trying to arrange an international peace conference on the Middle East may be taken when American and Soviet officials sit down for a periodic review of Middle East issues.
LEAD: Al Unser Sr., a man without a car for the Indianapolis 500 until 11 days ago, today became the oldest driver to win America's greatest automobile race.

LEAD: Citicorp's startling decision to write off $3 billion in third world loans has angered competitors with shallower pockets. LEAD: Suppose you want to talk to Lyn Nofziger, the former White House aide under investigation for allegedly using his influence to obtain Federal contracts for the Wedtech Corporation, a New York manufacturer. Mr. Nofziger, who left the Government's employ in 1982, has an unlisted number. But it was discovered last week that he can still be reached through the White House switchboard, which will take and forward calls for him.

LEAD: Mikhail Baryshnikov's 1978 staging of ''Don Quixote'' returned to American Ballet Theater this weekend at the Metropolitan Opera House. If the major debuts in the season's first two performances are an indication of how spiritedly the ballet will be performed in the future, then new life has obviously been breathed into a so-called old warhorse.

LEAD: Perhaps no span of time before our own was so subject to wild musical mood swings as the 18th century. Gwendolyn Toth - playing the organ, harpsichord and fortepiano - demonstrated this confusion of riches with four keyboard concertos at St. Michael's Church on Wednesday evening. Miss Toth was joined by the Artek

LEAD: New York City fields the nation's largest police department and ought to have the nation's best police training facility. Yet through recent massive rehiring, it has struggled along with a cramped, outmoded facility in Gramercy Park. Now a sound plan for a new facility is imperiled because Gramercy Park residents press to keep the Police Academy in their neighborhood.

LEAD: It isn't everybody who can sing ''We Are the World'' and do a reasonable approximation of all the voices - male, female, country, soul, rock and pop - on the record. But that is one of the skills of Muralidhar, a singer, keyboardist, composer and mimic, who entertains Wednesday through Friday evenings at Terranova, 18 West 38th Street, from 6:15 to 9:15 P.M.

LEAD: President Reagan's recent assertions that a Congressional ban on aid to the Nicaragua rebels in 1985 did not apply to his National Security Council or national security adviser directly contradict detailed statements to Congress in 1985 on how the Administration was complying with the law.
LEAD: THE ECONOMY

LEAD: Crowds on an approach to the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco yesterday as the bridge was opened to pedestrians on its 50th anniversary. An estimated 250,000 people jammed onto the bridge, spilling onto the San Francisco end about 45 minutes early, forcing a cancellation of the opening ceremonies.
LEAD: A major realignment of class power is taking place in the Soviet Union.

LEAD: Created in 1976 in response to this country's Bicentennial, George Balanchine's ''Union Jack'' rather perversely but amusingly celebrated the British Empire with a ballet changing of the guards. And Hershy Kay wove together British traditional tunes to make a colorfully, grandly nationalistic musical score.

LEAD: Summer began unofficially here Friday evening when sailors raised the gangplanks, passengers clogged the decks holding binoculars and beer and two grand old steamships once again chugged down the Detroit River, honking at nearby tugboats and freighters.

LEAD: A national organization of family and child welfare agencies plans to recommend the elimination of surrogate parenting contracts and payments to surrogate mothers, according to senior members of the group.

LEAD: James S. Walsh, president and chief executive officer of the Raytheon Company's Beech Aircraft Corporation subsidiary in Wichita, Kan., has been named president and chief executive officer of the Wyman-Gordon Company.

LEAD: The Forward, which helped hundreds of thousands of Jewish immigrants understand the often baffling life they found in America, is 90 this year. And while it surely is not as robust as it once was, its step is still spry and its Yiddish voice can still crackle with indignation.

LEAD: Ken Williams drove in Tim Hulett with a 10th-inning double to left that was misjudged by Jim Rice, and the White Sox went on to a 4-1 victory today over the Red Sox. Chicago swept the three-game series.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Iraqis continue to express dismay over the loss of life aboard the American frigate Stark, which was struck by two Iraqi missiles in the Persian Gulf a week ago, and some fear that the United States will now fire on all Iraqi warplanes flying over the gulf.

LEAD: QUESTION: Since the National Basketball Association began play after World War II, has one city ever had the winners of hockey's Stanley Cup and the pro basketball championship in the same year?

LEAD: THE Mets open a road trip in San Francisco today, but Dwight Gooden will be working out at Shea Stadium - alone with himself and his future. Tomorrow night and again next Sunday, he is scheduled to pitch for the Tidewater farm team. And a week from Friday night against the Pittsburgh Pirates, the 22-year-old right-hander is expected to stride to the mound at Shea Stadium, accompanied by cheers of encouragement.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y., yesterday Susan Sevilla and Kinnaird S. McQuade Jr. were married by the Rev. Richard Noonan.
LEAD: When thousands of Americans descend on France this summer, many will no doubt be toting the tourist's bible: the Michelin Red Guide to Hotels and Restaurants.

LEAD: The case for keeping a U.S. naval force in the Persian Gulf is summed up as (1) a superpower must maintain the principle of ''freedom of the seas'' everywhere; (2) we must not allow Iran to cut off the flow of oil to the Western democracies and Japan, and (3) unless we honor our decades-old commitment to protect the gulf, the Soviet Union will eagerly move into the vacuum and take control of the oil shipping lanes and the

LEAD: Caetano Veloso started to shake up Brazilian music in the late 1960's, when he and some Bahian cohorts created the pushy, rock-tinged ''tropicalia'' style. At the time, tropicalia was seen as a rebellion against the cool, jazzy bossa nova. And in previous New York appearances with his band, Mr. Veloso has raised a celebratory ruckus.
LEAD: Estelle Fielder wants to reverse what she calls a national tragedy: alcoholism among Indians, who suffer alcohol-related deaths at a rate nearly five times that of other Americans.

LEAD: In a graduation ceremony in Fauver Stadium yesterday, the University of Rochester awarded bachelor degrees to 1,133 students, master's degrees to 834 and doctorates to 313. Anthony E. Hecht, a former faculty member and 1968 Pulitzer Prize winner for poetry, gave the commencement address.

LEAD: In November 1975, my oldest son was bar mitzvah in ''the near perfect symmetry'' of a 19th century architectural landmark. Mark's bar mitzvah took place a month after the renovations that transformed Gramercy Park's Friends Meeting House into the Brotherhood Synagogue were completed.

LEAD: A jury has awarded Beverly Pittman, 44 years old, $403,000 in back pay and damages in a sex discrimination suit against the General Motors Corporation. The jury found Friday that the automaker discriminated against Ms. Pittman when she was laid off from her job as a production supervisor in July 1981.

LEAD: With their ''Salome,'' Moshe Leiser and Patrice Caurier have provided a good argument against the radical restaging of opera. The two young directors, who work principally in France, have brought their new production of the Strauss opera to the 11th Spoleto Festival U.S.A. here. The setting is a greenhouse belonging to Herod, in this incarnation a wealthy, drunken German industrialist from the 1930's.
LEAD: A high school principal who was lauded by President Reagan for his tough disciplinary policies has been ordered to face an assault charge filed by a teacher.
LEAD: The traditional Goldman Pairs Championship was the focus of attention at the Eastern Regionals, played this weekend at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan.

LEAD: It's been many years since old men in threadbare blue uniforms led the march down Main Street. Many years, too, since anyone wept for the soldier in the flag-markered grave, or spoke of the general whose statue broods over the park. To some Americans the flag of the Confederacy is simply something waved at football games; G.A.R.
LEAD: The Amoco Corporation's bid to buy financially troubled Dome Petroleum Ltd. appears to be in growing difficulty.

LEAD: ''PLEASE stop calling me ma'am,'' Phyllis Love said in mock annoyance to Phoebe Prewitt. They both laughed. It was a subtle breakthrough in a new relationship that should last at least until 1990. They had talked on the telephone, but in this first face-to-face encounter the conversation had tended toward ''nice to meet you.
LEAD: Among the artists with easels out on Fifth Avenue yesterday was one with an unusual sign: ''Hunger Strike: Day 15. K.G.B.: Return my 88 paintings, confiscated in Moscow on 8/5/82.''
LEAD: At the Community Synagogue in Sands Point, L.I., yesterday Laura Emily Ullman and Howard David Schwartz were married by Rabbi Martin Rozenberg, assisted by Cantor Jacob Yaron.

LEAD: In an effort to fire up his party for the June 11 general election, Neil Kinnock, the Labor leader, recently accused Margaret Thatcher of trying to recreate a Britain with Victorian extremes of wealth and poverty. ''Charles Dickens,'' he said in an impassioned speech in Birmingham on Wednesday, ''thou shouldst be alive at this hour.
LEAD: Nearly 60 years ago, Babe Ruth was bargaining with the Yankees over the same $80,000 salary that a borough president now makes.
LEAD: Dave Barr birdied four straight holes on the back nine, breaking a tie with the Masters champion, Larry Mize, and finished with a seven-under-par 65 today to win the Atlanta Golf Classic.

LEAD: Every few weeks an Iran-related demonstration takes place in the streets of Washington. Sometimes it is in favor of the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, and sometimes it is against. In either case, passers-by usually pay little notice. But ears picked up last week when a pro-Khomeini group marching by the White House sounded the cadences of an American sports cheer familiar to anyone who has attended a high school football game.

LEAD: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea replaced his Prime Minister and seven senior Cabinet members today in an attempt to defuse a crisis over scandals involving police torture and corruption charges.

LEAD: RON LEVY is a young pianist whose instincts and intelligence just slightly outrun his physical abilities at the instrument. In his performance at Weill Recital Hall Saturday afternoon, Mr. Levy played an interesting program with the kind of technique that probably flourishes in the practice room but may lack that final bit of fiber needed to withstand the pressures of performance.
LEAD: A proposal to dedicate a prime piece of Washington real estate, the Ellipse area behind the White House, as a memorial to slain police officers is running into resistance.
LEAD: East Coast, West Coast, the Mets go struggling on.

LEAD: Feeling endangered, the Flyers let their emotions run rampant, focused on their dislike for their opponent instead of the puck, and after another game spent chasing the Oilers, they retreated to their locker room by far the worse for wear.

LEAD: The Rev. Jerry Falwell said today that the PTL television ministry had fallen short of its weekend fund-raising goal of $2 million and would go out of business unless it got at least $3.2 million by Friday.

LEAD: Steve Garvey, troubled by a shoulder injury, was placed on the 21-day disabled list by the San Diego Padres. The 38-year-old Garvey, who has played in the majors for 17 years, has been bothered by pain in his left shoulder since spring training. The first baseman was benched May 3 after his poor start at the plate.
LEAD: In an encouraging step toward a revolutionary new form of treatment, scientists have transplanted a human gene into monkeys and it successfully directed production of a desired enzyme.
LEAD: The nation's leading steel producers, who have looked to the Federal Government for assistance in the form of import quotas, now contend that more Government initiatives are needed.

LEAD: IT was only a matter of time, needless to say, before a television movie got around to the hot subject of crack, a potent form of cocaine. Tonight at 9, the ''ABC Theater'' series is presenting ''Cracked Up,'' the story of a high-school track star succumbing to the deadly drug's addiction. Unfortunately the film, written and produced by Peter Lefcourt, is structurally flawed and ends up being kind of deadly itself.

LEAD: Just as the planned community that sprang up here in the potato fields of Nassau County set the pattern for the postwar migration to the suburbs, so Levittown may set the pattern for the bookstore of the future. Its name is Waldenbooks and More, a so-called superstore whose owners have ambitious plans for expansion.

LEAD: Straining for a bit of sun, some New Yorkers watched veterans marching in parades yesterday, some went bicycling in parks, and some shivered in sweatshirt weather that felt more like a prelude to fall than summer.
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived here today for a three-day visit on the last stop of his first round of visits to the Soviet Union's European allies since taking power in 1985.

LEAD: The real question for Americans, Gary Hart said, is the Reagan Administration's intentions in the Persian Gulf. What does our Government plan to do if tankers and other oil facilities come under increasing attack?

LEAD: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, with his political allies deeply divided over how to deal with the growing strength of the far right National Front Party, has publicly repudiated what he called ''intolerance and sectarianism'' in France.

LEAD: Bob Murdoch, assistant coach of the Calgary Flames, is reportedly about to be named head coach of the Chicago Blackhawks. ''I'm not at liberty to say anything,'' Murdoch said in Calgary. ''It's up to them to make any comment about it one way or the other.''
LEAD: The Israeli Supreme Court has ruled that a loyal Moslem officer in the Israeli Army was framed by Shin Beth, the domestic intelligence service, and unjustly sentenced to 18 years in prison.
LEAD: One hundred times the bailiff asked for the verdict. And 100 times it came back ''not guilty.''

LEAD: Racial discord was cast aside at a rowing competition that had once been marked by a dispute over comments by members of an all-white Boston team who said black rowers on a New York City club would not be welcome.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: During the Holocaust memorial ceremony in Brighton Beach last June, each of the neighborhood's synagogues sent forth one of its faithful to light a candle. A stooped old man named Jacob Tannenbaum represented Temple Beth El, and those who attended the service recall that as he lit the wick he began to cry.

LEAD: IN THE OFFICES of Esquire, the men's room door is labeled neither ''Men'' nor ''Gentlemen,'' but ''Man at his finest,'' which is the subtitle of the magazine. With spirit like that, how can the 54-year-old publication be denied an industry leadership position?

LEAD: Jack Clark, the St. Louis first baseman, tied a major league record by committing three errors during a five-run second inning, and the Atlanta Braves got 17 hits tonight in a 14-5 victory that ended the Cardinals' five-game winning streak.
LEAD: In the mornings I go to the garden.

LEAD: Sister Beverly Bligh and Sister Grace Reape rode from Jersey City to the beach on Memorial Day weekend, but they did not actually get on the sand. They looked at it from the Boardwalk. To go on the beach at Belmar costs $8 a person on weekends, too much for them.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Gulch, the lone 3-year-old in a field of nine, ran down King's Swan and Broad Brush in the final furlong and then survived a claim of foul to win the $601,500 Metropolitan Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY The U.S. semiconductor industry appears to be rebounding, according to industry executives and analysts. The success of the Reagan Administration's trade sanctions against Japan and a sudden surge in purchases of personal computers have spurred demand and driven up profit margins.
LEAD: During jury deliberations, Raymond J. Donovan, the former Labor Secretary, said, ''My mother knew what she was doing'' when she named him after St. Raymond Nonnatus.
LEAD: Tradition - that's why the Indianapolis 500 wasn't official until 8 o'clock this morning.

LEAD: Here in Hunan Province, where Mao Zedong was born, there are few signs of the economic transformations sweeping other areas in China, changes intended to invigorate industry and improve living standards.

LEAD: * Challenger International Ltd., Hamilton, Bermuda, which is involved in petroleum products and crude oil marketing, appointed Jeffrey W. Hobbing president and managing director. Mr. Hobbing, who will also continue as president of Challenger Petroleum U.S.A. Inc., succeeds Anthony P. Towell, who resigned to pursue other interests.

LEAD: A jury of seven men and five women was selected in Upper Marlboro, Md., yesterday in the trial of Brian Lee Tribble, the man accused of providing Len Bias, the University of Maryland basketball star, with the cocaine that killed him. Prince George's County Circuit Court Judge James M. Rea spent the latter part of the afternoon listening to a series of pre-trial motions.
LEAD: It was a perfect setting for a bit of old-fashioned politicking, but out among the throng at the annual Strawberry Festival here, Representative Lee H. Hamilton cut a somewhat aloof figure.

LEAD: The bond market rebounded from its lows last week, encouraging some analysts to speculate that the appearance of a 9 percent yield on long-term Treasury issues marked the end of the steep price declines of the last two months.

LEAD: THE financially troubled Pan American World Airways recently made an agreement with New York's Citibank to borrow $75 million, and the bank said it would try to raise $75 million more. As collateral for the loan, the airline will put up some of its equipment and parts, such as engines, rather than its already-mortgaged planes.
LEAD: HBO Video is quite willing to sell its movies on cassettes, but what it is really promoting is renting. And the company is doing it on network TV.
LEAD: Claudell Washington pulled a small whisk broom from his bagful of belongings and held it up for general inspection.

LEAD: It had truly been a struggle: The Los Angeles Lakers needed all of their talent to stave off the upstart Seattle SuperSonics in the first three games of this four-of-seven-game playoff series. But just minutes into the final period at the Coliseum this afternoon, the Lakers' best players were resting on the bench.
LEAD: Ivan Lendl and Steffi Graf won first-round matches in contrasting fashion today as the French Open began on the clay courts at Roland Garros Stadium.
LEAD: Doctors reattached a 7-year-old boy's ear after it was retrieved from the stomach of a Doberman pinscher that had bitten it off.

LEAD: The price of Genentech Inc. stock has been dropping steadily on expectations that the Food and Drug Administration will place restrictions on the use of the drug that is expected to become the company's biggest product. An advisory committee of the F.D.A. is set to hold a public hearing Friday on the drug, known as tissue plasminogen activator, or T.P

LEAD: A careless smoker apparently caused a fire at Goldwater Memorial Hospital on Roosevelt Island Sunday night that killed an 88-year-old, partially paralyzed woman patient and injured five others, two of them critically, the fire authorities said yesterday.

LEAD: The House of Hasselblad, the Swedish camera concern, will be using Della Femina, Travisano & Partners to promote its cameras and projectors in the United States, just as it uses the agency's parent company, the WCRS Group of London, throughout Europe.

LEAD: A city so richly diverse as New York is more than the daily dance or jab of its citizens getting through the rush, more than the groan of its buses or the wail of its sirens, more than the clash of its politicians.

LEAD: One year ago, Hands Across America was billed as the unassailable charity event of the 1980's: a proposed human chain across the United States to raise at least $50 million for the hungry and homeless.
LEAD: Making her way down a row of young cornstalks, Ifua Amoakwa leaned over and gave each stalk something her Fanti ancestors never tried: one white pellet of nitrogen fertilizer.

LEAD: Emily Sue Medine, the daughter of Mrs. Myer Medine of New York and the late Dr. Medine, was married in Princeton, N.J., yesterday to Michael Howard Schwartz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Schwartz of Bayside, Queens. Rabbi Deborah Hirsch, assisted by Cantor Susan Berkson, performed the ceremony at Prospect House on the Princeton University campus.
LEAD: The American team investigating the missile attack on the American frigate Stark arrived in Baghdad today, planning to ask Iraq to let them interview the pilot who fired on the ship.

LEAD: ''OLD textbooks never die they just get paraphrased.'' So says Diana B. Paul, associate professor of political science at the University of Massachusetts and a visiting scholar at the Museum of Comparative Zoology at Harvard University.
LEAD: International A3-13
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Reaffirming an earlier decision, the trustees of Wheaton College have voted to admit men in the fall of 1988, according to reports published today.

LEAD: Adrian Dantley has worn uniforms of five different teams during his 11 pro basketball seasons but the ritual has remained the same every time he shows up at the Boston Garden. Sometime during the game, he will look toward Loge 1 where Red Auerbach sits, and nod to him.

LEAD: Two New York City players, Lapt Chan of Woodside, Queens, and Carleton Lett of Manhattan added their names to a distinguished list Sunday night. Playing at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan, they captured the Goldman Pairs, a prestige event that has been won by many of the game's greatest players, starting in 1929 with Oswald
LEAD: Tee-Comm Electronics Inc. of Montreal said Sunday that it had reached an agreement to acquire Satellite Video Services of Catskill, N.Y. Terms were not disclosed.

LEAD: Supplemental appropriations bills are intended to provide Government financing for emergency situations that were unforeseen when regular appropriations were enacted. But, like others before it, the supplemental bill now moving through Congress has also become a vehicle for an array of projects, this time ranging from a new national weed center to sweeter

LEAD: Early this month three Airbus A-300's, some of the best planes in Eastern Airlines' fleet, were transferred to Continental Airlines under a lease agreement. Three more will follow next month, reconditioned and painted Continental's colors.
LEAD: Carroll A. Hochwalt, a chemist and former vice president of the Monsanto Chemical Company, died of a heart attack at his home in St. Louis on Saturday. He was 88 years old.

LEAD: A paroled rapist, Lawrence Singleton, was removed from an apartment in a bullet-proof vest today after 400 residents surrounded the building to protest a decision to place him there permanently.

LEAD: MANY computer users, concerned about possible health effects of the low-level electromagnetic radiation emitted by video display terminals, have installed antistatic screens over the glass fronts of their computer monitors.

LEAD: For decades, this small city on the Susquehanna River has celebrated Memorial Day with a seemingly timeless ritual. It would begin with a slightly ragged parade down Main Street and end with solemn speeches before a worn monument bearing the names of fallen servicemen from World War I, World War II and the Korean

LEAD: John D. McPherson, who founded the Airborne Freight Corporation and headed it for 22 years, died of cancer Saturday at Mills Memorial Hospital in San Mateo, Calif. He was 64 years old and lived in nearby Hillsborough.

LEAD: Scientists at the Smithsonian Institution's National Zoological Park have succeeded in producing three litters of kittens in domestic cats by in vitro fertilization. The achievement marks the first time ''test-tube'' fertilization has been successful in any type of cat - or any other non-human carnivores - and holds promise for increasing the reproductive capacity and the long-term survival of such endangered felids as

LEAD: In the past, the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. has generally regarded theater as the stepchild of the performing arts. This year, however, it is offering an event of theatrical magnitude - Athol Fugard's probing drama ''The Road to Mecca,'' featuring Yvonne Bryceland and Charlotte Cornwell in their American stage debuts.

LEAD: The favorite, the world champion Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union, had to be content with a tie for first place with the Yugoslav grandmaster Ljubomir Ljubojevic in the SWIFT International Tournament in Brussels. Both players left an elite field in the lurch by scoring 8 1/2-2 1/2.

LEAD: An article on May 15 about the nomination of Thomas F. Hartnett to be New York State Labor Commissioner misidentified the largest union of state employees. It is the Civil Service Employees Association, not the Public Employee Federation.

LEAD: Having just spent $657 million in a dramatic expansion of prisons, New York State faces a rising crisis: not enough prison space. The first round of building made sense, but it also left state officials free to neglect sensible steps for managing a growing convict population - measures that now merit urgent study.
LEAD: David Horton, an 81-year-old crime watch volunteer carrying a loaded rifle, was shot by police officers responding to a call and died near the dumpster in his apartment house parking lot.

LEAD: Q.Before scientists learned to make synthetic growth hormone, where was it obtained? A. Growth hormone was painstakingly removed in small amounts from the pituitary glands of human corpses. The hormone was in short supply, and there was a long waiting list. Growth hormone was also obtained from monkeys, the only animals whose protein is active in humans.

LEAD: Mexico's duty-free assembly industry, originally conceived as a program to link manufacturers in the United States and Mexico, is increasingly being regarded by Japan and other countries as a way to further their penetration of the American market while avoiding trade squabbles.
LEAD: Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole is telling Congress that if it does not come up with more money for the Federal Aviation Administration, air safety may be affected.
LEAD: The dollar was stable in Europe today in a session subdued by holidays in the United States and Britain. In Tokyo, the dollar moved up to its highest closing in a month.

LEAD: Dr. James G. Hirsch, a biological scientist, medical educator and president of the Josiah Macy Jr. Foundation, died of cancer yesterday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: John S. Reed, chairman and chief executive of the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation, has a load of worries.
LEAD: Former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan and seven other construction executives were acquitted yesterday of state charges of fraud and grand larceny after an eight-month trial in the Bronx.
LEAD: ''Mountain Stage,'' a live musical-variety show from West Virginia public radio, is carving its own niche in the down-home airwaves mainly occupied by the famed ''Prairie Home Companion.''

LEAD: Dominique de Menil does not really like to be labeled a collector. ''I find it pretentious,'' she protests. Yet the more than 10,000 art objects accumulated over a 40-year period by her and her late husband, John, make the term somewhat hard to avoid. And so the $25 million museum built to house their holdings -opening here on June 7 - has come to be called the Menil
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Treasury financings this week consist of today's three-month and six-month bill auctions, followed tomorrow by the sale of notes due in about five years.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: While television sets in official Washington are tuned in to the Iran-contra hearings, the single set at the office of the special prosecutor investigating the arms scandal is usually turned off.

LEAD: Caspar Weinberger displays an unusual management style for a Secretary of Defense. Instead of pushing the Army, Navy and Air Force toward a unified strategy under strong central management, he has mostly raised money and let them spend as they please. Now, as famine years follow the feast, the absence of a strategy by which to allocate the cuts is proving all the more harmful.
LEAD: When it comes to tail-wagging-the-dog politics, the Democratic primary campaign for Governor of Kentucky displays the state of the art.
LEAD: A chart Friday showing locations of attacks on Persian Gulf shipping omitted one source. It is the International Association of Independent Tanker Owners.
LEAD: GENEVA, May 25 - Uganda has received more than $6 million in international assistance to begin a five-year plan for combating AIDS, the World Health Organization said today.

LEAD: Three people died and and seven others were injured, four critically, when a fire swept through the second- and third floors of a three-story brick building in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn early this morning, officials said.
LEAD: WORKING with a miniature shotgun that blasts gene fragments into the cells of living organisms, scientists believe they have hit upon a powerful technique for engineering new forms of life.

LEAD: After $2 billion in losses and 25,000 layoffs, the nation's semiconductor industry - which makes the chips that run everything from computers to spy satellites to dishwashers -appears to have made a long-awaited rebound, industry executives and analysts say.
LEAD: Gerard L. Oestreicher, a real-estate developer and Broadway producer, died Sunday at New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: THE New York City Ballet offered some kinetically surprising works at weekend performances at the New York State Theater.

LEAD: At the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Manchester, Mass., yesterday, Kimberly Anne Howard, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert E. Howard of Manchester, was married to Christopher Joseph O'Donnell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence O'Donnell of Ridgewood, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev.
LEAD: As evidence has mounted of President Reagan's personal involvement in the Iran-contra affair, a quandary has been presented to some Republican members of the joint Congressional committees.

LEAD: Joe Paterno has agreed to lend his name to George Bush's presidential bid, according to aides and supporters of the Vice President's campaign. The Bush campaign expects to announce soon that the Penn State football coach is being named to a steering committee of about 500 people that will help organize the candidate's effort in

LEAD: Just outside the windows of the room where the Framers of the Constitution first convened 200 years ago today, that long-ago moment of high anxiety was celebrated this afternoon with pageantry and pride, but also with subdued reflection.

LEAD: THE powerful impact of Pina Bausch's Dance Theater has often left the impression that modern-dance choreographers in West Germany today are less influenced by movement exploration than by theatrical images.
LEAD: Henrik Beer, former Secretary General of the League of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, died Saturday at his Geneva home, the league announced yesterday. He was 71 years old.

LEAD: The Justice Department announced this month that a special prosecutor was taking over an internal investigation into links between the Wedtech Corporation and Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d. It said it was Mr. Meese's idea to seek the special prosecutor's review. His lawyer, Nathan Lewin, said his client wanted the matter settled ''as promptly as possible by an inquiry that will be fair and complete.

LEAD: Karl Lagerfeld, to practically nobody's surprise, has emerged as the hero of the fur showings in New York. After all, in his 20 years as designer for Fendi in Rome, he has built that company into the world's leading pace setter in fur fashions. Now he has added the French-based Revillon company to his repertory.
LEAD: MALE sheep, pigs, cattle and chickens tend to grow faster and heavier than females and produce the leaner meat that health-conscious consumers prize.

LEAD: Now that ''it's clear'' to Don Nelson that he won't be returning to the Milwaukee Bucks, he would appear to be headed to the Golden State Warriors, a franchise owned by his ''best friend,'' Jim Fitzgerald, once the Bucks' owner.

LEAD: Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline, the direct-marketing arm of Young & Rubicam, continued to bask in the pleasure of Time-Life Books this week, as it has for almost a quarter of a century, by getting four new assignments.
LEAD: WHY do some people infected with the AIDS virus fall ill and soon die while other virus carriers remain healthy for years?

LEAD: Frederick B. Rentschler, president and chief operating officer of the Beatrice Companies, has always been a hands-on manager, from developing some of the company's food products to cooking with them at barbecues.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Avies Copy took the lead for good on the first turn and held off a rally on the far outside by Proudest Duke to capture the 43d running of the $500,000 Jersey Derby today at Garden State Park.
LEAD: * Field Publications to Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston.

LEAD: Most Americans say the Constitution has accomplished the bulk of its aims, from unifying a nation of separate states to providing defense and domestic tranquility, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows, but a majority say the Constitution has done a poor job of treating all people equally.

LEAD: Marcel Chandelier, a former head chef at Lutece restaurant in Manhattan and co-founder of Maison Germaine, a catering concern, died Saturday at his home in Long Island City, Queens. He was 53 years old.
LEAD: THE genes of the black rhinoceros are being analyzed at Columbia University in a project that may be crucial to the survival of that endangered species in Africa.
LEAD: * Florida Power and Light Co. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $350 million of first-mortgage bonds.
LEAD: PERSONAL computers are bringing about a subtle change in the way we exchange information.

LEAD: So many people jammed onto the Golden Gate Bridge for its 50th anniversary party that worried engineers did rapid calculations to make sure the span could support the weight, officials said today.
LEAD: Just when it appeared as if Kareem Abdul-Jabbar had finally decided on a retirment plan, it appears as if there might be another change.

LEAD: Rameau's ''Platee'' is an incongruous piece of writing: the composer bestowed some of his most endearing music on what may well be the cruelest of operatic plots. To cure his wife, Junon, of jealousy, Jupiter pretends to court the hideous nymph Platee. When Junon sees the object of his affection, she laughs at her own suspicions.

LEAD: Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson of Boston beat out Ketchum Advertising of Pittsburgh and Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver of New York for the non-cranberry business of Ocean Spray Cranberries Inc., a farmers cooperative based in Plymouth, Mass. That means Ingalls will handle advertising for grapefruit and guava juices, which have an ad budget of $15 million.

LEAD: IN fields, forests, city parks and suburban yards throughout the country, plants and trees are gearing up for an annual pitched battle against myriad enemies - predatory insects, pathogenic microbes, foraging animals and even other plants that try to invade their turf.
LEAD: ''The indictment should never have been brought.'' - Rosa Milligan, jury forewoman in the Raymond J. Donovan case. [ A1:5. ]

LEAD: IT seems a funny thing to say, but what really made Alan Weinberg's piano playing at Weill Recital Hall pleasurable last Friday night was his obvious pleasure in the doing of it. This is a performing space that has witnessed a lot of grim struggle and half-panicked efforts at survival. Mr. Weinberg, on the other hand, could bring to the finale of Beethoven's ''Adieux''
LEAD: Donald H. Putnam, chairman of the Conrac Corporation, died of lung cancer Friday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 62 years old.
LEAD: Virginia Swanson Kamen, a West Coast pediatric pathologist, died of cancer Wednesday at Santa Barbara Cottage Hospital in California. She was 64 years old and lived in Montecito, Calif.
LEAD: The Soviet Union has stopped jamming Voice of America radio broadcasts into the country for the first time in seven years, officials of the American radio service announced today.

LEAD: TRACK Caraher Sets Record: Phil Caraher of North Rockland High School won two events and White Plains posted a meet record of 41.9 seconds in the 400-meter relay at the 31st annual Eastern States Interscholastic Boys Track and Field Championships at St. John's University. Caraher scored victories in the discus throw at 183 feet 7 inches, and the shot-put at 62-7 3/4.
LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY
LEAD: Five small bombs exploded at different points across Puerto Rico today, hours before a public appearance by King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia of Spain.

LEAD: A full-page advertisement in the publishers' catalogue calls it the book of ''a new breed of politician.'' But ''One Man's Luck,'' the Gary Hart campaign biography that was set for publication in September, has been canceled by William Morrow & Company.

LEAD: A prominent anti-apartheid leader was sentenced to 11 years in prison today by a court in the so-called independent homeland of Ciskei for furthering the aims of the outlawed African National Congress, the main nationalist movement fighting to end white rule. The leader, the Rev. Arnold Stofile, a member of the executive of the United Democratic Front, and three others were convicted Friday of terrorism and illegal possession of weapons.

LEAD: SEVERAL hundred companies are offering programs to help employees deal with stress, according to a survey to be published soon by the health-promotion office of the Department of Health and Human Services. But the economic and health value of such stress-management programs, aside from subjective feel-good reactions as measured over a few months, has yet to be established.
LEAD: It appears that everyone is going a little shutterbuggy these days. And why not, when taking pictures is so easy?

LEAD: A dispatch from Las Vegas, Nev., in some copies Saturday on the World Championship of Poker misidentified the site of the tournament. It was Binion's Horseshoe Casino. An accompanying photo caption misidentified the casino's proprietor. He is Jack Binion.

LEAD: ''I WAS definitely the only man there in an Issey Miyake minidress,'' Billy Boy said. Billy Boy, the American jewelry designer, Barbie doll collector and fashion archivist who is based in Paris, was describing his weekend sojourn in Washington for the annual American Booksellers Association convention.

LEAD: On most days, outside American diplomatic missions here and elsewhere in Turkey, small knots of people gather -sometimes whole lines of them -clutching documents, some false, and harboring dreams, some in vain.
LEAD: This village of seaside estates and elegant, brick-cobbled sidewalks is putting summer visitors under wraps.

LEAD: The leader of a military coup d'etat was assigned to the most important portfolio in an interim government today, in another sign that the military continues to play a crucial role after nominally returning to the barracks.
LEAD: Four girls kept their promise and showed up at their high school prom wearing tuxedo jackets, leotards and tights.

A citywide committee of black leaders, displaying unusual unity, formed to choose a candidate to oppose Mayor Koch in the

LEAD: Four prisoners being taken to Florida overpowered their guards early today, took one hostage and stole a prison van before being stopped at a roadblock, officials said. One inmate was found in the van, dead from a bullet wound to his head, and the three others were captured. The authorities have not ruled out suicide in the man's death.

LEAD: The decision by Citicorp last week to admit to a staggering $3 billion in potential losses on foreign loans spells the end of the Reagan Administration's 20-month-old ''Baker Plan'' to deal with the turmoil over the debts of the developing countries, according to political and economic analysts.

LEAD: The marriage of Cynthia Ann Thole, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Thole of Redlands, Calif., to Richard Loewus, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Loewus of New York and Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. David Fischell, the brother-in-law and sister of the bride, in Fair Haven, N.J.

LEAD: THE Unilever Group, with $25 billion in annual revenues, is the world's largest purveyor of consumer packaged goods. In the United States alone, its operations include Lipton, a producer of specialty foods, along with Chesebrough-Pond's in beauty care and Lever Brothers in detergents and personal products.

LEAD: ROCKET builders eager to tap the proven technology of the giant Saturn 5 moon rocket have been frustrated because long ago blueprints and other documents were scattered - a few even lost - and all the old dies, jigs and tooling were sold as scrap metal for pennies a pound.
LEAD: ''THEM.'' Stalin's Polish Puppets. By Teresa Toranska. Translated from the Polish by Agnieszka Kolakowska. Illustrated. 384 pages. Harper & Row, $22.95.

LEAD: McCann-Erickson, the lead ad agency network of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has acquired a 70 percent interest in United Communications of Taiwan, which brings McCann's total to 134 agencies in 63 countries and its billings to $2.85 billion.
LEAD: The number of women in state Legislatures has grown in every election over the past 18 years, according to a recent study by Rutgers University.
LEAD: Klaus Barbie, on trial for Nazi war crimes, is likely to be brought before the court Tuesday to confront witnesses who say he tortured them, the assistant prosecutor said today.
LEAD: Craig Bubier scored his fourth and final goal with 1 minute 51 seconds remaining today to break a 10-10 tie with Cornell and give Johns Hopkins the national collegiate lacrosse championship.
LEAD: Max. Load: 250,000
LEAD: Florida now has more cases of syphilis than any other state, and health officials attribute the disease's swift spread to the practice of exchanging sex for drugs.

LEAD: Joy Baker, the wife of the White House chief of staff, was admitted to Georgetown University Hospital today. The White House said she was there for routine tests and was expected to be released soon. Mrs. Baker had an abdominal operation last year, and several years ago underwent surgery for lung cancer.

LEAD: AEROSPACE engineers around the country, responding to a new challenge, have begun to develop the rocket that some expect to carry the nation into its next phase of space exploration and exploitation.
LEAD: More than 1,000 relatives and friends of the 29 people killed by a tornado last week in the nearby town of Saragosa filled a school gymnasium for a rosary service tonight for the victims.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from addresses yesterday by Vice President Bush, former Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and Mayor W. Wilson Goode of Philadelphia at ceremonies in Philadelphia opening the celebration of the 200th anniversary of the United States Constitution, as recorded by The New York Times:

LEAD: Ecolab Inc., embittered by cutthroat competition on the supermarket shelf, has decided to sell its consumer dishwasher detergent business to Joh. A. Benckiser G.m.b.H. of West Germany for $242.5 million.

LEAD: The New York City Health Department will more than double its capacity to offer voluntary testing of blood for the AIDS virus by opening two new testing sites this summer and by extending testing to some private and municipal teaching hospitals, a key health official said yesterday.
LEAD: New Jersey's garbage problem has spilled over in anger and grief here after five motorists were crushed by one of the garbage trucks that use the huge Edgeboro Landfill.

LEAD: When President Reagan meets this week to discuss policy in the Persian Gulf with his national security advisers, he will have to make a crucial decision: Is the United States prepared to bomb Iran to protect Kuwait's ships?
LEAD: Norwegian officials say Israel is resisting a proposal that would allow international inspectors to determine if Israel is using Norwegian ''heavy water'' to produce nuclear weapons.
LEAD: In a salon usually reserved for artistic debate, a group of 200 people gathered the other day to discuss a question that reflects a national enigma: Are Turks Europeans?

LEAD: After a farewell banquet, the curtain will descend tonight on the four days of entertainment and hoopla that have dominated the convention of the American Booksellers Association. The hard part will begin in a few months, when the fall books that have been on display here begin wending their way out of warehouses into the nation's bookstores.
