LEAD: A thorny tree that thrives in the bogs of southwestern Georgia has become a symbol of success in an economically depressed area.

LEAD: A doctor responsible for performing drug tests on employees involved in railroad and airplane accidents pleaded guilty in Federal District Court today to giving officials false test results on workers in three train accidents.

LEAD: The Navy awarded construction contracts for three new ships, including a $615 million deal with the General Dynamics Corporation for a new Trident missile submarine. The contract, given to General Dynamics's Electric Boat Division, calls for it to complete construction of the Trident by December 1992.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Ciba-Geigy Corporation today offered to acquire Spectra-Physics Inc., the world's largest laser company, for $32 a share in cash, or about $194.7 million for all the shares it does not already hold. Ciba-Geigy, the Swiss pharmaceuticals giant, currently owns about 1.4 million shares, or 18.8 percent, of Spectra-Physics, which is based in San Jose,
LEAD: The Metropolitan Opera's proudly announced commissions to Jacob Druckman and John Corigliano for operas in celebration of its 1983 centennial are in disarray.

LEAD: Sally K. Ride, the first American woman to fly in space, is leaving the astronaut corps to take a position as a science fellow at Stanford University, her alma mater, the space agency announced yesterday.
LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that an alien re-entering the country after being deported cannot be convicted if he can show the original deportation order was invalid.

LEAD: Federal health officials are fond of calling the home health care component of Medicare a bottomless financial pit. If it is, that seems reason enough for those same officials to take an intense interest in how well the money dropping into the pit is being spent. That amounts to $2 billion a year so it's strange to say they don't.

LEAD: Floating Happy Hour In the old days, New York's harbor trafficked in human and material cargo in numbers unequaled in the nation. Although the port has now surrendered its primacy, the harbor is playing a major role in leisure-time activities. Joining the sightseeing boats and daytime cruise ships are vessels bouncing gently around Lower
LEAD: It is one of those once-in-a-lifetime offers from the Internal Revenue Service that nobody can refuse. But millions are refusing, and the offer is about to expire.

LEAD: Federal officials said today that they would generally not cite employers for hiring illegal aliens in June because the Government had not distributed forms needed to start enforcement of the new immigration law.

LEAD: THE central thesis of ''Faces of the Enemy'' is stated early by Dr. Sam Keen, who wrote and narrated this earnest documentary based on his book of the same title: ''Before we make war, even before we make weapons, we first create the idea of an enemy whom we can fight.'' Not a complicated thought, nor an original one, but it is made vivid by Bill Jersey, who produced and directed the hour-long program that can be seen on Channels 13, 21 and 31 tonight at 9 o'clock.

LEAD: AT the University of Wisconsin's fast-food laboratory here, the sesame-seed buns were delayed somewhere in browning. As a result, flame-broiled meat patties were dropping helter-skelter onto bare conveyor belts and a computer-controlled arm was lifting the top buns, flipping them through the air and setting them down where they should not have been.

LEAD: President Reagan's eulogy of the 37 men killed in the Iraqi attack on the frigate Stark and the personal solace he brought to survivors at the Mayport Naval Station in Florida constituted the latest evidence that he has become the nation's chief pastor.
LEAD: Thomas J. Kalinske, a man who helped to build the Barbie doll into what it is today, will turn his toy salesmanship to the Universal Matchbox Group, best known for its small metal cars.

LEAD: The Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee on Terrorism, Narcotics and International Operations is scheduled to hear testimony today from Gorman Bannister, son of former Foreign Minister Everette Bannister of the Bahamas regarding the reputed involvement of high-level Bahamian officials in drug trafficking.

LEAD: The American Ambassador to Bonn told senior West German officials today that the United States would not accept any deal that resulted in the early release of a Lebanese suspected in the hijacking of an airliner.

LEAD: FRED HOLLAND trained as a painter before he turned to performing and choreography. His new ''Delicate Prey,'' performed on Saturday night at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, is filled with visual imagery whose muted quality makes it seem to exist beyond some mysterious scrim, though none is there.

LEAD: A compromise has been reached in a dispute over Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen's leadership that will largely restore his powers in the divided Seattle Archdiocese but require him to work with an assistant.

LEAD: ''THE SECOND VICTORY'' is a brisk action movie abounding in colorful characters, picturesque scenery and the homilies of Morris West, who wrote the screenplay based on his novel. The adroitly plotted tale, which opens today at Cinema 1, takes place in 1945. No sooner does Anthony Andrews, as a British major with a conscience as big as the Alps, arrive to head the Occupation forces at a scenic Austrian town than his sergeant is killed.
LEAD: Sally K. Ride, the first American woman in space, is leaving the space program for Stanford. A spokesman said she would take no questions about her decision. Page B7. (NYT)

LEAD: The Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair are only three weeks old, but already they have produced some unusual lingo. A mastery of these terms may not be essential to understanding the essence of the inquiry. But it helps. Here are some of them: B.G. - The code name for Lieut. Col. Oliver L.
LEAD: First-round play in the prestigious Reisinger Knockout Teams began at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan Monday afternoon and produced a major upset.

LEAD: Mayor Koch took a pass from the Knicks' captain, Bernard King, and drove for a basketball hoop outside City Hall yesterday. The layup was perfect, as was the scenario kicking off the 1987 Mobil Big Apple Games.

LEAD: CAPT. JEAN-MARIE GUILLOU, standing on the bridge of the 440-foot-long Wind Song, the longest and most technically advanced sailing ship ever built, gave the order to set sail into New York Harbor. He extended his right index finger, tapped a few buttons on the console in front of him, and nodded approvingly as the computer monitor diagrammed each of the ship's six triangular sails as they began unfurling automatically.

LEAD: FIVE years ago, in its very first episode, NBC's ''St. Elsewhere'' revealed that kindly Dr. Auschlander (Norman Lloyd) was suffering from a terminal illness. The chances of his making it through a single season looked decidedly slim. But thanks to the miracle of arbitrary plot developments, the good doctor is still among the ongoing characters, bringing a semblance of depth to the St.

LEAD: Nascar officials have fined Geoff Bodine $15,000 and placed him on probation until Dec. 31 for rough driving during the Winn-Dixie 300 Busch Grand National race at the Charlotte (N.C.) Motor Speedway last Saturday. Three days before the event, Bodine was fined $1,000 and required to post a $4,000 bond for unsportsmanlike conduct in the Winston on May 17 at
LEAD: A New York developer said today that he had signed a $17 million contract in Beijing last week to build a Chinese theme park 60 miles north of New York City.

LEAD: American after-tax incomes took their sharpest plunge in 12 years last month as individuals dipped into savings to pay tax bills, the Commerce Department reported today. It said that after-tax incomes plummeted 2.4 percent in April while the personal savings rate fell to an all-time low of one-tenth of 1 percent.
LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled today that Federal courts may jail criminal defendants before trial if they are deemed a threat to public safety.

LEAD: Airlines could help to ease air traffic congestion and reduce the danger of collisions by telling consumers the truth about expected arrival times of their flights. But since some airlines will not share this information voluntarily, Congress should make it Federal policy to require truth in scheduling.

LEAD: The Norwest Corporation said yesterday that it would set aside $200 million for losses on its $650 million portfolio of troubled foreign loans. The action by the big Minneapolis-based bank holding company, the nation's 24th largest, will result in a $160 million second-quarter loss, wiping out 12.3 percent of its net worth, and a $30 million loss for the year.

LEAD: Herbert Jacobs, an emeritus lecturer at the University of California School of Journalism who helped change the course of American architecture, died of cancer last Wednesday in Berkeley, Calif. He was 84 years old.
LEAD: The NCR Corporation will announce a new series of personal computers today, in one of the first major responses to the International Business Machines Corporation's Personal System/2.

LEAD: 1. Collecting Street Art Architectural ornaments are the rage as wall decorations. This plaster cherub, for $26, is part of a collection of eye-catching reproductions from Gargoyles Studio in Brooklyn. Farfetched, at 110 Fourth Avenue in Manhattan, between 11th and 12th Streets, carries these street finds.

LEAD: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, speaking to Georgia Republicans in Savannah last week, took a swipe at Senator Sam Nunn, saying that if the Georgia Democrat wanted to conduct foreign policy, then he should ''suit up'' and run for President.

LEAD: CHRIS REED'S deep, sepulchral voice and the precisely modulated machine-shop drone of interlocking guitar harmonics define the Lorries' distinctive, hard-edged sound. Performing at the Ritz on Saturday, the quartet from Leeds, England, hadn't changed much since its first recordings, made in the early 80's.

LEAD: SOCIAL commentary - on apartheid, the disease AIDS, drugs, poverty and multinational investments - took a major role in this year's Reggae Sunsplash, the traveling reggae show that came to the Felt Forum on Monday as part of its 26-city North American tour. The show featured winners of Jamaican Music Industry (Jammy) Awards, and in five hours of music it offered a survey of current reggae - from pop with an eye on the international market to toasting (rapping) with a specifically
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A report in the Executive Changes column of Business Day yesterday misidentified the new president and chief operating officer of Steris Laboratories Inc. He is James C. McGee.

LEAD: The Mets suffered the fourth casualty in their five-man pitching rotation tonight when Rick Aguilera felt his right elbow tightening while he was warming up and was scratched as the starter against the San Francisco Giants.

LEAD: A Tibetan teacher who made Buddhism accessible to a generation of Americans, including poets, psychologists and investment bankers, was cremated today in an ancient funeral rite before more than 2,000 students and friends.

LEAD: William H. Webster was sworn in today as Director of Central Intelligence and pledged that America's intelligence agents would ''carry out their assignments throughout the world with fidelity to the Constitution and to the laws of our beloved country.''

LEAD: New York State officials, trying to end an impasse over how to dispose of 3,100 tons of garbage that have been aboard a barge since March, offered a detailed plan yesterday on how to unload and truck the garbage to Islip, L.I.
LEAD: Interest rates at Citicorp's weekly commercial paper auctions declined for the first time in five weeks.

LEAD: Next month's Meadowlands Indy, as it is now called, and the other 12 races remaining on the Championship Auto Racing Teams schedule will likely have to do without Al Unser Sr., the winner of the Indianapolis 500 last Sunday.

LEAD: Herzog, Heine, Geduld Inc., a leading market maker in over-the-counter securities, announced yesterday that the board had elected John E. Herzog, 51 years old, as chairman and chief executive and that Emanuel E. Geduld, 44, would replace him as president. Mr. Herzog succeeds Max L. Heine, 76, who has been chairman since 1976, when his firm, Heine, Fishbein, was acquired by Herzog & Company.
LEAD: The prosecutor in the trial of Brian Tribble said today that Len Bias, the former Maryland basketball star, acted as ''courtesy middleman'' for Tribble in the distribution of cocaine.
LEAD: CROOKED HEARTS. By Robert Boswell. 340 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.
LEAD: New York City's Health Commissioner urged the city's 25,000 private physicians yesterday to accept a much larger responsibility in containing the spreading AIDS epidemic.
LEAD: The Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation, the largest insurer of tax-exempt bonds, has announced plans for an initial public offering of common stock.

LEAD: On March 7, Secretary of Defense Caspar Weinberger, with the approval of President Reagan, notified the Government of Kuwait that the United States Navy would provide escort for 11 Kuwaiti oil tankers in the Persian Gulf.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In an atmosphere that swung between student protest and courtroom trial, Columbia University yesterday began disciplinary hearings against 45 students who participated in a campus demonstration against racism.
LEAD: To The Living Section:
LEAD: Larry Bird did not let the Boston Celtics lose tonight.

LEAD: THE computer ate something this afternoon. I suppose that is inaccurate, or, as the computer itself might say, ''Error: file not found.'' The truth is that I did something wrong and a whole lot of words disappeared into that great ozone where all our computer mistakes float about in disconnected turns of phrase and truncated quadratic equations.

LEAD: One of the men acquitted in the fraud and larceny trial of Raymond J. Donovan sent his lawyer back to the same Bronx courthouse yesterday to file papers seeking a quick trial on a murder charge that sparked the fraud case.
LEAD: Tens of thousands of firefighters, with some help induced by seeding the sky, have finally extinguished the worst forest fire in China's history, the official Xinhua News Agency said today.
LEAD: Ever wonder whether any of the policy recommendations by the hordes of witnesses appearing every week before Congress ever find their way into legislation?

LEAD: Winthrop G. Brown, a retired State Department official and former Ambassador to Laos and South Korea, died Monday at his home in Washington. He was 79 years old and had suffered from Parkinson's disease for several years.
LEAD: Somewhere in the dark building lurked a man with a gun and, perhaps, an accomplice wielding a machete or a sawed-off shotgun.

LEAD: Jack Nicklaus's 12th annual Memorial Tournament at Muirfield Village Golf Club this week honors the memory of Tom Morris Sr. and his son, Tom Morris Jr., the Scots who were the most renowned players of the mid-19th century. They are best known as Old Tom Morris and Young Tom Morris, each of whom won four of the first dozen British
LEAD: Dave Parker hit a homer to lead off the ninth inning tonight, giving the Cincinnati Reds a 3-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

LEAD: Mark McGwire, an Oakland rookie, is leading the American League in home runs with 16, and is slugging them at the astounding rate of one every 7.75 times at bat. If he were able to maintain that pace, the 6-foot-5-inch, 220-pound first baseman would need only 303 times at bat to break the rookie home run record of 38, shared by Wally Berger and Frank Robinson.

LEAD: Surge for the Dollar The dollar rebounded on world markets, posting one of its largest gains of the year and lifting stock and bond prices sharply. Page D1. Brown Upset in Kentucky A political newcomer, Wallace Wilkinson, rose from obscurity to win the Democratic nomination for Governor over John Y.

LEAD: Lunch-hour pedestrians watched in horror as winds ripped a window-washing platform from near the top of a 36-story skyscraper and hurled it to the street today, killing two men aboard it and a woman on the ground.
LEAD: There is often a man on board the F train who plays the saxophone so atrociously - almost cruelly, really - that riders pay the man (who incidentally says he hails from Mars) to stop.
LEAD: In a change of plans, the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair have decided to delay taking public testimony from Albert Hakim until next week.

LEAD: More than 40 performers will offer a variety of music, from Dixieland jazz to classical, at the Museum Mile Festival on June 9. Museums along Fifth Avenue, from 82d Street to 104th Street, are to open their doors for the festival, which is to be held from 6 to 9 P.M., rain or shine.

LEAD: The board of the Cadillac Fairview Corporation today voted to approve the sale of its office buildings and business parks in the United States to a group led by Copley Real Estate Advisers and Michael V. Prentiss, president of the company's United States commercial properties division. Copley Real Estate, which is based in Boston, is acting on behalf of a number of investors, including the New England, formerly known as the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company.

LEAD: Two Israeli Government investigations into the Israeli espionage operation in Washington cleared all of Israel's political leaders today of any knowledge of or involvement in the Pollard spy affair.
LEAD: Klaus Barbie was returned to court against his will today to confront some of those who say he tortured them in prison here 43 years ago and sent them to Nazi camps.

LEAD: Asher B. Edelman informed Burlington Industries yesterday that he might be willing to top the $76-a-share offer from the leveraged buyout group of Morgan Stanley Group Inc. and members of the textile company's management.

LEAD: Dwight Gooden, making his fourth start since his cocaine rehabilitation treatment, again struggled and was hit hard tonight in pitching seven innings for Class AAA Tidewater in a 5-4 International League victory over Pawtucket.

LEAD: BARBERSHOP harmony singing, the four-part unaccompanied male vocal style that became popular in the late 19th century, still flourishes in this country, thanks largely to groups like the 130-voice Big Apple Chorus. This mighty ensemble, led by its conductor-director, Don Clause, was the headline act in a Saturday evening program at Carnegie
LEAD: Thousands of people joined with the surviving residents of this little town today as they buried 17 of the 29 people killed by the tornado that destroyed Saragosa.
LEAD: To The Living Section:

LEAD: The landlords of rent-stabilized apartments in New York City said yesterday that they wanted rent increases of up to 18 percent on apartments whose leases are due for renewal in the 12 months beginning Oct. 1.
LEAD: Sales of existing homes edged down 1.4 percent in April, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.63 million units, the National Association of Realtors said today.

LEAD: AS the society has become more health, weight and diet conscious, Americans, particularly children, have become fatter. This seeming paradox has its roots in environmental factors, among them easy access to high-calorie foods; the additional time spent watching television, which can lead to the consumption of foods advertised on television, and reductions in school physical education programs.
LEAD: The weak dollar suddenly rebounded yesterday, posting one of its largest gains this year against almost all leading currencies on a wave of buying that began in Japan.
LEAD: The last remaining all-male eating clubs at Princeton University were ordered by the state today to begin admitting women.

LEAD: The BankAmerica Corporation's chairman, A. W. Clausen, will meet with Japanese officials and businessmen later this week and next week to discuss possible Japanese purchases of new BankAmerica securities.
LEAD: Two young conductors will substitute for Sir Georg Solti, music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, for the season's final week of concerts, orchestra officials have announced.

LEAD: Talk about confusion. Iranian attacks on American vessels in the Persian Gulf could provoke war with the United States, a State Department official said last week. What did the White House think of that? ''We disagree,'' a spokesman said the next day. Months ago, Pentagon officials insisted that American warships in the gulf had the capability and authority to defend themselves.
LEAD: DEAR Diary:
LEAD: Wallace Wilkinson, a self-made millionaire making his first bid for public office, today won the Democratic nomination for governor of Kentucky after a remarkable rise from political obscurity.

LEAD: FRIENDS often tell me they are reluctant to use pork chops as a main ingredient because the chops never come from the skillet quite tender enough. I suspect that often has to do with the quality of the meat, and there is no way to determine at a glance whether the meat is likely to be tender after frying.
LEAD: Organizers of a failed drive to maintain Wheaton College as an all-women's school criticized the college trustees' decision to admit men as students beginning in the fall of 1988.

LEAD: About the time of the first disclosures about United States arms shipments to Iran, the Soviet Union quietly delivered more than $18 million in advanced weapons to Iranians, according to records of a French arms dealer.

LEAD: There was no champagne, no whirling series of high-fives in celebration. Moments after the Los Angeles Lakers had returned to the National Basketball Association final after a one-year absence on Monday, there was no feeling of redemption in their locker room. The mood was businesslike, almost solemn.

LEAD: For a National Collegiate Athletic Association member school with Division II status, Kutztown (Pa.) University has a success rate for gaining its brightest stars tryouts in National Football League training camps that larger and more prominent Division I universities might envy.
LEAD: The deposed chairman and chief executive officer of Guinness P.L.C., Ernest Saunders, resigned from the brewer's board today, one day before shareholders were to vote on whether to oust him.

LEAD: THE demand for office space in Manhattan's SoHo area is so strong that some developers are pressing on with conversion plans for loft buildings in that neighborhood despite restrictions that limit the use of renovated space there.

LEAD: Companies like GTE rely on vendors to develop computer-controlled automation machinery capable of being tied into the CIM network. But some vendors are as much a part of the problem as the solution.

LEAD: IN recent months San Franciscans have been haggling over how to fete their illustrious Golden Gate Bridge on its 50th birthday, but now that the celebration is over they can return to their most impassioned topic of conversation: Restaurants.

LEAD: The Soviet Union began AM radio broadcasts to the United States from Cuba last weekend, about the same time it stopped jamming Voice of America transmissions, the United States Information Agency said today.

LEAD: Speaking at College Park, Md., Baseball Commissioner Peter Ueberroth urged University of Maryland graduates yesterday to let the accomplishments of Len Bias and Judy Resnik, two ''remarkable people with great, God-given skills,'' serve as inspiration for them. Bias, a Maryland basketball star who was drafted in the first round by the Boston Celtics, died of cocaine intoxication last year.
LEAD: President Reagan said today that the increased American military presence in the Persian Gulf would not lead to United States involvement in the Iran-Iraq war, now in its seventh year.
LEAD: A small New York-based investors' group emerged yesterday as a threat to the independence of the Allegis Corporation.

LEAD: THE Iran-contra affair, the AIDS epidemic, New York City's corruption scandals and personalities ranging from Edwin Meese 3d to Barry Manilow were among the subjects addressed in an evening devoted to political comedy at Stand-Up NY (236 West 78th Street) on Monday. The show, which featured Robert Altman (also known as Uncle Dirty), Jim Morris, Beverly Mickins, Randy Credico and Scott Blakeman, was the second in an ongoing Monday night series of politically oriented shows presented by the club in association with WBAI-

LEAD: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, describing Western access to the Persian Gulf as essential, called today for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies to join Washington's military effort to protect the movement of oil tankers in the gulf.

LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev explained his concepts of openness and restructuring today to a mass rally in the Communist country whose leader is believed to be the least interested in introducing such policies.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from a report to the Holy See by a commission of three Roman Catholic bishops named to assess the situation in the Archdiocese of Seattle, which is headed by Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen. The report is to be issued today in Washington.

LEAD: Fresh from a tortellini salad with high-cal dressing, a friend who works in midtown strolled through the International Paper Company Plaza on West 45th Street recently and found that she was not the only New Yorker who needed to walk off her lunch.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A fire that injured 13 people, including 4 children, in a Brooklyn tenement early yesterday was caused by arson, the authorities said last night.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Two United States Embassy security officers were shot and slightly wounded here today while driving to work. The attackers, who escaped, fired an automatic weapon from another car.

LEAD: Carmen Perez, center, at funeral for her son, Juan, who was killed last week by two polar bears in the Prospect Park Zoo. He had climbed into the bears' den after the zoo had closed. With her were a brother and sister-in-law, Jose and Maria Torres.

LEAD: SOME children receive a set of encyclopedias or an unabridged dictionary when they graduate from grade school. Not Rick Bayless. His parents, who owned a barbecue restaurant in Oklahoma City, gave him a copy of Julia Child's ''Mastering the Art of French Cooking.'' Every weekend in the ensuing summer, he cooked a complete meal from the book, making his family ''sit down and suffer through'' each of them.
LEAD: About 2,500 criminal defendants have been held by the Government without bail under the three-year-old law allowing pretrial detention of suspects considered dangerous to the public.

LEAD: As expected, Bob Murdoch, who was passed over for the No. 1 job with the Calgary Flames after five years as an assistant, was named head coach of the Chicago Blackhawks yesterday, reportedly with a two-year contract. The 40-year-old former defenseman succeeds Bob Pulford, who returned to his role as the Blackhawks' full-time general manager.

LEAD: SHARES of the seven regional Bell companies have run into a selling squall since late last summer, when the stock market gradually changed gait to favor cyclical companies rather than the longstanding beneficiaries of a disinflationary environment. Last week three of these operating companies - Ameritech, Pacific Telesis and U S

LEAD: Following are excerpts from the opinions in the Supreme Court's decision today in United States v. Salerno, upholding use of a 1984 Federal law to deny bail to a ''lethally dangerous'' Mafia leader and a co-defendant before trial to prevent them from carrying on crime that the Government argued included ''murder and mayhem.

LEAD: The State Senate's majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, emerged this evening from a three-hour meeting with Senate Republicans and said there were still two main areas of disagreement between them and Governor Cuomo on proposed ethics legislation.

LEAD: IN spring, the Ensemble Studio Theater holds its annual marathon of one-act plays and, around the corner at Intar Stage 2 on West 53d Street, the Working Theater sponsors a satellite festival. The newer company shares some playwrights - and a point of view - with the more established Ensemble Studio.

LEAD: Dr. Arthur M. Sackler, a research psychiatrist, entrepreneur and philanthropist who became one of this country's leading art collectors and patrons, died of a heart attack yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: Azorin & Davis of New York and Dugan, Valva Associates of Fairfield, N.J., will share the responsibility for the Melitta account.

LEAD: The first police officer to reach the four youths shot by Bernhard H. Goetz testified yesterday that one of them, lying on the floor, had said, ''We were gonna rob him, but the white guy shot us first.''

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a Tokyo dispatch in some copies yesterday about a shake-up of the South Korean Cabinet misidentified the body that has replaced the Korean Central Intelligence Agency. It is the National Security Planning Agency, not the Legislative Administration Agency.

LEAD: The Hartford National Corporation is offering $150 million of 9.85 percent subordinated capital notes due in 1999 at a price of 99 7/8 to yield 9.868 percent through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.
LEAD: Sales of the eight domestic automobile makers declined 24.9 percent in the middle of May, to a daily rate of 24,569, compared with 32,710 in the period last year.
LEAD: Bond prices rose sharply yesterday, erasing all the declines of the previous two weeks and injecting new optimism in a market dominated by despair in recent months.

LEAD: Retail milk prices in New York City have fallen an average of 17 percent since a Federal court allowed a New Jersey distributor into the tightly controlled market in January, a new state survey has found.

LEAD: Susan M. Phillips, chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission since November 1983, has informed the White House that she intends to resign on July 24 to take an administrative position at the University of Iowa.

LEAD: Kicking off the Christian Democrats' campaign in this city last week, the party secretary, Ciriaco De Mita, issued a dramatic warning. ''The alternative is around the corner,'' he said in a loud threatening voice.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Lawyers for a Marine guard accused of spying in the United States Embassy in Moscow have uncovered a confidential 1940 memo from J. Edgar Hoover that was highly critical of security measures in the embassy and urged that unmarried employees be assigned elsewhere.
LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

LEAD: THE latest publisher of The Atlantic - and there have been a number in the last few years -is Robert E. L. Johnson, better known to masthead readers as Robin Johnson. He will be 30 years old on July 31.

LEAD: Dr. Monroe Maximilian Broad, a general surgeon, died May 19 at Long Island Jewish Hospital after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived in Queens.

LEAD: On the other side of the Hill, the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations, which is headed by Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, is preparing for the appearance of Dennis B. Levine, the former Drexel Burnham takeover specialist accused last year of a $12 million insider trading scheme.
LEAD: Spectradyne Inc., the nation's largest operator of pay-per-view hotel movie systems, said today that it had agreed to be acquired for $452 million, or $46 a share, in cash and securities.

LEAD: For more than three years Raymond Donovan, the former Secretary of Labor, has had the unhappy distinction of being the first sitting Cabinet officer to be indicted. The Bronx District Attorney, Mario Merola, accused him and his construction company of stealing $7.4 million from New York City in connection with a huge subway tunnel project.

LEAD: The Flyers, facing elimination from the Stanley Cup final, came into tonight's game at Northlands Coliseum without much reason for optimism and then fell behind by two goals in the second period. But just as they had done in Game 3, Philadelphia staged a comeback, and the Flyers went on to a 4-3 victory over the

LEAD: A Brooklyn grand jury has refused to indict three plainclothes police officers who fired a fusillade of bullets at two unarmed men crouched in a car last year in what the Police Department says was a case of mistaken identity.
LEAD: A Navy honor guard standing by some of the 36 coffins of sailors from the frigate Stark that arrived yesterday at Dover Air Force Base, Del.
LEAD: Because of the Feast of the Ascension, alternate-side parking is suspended in New York City tomorrow.

LEAD: Sephardic Cooking Special dishes will be among the attractions at the Sephardic Fair Sunday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Congregation Shearith Israel, Central Park West at 70th Street. Pastries including borekas, baklava and biscotios will be sold, and Gilda Angel, a cookbook author, will autograph copies of her book ''Sephardic Holiday Cooking'' (Decalogue Books, $19.95).

LEAD: Bus drivers and mechanics for Shortline Bus System were back at their jobs today for the first time since May 7, when they went on strike, affecting 10,000 riders in New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania. The employees of the commuter bus service approved a new contract Saturday by a 2-to-1 margin.

LEAD: The Canadian Government said tonight that its Ambassador to Washington had been subpoenaed to testify at the perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver, the former White House aide, but would refuse to appear.

LEAD: Frank E. Canavaciol, an electrical engineer who taught at Polytechnic University in Brooklyn from 1919 to 1966, died Monday at Parkway Hospital in Queens. He was 91 years old and lived in Queens. He is survived by two daughters, Marie Giorgi of Queens and Vita Tauss of Manhasset, L.I.; a brother, John Canavaciol, and four grandchildren.

LEAD: Somewhere, lost in all the hoopla about pitching and offense and the rise to first place, the defense has been neglected. Perhaps it is the way, Willie Randolph says, that the fielders are quietly performing their tasks. No one notices consistency.

LEAD: DEEP in the vast GTE Corporation telephone switch factory here, portions of a model factory that will be the centerpiece for next month's Advanced Manufacturing Systems Exposition in Chicago are being put through their final tests.

LEAD: Charles Eliot Pierce Jr., a scholar of English literature and the chairman of the English department at Vassar College, has been named the new director of the Pierpont Morgan Library, one of the nation's leading museums and centers for scholarship in the field of printed books, illuminated manuscripts and drawings.
LEAD: Thirteen former directors of the Getty Oil Company said in a statement that Getty never had a contract to merge with the Pennzoil Company in January 1984.
LEAD: Joggers using a lane marked for runners yesterday in Central Park.

LEAD: Two Government soldiers and 10 leftist guerrillas have been killed in two battles in the northern part of the country, the army announced. A statement released Monday night said the fighting occurred Sunday in Peten Province.

LEAD: The Standard Oil Company said yesterday that it would sell some of its manufacturing and mining assets, as well as a note held by one of its units, in a complex financial transaction valued at about $1.8 billion.
LEAD: Way back in 1885, 18 years before the first World Series and 8 years before Lord Stanley unveiled his hockey cup, the United States played its first soccer game against Canada - and lost, 1-0.
LEAD: LARRY and Connie Weinberg of Montrose, N.Y., peered at Tom Lake, a fisherman proudly displaying a freshly caught silvery fish so large that each end draped far over the platter.

LEAD: WHEN Genesis performs at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., this Saturday and Sunday, the concerts will mark a pinnacle in the career of one of the longest-running English rock groups. Genesis, which was formed more than 20 years ago and released its first album in 1969, has sold over four million copies of its 16th album, ''Invisible Touch.

LEAD: The original Pulsar watch, with its startling red numerals on a black face, cost $2,100 in 1971. By 1985, Chiquita Bananas was giving away digital watches as favors at Yankee Stadium. Digital displays had become so ubiquitous that teachers worried that schoolchildren might never learn how to read a clock face.

LEAD: Toyohiro Akiyama, Washington bureau chief of the Tokyo Broadcasting System, bought a Chrevrolet Impala a couple years ago as his personal contribution to easing trade tensions between Tokyo and Washington. ''This is my own way to redress the trade imbalance,'' he said.

LEAD: Jim Bakker said tonight that he made a ''terrible mistake'' in turning over his PTL television ministry to the Rev. Jerry Falwell and accused Mr. Falwell of misleading him by pretending the arrangement would be temporary.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Old maps show a small waterfront colony at Moore's Beach here on Delaware Bay, but the tides have been rising for years. Now Charles and Marie Holmes are the last year-round residents.

LEAD: A reporter from Washington can hardly make even a brief political tour of Paris and London these days without feeling uneasy about the Western alliance.

LEAD: Earvin (Magic) Johnson - who led the Los Angeles Lakers to 65 victories, the best record in the National Basketball Association this season -was the only player unanimously voted to the all-N.B.A. team announced yesterday. The 6-foot-9-inch Johnson, who has made the first team at guard for five straight years, and Larry Bird of the Boston Celtics, who has made it at forward in each of his eight seasons in the league, were the only two first-team repeaters from last season.
LEAD: Martin T. Sosnoff said he would consider raising his $32-a-share cash tender offer for Caesars World Inc. under certain conditions.

LEAD: In the rough-and-tumble world of the nation's busiest futures pits - where as many as 700 traders shout their orders and elbow for position for hours each day while trying to remain on two feet - it has become increasingly difficult to discern prices and execute orders.

LEAD: Shops were closed and buses stopped running today in the western part of Fiji's main island in what was described as the first of a series of economic protests against the military-backed interim Government.

LEAD: Steve Garvey, the San Diego first baseman, will undergo surgery Saturday to repair a ruptured tendon in the left shoulder area, the Padres announced yesterday. LEAD: The Lockheed Corporation's stock jumped sharply today in heavy trading. LEAD: SOCCER Portuguese Team Wins Cup: Porto of Portugal won the European Champions' Cup yesterday by upsetting Bayern Munich of West Germany, 2-1, in the final in Vienna. Bayern Munich opened the scoring in the 25th minute when Helmut Kogl picked up a ball deflected by Jaime Magalhaez of Porto and headed it in.

LEAD: A supermarket roof collapsed Tuesday while it was being renovated, killing a repairman and slightly injuring a woman, officials said. The repairman, Edward Mamasian, was trapped when half the roof of the two-story J. C. Supermarket collapsed after a beam holding two supports gave way without warning, the authorities said.

LEAD: On a day of rare warmth and brilliance for this misty island that makes its living off pen-raised salmon and Harris Tweed, Dr. David Owen tackled yet again the most daunting task in British politics. He was trying to talk people into voting for a third party that offers little hope of an outright victory.

LEAD: ARE the parts of the Allegis Corporation worth substantially more than the whole? That is the key question in the developing battle for control of the company whose single most valuable part is United Airlines. From recent rapid rises in the price of the stock, the answer would appear to be yes.

LEAD: The Schoharie Creek was narrowed during construction of the bridge that collapsed last month, despite an engineer's warning that a narrower creekbed could increase the pressure on the bridge and endanger it during floods, state officials said today.

LEAD: Everyone is presumed innocent until proved guilty but not every defendant is entitled to release pending trial. Murder suspects, for instance, are locked up. Still, America's very sense of justice turns on the noble presumption of innocence; the exceptions should be rare.

LEAD: A Federal judge who had rebuffed four defense requests to step down from the complex Hunt brothers bankruptcy case agreed today to turn the matter over to another judge because a bank merger could create a conflict of interest.

LEAD: SYLVIA TORAN'S piano recital at Weill Recital Hall Monday began with Mozart of vivid lyric propulsion: the Sonata in F (K. 332), played at brisk tempos with a firm sense of where the music was going and no inhibiting caution about getting there. That kind of uncomplicated vigor characterized the best of her work throughout the program.
LEAD: Mayor Koch yesterday proposed new tax incentives for companies that relocate to new or rehabilitated quarters north of 96th Street in Manhattan or to the other four boroughs.

LEAD: DEBORAH HAY stepped onto the stage at the start of her performance Monday at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center and talked to the audience about how to look at her dance. She was engaged, she said, in the ''recognition of changing'' and not the kind of strict linear progression one tends to expect in dancing.

LEAD: President Reagan, acknowledging that his credibility had been damaged, said today that he had not been involved in illegal acts in the Iran-contra affair and blamed the Washington press corps for creating a false impression that he had.
LEAD: After graduating last week from Macalester College in St. Paul, Minn., Julia Kirtland is planning an extensive vacation from academic studies and serious physical training. She deserves it.
LEAD: The Celtics say Robert Parish could have played last night, which makes his one-game suspension all the more appropriate.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: John Jenkins, the coach of the Bolton (Conn.) High School baseball team, knew early this season that he was in for another bad year when his squad was beaten by two junior varsity teams.

LEAD: Except for their first nine years, when all they wore was a star pinned onto any old thing, the New York City police have been snappy dressers - the spit and polish of their outfits reflecting the discipline of their work. Their first uniforms, for instance, were double-breasted velvet-collared frock coats; and so what if their hats, designed to deter flying objects, had to be leather?
LEAD: New Inquiry on Bakkers
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Buffy Sainte-Marie and Livingston Taylor, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300). One of the most powerful folk commentators of the 1960's, Buffy Sainte-Marie hasn't lost her bite. Her eerie buzzing alto still flays into songs that discuss the plight of American Indians while evoking Indian cowboy ritualism.
LEAD: The Japanese Government today approved a larger-than-expected program of $43 billion to stimulate its economy and ease trade frictions with the United States.

LEAD: MAHLER'S rapturously nostalgic Third Symphony, like his more haunted Ninth, ends in an extended Adagio that demands almost inhuman concentration and dedication from the conductor and his orchestra. Despite that, or perhaps because of it, successful performances of both works have not been uncommon, especially in recent years as the Mahler revival turned into something like a stampede.

LEAD: Kadri Gopalnath, Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street (206-1050). South Indian ragas on the alto saxophone? Kadri Gopalnath, whose concert here, sponsored by the World Music Institute, is part of his first American tour, has made the instrument acceptable in Indian classical music circles, playing ragas with a creamy sound and delicate, voice-like inflections.

LEAD: A platoon of fourth-graders from Syracuse, armed with their favorite pastry, being escorted through the Capitol. They asked lawmakers to make the apple muffin the official New York State muffin. Page B4. (NYT/David Jennings)
LEAD: The United States and New Zealand have suspended aid to Fiji to protest the coup that ousted an elected Government, officials said today.
LEAD: Kraft Inc., said today that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Anderson, Clayton food division of the Quaker Oats Company for $235 million in cash.

LEAD: ELIOT NESS, the strait-laced United States Treasury officer whose group of hand-picked officers finally felled the mighty Al Capone, is more than the stuff of history and legend. Through television, which from 1959 to 1963 projected Ness's stiff incorruptible image into American homes as a symbol of good against evil, he also became a fantasy.

LEAD: The Belmont Stakes on June 6 is the racing event of the year, because Alysheba is bidding for the Triple Crown, but the Red Smith Handicap at Belmont Park tomorrow could be the best horse race of the season. The Triple Crown races were missing some leading 3-year-olds who were sidelined by injury or illness, but the Red

LEAD: A former United States Ambassador to Costa Rica, who has been accused of improperly helping the rebels in Nicaragua, testified today that he was operating under direct orders from the National Security Council, the State Department and the Central Intelligence Agency.

LEAD: Herbert E. Alexander, a professor of political science at the University of Southern California, says he already knows who will win the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination. ''My prediction is that the candidate who will win the Republican nomination has four letters in his name,'' said Mr. Alexander, who was in Washington promoting his new book on financing of the 1984 campaign.

LEAD: Officials of Turner Broadcasting System Inc. said they would delay a preferred stock dividend scheduled for Monday to gain time to close a deal that would provide Turner with a cash infusion of $557 million.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company has announced that it will recall 290 heavy-duty Econoline vans and 2,300 chassis for buses and medium-duty trucks, both for the 1987 model year. The F and L series truck chassis and B series bus chassis are being recalled for replacement of an accelerator part that may come apart.
LEAD: The judge in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz yesterday threw out all the testimony of a key prosecution witness, one of the four youths Mr. Goetz shot in a subway car in 1984.

LEAD: The chairman and chief executive of the BankAmerica Corporation suggested today that the troubled banking company might have to increase its reserves to cover shaky Latin American loans, an action that could mean a return to the red.
LEAD: Federal agents and New York City police detectives said yesterday that they had foiled an attempt to steal more than $1.2 billion in stock certificates from an armored car in lower Manhattan.
LEAD: Semifinal play in the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship resumed last night at the Beverly Club, at 130 East 57th Street in Manhattan, with teams led by two world-famous players in the lead.
LEAD: Declaring the contents of the infamous garbage barge Mobro to be nonhazardous, a state judge today lifted a restraining order that had kept the scow moored off Brooklyn for 13 days.

LEAD: JEAN ANTOINE HOUDON'S ''Painted Plaster Bust of Thomas Jefferson,'' from 1789 - the oldest surviving version of this, the most famous portrait bust of the statesman - will be auctioned today in the first session of Christie's American art sale, taking place at 10 A.M. and 2 P.M., at its galleries, at Park Avenue, at 59th Street.
LEAD: Like the storied engine of kindergarten books, Missouri City Elementary is the little school that could. And now, after a 10-year struggle, it has the credentials to prove it.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Name: Lewis A. Tambs Age: 59 Position: Professor of history at Arizona State University. Resigned in January as Ambassador to Costa Rica. Previously was Ambassador to Colombia. Role: Ambassador Tambs says Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North asked him to open a ''southern front'' of contras in Costa Rica.

LEAD: An effort to preserve the remains of one of the most celebrated warships in history began today when a deep-sea robot descended to the murky Atlantic grave where the U.S.S. Monitor has lain for 125 years.

LEAD: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company is offering $250 million of 10 percent bonds due in 2020 at a price of 98 7/8, to yield 10.12 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

LEAD: Bob Beamon says that not a day goes by in which he does not think of the long jump he made in the 1968 Summer Olympics at Mexico City, one that lifted him past the existing world record by 21 3/4 inches. His extraordinary leap to the end of the landing pit covered 29 feet 2 1/2 inches and has never been equaled.
LEAD: Natica Nast Warburg, widow of Gerald Felix Warburg, the cellist, died last Friday at New York Hospital after a long illness. She was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Brookville, L.I.
LEAD: The Allegis Corporation, which owns United Airlines, the Hertz car rental agency and major hotel chains, took a drastic step yesterday to avoid being taken over or broken up.
LEAD: * Allied Research Associates Inc., Severna Park, Md., said it had acquired Barnes & Reinecke Inc. for $4 million, with $3.3 million in cash and the balance in Allied Research common stock.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Armed men abducted a British diplomat in Iran today after forcing his car to stop on a highway in Teheran, the Foreign Office said.

LEAD: Lieut. Gen. William K. Harrison, who headed the United Nations armistice delegation in the Korean War, died Monday in Bryn Mawr Terrace, a nursing home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 91 years old and lived in Springfield, Pa.

LEAD: ''There was a man on second, and the ball was hit up the middle. It bounced funny off the mound, and by the time Dean fielded it, there's no play at first,'' Ed Tatarian explained. ''So I say to the guy next to me 'watch third.' Boom, Dean spins and nails the guy at third, who'd taken too big a turn.
LEAD: Jack Clark continued his May hitting rampage with two home runs, leading an 18-hit St. Louis attack today as the Cardinals scored an 11-5 victory over the Atlanta Braves.
LEAD: Ever since Gary Hart withdrew from the 1988 Presidential contest three weeks ago, friends and supporters have wondered what lies ahead for the former Democratic Senator.

LEAD: ''WHATSA matta, you look upset,'' says the big lug. ''I was born upset,'' snaps Barbara Stanwyck. It is a characteristic bit of movie dialogue for the woman who was born in Brooklyn in 1907, named Ruby Stevens, and wound up a Hollywood star, the genuine article. In April, Miss Stanwyck became the 15th recipient of the American Film Institute's annual Life Achievement Award.

LEAD: Newly released papers of President Nixon showed today that the seed of the Watergate scandals may have been a memorandum dated Jan. 14, 1971, from Mr. Nixon to his White House chief of staff, H. R. Haldeman.

LEAD: IT'S a long way from France to Tahiti. And so, to relieve the solitude of life at sea while en route from the shipyard to her exotic home port, the Wind Song, a new four-masted cruise ship, put into New York this week. The gleaming white 440-foot vessel - one of the largest under sail in the world - dominated not only the harbor, but the local social scene as well.

LEAD: Bret Iba, representing a third generation of basketball coaches, has been hired as the assistant coach at the University of Idaho, according to the head coach, Tim Floyd. The 28-year-old Bret will replace Larry Eustachy, who left last month to become an assistant at the University of Utah. Bret was a part-time assistant at Southwest Missouri State last year.

LEAD: FOR nine years, long before French bistros became the rage in Manhattan, La Gauloise was quietly and competently serving up such homespun fare as mussels mariniere, pepper steak and French fries, roasted rabbit, roast chicken and creme brulee. LEAD: Our country is the leader of the world. But can we continue to meet the challenges that this leadership poses for us? Can we continue to stimulate the global economic growth so essential to our prosperity? Can we fulfill the commitments to our friends and allies that keep the peace?

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said yesterday that he would seriously consider accepting the Democratic nomination for Vice President.

LEAD: ''Sometimes I wake up feeling like certain colors,'' said the artist. ''Right now, I'm into happy colors, summer colors -oranges, pinks, reds - in conflict and in contrast with a phosphorescent yellow offset by blacks and brown.''

LEAD: Derek Hardwick, president of the International Tennis Federation from 1975 to 1977 and an early advocate of open tennis, died at his home Wednesday night after a short illness. He was 66 years old. Along with Herman David, then chairman of the All England Club, Mr. Hardwick was determined to introduce open tennis, involving both amateurs and professionals, at the Wimbledon championships even if other nations were against it.
LEAD: THE jeremiads of financiers and economists, like those of other prophets or physicians, are usually intended to alarm miscreants enough to bring about actions that will avert the evil.

LEAD: The defense lawyer for Robert M. Freeman, the Goldman, Sachs & Company executive who was charged by the Government with insider trading, is expected to file shortly, under seal, a motion charging the United States Attorney with misconduct in the case, according to several legal sources.

LEAD: Daniel G. Amstutz, who played a pivotal role in shaping the Reagan Administration's farm program and in efforts to reduce global agricultural trade friction, is resigning as Under Secretary of Agriculture for international affairs and commodity programs.

LEAD: The Cathedral Choristers will sing Britten's ''Rejoice in the Lamb'' and a medley of works by Duke Ellington, Sunday at 3:30 P.M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th St. The concert is free. Information: 662-2133.

LEAD: A former Air Force sergeant originally accused of trying to deliver military secrets to a foreign agent has pleaded guilty to a charge of attempting to communicate secrets to an unauthorized person. He faces up to 10 years in prison and a fine of up to $250,000.

LEAD: Paul L. Sitton, the first Administrator of the Urban Mass Transportation Administration and a senior official at the National Academy of Sciences, died Wednesday of a liver ailment. He was 60 years old.

LEAD: Charles Ludlam, one of the most prolific and flamboyant artists in the theater avant-garde, who seemed to be on the verge of breaking into the mainstream of American culture, died of pneumonia early yesterday. He was 44 years old and had been suffering from AIDS.

A communique by the Lebanese military command said the plane had been trying to rescue a small boat in the Mediterranean off Sidon.

LEAD: In 19th-century England, orphaned and deserted children were often sent to large, shabby barracks-like institutions called ''poor law schools.'' In 20th-century New York City, a million public school students are sent, like orphans, to buildings with crumbling plaster, broken windows, leaky roofs and littered hallways.

LEAD: A teammate who was with Len Bias on the morning he died testified today that the University of Maryland basketball player provided him with cocaine on three occasions.

LEAD: New England houses of the 18th and 19th centuries, like antiques of any kind, are in limited supply. Even fewer remain in choice residential areas. Many are on roads that have become busy thoroughfares or are in neighborhoods that have become industrial. Others are in environments that are totally unsuited for a weekend or vacation retreat.

LEAD: Golf Americans Win: Bob Lewis of Warren, Ohio, won his fourth match in two days yesterday, leading the United States Walker Cup amateur golf team to a 16 1/2-to-7 1/2 victory over Britain and Ireland in Sunningdale, England. The triumph was the United States' 28th against two losses and a tie in the biennial match-play tournament, which began in 1921.

LEAD: John F. Kidde, a former president and chairman of Kidde Inc., which is known for lighting and home products, died Saturday at the Clara Maass Medical Center in Belleville, N.J. He was 81 years old and lived in Montclair, N.J., and Gulf Stream, Fla.

LEAD: Moslems praying toward Mecca during a festival in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, marking the end of Ramadan, the ninth month of the Moslem year. During Ramadan, which celebrates God's revelation of the Koran to Mohammed, Moslems are obligated to fast during the day. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)
LEAD: McCall's, which is part of the magazine category most affected by the competition of television, will formally adopt the advertising sales techniques used by broadcasters.

Terms were not disclosed, but Dillingham said SC-US would make a minority investment with management and employees taking the majority interest in the new company.

LEAD: The Pressmans, owners of Barneys New York, the men's specialty store at 17th Street and Seventh Avenue, bit off a bit more than they could chew when they opened their $25 million women's store last September. So in January they closed its casual, contemporary fashion annex, the Co/op, for renovation.
LEAD: President Reagan assailed critics of his economic and budget proposals today in a wide-ranging speech, vowing to resist any attempts in Congress to raise taxes.

LEAD: THE rage for furniture-as-sculpture continues apace in New York and the work of John Armleder, a Swiss artist who is one of the phenomenon's early proponents, confirms that it is not a purely American one. Mr. Armleder is known for combining old styles of abstraction with old styles of furniture, conjuring up effects that, in addition to being rather beautiful, are peculiarly neutral and tinged in equal amounts with a dandyish irony and a respect for the past.

Some of these stone objects are barely larger than a thumb; none are more than eight inches tall. All 94 fit nicely into a small gallery in the Michael C. Rockefeller Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

LEAD: Transplanted organs from a North Carolina accident victim have infected two people with the AIDS virus, the first case of transmission through donated organs that doctors thought they had determined to be safe, Federal health officials said today.
LEAD: Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday as traders vacillated between pessimism and optimism about the prospects for improved investor demand.
LEAD: Chris Evert, struggling with her timing and a little-known opponent, battled into the third round of the French Open today as she and other top-seeded players managed to stem upsets.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had won a Federal court case brought against it by one of its personal computer dealers, in a decision that appears to strengthen I.B.M.'s hand against retailers who sell its products in the ''gray market.''

LEAD: SUMMER HOME - Harlem Heights: 19 rms Georgian-style mansion, octagonal dining room. On 130 acres, Manhattan's highest pt., superb view all directions. Restored since Revolution. 45 mins. from city. Available for viewing.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged an investor with violating the anti-fraud provisions of Federal securities law by falsely telling Talley Industries that he had the necessary financing to complete a $233 million takeover.

LEAD: ON the surface, New York may seem like no place for musical traditions to make themselves heard. The rate of change is high; overnight, the corner bookstore turns into a boutique, or a dependable radio station switches to a new format. But New Yorkers, buffeted by trendiness, are happy to take refuge in music that looks back decades or centuries.

LEAD: Although the Reagan Administration has made some radical economic proposals in the past six years - tax overhaul and privatization among them - the prize for sheer daring might well belong to the Office of Management and Budget for introducing what it calls, somewhat blandly, ''shared savings.''

LEAD: Striking a blow for courtroom decorum, a Federal judge in the trial of a reputed Mafia captain and nine other defendants has laid down the law: there will be no eating candy or chewing gum in the courtroom.

LEAD: A Montreal dispatch yesterday about the Canadian visit of President Francois Mitterrand rendered the final word incorrectly in a comment before Parliament by Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. The passage should have read, ''Twenty years after General de Gaulle's visit, you will find, Mr. President, a Canada at peace with itself, aware of its diversity and resolved to recognize it with respect, tolerance and generosity.

A NUMBER of the musicians seen in ''Athens, Ga. - Inside/Out'' point to Pylon as the best band in town, but Pylon isn't even operational any more. The group, according to one member, ''just decided to quit while we were still having a good time.'' Formerly art students, the band members now hold odd jobs; the lead singer, a dynamo on stage, works in a copying shop. ''But I never planned on being a musician, so it's no big loss in my life,'' she said. Bear in mind that Pylon, having played several shows with U2 and begun to get some big-city bookings, stood on the verge of stardom while throwing in the towel. In Athens, Ga., which is the subject of Tony Gayton's bright, scrappy new documentary, this kind of attitude makes more sense than it might in other places. The musicians who are interviewed and perform in concert sequences display a uniformly easygoing attitude toward mainstream success. Some of them have made it (like the B-52's, senior statesmen of the Athens scene, and R.E.M.), and some have little chance. But they all share an appreciation for the friendly and comforting cultural atmosphere of Athens, and for the energy and eccentricity that have put the place on the map.

LEAD: A crowd gathered quickly round the television set near the middle of the room. The volume was turned up almost loud enough to drown out the voice of the winning pitcher. But Rick Rhoden, still perspiring from an uneasy night at Yankee Stadium, persisted.
LEAD: A ranking member of Congress charged today that the manufacturer of a highly publicized drug for AIDS had presented misleading and inaccurate information to the Government and to the public.
LEAD: Alvin C. Eurich, an educator who was the first president of the State University of New York, died Wednesday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 84 years old.

LEAD: Mitchell Price, a Southern Methodist University defensive back, has transferred to Tulane following suspension of the S.M.U. football program for repeated recruiting violations. . . . John Ayers, who started 69 straight games at left guard for the San Francisco 49ers before he injured his left knee late last season, has not been invited to training camp after ignoring the advice of Coach Bill Walsh to retire.

LEAD: President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica is touring European capitals with his plan to stop the war in Nicaragua. There will probably be a strong endorsement from the European Community in the next week or so, and the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, intends to bring it up at the seven-nation Venice summit meeting.

LEAD: Although next year's Summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, will be televised in this country from Sept. 17 to Oct. 2 by NBC, ABC announced yesterday that it had acquired the television rights to the trials that will determine the United States team. ABC did not disclose how much it had paid the United States Olympic Committee for the rights to the trials.

LEAD: VIVECA LINDFORS is the writer, director and star of ''Unfinished Business,'' which looks and sounds like a monodrama, though there are a number of other speaking parts in it. The film, a project of the Directing Workshop for Women, of the American Film Institute, is an intensely self-absorbed, self-referential work about Helena (Miss Lindfors), a great actress attempting to come to terms with herself and her dedication to the theater, thus ''to justify my time on earth.
LEAD: A New York City jail guard who traded gunfire with a suspected drug dealer on a Queens street early Wednesday was arraigned yesterday on a charge of reckless endangerment, the authorities said.

LEAD: The Justice Department has opened a preliminary inquiry into reports that the Rev. Jim Bakker and his wife, Tammy Faye, were involved in financial wrongdoing at the PTL television ministry, according to Federal law-enforcement officials.

LEAD: House tax writers agreed informally today to focus mainly on raising excise taxes on fuels and other items, as well as estate taxes, to meet 1988 budget needs, according to members who attended the closed-door meeting.
LEAD: The nation's largest Medicare-certified health maintenance organization has reportedly paid more than $350,000 to former aides of President Reagan for lobbying and legal fees.
LEAD: The Senate's ambassadorial pipeline is filling up.

LEAD: Say, you got any shopping centers that are still unleased, or bankrupt housing developments that need another mortgage? We could do business, if you're willing to pay a fee up front. Let's talk, over a bottle of Dom Perignon.

LEAD: IMAGINE Lenny Bruce at the height of his notoriety becoming a popular talk show host -and you may begin to have an idea of the whiplash intensity and black, hard-edged cynicism of Eric Bogosian's ''Talk Radio.'' With his new play, opening last night at the Public Theater, Mr. Bogosian takes a long leap from performance artist to playwright.

LEAD: Robert Maxwell, the British publisher who is eager to add an American book company to his worldwide communications empire, yesterday withdrew his $2 billion offer for Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., but said that he was ''continuing to review alternatives.''
LEAD: Three senior police commanders were arrested today on charges that they covered up information on the torture death of a student, officials said.

LEAD: Joe Capuana painting the rim of the seal pool at Coney Island as the occupants waited patiently for their water yesterday when the New York Aquarium opened its outdoor exhibits for the season. The porpoises and penguins had water, but the seals don't get to swim until today. (NYT/William E. Sauro)

LEAD: THE beautiful, slinky Lori Singer moves like a sleepwalker through ''Summer Heat,'' barely shaking her mane of back-lighted hair. As a sheltered young wife and mother in rural North Carolina tobacco country, she is called upon to knead, scrub, mend and otherwise convey the becalmed monotony of her life.
LEAD: Gilbert B. Phillips, a former president of the Automobile Club of New York, died of cancer Tuesday at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 77 years old and lived in Rockville Centre.

LEAD: Isiah Thomas waited for the ''go'' signal tonight. It came at the start of the fourth quarter, and with the ball his to command, the Detroit Pistons turned out their young, fast legs and defeated the Boston Celtics, 113-105.

LEAD: Shannon Douglas wading through the streets of Oklahoma City after nine inches of rain fell Wednesday, stranding her car. A 1,000-mile atmospheric battle of warm air from the Gulf of Mexico with cool air from the North and West yesterday produced funnel clouds in Texas and Kansas; more flooding in Oklahoma, where two people have drowned, and in Missouri and Iowa, and damaging winds in Wisconsin.

LEAD: The New Jersey Symphony, conducted by Hugh Wolff, will perform works for chamber orchestra by Ravel, Tchaikovsky and Stravinsky tonight at 8:30 in Princeton University's Richardson Auditorium, near Nassau Street behind the Nassau Presbyterian Church on the campus. LEAD: Nearly all Americans belong to a national or ethnic group once considered a ''minority'' that suffered - and may still suffer - discrimination. LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate fell five votes short of the 60 needed to waive the spending limit in the budget balancing act for the fiscal 1987 supplemental appropriation bill. LEAD: The Iraqi pilot who fired two missiles into the Stark appears to have been an accomplished aviator with 1,300 hours of flying time and 15 successful missile attacks on tankers in the Persian Gulf, Pentagon officials said today.

Behind the raised voices lies the tense, high-stakes negotiation over the National Broadcasting Company's need for a new home.

LEAD: The Henry Street Settlement Playhouse, 466 Grand Street, at Henry Street (598-0400), begins its Jazz at the Center season this weekend. Tonight Paquito D'Rivera, an alto saxophonist, is to lead his Latin-jazz quintet. Tomorrow, Cassandra Wilson sings with her jazz quartet. Concerts begin at 7 P.M.; tickets are $8, $4 for students and the elderly.

LEAD: President Reagan today stated once more the goals of American policy in the Persian Gulf. But he did not say how or when the Navy would begin to escort merchant tankers through the gulf war zone, apparently because those details have yet to be worked out.
LEAD: B. H. Haggin, an American music critic noted for his passionate convictions and clean, cutting prose style, died yesterday after a short illness. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The Unocal Corporation has decided to suspend temporarily its $2.5 billion lawsuit against Goldman, Sachs & Company, which it has accused of leaking sensitive information during a 1985 takeover fight with T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman.

LEAD: The Southern Christian Leadership Conference, saying that blacks have been silent too long on the topic of AIDS, today urged blacks to accept a much larger responsibility in containing the deadly disease.

LEAD: Stephen James, a 34-year-old Bronx bus driver and high school dropout, will graduate summa cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa next week from Lehman College with either a 3.99 or a perfect 4.0 average (depending on final marks).

LEAD: Trading on Wall Street was mixed yesterday, as the majority of issues moved higher even though many of the blue-chip stocks were being hit hard. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 19.11 points, closing at 2,291.57, but advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange led decliners by 943 to 637.
LEAD: The jury in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz yesterday filed into a graffiti-smeared subway car for what one of Mr. Goetz's lawyers called ''a class field trip.''

LEAD: Jack A. Partington Jr., a former house photographer for the old Roxy Theater in Manhattan, died Tuesday at his Manhattan apartment after a short illness. He was 73 years old and was also a resident of Southampton, L.I.
LEAD: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that its purchases of dollars during the three months ended April 30 were the largest in nearly a decade.

LEAD: John Cardinal Krol, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Philadelphia, was discharged today from St. Agnes Medical Center where he underwent a seven-hour operation May 19 to stop internal bleeding, a hospital spokesman said. ''He went home to recuperate,'' the spokesman, Bob Gallagher, said of the 76-year-old Cardinal.

LEAD: Poisonous protectionism is spreading in Congress. Practically speaking, the foreign trade bill that the Senate Finance Committee has concocted is hardly distinguishable from the House version. Both ought to provoke urgent opposition. The longer this false flower lives, the more it threatens to intoxicate politicians and public.

LEAD: The judge in the Howard Beach racial assault case ruled yesterday that the prosecution could not use some incriminating statements that a youth charged with murder reportedly made to the police.
LEAD: TENNIS
LEAD: Questions appear on page 6.

LEAD: Bill Madlock, the Los Angeles Dodgers third baseman who has been vocal about his frustration over being benched, was released yesterday. He appeared in 21 games this season, batting .180 with 3 home runs and 7 runs batted in. . . . Roger Maltbie, the 1985 winner of the Westchester Classic, has entered this year's tournament, which will be played next month at the Westchester Country Club in Harrison, N.Y.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson's disclosure that he would seriously consider the Vice-Presidential nomination underscored the dilemma his candidacy and his strong black support presents for the Democratic party.

LEAD: The final of the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship began last night at the Beverly Club, 130 East 57th Street, with an Old Guard team led by Sam Stayman of Manhattan opposing a group of rising young stars led by Maurice Wong of Larchmont, N.Y. The match ends today. In the Flight B final Thursday night, Alfred Lewis, David Robinson and Robert Christman, all of Manhattan, and Charles Greeley of Larchmont, N.Y., won by 19 international match points against Jeffrey Allen of Hastings-on-Hudson, N

LEAD: A Food and Drug Administration advisory committee recommended today that the agency not approve a drug that proponents say can save the lives of heart attack victims by dissolving clots in their blood.
LEAD: Alvin D. Chandler, former president of the College of William and Mary, died of a heart ailment Tuesday at the Virginia Beach General Hospital. He was 84 years old.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL 2-7 2,,q>A West German pilot flew to Moscow from Helsinki, crossing the heavily defended Soviet-Finnish border and landing his Cessna unimpeded next to the Kremlin wall.Page 1 Matthias Rust, the pilot of the plane, was described by his mother as ''a quiet young man of wonderful character with a passion for flying.
LEAD: Archibald L. Gillies is president of the World Policy Institute, a public-policy organization.

LEAD: Seventeen games ago, on April 19, which now seems like years ago to the Boston Celtics, they ended their regular season by defeating the Atlanta Hawks. The victory assured the Celtics of playing the final game of any Eastern Conference playoff series at home, where they have been virtually unbeatable.

LEAD: A Washington dispatch last Saturday, quoting Representative Helen Delich Bentley about Kuwaiti oil tankers now flying the American flag, incorrectly described crews of American-registered tankers carrying natural gas between Indonesia and Japan. Representative Bentley says she was misinformed. The crews of the natural gas tankers consist entirely of Americans, not of foreigners with American captains.

LEAD: Every year hundreds of thousands of Americans die or are maimed because of the incompetence or negligence of members of the medical profession -more than were killed or wounded in any year of the Vietnam War. That makes medical negligence one of the nation's worst public health menaces.

LEAD: A busload of pupils from Massachusetts, visiting Manhattan on the hottest day so far this year, got stuck in traffic yesterday and nine of them were sent to the hospital with heat exhaustion after their air-conditioning failed.

LEAD: Refusing to appoint an acknowledged homosexual to a White House commission to study AIDS is the equivalent of having a ''Holocaust memorial without a Jew on it,'' the only avowed homosexual in Congress said today. The lawmaker, Representative Gerry E. Studds, Democrat of Massachusetts, said of reports that President Reagan will not appoint a homosexual to the panel, ''The most charitable characterization of it would be insensitivity.

LEAD: The Standard & Poor's Corporation and Moody's Investors Service Inc. said yesterday that they were considering cutting their bond ratings for the Allegis Corporation and its United Airlines and Hertz rental car subsidiaries because of the company's proposed recapitalization plan.
LEAD: The River Thames is the oldest thoroughfare in London.
LEAD: ''LET us celebrate, let us celebrate our happy, happy loves,'' Henry Purcell, the late Renaissance composer, wrote in a spirited madrigal as the 17th century waned.

LEAD: FOR a brief respite, it appeared that Ocean Beach, which has seen more than its share of controversy over its public-nuisance laws, might finally become just another blase resort community. In this Friday's village election, every candidate, including the recently appointed Mayor, Edward E. Krepela, is running unopposed.
LEAD: Under the heading ''tourist sights,'' a city map here lists ''Qaddafi Mosque.''

LEAD: Citicorp's recent move to add $3 billion to its loan-loss reserves because of its troubled foreign loans has firmed the previously soft prices of money-center bank stocks. Citi's stock jumped more than 7 points after the announcement on May 18.

LEAD: On May 19, 1962, President John F. Kennedy, at a dedication speech in sweltering heat, urged the founders of the Penn South Cooperative - a middle-income housing complex in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan - to ''keep the faith and fight to preserve this desperately needed type of housing for generations to come.

LEAD: The Wedtech Drama's Cast The Wedtech scandal has touched a host of people, from Bronx businessmen to two men with links to the White House. An article with a guide to the role of 21 key figures, page 20.

LEAD: I was greatly disappointed when I read an answer [ Letters to the Long Island Editor, May 3 ] to a recent article on the ''Olympics of the Mind'' competition. Ronnie Cohen of Rego Park seems to feel that there is no need to expand students' minds. Students should just stick to the book and be either right or wrong.
LEAD: The Food Processor Video Cookbook with Jane Freiman Produced and directed by Lee Kraft. Videocraft Classic. 1790 Broadway, New York 10019 (212) 246-9849. 86 minutes. $39.95.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a report last Sunday in ''Going On in the Northeast,'' about the premiere of Julia Newton's play ''Flashpoint,'' incorrectly located the theater for the opening. It is the East Coast Arts Center at Wildcliff, which is in New Rochelle, N.Y.

LEAD: In this summer of the Constitution's bicentennial, Independence Hall may become the single most prominent tourist attraction in the country.
