LEAD: AFTERrrxh six years of strenuous military buildup, the Reagan Administration is within sight of its goal of a 600-ship Navy. More than 550 vessels are on hand, with the rest to be delivered in the next year or so. John F. Lehman Jr., who retired last month as Navy Secretary, summed up the maritime strategy used by the Administration to justify the expense in building such a fleet with the old slogan dispatching the Navy to ''go in harm's way.
LEAD: THEY were sharp-eyed sleuths who would let nothing escape them - not a bracket, not a pilaster, not a single fancy shingle.
LEAD: WHEN Thomas E. Donilon was in high school, he read Hunter Thompson's ''Fear and Loathing on the Campaign Trail'' and fell in love with the drama of Presidential politics.

LEAD: Had Congress known in advance that the Administration planned to sell arms to Iran in exchange for American hostages in Lebanon, Congress would have stopped the disastrous scheme - to the enormous benefit of our foreign policy.
LEAD: Most Americans believe the potential benefits of new genetic technologies to alter biological functions outweigh the risks, according to a poll published by Congress.
LEAD: A Great Lakes sailor is challenging the United States Coast Guard's right to board vessels without warrants or the suspicion of illegal activity on board.

LEAD: In a collapse of negotiations heard round the city, Mayor Koch last week told Donald J. Trump he could not have the tax and zoning concessions he wanted for his proposed Television City on the Upper West Side - not even in return for a share of the profits.

LEAD: RECENTLY I was walking on a country lane with a young neighbor and we saw in the road, soiled by sand and melting snow, five shining pennies. I expected the youth to pick them up, a nickel for free. He looked at me with as much scorn as he dared muster and said, ''What can you buy with a nickel?''

LEAD: The two men who figured in the shakeup at the top of the Soviet Defense Ministry yesterday were professional soldiers who had moved steadily through the ranks of the military to attain the post of Defense Minister.

LEAD: George Gershwin died 50 years ago, leaving behind a legacy that tried to bridge the gap between art music and jazz. Crossover efforts have continued, but rarely do they make their way onto the programs of the standard symphony orchestras. This week, the New York Philharmonic is presenting works by Gershwin and Duke Ellington and the premiere of a work by David Baker titled ''Ellingtones: A Fantasy for Saxophone and Orchestra.

LEAD: YET another disposable product -the paper wedding gown - was introduced a little over a year ago at a dress shop in the Los Angeles area.
LEAD: A Philippine Air Force helicopter on loan to an American movie crew crashed into Manila Bay today, killing four Filipinos and injuring five Filipinos and a West German.

LEAD: Defense Minister Sergei L. Sokolov was relieved of his duties today, and the Soviet military was rebuked by the Politburo after a small civilian plane penetrated Soviet airspace Thursday and flew unimpeded 400 miles to Moscow to land beside the Kremlin.

LEAD: WILLIAM VANDER ZALM, the Dutch-born Premier of British Columbia, exudes the bonhomie of one who knows that he and his fellow citizens have something to celebrate. ''Welcome to British Columbia, God's chosen place in North America,'' he said one day recently, guiding a visitor to a seat in his office in Victoria, the provincial capital.
LEAD: PALE KINGS AND PRINCES A Spenser Novel. By Robert B. Parker. 256 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $15.95.

LEAD: The sculpture of Tom Bills has the formal simplicity and referential richness that has defined some of the best American sculpture of the last 25 years. Almost all the steel and lead pieces in his show at the Anne Plumb Gallery (81 Greene Street, through Saturday) are two to three feet tall. All are frontal and symmetrical.

LEAD: Karin Dewing Morgenstern, a teacher at the Creative Pre-School in Las Vegas, Nev., and Michael Louis Papp, a soil scientist, were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in West Stockbridge, Mass., by the Rev. Leonard J.M. Perreault. The bride is the daughter of Dorothy Morgenstern Thomas of Princeton, N.J., and Lenox, Mass., and the late Oskar Morgenstern, a professor of economics at Princeton and New York Universities.
LEAD: An armed man was arrested today after a nine-hour manhunt that followed a shooting rampage here in which a firefighter was killed and two other men were critically wounded.

LEAD: The long, often grueling hours of interns and residents trained in New York hospitals, which health officials and a grand jury said have resulted in patients' deaths, would be drastically reduced under proposed new state hospital regulations.

Hospital, also in July, were married last evening. Rabbi Rueben R. Levine and Cantor Allen Green performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

LEAD: Tammy Bakker, wife of the former PTL evangelist Jim Bakker, was detained at the Mexican border for an hour and a half Friday while the authorities checked a report that the car she was in had been stolen, the California Highway Patrol said today.

LEAD: Devin-adair Mahony's graphic article ''Coxing Her Way to Victory'' (April 26) quickened my pulse. It accurately portrayed what I have experienced as a Brown oarsman: a highly structured activity in which one pushes oneself beyond one's limitations while striving for excellence. This is a paradigm of the best of American society.

LEAD: June 8, 1944, was the longest on Normandy Beach for the Allied Army invasion and the Nazi holdout, and for the waiting world. The stirring movie version of this historic event tops a worthy batch of war-theme offerings on cable this week.

LEAD: Ever since May 13, when Klaus Barbie walked out on his trial in Lyons, France, for crimes against humanity during World War II, his accusers have demanded the chance to confront the onetime Gestapo official in court. Last week, four veterans of the wartime French Resistance got their wish.

LEAD: WHEN last season ended, the Boston Red Sox and the Baltimore Orioles were separated by 22 1/2 games, the distance from first to last. They are closer to each other this season, but they have traveled in opposite directions. The Red Sox, defending champions of the American League East, have been in sixth place for two weeks, and the Orioles, who finished a dismal seventh last year, have climbed explosively to third place with a four-week record that is even better than the

LEAD: ''PATIENTS are adversaries today,'' said one of the elder practicing physicians at the hospital. ''Take those senior citizens who were lobbying the Capitol in Hartford trying to convince the legislature to compel physicians to accept the Medicare assignment. As they picketed, some were chanting, 'Doctors are crooks.
LEAD: PROCLAMATION: With the Paper Mill Playhouse's rip-roaring revival of Irving Berlin's ''Annie Get Your Gun,'' the celebration of the composer's centennial has officially begun.

LEAD: Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., the yachtsman and diplomat, has warm memories of his family's home in White Plains where he lived first as a boy and then as a husband and father. ''It was quite a wrench to leave it,'' said Mr. Mosbacher, who now lives in Greenwich, Conn.

LEAD: PARIS, May 30 (AP) - Steffi Graf of West Germany, seeded No. 2, survived a scare from Helen Kelesi of Canada and stretched her winning streak to 36 matches to move into the quarterfinals of the French Open with a 7-6, 6-2 victory today.

LEAD: Alison Leigh Hart and Peter Jay Schlosser, architects in San Francisco, were married last evening at Temple B'nai Jeshuran in Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi David J. Seligson, rabbi emeritus of the Central Synagogue in New York, performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor David Summers.

LEAD: The marriage of Cindy Sernau and Bruce Gilburne, graduates of the University of Hartford, took place last night at the Tammy Brook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J. Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Sernau of White Plains and Mr. and Mrs. Richard Gilburne of Short Hills, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla.

LEAD: THE 911 emergency telephone system long used by New York City residents is coming to Westchester, according to county leaders, and in an improved mode that will let police and civilian dispatchers identify the calling number and address immediately.
LEAD: The dominant use of white models in real-estate advertisments is increasingly coming under attack by open-housing groups and public-interest lawyers in New York and elsewhere.

LEAD: IT IS TIME ONCE AGAIN TO CLEAN OUT THE MIS-cellaneous folder, in which the thrifty critic squirrels away provocative letters, offbeat news clippings, particularly remarkable press releases and other ephemera for possible consideration as future column material. Sad to say, most such nutmeats seem to lose pertinence when stored in this way and resist expansion to serious lengths.
LEAD: FILM FLAM Essays on Hollywood. By Larry McMurtry. 159 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

LEAD: Sri Lankan armed forces pressed a major offensive against Tamil insurgent strongholds in the north today, amid reports that hundreds of people had died in fighting and bombardment in the last five days.

LEAD: ''Get thee to Iowa,'' political soothsayers advised Democratic candidates in the aftermath of the funny thing that happened to Gary Hart on his way to the White House. I have a better suggestion: Stay away.

LEAD: The heat and humidity might have been unbearable for the average New Yorker yesterday, but it didn't seem to discourage the 8,356 women who participated in the 16th L'eggs Mini Marathon in Central Park.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: In the grand scheme of things, skirt lengths are not important (''Why Short Is Chic,'' by Carrie Donovan, Fashion View, April 26). Short may be chic for those women who have nothing better to do than lunch at Le Cirque. (Although I, for one, find scrawny middle-aged women in mid-thigh creations pitiful.) However, in the business world, the length of a woman's skirt is important.

LEAD: Richard M. Nixon regarded most reporters as enemies long before the Watergate scandal engulfed his Presidency and ordered his aides to treat them with contempt.
LEAD: The air is filled with fret about ordinances on smoking in public places and court appeals on such rules.

LEAD: THIS WEEK, AT THE annual Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago, thousands of Americans are getting their first earful of DAT - Digital Audio Tape. What they are hearing is by far the best home recording method ever devised - a system greatly superior to the familiar audio cassettes, which it may eventually replace.

LEAD: THE Environmental Protection Agency has given its blessing to three huge development projects in downtown Brooklyn even though they are likely to worsen air pollution at a time when it already exceeds Federal standards.

LEAD: A brief article on the theater page in some copies of the Arts and Leisure section today about the acting teacher Sanford Meisner omits a name from the list of surviving members of the Group Theater of the 1930's who are still active as teachers. The list should include Stella Adler.
LEAD: IN AN experimental arts program at Madison High School this semester, 16-year-old Erik Morsink, a junior, wrote his first play, ''Tides.''

LEAD: NO APPLE FOR TEACHER When Mark Shechner gave a college course in the contemporary Jewish-American novel several years ago, his students treated him to a rude surprise. This is from ''After the Revolution: Studies in the Contemporary Jewish American Imagination'' (Indiana University).

LEAD: SOME HOUSES BE-come legends because of where they are; others, because of the personalities who have lived in them. The house shown on these pages is special for both reasons. For 30 years, the late actress Katharine Cornell summered on this 18-acre peninsula in Martha's Vineyard. Named Chip Chop to conform with East Chop and West Chop, two other points on the island, the property consists of a shingled main house, two adjoining guest cottages, a pool and a cabana.
LEAD: THERE are no two ways about it: Year-rounders are year-rounders. Summer people are summer people. And never the twain shall meet.

LEAD: IN rrwhat one political consultant called a ''festival of consultants,'' Wallace Wilkinson, a millionaire businessman, defeated former Gov. John Y. Brown Jr. in Kentucky's Democratic gubernatorial primary.

LEAD: SUMMER vacations are coming, but before they get here, a number of exceptionally gifted students are getting their chances in the spotlight.

LEAD: If you're one of those who respond to the Byzantine kind of espionage story, A CONSPIRACY OF ANGELS by Frank Ross (Atheneum, $18.95) is made for you. It is one of those wheels-within-wheels clockwork pieces of work. It has a lot of action but absolutely no hysterics or heroics. It also happens to be exceedingly well written, full of sharply defined, believable characterizations and a kind of 1960's
LEAD: SPRING on the East End always brings a game of restaurant roulette for diners.

LEAD: Putting aside Dwight Gooden's baseball statistics that have made him a superstar; putting aside his brushes with the law; putting aside his connections with drugs, guns and women, Dwight Gooden will be greeted with the most thunderous applause yet to be heard in Shea Stadium as he strides to the mound for his first game since being suspended.

LEAD: Morton Hunt's useful article ''A Common-Sense Guide to Health Insurance'' (May 3) needs to be considered in this larger context: Why does the world's wealthiest nation indulge in a health system so chaotic, expensive and inefficient that such guides are necessary? Moreover, nearly one in four Americans has either no insurance or such poor coverage that a major illness may bankrupt them.

LEAD: An Atlas Centaur rocket and Navy communications satellite identical with those that were destroyed in March after being struck by lightning will be launched on July 24, the National Aeonautics and Space Administraton announced Friday. On March 26, technicians had to destroy a rocket carrying a satellite when it veered off course.
LEAD: Joe and Phil Niekro have to stop meeting like this.

LEAD: The time has come, in the wink of a computer screen, to redefine the romance of sail. For centuries, sailing meant following unpredictable winds to little-known places. In his 1926 book, ''The Romance of Navigation,'' Master Mariner W. B. Whall relived an era ''when the seaman from stormy Europe could find fairylands, where soft breezes blew the year round, where the harsh teeth of winter were never felt, where strange races were found, with gold, spices and pearls.

LEAD: At the Beacon Hill Friends House in Boston yesterday, Sarah Paula Brickman, assistant to the Director of Policy for the city of Boston, was married to Christopher Taylor Gant under the care of the Beacon Hill Monthly Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends.
LEAD: It may be the writer's job ''. . . to seek out the truth,'' but who wants to know? Leave some heroes untarnished for us to foolishly admire. ROBERT F. SCHULTZ Johnstown, N.Y.

LEAD: FIRST I did the arithmetic. M. F. K. Fisher was in her mid-30's when she started the translation. She must have been reading, writing, drinking and dreaming the man. It's no wonder he captured her heart, that she fell in love with him ''that way'': the way you do when you're married and have two daughters and no time to carry on an affair properly.
LEAD: A SLIM woman of about 20 approached Bill Ravenal on West Farms Road in the Bronx a week ago and asked him if he could rent her an apartment.

LEAD: MORE than a year has passed since that chilling night Red was shot to death by a group of teen-agers. He was attempting to stop them from robbing three other youths of their leather bomber jackets.

LEAD: A woman whom the police call the ''crack queen of Washington Square'' was arrested late Friday in a raid on her Greenwich Village apartment that culminated a three-month undercover investigation.

LEAD: THErr concept of ''inclusionary zoning,'' which is aimed at enabling low-income families to live in high-income neighborhoods, was recently incorporated into New York City's zoning regulations. In certain areas, developers will be allowed to build luxury apartment towers as much as 20 percent higher than would otherwise be allowed.
LEAD: At Grace Episcopal Church in New York yesterday, Grace Bradlee Bingham and Michael Thomas Ott were married by the Rev. Harold Elliott Barrett, an uncle of the bride.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Horowitz of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Eve Horowitz to David Leibowitz, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Morton Leibowitz, also of New York. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: In Lexington, Va., on the trim campus of Washington and Lee University crowned with its classic white colonnade, students still go by the gentleman's code of honor. At the nearby Gothic barracks of Virginia Military Institute, cadets still bow to rigid regulations and cut an impeccable figure in the ritual dress parades.

LEAD: WHEN International Business Machines and Pepsico announced in the early 1980's that they would build giant new office buildings in Somers, many residents predicted gloomily that the town would lose its rural atmosphere.

LEAD: In the many neighborhoods of New York City, there are ''blockwatchers'' and ''graffiti busters,'' people fighting - some inside the system, some outside it - to maintain decent housing and drive away drug dealers, to beautify streets begging for greenery and make the city just a little more livable.
LEAD: Although Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's term does not end for five months, a struggle to succeed him is already under way, and it may alter power lineups within Japan's ruling party.

LEAD: THE philatelic market is enjoying a resurgence reminiscent of the mid-1970's. Buyers are flocking to stamp auctions and competition for scarce stamps and covers is heating up. Prices are encouraging dealers to predict further increases.
LEAD: ''LA BAYADERE'' as staged by Natalia Makarova for American Ballet Theater, is exactly the kind of full-evening grandiose 19th-century ballet American audiences seem to crave.

LEAD: A collection of notes scrawled by John F. Kennedy when his voice gave out in the 1960 Presidential campaign is being offered for sale by a handwriting expert on behalf of a former Kennedy assistant who had salvaged them from wastebaskets.

LEAD: Jean Antoine Houdon's ''Painted Plaster Bust of Thomas Jefferson,'' the oldest surviving version of the most famous portrait bust of the statesman, was sold yesterday at Christie's for $2.86 million, an auction record for pre-20th-century sculpture and the highest price ever paid for a work by the artist.

LEAD: Floriane Chiady Wu, a third-year medical student at the State University of New York Health Science Center at Brooklyn, and Dr. Paul Tornetta 3d, who received an M.D. degree this month from the center, were married yesterday at the Post Chapel of the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y.
LEAD: Princeton University has received a $5 million pledge for the construction of a new computer science building, the school has announced. The pledge came from an alumnus who was not identified.

LEAD: The Soviet air defense system, which failed to intercept the single-engine Cessna that flew from Helsinki to Red Square on Thursday, is enormously extensive, with forests of missiles, thousands of warplanes and more than 1,500,000 men and women either deployed or on call.
LEAD: Members of Congress have stepped in to head off potential violence in the East Coast's lucrative sea scallop industry.

LEAD: WHILE its archives are filled with the names of visionary inventors like Edison and Bell, the United States Patent and Trademark Office is itself a paper-shuffling bureaucracy - one that ought to be the safest place imaginable for a Government functionary.

LEAD: The way the new immigration law is interpreted by its enforcers is making it hard for foreign students who are illegal aliens to gain amnesty. A result, according to lawyers who specialize in immigration cases, is that many of the best-educated aliens stand a poor chance of staying in this country.

LEAD: As the nation celebrates the creation of its Constitution, many American blacks are uneasily questioning the extent to which they should honor the Founding Fathers, a number of whom were slaveowners.
LEAD: NINE families in the Meriden-Wallingford area are taking part in a program to give homeless pregnant teen-agers a place to stay before and after they give birth.
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 31 food establishments cited for violating the health code.
LEAD: Beginning tomorrow, employers who hire illegal aliens are subject to fines and possibly even imprisonment. That's what it says on paper anyway.

LEAD: Allison Meder Eckardt, a daughter of Mrs. Harold J. Eckardt of Somers, N.Y., and the late Mr. Eckardt, was married yesterday to George Macgill Ledes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John George Ledes of Katonah, N.Y. The Rev. Stephen M. Bolle performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Katonah.

LEAD: On May 2, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology men's second frosh heavyweight boat raced against Dartmouth. On the way to Hanover, our coach passed out copies of Devin-adair Mahony's article to the rowers and to me, the coxswain. He called it the best article about crew that he'd read, and felt it showed the intensity and commitment you need to win.

LEAD: MANY TRADITIONAL AMERICAN pastimes are excuses to eat outdoors. Open-air concerts mean raiding the gourmet takeout shop. Fireworks on the beach require grilled hamburgers. And there are even those avid baseball fans who admit, when pressed, that they go to the ballpark as much for the hot dogs and beer as for the game.

LEAD: Primerica is to buy Smith Barney for $750 million, making a services business the mainstay of the company that used to be American Can and had been concentrated in industry. Gerald Tsai Jr., Primerica's chief executive, was a top Wall Street executive for many years, thus returns to the investment business.

LEAD: The paradox of Europe these days is that it invented science and is spending twice as much on research and development as Japan, but it is still lagging behind in the high technology race to the future.
LEAD: PLEASE stop comparing AIDS and the black plague.

LEAD: Eleven former college football players, seven deceased college players, a retired coach and two deceased coaches were enshrined in ceremonies Friday night at the National Football Foundation's College Football Hall of Fame. The Hall conducted no enshrinement program last year, so Friday night's program was intended to cover the last two incoming classes of former college stars.

LEAD: It's distressing to think that so many Americans are uncomfortable with the idea that homosexuals might be so masculine as to be unrecognizable. When will they realize that gays might be their doctors, lawyers, sports heroes, garage mechanics or brothers? One woman was quoted as saying that Rock Hudson couldn't be gay because he was so masculine and enjoyed watching football, an infallible measure of heterosexuality, to be sure!

Secord, the coordinator of several covert operations, and illustrated the bickering that surrounded the secret programs. Highlights of the week's developments follow.

LEAD: Fictional characters have been known to haunt, amuse, teach and infuriate their creators. Family ties are strong, even when some of the relatives are made up. The Book Review asked a number of fiction writers and playwrights: Which of the characters you have created has had the greatest effect on your own life?

LEAD: ONE day last month, a petrol bomb was thrown through the window of a car carrying Jewish settlers near Qalqilya village on the Israeli-occupied West Bank, killing a woman and injuring her husband and four young children. After the attack, there was a chorus of indignation from within Israeli society that produced two demands: that more Jewish settlers be moved into the West Bank, and that the orange trees that line some of the roads be cut down, to make the roads more secure for Jewish settlers.
LEAD: The Boston Garden worked its charm for the Celtics again today.
LEAD: THERE'S only one thing worse than not having a job. It's your son's not having one.

LEAD: CONGRESS is considering legislation that would restrict trade with countries that do not respect certain ''internationally recognized workers' rights,'' such as the right to bargain collectively, a minimum wage, occupational safety and health standards and others. In this misguided approach, countries that do not live up to the standards we set for them could face tariffs, quotas or the loss of special trading privileges.

LEAD: LOVER. Significant Other. Steady companion or domestic partner. The search for a comfortable way to describe a mate who is not your spouse goes on, as increasing numbers of couples choose to live together without benefit of marriage.

LEAD: Since 1969, the Dwight D. Eisenhower Society has been quietly working to keep the memory of the late five-star general and two-term President vivid by awarding student scholarships and celebrating his birthday every Oct. 14 at Gettysburg College near his beloved farm in Gettysburg, Pa.

LEAD: Prime Minister Lee Han Key apologized to the nation today for the police torture killing of a dissident student in January, but he warned opposition groups that the Government would not tolerate any attempt to embarrass it further.

LEAD: It's on to Wisconsin for Donna E. Shalala, president of Hunter College. The outspoken educator was named last week as the next Chancellor of the University of Wisconsin at Madison, whose enrollment of 44,000 is more than twice that of Hunter. Wisconsin, a major research institution, attracted $208 million in research grants in 1985, dwarfing Hunter's $11.5 million a year in research financing.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: BILL PHILLIPS says he has ''absolutely no doubt'' that a world-record largemouth bass will be caught within a few years from a small farm pond. But he argues that it will be a pond that is professionally managed by trained biologists.

LEAD: In addition to H.M.O.'s and P.P.O.'s, there is another ingredient in the alphabet soup - I.P.A. H.M.O.'s, an Individual Practice Association H.M.O. Unlike the staff-model H.M.O.'s discussed in the article, I.P.A. H.M.O. members can continue to use community physicians who participate in the plan.

LEAD: THE Arizona Board of Regents has offered lucrative multiyear contracts to several coaches at the University of Arizona and Arizona State. John Cooper, the Arizona State football coach, was the big winner with an offer of a five-year pact worth $96,600 a year, while the school's basketball coach, Steve Patterson, was offered $79,000 a year for three years.

LEAD: Every spring when the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus comes through Baltimore, ''the Greatest Show on Earth'' brings the elephants down to the Lexington Market for lunch, celebrating what the 205-year-old landmark is all about - eating.

LEAD: It's no secret that the tiny southeast Virginia town of Smithfield produces a particularly lusty ham, for the pungent, smoky evidence smacks your nose as soon as you cross the town line. The reputation of this most distinctive of country hams has kept it in demand by both outsiders and locals for centuries, from Colonial days when settlers discovered that salt curing and prolonged aging would keep pork almost indefinitely.

LEAD: BEFORE the morning mists have cleared, when the light falling around Paris is still soft and diffused, an American woman can often be found strolling the shrub-studded paths of Versailles. Map in hand, cameras over her shoulder, she pauses at a statue turned a certain way, or at a particular juncture of foliage and sky, and she takes a picture.
LEAD: Five years after the last downtown department store in this city closed, three developers have announced plans for a $300 million retail, office and hotel complex in the city's center.
LEAD: The only regular starting pitcher on the Mets who has been healthy while the rest of the staff was collapsing is Ron Darling. And he hasn't won a game in five weeks.

LEAD: IT'S time someone revealed the harsh truth about new swimsuits. I adore every tiny ritual of spring except buying a new swimsuit. There is, of course, the usual disgruntled acceptance of winter's contributions to one's figure. Like others, I, too, stand in the dressing room and resolve to diet. I then rush home for a soothing bowl of ice cream to prop up my damaged ego.

LEAD: A WEEK after he lost his World Boxing Association light-heavyweight title, Marvin Johnson said he did not expect to fight again. LEAD: A LITTLE BIT OF HISTORY WAS made earlier this month - and a little bit was resurrected, too -when ''On Social Grease,'' a 1975 work by the Conceptual artist Hans Haacke, was sold for $90,000. It was the first time that a work by Mr. Haacke had ever come up at auction, and the transaction, part of the sale of the Gilman Paper Company collection of Minimal and Conceptual art, set a price record for the artist.

LEAD: WITH its Revolutionary-era homes, strand of elms along Main Street and Town Green, Litchfield is one of the state's most beautiful towns and, seemingly, the quintessence of a small Connecticut community.

LEAD: THErr concept of ''inclusionary zoning,'' which is aimed at enabling low-income families to live in high-income neighborhoods, was recently incorporated into New York City's zoning regulations. In certain areas, developers will be allowed to build luxury apartment towers as much as 20 percent higher than would otherwise be allowed.

LEAD: AT the parents' meetings of my children's cooperative day-care centers, the No. 1 perennial complaint usually centers on cleaning. ''Why can't we send our maid''; ''I never clean my own house - my time is too valuable''; ''Why don't we just raise the tuition and hire someone'' are the oft-heard comments.

LEAD: RESES PHARMACY stands on a tree-shaded block of clapboard houses down from the Wawa Food Market in the center of Pleasantville, a drowsy town of about 8,000 on the outskirts of Atlantic City. The store maintains a dim, cool atmosphere, perfumed with a slight medicinal scent. When you walk in, you're beset by a great many things: catnip, Spanish olives, toothpaste, corn remedies, beach chairs, curling irons, alcohol prep swabs and garden hoses, not to mention the obligatory racks of greeting cards.
LEAD: FOR CENTURIES, Indians and European settlers canoed to get from Point A to Point B; today, people canoe for pleasure and to explore natural areas that are inaccessible any other way.

LEAD: WHEN IT COMES TO THE exact date of their birth, neither a beautiful woman nor a great city is on oath. In the one case, it's none of our business. In the other, we don't care. If it suits the Mayor of West Berlin to say that Berlin was founded exactly 750 years ago, who are we to spoil the sport?
LEAD: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV is making the Germans nervous - East Germans and West Germans alike.

LEAD: Charles Eliot Pierce Jr. has no experience in museum management, but, as a lifelong scholar, he figures he can learn. LEAD: Dr. Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, a former chief United States delegate to the United Nations, withdrew Friday as the commencement speaker at Lafayette University here after faculty members protested plans to award her an honorary degree.

LEAD: Along a 30-mile strand of sand on Delaware's Atlantic Coast is Rehoboth Beach. If you've never been in this neck of the woods, the first thing you should know is that the woods in question is a pine forest, one that, in the northern residential areas, extends to the very edge of the broad, white sand beach.

LEAD: BUD CLARK, the tavern owner who became Mayor of this Oregon city in 1984, pedals his bicycle to City Hall most days, but he seldom draws so much as a second glance from pasers-by. That is because Portland has restricted cars and turned its downtown over toe pedestrians. The result of that and several other zoning decisions has been a dramatic revitalization.

LEAD: THE seven-story Grand Central Post Office, at 45th and Lexington, is one of those older, grimy midtown buildings lost among taller structures. But it is also among the last remaining buildings of the original ''terminal city'' complex around Grand Central Station. Although the details are not yet definite, a development group expects to begin work this year on a 25- to 30-story addition on top of the postal building.

LEAD: Mets fans will doubtless bestow a rousing hero's welcome to Dwight Gooden upon his return to the baseball diamond. And that will be a sad development. Not the rousing part, mind you, the hero part.

LEAD: DURING THE YEARS when I lived many miles from my hometown of Highland Park, N.J., I generally visited once around Thanksgiving and once during the summer, when the most wonderful listlessness settled over the place.

LEAD: GLORIA SWANSON, BEING interviewed in the 1970's, recalls how more than 50 years earlier she insisted that the director Cecil B. De Mille let her enter a lion's cage for a scene in the silent movie ''Male and Female.'' Later at a preview, Swanson overheard a fan ask, after watching the star under the menacing paw of the animal: ''I wonder which one is stuffed.

LEAD: HANDS on hips, Tim Ward thoughtfully surveyed the Danbury mansion's half-papered foyer. Painters, movers and frenetic interior designers darted about. Wrapping paper crackled in the drawing room off the foyer, followed by the whoosh of plastic as an antique French sofa, newly reupholstered in a turquoise-and-off-white 18th-century documentary toile de Jouy, was carefully unwrapped by Carole Winer, a designer and the owner of Country Loft Antiques in

LEAD: THERE ARE SOME WOMEN WHO, at the faintest whiff of a change in fashion, chop off their hair, bleach it white, spray it straight up or slick it straight back. Others stubbornly hold on to their blunt, shoulder-length haircuts regardless of the current trends. And then there are the adapters, those who make minor adjustments to bring them up-to-date.
LEAD: The Rev. Pat Robertson plans to pass up Federal matching funds for his Republican Presidential bid, freeing his campaign from spending limits in the primary elections, according to his aides.

LEAD: MIDWAY in Thursday's opening-night performance of her three-week Carnegie Hall engagement, Liza Minnelli struck an uncharacteristically formal pose. Arriving onstage in a sumptuous burgundy-colored gown by Halston, the singer positioned herself between a string quartet and a harpist. Ignoring the 47-piece orchestra behind her, she proceeded to offer an amusing ''highbrow'' chamber interpretation of the Al Jolson favorite, ''Toot Toot Tootsie.
LEAD: MISERY By Stephen King. 310 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

LEAD: A CAVALCADE of musicals, spanning five decades, from vintage rarities by George Gershwin (1924) and Kurt Weill (1943) at East Haddam's Goodspeed Opera House to standard 1950's and 60's favorites by Rodgers and Hammerstein, Frank Loesser and Jule Styne at New Fairfield's Candlewood Playhouse, dominate the state's summer theater season.

LEAD: The North Carolina Maritime Museum in Beaufort is offering weeklong courses for school-age children this summer. Families vacationing in the area can send their children to the museum for three hours a day for the programs, ranging from fishing trips to stalking wild foods to underwater biology classes.
LEAD: The Oilers played beautifully and opened a 3-games-to-1 advantage in their quest for a third Stanley Cup, but the Flyers played rough and fought back to tie the series and force a seventh game.

LEAD: Theatrical, who lost the Breeders' Cup Turf by just a neck to Manila last November, benefited from that rival's absence to score a 1 3/4-length victory over Dance of Life in the $194,100 Red Smith Handicap on the turf yesterday at Belmont.

LEAD: After nine years as an astronaut, Sally K. Ride has decided to undertake more earthly pursuits. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced last week that Dr. Ride, the first American woman to go into orbit, would leave the space agency in August to take a Stanford University fellowship on arms control and national security policy.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: President Reagan will be heading to the economic summit meeting in Venice next week amid expectations that have been lowered by his own domestic difficulties and by economic and political uncertainties in the six other industrialized democracies that will take part, Administration officials say.

LEAD: Vice President Bush vigorously defended President Reagan's policy in the Persian Gulf today and warned against ''faint-hearted voices'' who would have the United States weaken its military commitment in the region.

LEAD: About 80 children exposed to meningitis in an unlicensed East Harlem foster care center have begun a course of treatment to protect them from the contagious disease, New York City officials said yesterday.

LEAD: The Administration in Washington is opposed to making sure that a representative of the homosexual community is named to a panel to study the AIDS plague and what it might mean for the whole country. It shows vividly the people who run the Government simply have not faced reality.
LEAD: Frank Carlson, a former Governor, Senator and United States Representative from Kansas, but above all a farmer, died yesterday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Concordia, Kan. He was 94 years old.

Testa Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., and Bar Harbor, Me., and the late Eleanor Moran Testa. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony at St.
LEAD: Unfortunately, Gooden will receive a standing ovation upon his return. MICK FALTON Smithtown, L.I.
LEAD: GARY HART AND I HAD FEW things in common besides being occasional novelists of a political sort and believing that he might make a good President of the United States.

LEAD: What was all this mystique about the Boston Celtics in Boston Garden? That's what the Detroit Pistons wanted to know as they arrived in the old barn at North Station yesterday for the seventh-game showdown.

LEAD: While much attention has been paid to the problems of battered women who have taken refuge in shelters across Massachusetts, about two-thirds of the residents of those shelters are children. For them, the services are few. Of the 30 shelters in the state, which are supported by state and Federal funds, only about 10 have even one staff member expressly for children, according to Gayle A.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: IN most cases, dampness in a basement is due to poor drainage of surface water around the outside of the house, or to excess accumulation of ground water in the soil around the outside of the foundation. To make sure that surface water runs off rapidly when it rains, or when accumulations of snow start to melt, it is essential that the ground be properly graded so that it slopes away from the house in all directions.

LEAD: FEW industry groups have displayed more erratic stock market behavior than the biotechnology companies. After last year's swing from favor to neglect, the shares of most companies in the industry sprang back strongly in the first few months of 1987. The upswing, in large part, can be attributed to the growing visibility of new products - many of them getting human clinical trials - with potential markets that analysts put in the hundreds of millions of dollars.

LEAD: WHEN her family is the host to a Fresh Air Fund child for two weeks each summer, Corrine Gould, who works part-time in real estate sales, gets a chance to see her surroundings through different eyes.

IN the late 1970's Beth B and Scott B began making Super-8, home-movie spectacles for the entertainment of their friends in the downtown music and art scenes. Five years ago they went all-out for their 16-millimeter send-up of Big Business, ''Vortex,'' which was shown at the New York Film Festival. Now, on her own, Beth B has directed ''Salvation,'' a comparatively ambitious (35-millimeter), mini-budgeted satire of television evangelists so topical that it could have been made yesterday, which is also the way it looks.

LEAD: The annual spring concerts of the Duke Ellington Society have traditionally been a yearly renewal of the joys of Duke Ellington's music, both the familiar and the unfamiliar, frequently spiced with arcane tidbits. This year's concert, the 26th in the series, will be played by Loren Schoenberg's 17-piece orchestra with the cornetist Ruby Braff, the pianist Dick Katz and the trombonist Britt Woodman, a veteran of the Ellington band, as guests.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: DEMOCRATS and Republicans will go to the polls Tuesday to elect the candidates who will represent their parties in the coming fall legislative elections, when all 120 seats in the Senate and Assembly will be contested.

LEAD: PERSONAL saving is the part of your paycheck that is left over after taxes and all the bills are paid. For most Americans struggling to make ends meet, it will come as little surprise that saving amounts to a small share of income. But the 2.5 percent of after-tax income it represented in 1986 was well below the average of 6.6 percent for the last five years and the lowest level in the postwar era.

LEAD: BOAT RACES A series of eight races organized by the Norwalk Islands Sailing Fleet, an informal group of sailing enthusiasts, begins at 11 A.M. Saturday off Cockenoe Island. Any performance-handicap-rated boat may enter at a fee of $25 for the series. ''We go all around the islands - 10 to 17 miles - and we have one all-night race to City Island in New York and back, starting at 7 P.M.,'' said Michael Brown, chairman of the fleet.

LEAD: The greasy antique machines that were used until two months ago to make drills at a huge brick factory here are now the subject of an intense legal battle, along with the rest of the factory's contents.

LEAD: To the Editor: As your headline says, Linz, Austria, does ''Cast a Spell'' (Travel, April 5). An interesting industrial-historic city, it and its suburbs straddle the Danube with economic and tourist bustle. Approaching it, as my husband and I did in 1981, by traversing the length of Austria from west to east, we were infused by visions of Alpine farms, breathtaking mountain scenery and some of the finest hiking and skiing centers in the world.

LEAD: THEY are just the right size to tuck into a suitcase as house gifts - especially if the recipients of the colorful tin boxes are either fans of diner food or owners of new cars. Made in England, the illustrated boxes are filled with items that can be especially handy. Shaped like an old-fashioned diner, and illustrated with vintage cars parked outside, the 11-inch long Deluxe Diner Open All Night box includes a Rand McNally map of the United States, three Band-Aids, one moist towelette, four Alka-Seltzer tablets, two Anacin tablets, a package of tissues, a packet of

LEAD: When shopping for a supplement to Medicare, you have to be careful of what type of surgical coverage is provided. Most plans will cover only the remaining 20 percent of the Medicare schedule. A good supplement to Medicare will cover the full balance of the surgical fee over the Medicare allowance, subject to a reasonable-and-customary provision.

LEAD: A BLOODIED TOE INSIDE HER FIRST PAIR OF toe shoes is a welcome symbol of initiation for a young ballerina, just as it is considered a sign of good luck for a professional. It is the initial stage in the development of the corns and calluses that are a prerequisite for a career in toe shoes. Herein lies one of the many choices dancers must make through the years about whether or not this is a career they want.

LEAD: TODAY being the eve of the June mating season, a few words about wedding photography are in order. If you ever have been seen so much as holding a camera, chances are you'll be asked by someone to take pictures at his or her nuptials. You can be a nice person and give it a try, or you can follow my advice:

LEAD: TOMORROW, IT BEGINS. THE RELEASE OF the Beatles' ''Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band'' as a compact disk (Capitol CDP 7 46442 2), exactly 20 years after the album appeared, will usher in the anniversary of the ''Summer of Love,'' when the hippie spirit seized Western culture. There'll be reminiscences, chin-pulling and milestone-mongering as the calendar turns for such 1967 events as the Monterey Pop Festival and the founding of Rolling Stone magazine.

LEAD: THE last time a do-it-yourself street fashion captured the youthful imagination was during the famous Ripped Sweatshirt era several years ago. Now we seem to be heading into the Great Button period. Imagine, if you will, legions of young folk, needle and thread in hand, sewing buttons onto almost everything: jackets, vests, shirts, collars, skirts, hats, even the soles of boots.

LEAD: Despite advice from naval commanders in the Persian Gulf that relatively small frigates are ideal for escorting merchant vessels, the Pentagon is likely to send larger, more sophisticated cruisers there, according to Government officials familiar with planning for the operation.
LEAD: Cab Calloway and His Orchestra, 1935-1950 With Jonah Jones, Shad Collins, Milt Hinton. Jazz Classics, P.O. Box 86, Rahway, N.J. 07065. 30 minutes. $19.95.

LEAD: In much the same way as the top executives at Levi Strauss are reputed to wake in a cold sweat each morning wondering whether anyone is going to want their products anymore, booksellers must wonder whether the apparently insatiable demand for travel books will suddenly come to an end, leaving them with enough stock to build a chain of covers from Kansas to Katmandu.

LEAD: Japan's defense chief said today that he had assured Chinese officials there was ''no possibility'' of Japan's again becoming a military threat in Asia, despite efforts to strengthen its military.

LEAD: Whether the Rev. Jerry Falwell is trying to steal the PTL ministry, as Jim Bakker says, or to save it, there is more at stake here for the American evangelical movement than an air-conditioned doghouse or gold-plated bathroom fixtures.

LEAD: ELECTRONIC MUSIC, ONCE feared and misunderstood, is all around us these days - in film scores, commercial jingles, New Age dabblings and certain varieties of rock and jazz. For the composers working in these fields, the latest generation of sophisticated digital synthesizers provides everything from simple percussion accompaniments to almost-convincing orchestral timbres and outlandish effects.

Mrs. Poppe is supervisor of telemarketing at the Direct Marketing Association in New York.

LEAD: When the Arkansas Legislature convenes in special session here next week, there is more on the line than Gov. Bill Clinton's plea that lawmakers find some extra money for the state's ailing welfare and prison systems.

LEAD: The prime rate's three-month climb - to 8.25 percent from 7.50 percent - is dragging most consumer loan rates with it. But interest rates on bank credit cards have continued to fall, and will probably drop even further.

LEAD: THE vultures are circling again. A television network plans to turn a local tragedy into big bucks. NBC bought the screenplay rights for a miniseries based on a forthcoming book about the Marshall murder case. (Robert O. Marshall, a former insurance salesman, was sentenced to death in March 1986 after having been convicted of conspiring to murder his wife.

LEAD: THE Supreme Court's landmark decision last week upholding ''preventive detention'' of allegedly dangerous defendants was more a milestone than a surprise. It capped a 15-year trend in which the Court has sided more and more with prosecutors against criminal defendants.

LEAD: SOFT-SHELL crabs are at their peak now. These are not, as some people think, a separate species, but are blue crabs that have molted their hard shells. They are at their best at this time of year, when the water is warm. They settle in the marshes, where they are held in ''floats'' until they molt.

LEAD: AS Alysheba tries for the crown that eluded his father, horseplayers fondly push the memory button labeled ''Affirmed vs. Alydar.'' And once again, thoroughbred racing's most persistent adversaries come charging through the stretch.

LEAD: THE caribou that were trucked into Maine from Newfoundland last winter have started bearing a new generation that biologists hope will one day return the once common species to the wilds of Maine.

LEAD: Joy Jacobson, finance director of the Democratic Senate Campaign Committee, was married in Middleburg, Va., yesterday to Gerald Felix Warburg 2d, foreign policy and defense adviser to Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California. The Rev. John Thomas of St. Albans Episcopal Church in Annandale, Va., performed the ceremony at the home of Mrs.

LEAD: To the Editor: As a photojournalist, I travel a great deal and always have my camera and films checked at airport security gates. To save time and to avoid possible damage by radiation, I carry opened and unopened film in a clear plastic food storage bag and I ask the guard to hand the film bag and camera over to the other side.

LEAD: A rough concrete-block and brick addition is rising behind and atop a graceful five-story limestone town house at 126 East 73d Street between Lexington and Park Avenues - a common occurrence in Manhattan, where building owners try to benefit from every square foot of their properties.

LEAD: Golf Coe Leads by a Stroke: Dawn Coe of Canada shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead over Kathryn Young after three rounds of the $275,000 Corning Classic on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association tour at Corning, N.Y.. Coe, a four-year tour veteran, carded four birdies on the back nine and finished at 203 after 54 holes.

LEAD: The author Joan Didion delivered the commencement address at Bard College yesterday, where 163 Bachelor of Arts and 12 Master of Fine Arts degrees were conferred. Ceremonies were held on the main campus lawn in Annandale-on-the-Hudson, N.Y.

LEAD: At the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Chapel at Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J., yesterday, Jane Kamensky and Dennis J. Scannell Jr. were married by the Rev. Thomas P. Lipnick. Ann Kamensky was her sister's maid of honor, and Michael G. Scannell was his brother's best man.

LEAD: At St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in Wilmette, Ill., yesterday Laurette Irene Angsten, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Angsten of Winnetka, Ill., was married to Ralph Wade Kittle Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kittle of Keswick, Va. The Rev. Edward Harnett performed the ceremony.
LEAD: ITEM: Jack O'Dwyer's Newsletter, the bible of the public relations profession, lists huge increases in billings at P.R. agencies this year.

LEAD: TURNING A NOVEL INTO A play can be a difficult operation - a good deal more difficult than those who perform it often seem to realize. But it is hardly something you can object to in principle. If you did, you would have to draw the line at ''Othello,'' which is based on a story by the 16th-century Italian novelist Giraldi Cinthio, to say nothing of ''Measure for Measure'' (also based on Cinthio), or ''The Winter's Tale,'' which has a plot lifted from a prose romance by Robert Greene, or ''As You Like It,'' which is adapted from a story by Thomas

LEAD: TWO PERIOD JEWELRY collections formed more than 50 years apart by two quite different men -Henry Walters, a turn-of-the-century Baltimore financier and railroad magnate, and Benjamin Zucker, a New York gem dealer -are being presented together here at the Walters Art Gallery in one of the largest and most comprehensive exhibitions of historical baubles and bangles seen in this country in recent years.

LEAD: WHEN Henry Jones, known as ''Cavendish,'' accidentally invented duplicate 130 years ago in a effort to compare the skill of whist players, he had no idea where it would lead. What it led to earlier this month was more than 75,000 players competing at one time around the world.

LEAD: The search has begun for a successor to Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow as Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

LEAD: ''IF you find something you're good at and work hard at it, there's no reason why you can't do it,'' said Edwin I. Gersh of Huntington. ''There's absolutely nothing in this world that you cannot achieve if you try hard enough to achieve it.''

LEAD: Reduction in Service Question: I have an apartment in a building that was recently converted to a co-op but I elected to continue as a rent-controlled tenant. For as long as I have lived in the building - more than 30 years - garbage has been collected dailyfrom the stairwells on each floor.

LEAD: The Boston Phoenix, an alternative weekly newspaper, distributed a ''safer sex'' guide and condom in each copy of its paper today. Stephen M. Mindich, publisher of the 125,000-circulation newspaper, said the move was intended to help fight acquired immune deficiency syndrome. The eight-page guide was prepared with help from Boston's AIDS Action Committee.

LEAD: A CHERISHED Congressional privilege known as the frank -sending mail to constituents at taxpayer expense - came under fire last year.

LEAD: In September 1985, when Ursula Meese, the wife of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, was honored at a Washington charity ball, the executives of the Wedtech Corporation, a little-known South Bronx military contractor, bought a $1,500 table.

LEAD: THE landmark neo-classical Peoples Gas Building, designed by the turn-of-the-century architect and urban planner Daniel Burnham, is emerging from a $16 million restoration as a general-purpose office building.

LEAD: A paroled rapist forced out of town after town by public protests has been placed on the grounds of San Quentin Prison under 24-hour supervision of parole agents, Gov. George Deukmejian said today.

LEAD: STUDENTS simulating the actions of young business executives form corporations, sell stock, elect officers, market products and, ideally, post a profit. Within 15 weeks, they then liquidate. These ''young executives'' attend Lincoln High School in Yonkers, one of a growing number of area schools teaching business skills by having students organize enterprises and operate them like real companies.

LEAD: The spreading epidemic of AIDS, which threatens to have a destabilizing effect on world economics and politics, is expected to be high among the issues addressed by the leaders of the seven-nation industrial summit conference in Venice next week.

LEAD: THE UNION representing Hollywood's extras has agreed to studio demands for sharp cutbacks in wages and benefits for new members. MCA/Universal has discharged 200 employees and is about to order executives traveling to New York to use only those hotels that offer special corporate rates. 20th Century

LEAD: THIS Monmouth County community may be little, as its name indicates, but it has two post offices, one of them an ''antique'' converted into a museum. It also has Gallery Jupiter Inc., which took up residence last fall at 25 Church Street.

LEAD: Mayor Koch announced last week that in an effort to attract employers to northern Manhattan and New York's other boroughs, the city would offer new tax breaks aimed at providing businesses with all the comforts of New Jersey.

LEAD: Hanya Holm, the choreographer of ''My Fair Lady,'' ''Camelot'' and other musicals, will receive a special award for her contributions to modern dance during the sixth annual Astaire Awards presentations, tomorrow at the Racquet and Tennis Club, 370 Park Avenue, at 54th Street. Robert Lindsay, the star of ''Me and My Girl,'' will be honored as best male dancer on Broadway.

LEAD: On Tuesday, a large section of inner-city Los Angeles will vote on a proposal to raise property taxes to pay for more city police. That's noteworthy because the rest of the city is not doing the same. This special referendum raises troubling questions about majority will, minority rights and the relationship of a city's parts to the whole.

LEAD: Amy Susan Chefitz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold N. Chefitz of Livingston, N.J., and John A. Bass, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Lee W. Bass of Pittsburgh, were married last evening at the Headquarters Plaza Hotel in Morristown, N.J., by Rabbi Peter Kasden.

LEAD: An article April 19 about good buys in Australia incorrectly suggested that all boots sold at R. M. Williams were made of cowhide. The store does sell one boot that is made of kangaroo and is so labeled.

H. T. Grayson of Panama City, Fla., and the late Ethel Sageser Grayson.

LEAD: THE DELIGHTFUL PERFORM-ances of Serge Lifar's ''Suite en Blanc'' and Albert Aveline's version of ''Les Deux Pigeons'' given in Paris this month by the Paris Opera Ballet School serve as vibrant reminders that France's classical ballet tradition is not only alive and well but worthy of deeper appreciation.

LEAD: ''When does your flight leave?'' my young acquaintance inquired as our Philadelphia convention drew toward a close. For a split second I considered an evasive answer, then decided to brave it out: ''I rode the train.'' My friend's fleeting grimace probably mirrored her inner conclusion: any American in the 1980's who deliberately wastes 48 hours on a train trip to and from a professional meeting must ipso facto be phobic, indigent or verging on senility.

LEAD: Industrial chemicals are eating away at the high ozone layer that shields life from the sun's harmful ultra-violet rays. To most people the solution is obvious: Cut production of those chemicals and find alternatives. Not to Donald Hodel, the Secretary of the Interior, and William Graham, the President's science adviser.

LEAD: The Electric Boat division of the General Dynamics Corporation has been fined $5,850 after Federal inspectors reported they had found nearly 200 violations of safety rules at a plant that makes hulls for Trident submarines.

LEAD: NOT everything that David Hessayon writes comes up roses. He takes all plants for his province, and his is the world's best-selling series of gardening books. There are more than 26 million in print - everything from ''The Flower Expert'' with a million copies to ''The Lawn Expert'' with 2,500,000 to ''The House Plant Expert'' with 7,449,000.

LEAD: GARDENING AND BEYOND. By Florence Bellis. Illustrated by Valerie Willson. 178 pp. (Timber Press, $19.95.) Florence Bellis's place in the international world of horticulture is assured, thanks to her achievement in originating - over many decades of careful and imaginative hybridization - the many strains of primroses collectively named after her Oregon home, Barnhaven.

LEAD: TRAPPED by locked doors and barred windows, 19 persons died in a fire that swept a small factory in a Bangkok suburb one night last year. The victims, part of a work force of 30 producing leather goods, had bedded down for the night on three floors of their factory. Their normal work day was from 8 A.M.
LEAD: A woman has been convicted of killing her 3-year-old adopted son 22 years ago in a case reopened at the urging of the boy's natural mother.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, the method of selecting winners was incorrect in an article last week about teachers' receiving awards. The teachers were nominated by colleagues and then selected by nine-member panels representing each school, with school boards and teachers' unions each appointing three panelists.

LEAD: SINCE daffodil foliage does not ripen until late summer, bunch the leaves in an upright position and tie them together with their own foliage to make room for setting in annual plants. If the tulips have not bloomed well in recent years, dig up bulbs and discard; order new ones for planting in fall; finish pruning spring-flowering shrubs; cold soil has persisted and given tardy gardeners time to sow grass seed or set in sod; continue asparagus harvests from three-year-old plants or older; snap off spears at ground level just before cooking.

LEAD: A private study estimates that spending on national, state and local political campaigns reached a new high of $1.8 billion in the last Presidential election year.

LEAD: Some people relaxing in a hammock or beach chair would rather read of the rise of the perfect souffle than turn 600 pages of fleshy romance. For them there are ample choices this summer - new food books, cookbooks and wine books - that offer armchair contentment and might eventually inspire a trip into the kitchen, or at least over to light the grill.

Msgr. Russell R. Novello performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: JUST OVER A WEEK AGO, THE New York Philharmonic gave the last in the series of subscription concerts featuring works by Giovanni Gabrieli and William Byrd. To many listeners, they probably seemed the least significant events on a program that included Strauss's ''Also Sprach Zarathustra'' and the Schumann Violin Concerto, yet they were, in one sense, the most notable items on the menu: these were among the very few pieces from the
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: AL UNSER Sr., the Indianapolis 500 winner, will have a ride for at least three more races this season according to an announcement yesterday by Roger Penske, president of Penske Racing. He said Unser would have a ride in a third Penske car at both of the remaining 500-mile races this season, as well as the Marlboro Challenge, a special $730,000 invitation race during the final weekend of the season in Miami.

LEAD: A FEW weeks ago we received a notice from Town Hall announcing that Spring Cleanup/Collection would begin the weekend of May 15. This is the time when villagers can throw out anything that is too big to fit into the daily garbage cans. It is also a period of high excitement for local esthetes. The roads are filled with townspeople in their station wagons scouring the streets for collectible trash.

LEAD: OFTEN ASSAILED FOR BEING hermetic, for stressing style at the expense of substance, the theatrical avant-garde is increasingly expanding its vision and displaying a heightened awareness of science, history and politics. At the same time, conceptual directors are, to a greater degree, employing - and commenting on - other arts in their theater work: painting, sculpture, puppetry, modern dance and music, film and video.

LEAD: OFTEN ASSAILED FOR BEING hermetic, for stressing style at the expense of substance, the theatrical avant-garde is increasingly expanding its vision and displaying a heightened awareness of science, history and politics. At the same time, conceptual directors are, to a greater degree, employing - and commenting on - other arts in their theater work: painting, sculpture, puppetry, modern dance and music, film and video.

LEAD: To the amazement of all and the consternation of Soviet authorities, a 19-year-old amateur pilot from West Germany flew a tiny single-engine plane across more than 400 miles of heavily guarded Soviet territory last week and landed next to the Kremlin wall at the foot of Red Square.
LEAD: Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, said Friday that he is homosexual, becoming only the second member of Congress to openly discuss his homosexuality.

LEAD: Margaret Wood Marion, a daughter of Mrs. Haig Costikyan of Rye, N.Y., and the late B.Pope Marion, was married yesterday to John Brooks Lobkowicz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin M. George Lobkowicz of Dover, Mass. The Rev. Edward Johnston performed the ceremony at Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye.

LEAD: Pamela A. Pinto, an associate in the Hartford law firm of Cohn & Birnbaum, was married yesterday to William G. Millman Jr., an associate in the New Haven law firm of Wiggin & Dana. The Rev. Philip A. Davignon performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Isle Roman Catholic Church in Nantucket, Mass.

LEAD: SIX somberly suited men and one, the Italian, who invariably arrives in open sports coats, convene every three months or so in the opulent gilded chambers of the Louvre Palace, in the clubby rooms of No. 11 Downing Street or beneath the swooping brass chandeliers of the American Treasury's third-floor conference room.

LEAD: WHENEVER Dr. David C. Bladerston glances out the window of his apartment at Park Avenue and 96th Street, one of the most unwelcome sights in his neighborhood of Carnegie Hill looms before him: a red-brick tower with balconies protruding like concrete tongues.

LEAD: Amnesty International says hundreds of Iranian refugees in Turkey have been sent back to Iran, where they face the threat of torture and execution as enemies of the Government of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

LEAD: Yes, money can mean freedom. And so much more. Although I read Marshall Glickman's article with respect and, perhaps, a little awe, my feelings were tempered with a bit of sadness. A philosopher - a student of life -might know that money can also mean power. And with power comes responsibility. MICHAEL YAM

LEAD: TRAPPED by locked doors and barred windows, 19 persons died in a fire that swept a small factory in a Bangkok suburb one night last year. The victims, part of a work force of 30 producing leather goods, had bedded down for the night on three floors of their factory. Their normal work day was from 8 A.M.

LEAD: Donna Rice's friend, Lynn Armandt, asked for $25,000 from The National Enquirer for a photograph of Gary Hart with his arm around Ms. Rice, according to a person with knowledge of the negotiations.

LEAD: Former Gov. Frank Licht, who pushed through a state income tax to end Rhode Island's fiscal crises of the 1960's, died today at Roger Williams Hospital. He was 71 years old and had suffered from cancer.

LEAD: A minor design flaw may have caused an accident on a raft ride at Hersheypark in which six people were injured last weekend, according to an article in The Harrisburg Evening News. Richard Coulter, an amusement park safety specialist from Delaware, Ohio, said the flaw in the Canyon River Rapids could be quickly corrected, The Evening News reported Thursday.

LEAD: This tiny settlement was carved from the north Maine woods more than 150 years ago by men who would make a living from the land, first from the potato fields and then from the woods. It is a place where people feel a sense of the past.

LEAD: A small tribe of Pueblo Indians is resisting the creation of a national monument on a vast lava flow in north-central New Mexico, calling it another attempt by the Federal Government to chip away at Indian lands.

LEAD: FOURTH-grade students in New Rochelle were learning more about local history this month, thanks to a bus tour arranged by the city's school district and the Huguenot-Thomas Paine Historical Association.

LEAD: Sanford Sirulnick, the owner of more than 50 buildings with some 5,000 units in New York City, likes to recount the incident last fall that led him to consider the merits of selling buildings at auction.

LEAD: Dwight Gooden's bout with cocaine is but another of the dozen stories we read about in the newspapers every day. Urban New Yorkers (and perhaps the rest of the country) have become so accepting of drugs as part of daily life that we consider drug addiction no worse an offense than missing curfew. Perhaps some of us remember that Keith Hernandez spent time in court for his involvement in a cocaine scandal.
LEAD: Dr. K's return to the Mets will generate more electricity than Lilco and Con Edison combined. ERROL D. ALEXANDER Jr. New Brunswick, N.J.

LEAD: There was something stale and deceptive in ''Bar Group Opposes Court Amendment'' [ May 17 ] . What was stale was the Suffolk County Bar Association's announcement of its opposition to the merger of our state's trial courts; that position was announced two months ago (see New York Law Journal, March 18).

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York yesterday, Katherine Marie Galicich, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Galicich of Alpine, N.J., was married to William Charles Jaris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Jaris of Manhattan. The Rev. Richard J. Dillon performed the ceremony.

LEAD: This list has been selected from books reviewed since the Christmas issue of December 1986. It only suggests high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. The quoted comments are from The Book Review. Autobiography & Biography
LEAD: The chicken coops have been converted to storage sheds, the farms have gone to grass or weed and the farmers, too, are doing other things.
LEAD: I'M ENTERING THAT AGE WHEN songs from the hit parades of my adolescence bring tears of nostalgia. I'm a sucker for memorabilia of the 1950's.

LEAD: WHEN the jurors in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz descended into a dirty, old, graffiti-splattered subway car last week to view the type of setting in which he shot four youths, they were being asked, in dramatic fashion, to put themselves in Mr. Goetz's place.

LEAD: PHONG NGUYEN, the Vietnamese ethnomusicologist, instrumentalist and singer, noted during the World Music Institute's concert of Vietnamese music on Friday that he had collected 42 different folk songs titled ''Song of The Black Horse.'' He was sorry, he added with a smile, that he could not play them all.
LEAD: Each slow step was labored, but Ernestine Wellons smiled as she worked her way across the room unassisted, murmuring, ''I'm getting better and better.''
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Sophocles said, ''Though a man be wise, it is no shame for him to live and learn.'' It is no shame for us to learn from this experience.

LEAD: THErr concept of ''inclusionary zoning,'' which is aimed at enabling low-income families to live in high-income neighborhoods, was recently incorporated into New York City's zoning regulations. In certain areas, developers will be allowed to build luxury apartment towers as much as 20 percent higher than would otherwise be allowed.

LEAD: ONCE, THERE WAS A TIME WHEN THE CITY of New York saw its responsibility for physical planning as a simple mandate: to limit growth. The idea was not to restrict it unreasonably, or to meddle excessively with the forces of capitalism, but to guarantee that those qualities of urban living that are of public benefit, such as light, air, sunshine and a sense of comfortable scale, did not disappear.

LEAD: Shortly after Mikhail S. Gorbachev left here last Wednesday, the food lines began to form again at stores in the center of the city and in quarters that the Soviet leader's motorcade traversed during his three-day visit.

LEAD: A special prosecutor's attempt to serve subpoenas in the perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver, the former Reagan aide who left the White House to start a multimillion dollar lobbying business, stirred up a diplomatic tempest last week.

LEAD: A little competition has been a big help in bringing down milk prices in New York City, Attorney General Robert Abrams said last week. But he warned that unless Albany widens the hole in the fence made by a New Jersey dairy earlier this year, prices could soon go up again.

LEAD: At St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York yesterday, Anne Marie Dobson, head of the Lower School of the Hewitt School, was married to James Grinstead Glazebrook, a lawyer. The Rev. Thomas Dix Bowers, the rector, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Philip E. Dobson, a Roman Catholic priest who is the bride's uncle.

LEAD: I have always enjoyed reading The Times on Sunday, and especially look forward to reading the Long Island Weekly section now because of Barbara Klaus's articles. Her humor and sensitivity to family issues and feelings is both exciting and moving.

LEAD: ''MONOLOGUES, RANTS, tirades, complaints'' are Lydia Lunch's stock in trade these days. She is, officially, a performance artist, appearing at Soho's Performing Garage Thursday through Sunday through June 7. Ten years ago, armed with an electric guitar which she did not so much play as strangle, Miss Lunch was the assassin of rock-and-roll, leading a succession of bands that seemed to deal in sheer anarchy.

LEAD: Beginning this summer, a team from the New York City Department of Health will give out free condoms at singles bars, pornographic-movie theaters, massage parlors and sex clubs throughout the city to warn of the dangers of casual sex.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: When Alysheba steps onto the track for the Belmont Stakes Saturday, he will be lacking one ingredient in the formula that has brought him to the threshold of becoming racing's 12th Triple Cown winner: his usual dose of furosemide.

LEAD: HANDEL'S oratorio ''Saul'' contains some of the composer's most vivid writing, set to a theatrical libretto by Charles Jennens. Characters are sharply, realistically drawn. Handel added to his orchestra trombones, organ and carillon to produce sounds that match the work's subject in color and breadth.

LEAD: LATE last Thursday afternoon, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger briefed Congressional leaders on what amounted to a postponement of the plan to put American flags on Kuwaiti oil tankers in the Persian Gulf. At the same time, however, a White House spokesman, Dan Howard, was insisting to a reporter that the ''reflagging'' would go ahead as scheduled this week.
LEAD: A COMPUTER breakdown at the state's Division of Motor Vehicles some 20 months ago crippled its operations, which, in turn, caused serious inconvenience for thousands of New Jersey motorists.

LEAD: IT doesn't require any particular brilliance to know why thousands of dogs are named Rover, or why carloads of cuddly white cats answer to the name of Snowball. But why would a miniature poodle who looks like a powder puff be called Max, or a cat who, according to his owner, ''just lives for love,'' be named Moe?
LEAD: WHENEVER 13-year-old Mario Clayton of Brooklyn visits Douglas and Helen Opalski and their family in the Middlesex County community of Plainsboro, he learns something new.

LEAD: AS the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service saw it, if the Aleutian Canada goose, an endangered species, was to thrive again on the Aleutian island of Kiska, it was necessary to turn back the ecological clock. And that meant killing all the arctic foxes there - some 700.

LEAD: FOR someone who had seen a no-hitter slip from his grasp in the late innings of a game against Chattanooga the previous night, Bob Milacki, a 22-year-old pitcher for Charlotte, the Baltimore entry in the Class AA Southern League, was remarkably cheerful on Friday about the single that marred his performance.

LEAD: At the Community Congregational Church in Short Hills, N.J., Catherine W. Tulis, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Mott Walbridge of Short Hills and Stowe, Vt., was married yesterday to Chandler F. Stimmel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Stimmel of Slingerlands, N.Y. LEAD: Golfers had Jack Nicklaus's Muirfield Village Golf Club course at their mercy this week, and they weren't letting up. Their attack continued today as several records were equaled or broken on the soaking-wet course, before play in the Memorial Tournament was suspended for the day by a severe thunderstorm.

LEAD: ALMOST 70 YEARS AFTER THE death of Rosa Luxemburg, her name still conjures up images of revolution - and a good deal of controversy. She was, after all, a major political figure and one of the founders of the German Communist Party. What many people don't know is that she was also an ardent pacifist who spent most of World War I in prison.

LEAD: LIKE AMERICA'S CUP, A LITTLE Protest! ''We rule in favor of Dick,'' announced the commodore of the club, Jack Patton of Lloyd Neck.

LEAD: The death toll from the killings by leftist peasants of upper-caste landlord families in the state of Bihar rose to 54 today, the United News of India reported. The killings Saturday were described by Government officials as the worst instance of caste-related violence in eastern India. State officials said the attacks in the villages of Jalalchak and Bhagaura were by lower-caste Yadavs avenging the slayings of eight Yadavs.

LEAD: Officials and inmates were wary when the state prison here began housing women, as well as men, earlier this year. But of all the potential problems that crossed their minds, there is one that no one anticipated: how difficult it would be for the prison store to keep men's cologne in stock.

LEAD: In a move to curb accidental shootings, the New York City Police Department will require all newly hired officers, starting next month, to use a special type of stainless steel .38 caliber revolver that cannot be cocked before it is fired.

LEAD: The capital will become richer by two one-horned or Asian rhinoceroses tomorrow when Prince Gyanendra of Nepal presents the pair to the National Zoo. The number of Asian rhinos has declined 84 percent since 1970 because of illegal hunting and loss of habitat, according to the World Wildlife Fund.

LEAD: SHORTLY after dawn, the Electra climbed above the Amazon River, nudged through plumes and layers of steam, then bumped along just 500 feet over the jungle canopy. On board, a phalanx of scientists started probing the breath of the forest.

LEAD: The New York investor Asher B. Edelman and Dominion Textile Inc. have lowered their combined stake in Burlington Industries to 12.3 percent, from the equivalent of 13.4 percent.

LEAD: * Peter Engler has been named executive vice president at Siegel & Gale, a subsidiary of Saatchi & Saatchi.
