LEAD: A preliminary vote by the Federal Election Commission this week on whether Gary Hart's 1988 campaign can receive Federal matching funds could be crucial in determining whether he can resolve the mounting financial troubles of his two Presidential bids.

LEAD: Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey has been manfully resisting efforts to persuade him to take a few practice shots at the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination, but he has now agreed to appear on the same platform with seven declared or active competitors later this month. He will not be debating his party colleagues, however, but defending himself at a fund-raising ''roast'' at the Sheraton Washington hotel
LEAD: Two New York City welfare and hospital agencies said yesterday that they were overburdened with the rising AIDS caseload.

LEAD: There was an air of deliverance in Edmonton's champagne-splashed locker room as the players basked in their third Stanley Cup victory Sunday after defeating the Flyers, 3-1, in a tense finale to a seven-game series.

LEAD: As tension along China's easternmost border with India continues, China is pouring tremendous numbers of soldiers and weapons into the sparsely populated mountainous area along the two countries' disputed border.
LEAD: Just before his 45th birthday, which is Thursday, Marshall Karp, creative director of Lowe Marschalk, has opted for a second career.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it would concentrate the administration of its medium-duty truck operations in its G.M.C. Truck division. Until now, the Chevrolet division had handled the nearly 1,000 Chevrolet dealerships that sell medium trucks. There are about 660 G.M.C. medium-truck dealers.
LEAD: Quietly but persistently, serious Republicans are asking this question: Is Pierre S. du Pont 4th on the way to becoming a serious contender for the Republican nomination for President?

LEAD: Forty years ago, when all the world went to the movies on Saturday nights, the famous producer Harry Cohn told a tableful of screenwriters his infallible method for separating moneymakers from clinkers. If a movie was good, he could sit still. If not, he said, his backside wiggled in his chair. Today's technology and market research are presumably a big improvement on Mr.
LEAD: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation has settled lawsuits regarding asbestos-injury claims against its Fibreboard Corporation subsidiary.
LEAD: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, Mass., awarded degrees to 937 undergraduate and 825 graduate students at the 121st commencement held in Killian Court.
LEAD: The Reagan Administration is inclined to reappoint Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, a senior official suggested today.

LEAD: ''I think that organized crime was filtered into the teamsters' union a long time before I came there, and it'll be there a long time after I'm gone.'' - Roy L. Williams, Former teamster president. [ A1:3. ]

LEAD: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan used the dedication yesterday of a privately financed shelter for homeless families to denounce the conditions in New York City's welfare hotels as ''a scandal, an outrage, an ulcer.''

LEAD: Vice President Bush, addressing the opening of the largest scientific meeting ever held on AIDS, today pushed for broader testing at both state and Federal levels to detect individuals who are infected with the AIDS virus.

LEAD: The House of Representatives voted today to establish a national monument to protect ancient lava flows and archeological sites in northwestern New Mexico. The unanimous vote capped an 18-year effort to protect the region, which will be known as the El Malpais National Monument and the Grants National Conservation Area.

LEAD: The five permanent members of the Security Council have failed to agree on an American proposal to impose a global arms embargo against Iran, diplomats in Washington and at the United Nations said today.
LEAD: The New York office of Eric Mower & Associates has won a couple of exotic assignments that will care for it head and toe.

LEAD: ANTIBIOTICS and other drugs have revolutionized modern medicine. But for all their advantages, they continue to have two serious drawbacks: they are rapidly cleared from the blood system and they may be toxic to healthy cells as well as those they are meant to attack.

LEAD: Mayor Koch said yesterday that officials of the National Broadcasting Company should consider relocating to one of several Manhattan locations, including Battery Park City and the site of the current Madison Square Garden.

LEAD: The Sultan of Brunei is seeking to recover $10 million intended as a donation for Nicaraguan rebels that was mistakenly deposited in the account of a wealthy Swiss businessman, a judge said today.

LEAD: The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company said today that 16 million cigarettes containing more herbicide than is allowed by American law would not be sold in Japan, where they were shipped, or anywhere else. Reynolds said the Winston

LEAD: The Transportation Department, saying too many truckers were hiding traffic violations behind a ''wallet full'' of driver's licenses, ordered operators today to surrender their extra permits within 30 days or face stiff fines.

LEAD: If OPEC raises its oil production in the third and fourth quarters, as it earlier decided, it will probably push market prices below the organization's target of $18 a barrel, a high-ranking Mexican oil official said.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The PTL ministry uses television in two ways, both as a buyer and as a seller.

LEAD: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d testified today before a Federal grand jury investigating actions taken by him and a former White House aide, Lyn C. Nofziger, in behalf of the Wedtech Corporation, a military contractor linked to scandals.
LEAD: In the three weeks since the new immigration law took effect, far fewer illegal aliens have applied for citizenship than was expected, Federal immigration officials said yesterday.
LEAD: Experience paid off last week in Manhattan for four players who have had long experience at the rubber bridge table and make occasional forays into the tournament arena.
LEAD: In July, Kentucky Fried Chicken will introduce Chicken Littles with $40 million worth of advertising over three months.

LEAD: Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan are often treated, especially in the United States, as if they were political twins. They do have ideology in common. But in the way they do the work of politicians, getting elected and running governments, they could hardly be less alike.

LEAD: NANCY MEEHAN'S ''Into Summer'' was an excursion into a mysterious but attractive choreographic realm, and the journey was aided by a shimmering score by Eleanor Hovda, who played wind and percussion instruments and plucked the strings of a piano. ''Into Summer,'' a new work, was offered Sunday night at the Emanu-El Midtown Y by the Nancy Meehan Dance

LEAD: The single-handed yacht race around the world was such a success that the BOC Group plans to sponsor another one beginning and ending in Newport, R.I., sometime in the future. No date has been set, according to Richard Giordano, the chairman. At an award program on Saturday night, Philippe Jeantot of France, who finished first in overall time and first in Class 1 for boats of 50 to 60 feet, received $15,000.

LEAD: What becomes a boxing legend most? Well, if you are trying to sell shoe polish, nothing less than full, nationwide distribution in all of a retail sales chain's outlets. That is the position taken by a company known as Muhammad Ali's Champion Brand Industries, which last week staged a media event at K Mart's annual shareholders' meeting.

LEAD: Friday night at Shea Stadium, Mary Jane Watson - an actress, model and computer businesswoman - will be married to the Amazing Spider-Man, a superhero also known to comic-book cognoscenti as Peter Parker, a freelance photographer for the mythical Daily Bugle in Manhattan. LEAD: The State Athletic Control Board today told 35 boxers they will no longer be allowed to box in New Jersey because future bouts could endanger their health.

LEAD: The small group of investors holding a 13 percent stake in the Allegis Corporation said yesterday that they would continue to seek control of the company in order to liquidate it or sell off its divisions. The group, Gollust, Tierney &

LEAD: The joint Congressional committee holding hearings on the Iran-contra affair today made public a transcript of testimony given in closed session on Friday by Joe Fernandez, the Central Intelligence Agency station chief in Costa Rica. Following are excerpts from the transcript; some material was deleted by C.I.A.

LEAD: Noting the fact that George Abbott will turn 100 years old on June 25, the Great Lakes Theater Festival here is presenting two vintage Abbott shows: ''Broadway,'' the racy 1926 backstage drama that Mr. Abbott wrote and that he directed for this production, and the Richard Rodgers-Lorenz Hart-George Abbott musical ''The Boys From Syracuse,'' staged by the festival's artistic director, Gerald

LEAD: Capping a year of speculation and rumors, the Computerland Corporation, the world's largest personal computer retailer, said today that an investment group led by E.M. Warburg, Pincus & Company had agreed to acquire the company.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Friends of Joseph L. Rauh Jr., which means labor leaders, civil libertarians, lawyers and surviving liberals generally, are giving the 76-year-old lawyer, a fixture on the Washington political scene since the New Deal, a lunch today. It marks his return to the Washington scene after an uncharacteristic period of limited activity due to hip replacement surgery last January.

LEAD: A new assembly line to produce General Electric brand television sets at the Bloomington RCA plant has begun operation. The new assembly line follows a decision in February to move production of 500,000 G.E. brand color television sets to the Bloomington plant from Japan. The company said the plant's RCA brand production schedule had not been affected by the decision to assemble the G.E.

LEAD: THE Middle East war of June 1967 brought Israel control, among other territories, of 2,000 square miles of the West Bank of the Jordan River containing a million Arabs. LEAD: President Reagan indicated today that he would press Western allies at the Venice economic summit meeting to become involved in the efforts by the United States to protect ship movements in the Persian Gulf.
LEAD: Nine people who had been removed from the Criminal Court building in Brooklyn after a bomb threat yesterday were injured when part of a sidewalk on which they were standing collapsed.

LEAD: President Jose Napoleon Duarte offered amnesty today to political prisoners and leftist guerrillas who join the democratic process. Mr. Duarte, in a speech marking the start of his fourth year in office, gave no details of the amnesty plan, and there was no immediate response from the various rebel groups that form the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front.
LEAD: Members of the dance and theater worlds gathered yesterday to name the film and video section of the New York Public Library's Dance Collection at Lincoln Center in honor of Jerome Robbins.

LEAD: Construction spending edged up four-tenths of 1 percent in April as weakness in government and residential projects was offset by gains in construction of shopping centers and factories, the Commerce Department reported today.

LEAD: The sprawling new car factory here on a verdant flatland in northeast England is a source of jobs where they are badly needed, and it provides political and economic benefits for its Japanese owner, the Nissan Motor Company. More significant than jobs or investment, the Sunderland plant is a sharp break with the class-ridden ways of

LEAD: There is no talk. An attractive man and an attactive woman, both unsmiling and serious, begin to undress slowly. The camera does not intrude long enough to be improper, just long enough to catch her having a sip of Canada Dry Ginger Ale. Then it leaves the room to show us two youngsters in nightclothes staring at their parents' closed bedroom door.

LEAD: The concept of state authorities acting as bond financing conduits for small businesses has been expanded to the national market, according to officials at American Development Finance Inc. and Shearson Lehman Brothers.

LEAD: ASTRONAUTS who entered the space agency management with missionary zeal after the Challenger disaster have found that their ability to correct problems with space technologies and to strengthen the agency's safety planning is severely limited.

LEAD: Stung by the unexpected resignation of Dick Motta and spurned in their attempts to hire Don Nelson, the Dallas Mavericks interviewed the former Phoenix Suns' coach, John MacLeod, yesterday, but he said it could be a week before he gets another call. . . . The Los Angeles Rams' owner and president, Georgia Frontiere, announced that Coach John Robinson's contract has been extended by four years.

LEAD: The violinist Isaac Stern and the Polish composer Krysztof Penderecki were awarded 1987 Wolf Prizes for the arts Sunday by President Chaim Herzog and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. The two musicians will share a $100,000 prize.

LEAD: Ron Nachman's critics call him a one-man obstacle to peace. His neighbors just call him Mayor, friend and ''hey, you.'' He calls himself a simple pioneer for the Likud bloc, Israel's large nationalist party.

LEAD: Rashid Karami, who was assassinated in an explosion aboard his helicopter yesterday, was an adroit, flexible pro-Syrian politician who had been the Prime Minister of Lebanon 10 times since 1955.
LEAD: The Charles Hudson balloon lost a little more air last night.
LEAD: Faith Whitney Ziesing, a former trustee of Sarah Lawrence College, died of cancer last Friday at her home in Princeton, N.J. She was 75 years old.

LEAD: WAGNER, as a critic once observed about the famed composer's music, is really better than it sounds. Likewise, the Tax Reform Act of 1986: It will prove simpler for most taxpayers than the new tax forms look.

LEAD: They don't know if he can still pitch at the age of 42, but their pitching staff has been decimated by injuries, so the Mets are talking to Tom Seaver about the possibility of returning to the team for the second half of the season.

LEAD: Alfred A. Gross, a former ethics professor and founder of the George W. Henry Foundation, which provided job training and legal assistance to the indigent, died of a heart attack Thursday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Alysheba being led to the track for workout yesterday at Belmont. Jack Van Berg, his trainer, followed the colt's progress on a pony. Afterward, Alysheba got a bath and returned to the barn. (NYT/Vic DeLucia)

LEAD: India announced today that it would send a convoy of unarmed ships to northern Sri Lanka on Wednesday to provide ''humanitarian assistance'' to ethnic Tamils besieged by a weeklong offensive by Government forces.
LEAD: A recommendation against Government approval of a key drug manufactured by Genentech Inc. was bad news for the biotechnology sector on Wall Street yesterday.

LEAD: The State Assembly today approved broad legislation that would reduce the maximum contributions individuals can make to candidates for state office, and provide public campaign financing for candidates in New York's primary and general elections.
LEAD: A pedestrian on Eighth Avenue was struck and killed yesterday afternoon by an 8-foot wooden beam that fell from a condominium tower being built across the street, the authorities said.
LEAD: MOSCOW 2042. By Vladimir Voinovich.

LEAD: Evidence has been found that humans reached Australia 5,000 years earlier than previously found materials, according to the Australian Government's Science Newsletter. The evidence, stone tools found along the Nepean River near Sydney, is 43,000 to 47,000 years old, scientists say.

LEAD: Dozens of students were felled by heat exhaustion, air-conditioning sellers were mobbed, and demands for power surged to near-record levels yesterday as temperatures soared into the 90's for the fourth straight day across the New York metropolitan region.
LEAD: A Holocaust monument was defaced with swastikas today, one day after its dedication to six million Jews and other victims of the Nazis during World War II.
LEAD: THE earliest mention of the word ''computer'' dates to 1646, when it referred to people who calculated the passage of time and drew up calendars.
LEAD: VOLUNTEERS for Earthwatch are seldom too young or too old.

LEAD: Starting today, and continuing through Thursday, college and high school baseball players throughout the nation will be having some important questions answered. For many, the 1987 major league baseball summer free-agent draft will offer insight into how good they really are, and to whether or not they have a future in baseball.

LEAD: Right on top of some of the recent more exotic travel news is word that Suffolk Waste Distillation of Southold, L.I., has hired Douglas G. Hearle & Associates of New York to do its public relations. As the 1990 deadline for closing landfills in the county approaches, Suffolk Waste wants communities to know about its system of turning municipal waste into carbon char that occupies 10 percent of the space of the original mass.

LEAD: The investigation into the Wedtech Corporation has expanded to include a former Republican office-seeker from Brooklyn, who, law-enforcement officials said, was a conduit for the payment of a bribe to a Federal official.

LEAD: ''This is a battle against disease, not against our fellow Americans.'' In his first speech devoted to AIDS, President Reagan made plain that his heart was in the right place. What's less evident is why he ignores the best advice of public health officials and recommends compulsory AIDS testing that has little relevance to the incidence of the disease.
LEAD: Stock prices eased in a listless session yesterday, as concerns about the trade situation, the dollar and interest rates continued to hover over the market.

LEAD: Field organizers for the National Education Association went on strike against the union today in a dispute over salaries, pensions and what the strikers contend is a management attempt to take back existing benefits.

LEAD: PLUMMETING bond prices rattled investor nerves for much of April and May. But now that the dollar has stabilized somewhat and bonds have recouped part of their losses, some brokerage firms are taking a more favorable view of fixed-income securities.

LEAD: Signaling his continued interest in acquiring Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., the British publisher Robert Maxwell sued yesterday to stop the company from carrying out its $3 billion recapitalization plan.
LEAD: Friends and relatives of Nelson A. Rockefeller gathered this morning in a small corridor off the Senate chamber to unveil a marble bust of the late Vice President and New York Governor.

LEAD: The first wonder in the tale of Mathias Rust was the picture of the little Cessna parked in front of the fantastical onion domes of St. Basil's Cathedral. A 19-year-old West German really had flown into the heart of Moscow, buzzed Lenin's tomb and landed beside the Kremlin Wall.

LEAD: Donald Curry (27-1, with 20 knockouts), the former undisputed world welterweight champion, doesn't believe he can get down to the 147-pound limit anymore, but he has agreed to fight Mike McCallum (31-0, 28 knockouts), the low-profile World Boxing Association junior-middleweight champion, next month in Las Vegas, Nev., for HBO.
LEAD: Bond prices rose modestly for the third consecutive session yesterday and have now advanced on six of the last seven trading days.

LEAD: On a drowsy Sunday morning, one of the first great tourist hordes of the summer assembled outside Buckingham Palace for the changing of the guard. Meanwhile, a scant half-mile away, a livelier and more unusual scene - a scene with its own historic overtones - was being staged in St. James's Park for the lucky few who stumbled upon it.

LEAD: ELIMINATION of measles from the United States is proving to be a more difficult goal than many specialists had expected. A decade ago, Federal health officials announced a national goal of eliminating the infectious disease, by immunizing all children against the virus that causes it. But the number of cases has been climbing each year since the all-time low of 1,497 cases reported in 1983.

LEAD: Thousands of people suffering from AIDS-related illnesses will not automatically qualify for the Social Security disability benefits that they had expected to receive under an expanded definition of AIDS.

LEAD: The New York State Dormitory Authority is offering $500 million of bonds to finance new facilities for the City University of New York.
LEAD: THE quest for that leather-and-plastic grail of modern life, the perfect running shoe, has received an unexpected jolt from new research into the mechanics of the human foot.

LEAD: In most team sports, changing the lineup, replacing one athlete with another, is not so unusual. But with an eight-oared crew, it represents upheaval. And woe to the coach if change fails to increase speed.

LEAD: Delta Air Lines plans to start regular service between Atlanta and Seoul in the fall, a Transportation Ministry statement said today. It said the Atlanta-based carrier was seeking permission to operate six flights a week between the two cities via Portland, Ore., and Tokyo.
LEAD: Residents of inner-city Los Angeles will vote Tuesday on whether to approve a special tax on themselves to increase police protection in their area, but the plan's sponsor has now disavowed it.
LEAD: The Island State
LEAD: Thomas J. Reghanti, who retired from the Fruehauf Corporation in 1986 as president and chief executive officer, died here last Thursday. He was 62 years old.
LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY
LEAD: Prime Minister Rashid Karami was assassinated today when an explosion attributed to a bomb ripped through a military helicopter in which he was traveling.
LEAD: Joel H. Newman has left as president of Calvin Klein Industries to join the Leslie Fay Company as vice chairman and chief operating officer.

LEAD: When a 10-day strike shutting down nearly all highway work in Connecticut was settled last week, the man considered the catalyst behind the agreement shied away from the television cameras and stayed in his office.

LEAD: Lester D. Egbert, a former chairman of Brown, Crosby & Company, a Manhattan-based insurance brokerage firm, and a former trustee of Columbia University, died Sunday at Montclair (N.J.) Community Hospital. He was 95 years old and lived in Montclair.
LEAD: The PTL ministry has survived what it called its ''May emergency'' with the collection of more than $7 million in a fund drive that ended Sunday, ministry officials said.

LEAD: Dresser Industries, a diversified oilfield services company, said it had agreed to sell its insurance unit to RSL Holding Company, a unit of the private New York investment firm of Rosenkrantz & Company. The terms of the sale, which is subject to governmental approval, were not disclosed. However, estimates of the price ranged from $200 million to $250 million in cash.

LEAD: As far as the Lakers are concerned, Robert Parish is ready to run a marathon. Kevin McHale is in peak physical condition, as are Dennis Johnson, Danny Ainge and, of course, Larry Bird. Tired legs? Injured bodies?

LEAD: Because Bruce David Klein likes Bela Lugosi movies, thousands of Long Islanders watched half a dozen of them last summer. Because he likes Humphrey Bogart, viewers will have the chance to watch ''Dark Victory'' tonight.

LEAD: The final minutes in the lives of most of the 44 Jewish children taken from their refuge near Lyons in France and killed at Auschwitz were recounted by a witness here today as the trial of Klaus Barbie resumed after a four-day recess.
LEAD: Prime Minister Errol W. Barrow died at his residence today, the Government announced. He was 67 years old.

LEAD: An investment group led by Robert M. Bass of the wealthy Fort Worth family has lowered its stake in the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation to 3.6 percent, from 5.3 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group said it had sold 567,800 National Distillers shares on the open market for prices ranging from $59.94 to $63.44 a share.

LEAD: Representative Jim Wright finally got mad last week. Almost two weeks after an Iraqi plane had shot up an American frigate in the Persian Gulf, the Speaker of the House demanded -and received - a high-level briefing on Administration plans for the region.

LEAD: From casual black Persian lamb jackets fastened and decorated with industrial zippers to hooded floor-length evening coats in black broadtail trimmed with mink, a wide range of styles have been introduced for fall during fur shows in the last two weeks.

LEAD: On the screen, Earvin (Magic) Johnson looked helpless, even defeated. But as he stared at himself on the television screen in the game room of his secluded mansion in New Bel-Air, Calif., nestled at the base of the Santa Monica mountains, his expression didn't change.

LEAD: Phil Niekro pitching the Indians to a 9-6 victory over the Tigers last night that gave him and his brother, Joe, a major league record of 530 combined victories, one more than Gaylord and Jim Perry. The victory for Phil Niekro was his 314th, which tied him for 11th place on the career list with - that's right - Gaylord Perry.
LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's ruling coalition agreed today to endorse Soviet-American moves to eliminate missiles with a range of over 300 miles from Europe.

LEAD: William Feinberg, a founder of City Center who for 15 years served as vice president, then secretary of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The stars were still absent from the cast, but the Mets got another extravagant pitching performance from one of their understudies tonight and won for the sixth time in seven games on the long and dangerous road west.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A jury heard testimony yesterday from Roy L. Williams, a former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, who admitted being controlled by a top leader of the Mafia.

LEAD: The flight of Mathias Rust's Cessna into Red Square is no occasion for finding comfort in the Soviet Union's discomfort. The young pilot sent a message to us about our defense system - especially about ''Star Wars'' - and to other nations about theirs, too.

LEAD: The leading supplier of mainframe computer software, Computer Associates International Inc., said yesterday that it would acquire the second-biggest company in the field, the Uccel Corporation, in a stock swap valued at $779.5 million.
LEAD: George Michael's new single, ''I Want Your Sex,'' has become the first record to run into censorship problems because of fears that it might be too sexually explicit for the age of AIDS.

LEAD: A member of the Beastie Boys was arrested and charged with assault Sunday in connection with a melee that abruptly ended the final concert of the New York rock group's British tour, the police said.

LEAD: South Korea's trade surplus was basically steady in May, at $348 million, compared with $349 million a year earlier, but the results so far ths year remain well ahead of 1986 levels, the Government said today. South Korea posted a trade surplus of $1.8 billion in the first five months of this year, in contrast to a deficit of $340 million a year earlier, the Trade and Industry Ministry reported.
LEAD: Defense attorneys in the trial of Brian Tribble, the man accused of providing Len Bias with the cocaine that killed him, opened their case with two witnesses today.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: West German diplomats today visited the young pilot who flew from Finland to the Kremlin and described him as bearing up calmly after nearly four days in the K.G.B.'s Lefortovo Prison.
LEAD: The New York City Investigation Department said yesterday that there was no evidence of criminality in the way the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation has purchased ambulances since 1980.
LEAD: John Henry Grady, a former vice president of I.B.M., died of cancer Sunday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived in Greenwich.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH the personal computer would seem to be a natural tool for scientists and engineers, most commercial software is geared toward the business world: spreadsheets, word processors and other corporate productivity tools. Surprisingly little focuses on natural or applied sciences.

LEAD: Q.Can fiber-optic telephone lines be tapped? A.Fiber-optic telephone lines -microscopic filaments of glass fiber through which voice and data are sent on beams of laser light - can be tapped but only with great difficulty. And the party who receives the call can detect the eavesdropping.

LEAD: Golf Gary Player and Douglass Share Title: Gary Player shook off a bogey on the 17th hole to sink an 8-foot birdie putt on No. 18 yesterday to tie Dale Douglass for the championship of the first Iowa Seniors Golf Classic at Des Moines. The two PGA Senior Tour members each shot a 1-under-par 71 at the wind-swept Wakonda Club and won $5,250 each.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Credit Company is offering $200 million of 9.30 percent notes due in 1997 at a price of 99 3/4 to yield 9.34 percent. The underwriters are led by Salomon Brothers rather than Goldman, Sachs & Company, which manages most note financings for the Ford unit.

LEAD: The last substantial vestige of Scovill Inc., the consumer products company that the Belzberg brothers of Canada took over 18 months ago, will soon be sold, ending their proclamation to use Scovill as a springboard to build up a large manufacturing business.

LEAD: LAST week, most short skirts at Bonwit Teller's flagship store on East 57th Street were still at 23 to 25 inches, just above the knee and just about 4 inches longer than skirts other stores were selling. But change is stirring the specialty-store chain's formerly stuffy air, since it was sold last month to the Hooker Corporation, an

LEAD: ONE of the ad agencies preparing to go into battle for the $200 million Burger King account could well be armed with a very special weapon. Appropriately called Conquest Advertising, it is the creation of Lawrence S. Silverman, and is a joint venture between him and Dun & Bradstreet's Donnelley Marketing Information

LEAD: Two men described by the police as members of the Hell's Angels motorcycle gang were arrested in Manhattan yesterday after they smashed a motorist's windshield, apparently upset that the driver was honking the horn, detectives said.
LEAD: A total of 871 Jews emigrated from the Soviet Union in May, the highest monthly figure since May 1981, the National Conference on Soviet Jewry announced today.

LEAD: The head of the Central Intelligence Agency office in Costa Rica has told Congressional committees that his immediate superiors at the agency in Washington knew he coordinated air drops of weapons to the rebels in Nicaragua, according to testimony made public today.
LEAD: * Aluminum Co. of America, Pittsburgh, raised its prices for a number of products, including an increase of 8 percent on aluminum beverage-can body stock, end stock and food product sheet.

LEAD: Lidiya Chukovskaya, who was expelled from the Soviet Union of Writers 13 years ago for defending two outcast authors, Boris Pasternak and Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, emerged from official obscurity this weekend to take part in the first official ceremonies in the Soviet Union to honor Pasternak.
LEAD: Fox Broadcasting has announced several of the stars who are to serve as guest hosts on ''The Late Show,'' replacing Joan Rivers.

LEAD: The Defense Department has delayed the award of several electronic and computer contracts until Japan completes its investigation of the Toshiba Corporation's role in a diversion of high-technology goods to the Soviet Union, Pentagon officials said yesterday.

LEAD: Leaders of the black and Hasidic communities in Brooklyn's Crown Heights section agreed last night to cooperate in carrying out Mayor Koch's request that they form joint anti-crime patrols of the neighborhood.
LEAD: The State Senate, after a lengthy and tense debate, passed a measure today that would allow cameras and tape recorders in New York's lower courts for the first time.

LEAD: A brief article yesterday about the New York State Governor's Arts Awards misidentified the site of the ceremonies. The event, by invitation only, begins at 6:30 P.M. next Wednesday in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
LEAD: The dollar plunged and precious metals soared yesterday on the news that Paul A. Volcker would not serve a third term as the Fed's chairman.

LEAD: Baseball Ventura Extends Streak: Jimmy Barragan hit a homer in the seventh inning to break a tie, Marv Rockman shut out Louisiana State over the final seven innings and Robin Ventura extended his hitting streak to 58 games yesterday to lead Oklahoma State to an 8-7 victory in the winner's bracket of the College World Series in Omaha.
LEAD: A plan to build a new tennis pavilion in Central Park yesterday won a unanimous but somewhat qualified endorsement yesterday from the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission.

LEAD: EUROPE remains a favorite summer destination for many Americans, and dining well remains a favorite occupation when they get there. Happily, restaurants on the Continent are as good and as numerous as ever. What has changed this year is their value. Unhappily, Americans looking forward to a memorable meal at their favorite Michelin two-star can count on paying more for it than at any other time in the last few years.

LEAD: Floating Point Systems, the troubled manufacturer of scientific computing systems, said today it would lay off about 400 workers, reducing its total work force to about 800 worldwide. The cost-cutting measures are part of a restructuring to increase efficiency and reduce operating expenses.

LEAD: WHEN Zachary Bruell opened his restaurant in Cleveland he devoted the first four nights to raising money for cancer research in memory of his father, who was to have been his partner. Emotionally, he said, the benefit made the opening easier; it also helped introduce Z-Contemporary Cuisine.

LEAD: A controversial AIDS drug that was promoted as a promising treatment by its manufacturer in December has failed to prove effective in a follow-up study, which was released at an international AIDS conference here today.

LEAD: TO THE SARGASSO SEA. By William McPherson. 461 pages. Simon & Schuster. $18.95. IN his graceful first novel, ''Testing the Current'' (1984), William McPherson looked at pre-World War II America through the watchful, curious eyes of an 8-year old boy named Tommy MacAllister. The upper-class, Midwestern realm of his parents is an old-fashioned world, where genteel hypocrisy cloaks adultery and racial bigotry, where decorous manners enable everyone to hold onto the illusion of their innocence.

LEAD: EUROPE remains a favorite summer destination for many Americans, and dining well remains a favorite occupation when they get there. Happily, restaurants on the Continent are as good and as numerous as ever. What has changed this year is their value. Unhappily, Americans looking forward to a memorable meal at their favorite Michelin two-star can count on paying more for it than at any other time in the last few years.

LEAD: A consumer organization has petitioned the Food and Drug Administration to require that nutrition labels on prepared foods include the dietary fiber content. LEAD: Susan Dierdoff Taylor and Cory Fischer are on a tight schedule these days, driving a makeshift wooden trailer to East Coast regattas in preparation for their final push to the 1988 Summer Olympic Games. They are among 12 United States teams competing in the only women's division in yachting.

LEAD: ED HEATH'S amiably ramshackle musical, ''We're Moving On,'' folds a comic folk tale into a gospel service to make a show in which vaudevillian playfulness and gospel fervor become thoroughly intermingled. Exuberantly performed at La Mama E.T.C. by an 11-person cast whose members belong to the Arena Players, a 34-year-old, Baltimore-based black theater organization, ''We're Moving On'' presents a broad comic cross-section of parishioners in a Baltimore storefront church.

LEAD: With all of America's ad agencies to choose from, Campbell Soup, which already retains 10 of them, has gone to London to get creative work on $10 million worth of advertising.

LEAD: The stage is blacked out, but the moans and cries arising from the rumpled bed in the middle are unmistakably those of a man and woman making love. The sounds crescendo, reaching a peak that rivets the attention of everyone in the theater, and then begin to subside into whimpers and sighs. Not a word has yet been spoken, but already the audience is wholly engrossed in the most intimate of experiences being recreated onstage.

LEAD: When Wade Boggs of the Boston Red Sox lined a single in Seattle on April 30, he qualified for major league baseball's list of leading batters with at least 1,000 hits. Among active players, his nearest rival is George Brett of the Kansas City Royals who has a career average of .314.

LEAD: When Abraham Sofaer left his Federal judgeship two years ago to become legal adviser to the State Department, some people wondered why. LEAD: The fashion designer Calvin Klein has temporarily dropped plans to start a men's-wear division within his company, Calvin Klein Industries, according to his employees.

LEAD: Dave DeBusschere has filed a breach-of-contract suit against Gulf and Western, which owns the Knicks. DeBusschere, who was dismissed as general manager in January 1986, is accusing the company of refusing to allow him to exercise options to buy stock under the terms of his contract. The suit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, asks damages of $131,643.75, the difference between the market value of the stock and the option price.

LEAD: Kidder, Peabody & Company is prepared to announce today that it is paying more than $20 million to settle civil charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it profited illegally from trading on inside information, according to people with knowledge of the settlement.

LEAD: Lewis Smith, a retired lighting designer who worked on the lighting of more than 400 churches, died of emphysema May 27 at the Camden (Me.) Health Care Center, a nursing home. He was 83 years old and had lived in Camden since his retirement three years ago.

LEAD: A new Federal study indicates that more Americans could survive a nuclear war than was previously estimated. Civil defense officials say they may use the results to lobby for increased spending for measures to protect the population in event of an attack.

LEAD: Sammy Kaye, the leader of one of the most popular ''sweet bands'' of the swing era, died of cancer on Tuesday at the Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 77 years old. A bandleader for some 50 years, Mr. Kaye had more than 100 hit records, and his slogan, ''Swing and Sway With Sammy Kaye,'' became known throughout the country after he introduced it in the mid-1930's.

LEAD: Brian Dayett had a grand slam and Keith Moreland and Ryne Sandberg also hit home runs in a nine-run first inning to lead the Chicago Cubs to a 22-7 rout of the Houston Astros today in a game featuring a National League record of three grand slams.

LEAD: NORBERT BINOTTI, a 28-year-old interior designer, opened Antiques Mart a month ago, featuring furniture made in the 1920's in southern France. Nearly all the furniture is walnut and there are two styles: provincial and urban. The provincial furniture has carved motifs of fruits and vegetables, and was made for homes in the countryside.

LEAD: Will Sampson, the 6-foot-7-inch actor who played the silent Indian in the film ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest,'' died Wednesday, 43 days after undergoing a heart-lung transplant. He was 53 years old.

LEAD: Despite opposition from the Reagan Administration, the House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved legislation today that would write into law a policy requiring broadcasters to cover community issues and present differing views on controversial topics.

There has been a rush for most of these mail-order plants, so do not be surprised if they are not all available this season.

LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company entered the emerging field of electronic photography with the introduction of seven products designed for professional or commercial use. Electronic still cameras create pictures using the same technology as video cameras. The quality is lower than in pictures that use chemicals, but the images can be altered, stored and transmitted more easily.
LEAD: The Security Pacific Corporation has retained its high-quality Aa-2 long-term debt rating, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

LEAD: Luther Greene, a landscape designer and former theatrical producer, died Sunday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 78 years old. He essentially had two careers -producing Broadway plays, starting in 1935, and designing country and rooftop gardens, starting in the mid-1950's.
LEAD: Michael V. Prentiss is so busy completing a $450 million purchase of properties from the Cadillac Fairview Corporation that ''I've had a hard time doing anything else.''

LEAD: Can the mystique of sports be related in cinematic style? Do sports stars share the same celebrity status as movie stars? Was ''The Babe Ruth Story'' an accurate portrayal of the Yankee slugger, or was it an open distortion of the baseball hero's character?

LEAD: A Federal district judge has ordered the Farmers Home Administration to halt possible foreclosure proceedings for about 78,000 troubled farm borrowers, saying the agency needed to inform farmers again of their rights.

LEAD: Senior members of Congress questioned today whether Congress would approve new assistance for the Nicaraguan rebels if Elliott Abrams remained Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs.

LEAD: An Indian flotilla of fishing boats bound for northern Sri Lanka with food and medicine for ethnic Tamils abruptly called off its mission tonight and turned back after Sri Lankan naval vessels barred it from proceeding.

LEAD: Joseph Massino, portrayed by prosecutors as ''a powerful captain in the Bonanno family'' of the Mafia, won an unusual acquittal of racketeering charges yesterday that included the murder of three rivals.
LEAD: The Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair indicated today that it was unlikely they would substantially delay a vote on granting immunity to Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North.

LEAD: Iraq is maintaining that the American frigate Stark was inside an exclusion zone near Iran when the ship was mistakenly attacked by an Iraqi jet, but the United States has strong evidence that the Stark was outside the zone, the Pentagon said today.

LEAD: Dick Howser, the former manager of the Kansas City Royals who has had three operations for a cancerous brain tumor, was admitted to St. Luke's Hospital in Kansas City, Mo., yesterday. LEAD: FLAT roofs and those with very little pitch, called shed roofs, are usually covered with one or more layers of heavy asphalt roll roofing, rather than with the overlapping shingles found on many pitched roofs. Although flat and shed roofs are not as popular as pitched ones for homes, they are often found on row or attached houses, as well as on attached garages and on rooms that have been added to a house.

LEAD: Hundreds of switches were flicked, myriad motors began to purr and New York City's 14th sewage-treatment plant began operating last week, completing a network of treatment plants first conceived in 1910.

LEAD: President Reagan arrived here today for a meeting of the seven major industrial democracies prepared to make specific suggestions on how allied nations can become more involved in the Persian Gulf, White House officials said.
LEAD: Directors of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange approved a range of measures yesterday intended to deter trading abuses in its financial futures pits.

LEAD: Walter L. Nixon, only the second Federal judge convicted of crimes while in office, has asked a Federal appeals court to reconsider its ruling upholding his perjury conviction. Judge Nixon was sentenced last year to five years in prison for lying to a Federal grand jury regarding a drug suspect who was the son of a business partner.
LEAD: The General Assembly adjourned late tonight after a five-month session that saw legislators approve a $5.64 billion budget but fail to pass a late bill on property-tax relief.

LEAD: If a sterling shutout relief effort by Rich Bordi could overshadow another poor start by Dennis Rasmussen, then the Yankees might have walked away from last night's 9-3 victory over the California Angels feeling elated.

LEAD: Two Alcorn County churches were destroyed by fire within minutes early today, and two men have been charged with burglary and arson. Sheriff Bill Gant said John Harold Miller, 25 years old, of Michie, Tenn., and Eddie P. Brandon, 28, of Glen, Miss., had admitted setting the blazes. The first blaze was set to cover up a burglary, the Sheriff said.

LEAD: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones recommended yesterday that the New York City Board of Education continue to operate the eight high school health clinics that dispense birth-control prescriptions, and that the services be expanded to other high schools.
LEAD: The Department of Transportation said today that it planned to divert $51.5 million and hire 955 more air traffic controllers, supervisors and managers to meet next year's traffic growth.

LEAD: A helicopter crashed and burned this morning in a cornfield, killing both people aboard, the authorities said. The victims' identities were not immediately available. The Robinson R22 helicopter, which belonged to Northeast Helicopters of Ellington, crashed as it appeared to be heading to Ellington Airport, officials said.
LEAD: A memorial for Antony Tudor, who was choreographer emeritus of American Ballet Theater, will be held July 9 at 10 A.M. at the Juilliard School, 155 West 65th Street.

LEAD: Allies of Mikhail S. Gorbachev have mounted an intense campaign to scrap the Soviet leader's much-discussed plan for an economic restructuring and replace it with more far-reaching changes.
LEAD: Stock prices soared broadly yesterday on a positive reaction to the nomination of Alan Greenspan to succeed Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
LEAD: The Datapoint Corporation has announced that Robert J. Potter will succeed Doris D. Bencsik as chief executive of the computer maker in San Antonio.

LEAD: Laurence A. Tisch, the chief executive of CBS Inc., and his brother, Preston R. Tisch, the Postmaster General of the United States, both natives of Brooklyn, yesterday donated $10 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City for the construction of new galleries.

LEAD: There is important and good news in the making at the United Nations. About 100,000 people attended the burial of Mr. Karami, a Sunni Moslem and Lebanon's longest-serving Prime Minister. He was assassinated Monday when a bomb exploded aboard a helicopter in which he was riding.

LEAD: Sheldon Claar, an investment manager, died Sunday of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, at his Manhattan apartment. He was 53 years old.

LEAD: The Knicks can cross off John MacLeod from their list of candidates for coach and general manager. At least, that is how MacLeod feels so long as he remains a leading candidate for the coaching vacancy in Dallas. MacLeod has canceled a Friday appointment with the Knicks in the hope that it will convey his desire to coach the Mavericks.

LEAD: In a stately academy here, four women were citing Freud and Erik Erickson, analyzing the teething process and debating the flaws of baby powder. The women are part of a small but growing movement to create a cadre of American Mary Poppinses, nannies who can handle colic and fevers, make snacks out of wheat germ and perform the Heimlich maneuver on their 2-year-old charges.
LEAD: GORBACHEV'S CHALLENGE. Economic Reform in the Age of High Technology.

LEAD: ELIZABETH RICH is a pianist whose specialty is the reorganization of music by the German Romantics and Classicists into novel programming sequences. Monday evening she gave the first of two Merkin Concert Hall programs devoted to the music Beethoven wrote in 1802, a year of confrontation and struggle with his advancing deafness.

LEAD: Efforts on Capitol Hill to break the impasse over the sponsorship of next year's Presidential debates have failed, according to participants at a recent meeting held in the office of Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming.

LEAD: The Arizona Public Service Company is offering $125 million of 9 7/8 percent first mortgage bonds due in 1997 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. LEAD: A new kind of educational philanthropy, in which benefactors give money not to schools but to individual schoolchldren to inspire them to work harder, is taking hold in several American cities.

LEAD: THE GROUP started out as an all-star quintet of contemporary jazz musicians. Now they are working to become an all-star team. In its first set Tuesday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at 10th Street, where the Group performs through Sunday, the quintet played arrangements a step above jam-session, theme-solos-theme formats, working toward an ensemble sound without slighting soloists -and shifting easily in and out of free jazz.

LEAD: After months of disclosures, investigations and personnel changes, the Reagan Administration's efforts to recover from the covert White House operation to sell arms to Iran have now begun to have an important effect on foreign policy.
LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency, using a new method to calculate pollution, today adopted revised national standards for clean air.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. GAYLORD, #87 First Avenue, at Sixth Street (529-7990) - *(Feb. 20, 1987) The silk-garbed doorman and the purple, pink, yellow, blue and aqua ceiling lights may look uptown, but this 100-seat Indian restaurant is definitely downtown, with prices that agree.
LEAD: Japanese banks appear ready to invest between $100 million and $300 million in BankAmerica Corporation securities according to a source close to the negotiations.

LEAD: Defying the Sri Lanka Government, India sent transport planes and jet fighters over the country's northern territory today and dropped 25 tons of food and medicine by parachute into areas held by embattled insurgents.

LEAD: Tony Bird, an East African songwriter, is to perform songs tonight at Speakeasy, 107 Macdougal Street (598-9670), with Sonya-San, an a capella singer, opening. Tomorrow, Dave Van Ronk is to sing, with Riverrun, a folk group, opening. Sets are at 8:30 and 11 P.M.; admission is $6 with a two-drink minimum.

LEAD: The No Name Gospel Singers, the Golden Sons and the Brooklyn Skyways are to sing a gospel concert tonight at 8 P.M. at the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street (212-206-1050). Admission is $7.

LEAD: The pilots' union of United Airlines yesterday asked the management of the Allegis Corporation, United's parent company, to spin off its car rental and hotel divisions and turn the airline over to United's employees, with Allegis shareholders keeping a 20 percent interest.

LEAD: ''MAKE the music accessible and let the people decide whether they want to come hear it or not,'' said James DePreist, talking by phone the other day from his home in Oregon about the program with the New York Philharmonic he conducts tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. in Avery Fisher Hall.

LEAD: Two presentations of Yiddish theater - one by members of a troupe from the Soviet Union - are planned at two locations in the city this weekend.

LEAD: A FEW days before President Reagan took off for Venice this week, he spoke in the East Room of the White House in honor of the memory of George C. Marshall on the 40th anniversary of the Marshall Plan. On June 5, 1947, General Marshall, then the Secretary of State, delivered the commencement address at Harvard University, offering American help for the reconstruction of war-scarred Europe.
LEAD: A five-story floating barracks, built to house British troops in the Falkland Islands, is to be recommended for use as a 700-bed minimum-security prison for New York State.

LEAD: Alysheba was rained out of his final workout yesterday morning, then drew post No. 4 in a field of 10 and was installed as the 8-to-5 favorite to become racing's 12th Triple Crown winner by winning the Belmont Stakes tomorrow at Belmont Park.

LEAD: Marc Belzberg and his family's investment company - accused of using the chairman of Bear, Stearns & Company to avoid Federal disclosure rules when the wealthy Canadian family amassed a stake in Ashland Oil Inc. in 1986 - employed the same tactic earlier in the year when the Belzberg company bought shares of the Hartmarx Corporation, according to the Securities and Exchange

LEAD: THE Sindoni clan, whose pint-size Sicilian restaurant, Azzurro (84th Street and Second Avenue), turns out some wonderfully pristine pastas and seafood, has branched out on the Upper West Side with Baci, on Amsterdam Avenue between 79th and 80th Streets. The sparkling little cafe, seating about 55, serves the same bright, fresh food as the original.

LEAD: The West End Opera Theater is to present Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 2 P.M. at the American Theater of Actors, 314 West 54th Street. Tickets are from $8 to $10. Information: 799-0101.

LEAD: Safeway Stores Inc. has agreed to sell its 104-store Liquor Barn division to Majestic Wine Warehouses Ltd., a British wine and spirits retailer. Majestic, along with and equity partner M.J.H. LEAD: Roy Eaton, a pianist, is to present an all-Chopin program Sunday at 3 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall. Tickets are $15. Information 362-1911.

LEAD: Many people who believe - wrongly - that America is creating primarily low-skill, dead-end jobs are devising schemes for job protection and Government intervention. Such schemes have been tried in Europe and have failed; indeed, several countries attending next week's economic summit conference are now busily attempting to reverse interventionist policies that have prevented the creation of new jobs.

LEAD: Never underestimate the power of a movie star. Especially a superstar like Elizabeth Taylor. Once she attached her name to the American Foundation for AIDS Research, it became not only acceptable but desirable for other celebrities to become involved in the cause.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: MICHAEL GARIN, a droll, 32-year-old musical comic whose sense of humor is a bit too refined for comedy clubs, has written what may be the ultimate parody of a certain style of self-pitying cocktail song. In clubs and variety showcases around New York over the last several years, Mr. Garin has regularly performed his languid, tinkly love ballad, ''My Hand,'' whose verses echo the deadpan musical humor of Tom

LEAD: A picture caption on Wednesday about the removal of a sculpture from Astor Place for restoration incorrectly described donations being made under the Adopt-a-Monument program. Dan Neale, who adopted the sculpture, is paying for restoration but not for annual maintenance; the Cooper Union has assumed that responsibility.
LEAD: ''Sweep! Sweep! Sweep!''

LEAD: Super African Festival 1, Beacon Theater, 74th and Broadway (496-7070). Lilting, deftly interlocked electric guitar riffs and hearty choral singing in thirds characterize the brand of African pop music that dominates Zaire. Tabu Ley Rochereau has been the style's most consistently successful singer for a decade or more, and recently a series of duet recordings with the sparkling young singer M'Bilia Bel have given his popularity an added boost.

LEAD: THE spring dance season is bustling along its hectic way with the kind of variety and quantity that have made New York the dance capitol of the world. But this is also a weekend that offers a distinctive blend of the old and the new. The seasoned veteran and the newcomer take to the stage in dance that ranges from performances of 19th-century ballet rarities to the antics of exuberant children and adolescents.

LEAD: LINDA HART is a singer equally at home in two very different musical milieus. One is the brassy, bawdy contemporary vaudeville world of Bette Midler, with whom she has sung backup as a member of the Harlettes. The other is the world of her own evangelical Christian background. From the age of 3, the singer toured with her family group, the Harts, a Texas Baptist ensemble, in churches and revival meetings around the country.

LEAD: The head of the State Senate Investigations Committee, calling the maintenance and renovation of New York City's school buildings ''tragically inadequate,'' expressed doubts yesterday about trusting the Board of Education with a planned $4.5 billion building program.
LEAD: Hitting Streak Ends

LEAD: A night of instrumental rock and improvisation by Peter Gordon and the Love of Life Orchestra, Zozobra, No Safety and Dr. Nerve is to take place tomorrow at CBGB, 315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street (982-4052), beginning at approximately 10 P.M. Tickets are $8; for exact set times, call the club.

LEAD: A Superior Court jury today recommended a life sentence with no possibility of parole for Joe Hunt, the founder of a business and social group calling itself the Billionaire Boys Club, in the murder of a Beverly Hills man.

LEAD: Asserting that American farmers are being hurt by loans to less developed countries, some of the nation's most influential farm organizations today called on the United States to withdraw financial support from the World Bank and three other international development banks.
LEAD: In advance of next week's Venice summit meeting, Japan yesterday elaborated on the steps it is planning to liberalize its capital markets.

LEAD: For the last 25 years Martin J. Orlofsky has sold chrysanthemums and gladiolus in his flower shop in downtown Brooklyn, at the corner of Fourth and Flatbush Avenues, while the area around him has ridden an economic roller coaster.

LEAD: ''Saturday Night,'' a play about how a group of young adults spend their Saturday evening, is to be presented this weekend by the Walden Theater Conservatory at the Park Avenue Christian Church, 1010 Park Avenue, at 85th Street. The play was written by members of the conservatory's young playwrights program.
LEAD: After months of trade friction between the United States and Japan, a majority of Japanese consider relations between the two nations unfriendly, a new poll shows.
LEAD: A second AIDS virus, previously reported spreading in West Africa, has been detected in Europe and Brazil, Dr. Luc Montagnier of the Pasteur Institute in Paris said here today.

LEAD: ''In the 18th century, the tracker organ was the most complex machine assembled by Western man.'' That arresting thought comes from an hourlong documentary to be shown tonight at 10 on Channel 13 entitled ''The Wind at One's Fingertips.'' The subject is a Nebraska organ builder, Gene R. Bedient, and the yearslong process by which he and his crew of craftsmen researched, designed, built and installed an 18th-century, French-style, tracker-action organ at St.
LEAD: An article yesterday about the dedication of the first computer in a $400 million air control network misstated the role of Donald D. Engen, head of the Federal Aviation Administration.
LEAD: MARKETS

LEAD: Today CRAFT SHOW, #42d Street, between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas. Today, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Leather goods, jewelry, pottery, clothing. Through December. STREET FAIR, Public School 11, 21st Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. Today, 5 to 8 P.M. Games, crafts, flea market, toys, auction.

LEAD: Noel Baum, a candidate for Governor of Louisiana, died Wednesday when the small plane he was piloting crashed more than 500 miles from his intended destination, the authorities said today. He was 49 years old. Mr. Baum, an insurance executive, may have suffered a heart attack while flying the single-engine Cessna P210, said Lieut.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: IN 1908, Carlo Carra (1881-1966) produced ''Riders of the Apocalypse,'' a torrid piece of Symbolism featuring three mounted figures, two of whom are nymphs. Two years later, the artist was a Futurist, extolling machinery, speed, violence and other manifestations of the male principle.
LEAD: President P. W. Botha was mobbed by hundreds of cheering blacks today when he visited this bleak township, where 69 protesting blacks were killed by the police in 1960.

LEAD: Members of the Gibbs-Cox softball team showed up after work for a scheduled game on a field in Queensbridge Park, near the Queensboro Bridge in Long Island City. They came prepared for the light rain, but the opposition team, because of the weather, never showed up. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)

LEAD: ON READING RUSKIN. Prefaces to La Bible d'Amiens and Sesame et les Lys with Selections from the Notes to the Translated Texts. By Marcel Proust. Translated and Edited by Jean Autret, William Burford and Phillip J. Wolfe, with an introduction by Richard Macksey. Illustrated. 173 pages. Yale University Press.

LEAD: Two patterns emerge starkly from the Iran-contra hearings: of deception and self-enrichment. The Reagan Administration admits, with painful reluctance, that it misinformed Congress and the public about its secret activities in Nicaragua. Just as reluctantly, participants in the arms supply operation to the
LEAD: Attention must be paid when a movie is as aggressively awful as ''Harry and the Hendersons,'' though it's so pin-headed that it could be the last of its inbred line. It's not likely to spawn.

LEAD: Assets of the nation's 383 money market mutual funds decreased by $423.1 million, to $238.91 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 94 institutional funds were down $431.2 million, to $64.43 billion. Assets of the 199 general purpose funds were up $536.5 million, to $69.11 billion.

LEAD: The Mets came home from California yesterday to set the stage for the return of Dwight Gooden tonight. ''We're through the worst of it,'' Dave Johnson said. ''We got past the road trip. We pieced the pitching together, and we bought time.''
LEAD: Bruno Bernard, a photographer known as Bruno of Hollywood, died of cancer Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 75 years old.
LEAD: Building on the previous day's sharp rally, the Dow Jones industrial average added 16.39 points yesterday, to close at 2,337.08, its highest level in a month.

LEAD: Ranks of robed Ku Klux Klan marchers plan to parade through the streets of Greensboro Sunday in their first public demonstration here since a bloody shootout between armed Klansmen and leftists in 1979 left five people dead.
LEAD: A group of leading Democratic senators introduced legislation today that would outlaw or severely restrict a host of devices frequently used in corporate takeover battles.

LEAD: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., who will formally declare his candidacy for the Democratic nomination next week, was asked about his ''reputation as a hothead'' yesterday. ''I think there are certain things that warrant being angry,'' said the Senator from Delaware, who distinguished between being angry and losing one's temper.
LEAD: Penguins Hire Coach
LEAD: The New York investor George Soros has purchased 2.13 million shares of the Texas Air Corporation, a 5.3 percent stake in the nation's largest airline, for $85.5 million.

LEAD: Diane Chaplin, a cellist, is to play works by three American composers - Horace Wadham Nicholl, Charles Wakefield Cadman and Arthur Foote - tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. in Weill Recital Hall. The program also includes pieces by Boccherini and Hindemith. Emily Wong George is the pianist. Tickets are $8, $4 for students and the elderly.

LEAD: THROUGH the first part of the century, Berlin was a city in which culture flourished - not just art movements like German Expressionism and Dada, but also music, literature and theater. Under Hitler, Berlin was the Nazi headquarters. During World War II, it was almost leveled. In 1961 it was divided in two by the Berlin Wall.
LEAD: Rolande Clair, a tall, slightly graying 63-year-old woman from Lyons, kept a 43-year-old promise today.

LEAD: IF you have been disappointed lately with the lack of taste in strawberries bought in supermarkets, take heart: ripe, red berries with the old-time flavor are now ready for picking in nearby New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
LEAD: MacLeod Joins Dallas

LEAD: ONE of the encouraging notes for the Broadway season coming up is that Lanford Wilson's new play, ''Burn This,'' is scheduled for the Great White Way as of Oct. 15. The comedy had a limited run this year at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, where it was one of the biggest hits in its history, and by the Circle Repertory Company, which opened its 22 performances to subscribers only.

LEAD: Over the objection of the special prosecutor, the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair voted today to compel testimony from Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North by granting him limited immunity from prosecution.
LEAD: ''Our goal is to avoid the useless prolongation of dying. This is not a quality-of-life issue, a question of what the patient's life will be like if he gets better.

LEAD: On Wednesday, The Plain Dealer in Cleveland, in an article that covered the top of its front page, said that Gov. Richard F. Celeste of Ohio, a Democrat who is considering a run for the Presidency, had been ''romantically linked'' with at least three women other than his wife, one as recently as 1985.

LEAD: ''THE next song, 'Scratch,' requires four alligator clips, a bolt, a comb and a guitar slide to make it sound just right,'' Roger Miller said Wednesday night at CBGB. He calmly placed those objects on the strings of a Yamaha electric grand piano and -using reverberation and distortion devices, a synthesizer and a tape-loop echo-repeat system - played another plinking, clanking, crunching, howling song.

LEAD: The Taft Broadcasting Company said its board had approved a sweetened takeover proposal for the media company from a partnership of Taft's major shareholders. The partnership is led by the FMI Financial Corporation, of which the Cincinnati financier Carl H. Lindner's American Financial Corporation owns 72 percent.

LEAD: Every morning for nearly six weeks, the judge in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz has carried the same manila file folder under his arm as he strides to the bench in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

LEAD: Space agency officials announced yesterday that they had established a new confidential system to encourage ''whistle blowers'' to report safety concerns about the space shuttle and any other operations.
LEAD: The Wedtech Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of a new chief executive officer as the South Bronx military contractor struggled to stay in business.

LEAD: A brief article yesterday about a memorial service for the choreographer Antony Tudor misstated the date. It will be at 10 A.M. next Tuesday - June 9, not July 9 - at the Juilliard School, 155 West 65th Street.

LEAD: The Pentagon has selected two teams of contractors to pursue research and demonstration work on one of the most important elements of the proposed ''Star Wars'' antimissile system - the use of orbiting ''killer'' rockets.
LEAD: Steffi Graf and Martina Navratilova won semifinal matches today at the French Open, setting up what promises to be an emotion-charged final.

LEAD: Gov. Bob Martinez signed the Florida lottery bill into law today, with a starting date of Jan. 15. The bill was approved by the Legislature seven months after voters passed a referendum to use lottery games to finance education. The lottery is expected to raise an estimated $144 million in the last half of the fiscal year 1987-88 and become a billion-dollar business in its first year.
LEAD: The bright green rice shoots stand in the flooded paddies of Furukawa; the spring planting is over and in a few months the harvest will begin.

LEAD: Charles S. Sanford Jr., who played a major role in turning the Bankers Trust New York Corporation into one of the most profitable of the nation's major banking institutions, yesterday was named chairman and chief executive of the company and of its subsidiary, the Bankers Trust Company. The appointment will become effective July 1, when Alfred Brittain 3d, the current chairman and chief executive, retires.
LEAD: DEBT

LEAD: ''Waldo's All New 1927 Revue,'' Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street (864-5400). Terry Waldo, a pianist, and the Gotham City Jazz Band head a variety show that evokes the spirit of the 20's, mixing hot jazz, classic ragtime, eccentric dancing, comedy and vocal numbers. The cast includes Patty Holley, who was featured last fall in Duke Ellington's ''Queenie Pie'' in Philadelphia and at the Kennedy Center in Washington, as well as Betsy Baytos, an eccentric dancer, and Danny Willis, a 23-year-old baritone who came to New York in hopes of making 78 rpm records.

LEAD: * Buckeye Financial Corp., Columbus, Ohio, a holding company, said it had accepted an offer in which First Financial Group Inc. would acquire each common share of Buckeye for a package consisting of $9 in cash, $8 in First Financial debentures, and $3 in preferred stock.

LEAD: President Reagan will seek support at the economic summit meeting here for a United Nations resolution threatening Iran and Iraq with an arms embargo if they refuse negotiations to end their war, White House officials said today.

LEAD: Opening a new front in his confrontation with state legislators over new laws on ethics in government, Governor Cuomo said today that an ethics bill now under negotiation would be inadequate to prevent corrupt practices in state government.
LEAD: John T. Agresto, deputy chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, has notified the White House that he is withdrawing his candidacy to become Archivist of the United States.
LEAD: Bret Saberhagen became the first 10-game winner in the major leagues, pitching a seven-hitter tonight as the Kansas City Royals beat the Seattle Mariners, 6-1.
LEAD: The people who saved one of the city's most desirable dance and theater rehearsal spaces from commercial development held a victory celebration yesterday in the turn-of-the-century building.
LEAD: The state's environmental commissioner today ordered 15,000 barrels of radium-contaminated soil that have been stored in Montclair and Kearny moved to state-owned land in Jackson Township.
LEAD: International A2-11

LEAD: Faced with mounting consumer complaints and moves in Congress to pass new laws, the Department of Transportation acted today to press airlines to improve baggage handling, operate closer to schedule and reduce cancellations.

LEAD: A reading of ''Hans Clodhopper,'' the Hans Christian Andersen story, is to open the 31st season of free storytelling at the Hans Christian Andersen statue tomorrow at 11 A.M. in Central Park, near Fifth Avenue and 72d Street. The reading will be given by Diane Wolkstein, with musical accompaniment by Shirley Keller, a guitarist.
LEAD: Jerry Roberts, a veteran broadcaster, died May 24 at the Hackensack (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 71 years old and lived in Lyndhurst, N.J.

LEAD: The West German Parliament today formally endorsed the Government's decision to support Soviet and American efforts to eliminate medium-range land-based missiles from Europe, though Chancellor Helmut Kohl came under fire from both left and right.

LEAD: Tucson High School won the Arizona state baseball championship last week, defeating its crosstown rival, Sahuaro High School, 11-3, at Tempe Diablo Stadium. That was the 28th state title for the team, and it added to the school's national record in that category.

LEAD: An unpopular Congressional experiment has died a quiet death. Last year, under pressure from a new budget-balancing law, Congress started charging the public for bills, committee reports and other official publications.
LEAD: In a step that broadens the scope of the Wall Street scandals, Kidder, Peabody & Company agreed yesterday to pay a record $25.3 million to settle insider-trading charges.
LEAD: Looking for someone to lend advice on the problems of the day, The Chicago Sun-Times in the 1950's turned to a housewife from Iowa named Eppie.

LEAD: Donald Byrd, a trumpeter, is to lead a quartet featuring James Williams on piano, and Michel Petrucciani, a pianist, leads a trio tonight through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (212-475-8592). Sets begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M. through Sunday, plus a 1:30 A.M. show tonight and tomorrow; there is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $7.50 charge at the bar.
LEAD: It is said here, adapting an old folk expression, that Chernobyl is seven seas and 13 rivers away from Bangladesh. But these days it seems much closer.

LEAD: Two operators of a Long Island company pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal charges that they stole $1 million of pipes owned by New York City and then sold the pipes to contractors working on the city's sewer and water mains.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: New York State's highest court today overturned the murder conviction of a Long Island youth serving 25 years to life in prison for killing a 13-year-old boy by stuffing rocks into his mouth.

LEAD: Wrappings and ribbons from tobacco packaging of the late 19th century are included in the exhibition ''Tobacco Roads: The Popular Art of an American Pastime,'' on view at City Gallery, 2 Columbus Circle. The display, organized by the Museum of American Folk Art, features about 70 items that illustrate the relationship of the tobacco industry and folk art.

LEAD: A senior Iranian diplomat urged Washington's allies in Europe today to reject plans to safeguard shipping in the Persian Gulf, warning that an increased American military presence there would prove dangerous.

LEAD: Two rare white tigers in the back of a parked truck were abducted on the West Side of Manhattan yesterday morning, apparently by someone who was unaware of the truck's cargo. Five hours later, after a citywide search by the police, a safety alert by health officials and a news alert by television and radio stations, the tigers were found unharmed in the back of the truck, which had been abandoned in the

LEAD: A Federal appeals court today overturned a ruling freezing assets of the former President of the Philippines, Ferdinand E. Marcos, and his wife, Imelda, saying the Philippine Government had little chance of regaining $1.5 billion it claims the couple stole.

LEAD: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has proposed that negotiations on the continued presence of United States military bases in Greece be linked to this country's long-running dispute with Turkey and that any accord with Washington be put to a referendum.

LEAD: MAYBE ''Shadey'' is meant to be a spoof on formula movies. Snoo Wilson, who wrote the British feature that opens today at the Quad Cinema, has tossed elements of many formulas into his brew - science-fiction, spy thriller, screwball comedy, black humor, political satire, psychosex, fantasy and more - and mixed ill.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Hub, a computer-music group, is to play a concert for computers linked by telephones Saturday and Sunday at 9 P.M. simultaneously at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation, 224 Centre Street, at Grand Street (212-431-5127), and at the Clocktower, 108 Leonard Street (212-233-1096). The performers and composers will be Chris Brown, John Bischoff, Mark Trayle, Tim Perkis, Scot Gresham-Lancaster and Phil Stone.

LEAD: In a major decision broadening the legal rights of homeless families, New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that courts had the power to set requirements for safe and sanitary conditions.
LEAD: GOLF

LEAD: Tony Bird, an East African songwriter, is to perform songs tonight at Speakeasy, 107 Macdougal Street (212-598-9670), with Sonya-San, an a capella singer, opening. Tomorrow, Dave Van Ronk is to sing, with Riverrun, a folk group, opening. Sets at 8:30 and 11 P.M.; admission $6 with a two-drink minimum.

LEAD: The head of the Small Business Administration today strongly opposed a bill to revise the Federal program that enabled the Wedtech Corporation to obtain hundreds of millions of dollars in Government contracts.

LEAD: The chairman of a House subcommittee said today that he would ask the White House to reveal the duties of three Small Business Administration employees working at the White House without the consent of their agency.
LEAD: Edward A. Eppinger, who built a fishing-lure empire through the sale of the Dardevle lure, died Monday at his home here. He was 82 years old.

LEAD: The Justice Department said yesterday that it would not join a lawsuit against Morton Thiokol Inc., maker of the space shuttle's solid-fuel booster rockets. The suit charges the company with defrauding the Government by knowingly providing defective rockets.

LEAD: Il Piccolo Teatro dell'Opera is to present a double-bill of Mozart's ''Impresario'' and Lukas Foss's ''Introductions and Goodbyes,'' conducted by Mr. Foss, today at 10:30 A.M. and tomorrow at 8 P.M. in the Carey Playhouse of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, in the Fort Greene section.
