LEAD: THE place was the Museum of Modern Art Sculpture Garden, where Blaine Trump let out a hearty but ladylike cheer at Wednesday night's fund-raising Party in the Garden. Carolyne Roehm had just told her that the Victorian Boating Party had been postponed.

LEAD: Parliament approved legislation Thursday banning nuclear-armed and nuclear-powered ships from New Zealand's ports, putting into law a policy that the Labor Government adopted nearly three years ago.
LEAD: When Sugar Ray Leonard announced his conditional retirement from boxing last week, it set off a scramble among middleweight contenders in the suddenly wide-open division.

LEAD: A majority of Japanese described United States-Japan relations as unfriendly in a poll conducted last month by The New York Times, CBS News and the Tokyo Broadcasting System. That represented a dramatic shift in attitude from a poll in April 1986 in which less than a third of the Japanese characterized relations with the United
LEAD: Resch Retires
LEAD: The World Bank announced yesterdaythat it is offering the largest issue ever of fixed-rate Eurobonds denominated in sterling.
LEAD: Few people in the history of the game, or indeed of any competitive recreation, have won the same major title with an interval of 47 years.

LEAD: The National Education Association's professional organizers ratified a new contract today, ending a three-day strike that had hobbled activities at the union's national headquarters. Barry Abel, a spokesman for the 63-member Association of Field Service Employees, said the three-year contract provided annual raises of 5 percent and improvements in the pension plan.

LEAD: AMERICAN HARVEST, the showcase restaurant at the Vista International Hotel in the shadow of the World Trade Center, bills itself as a star-spangled celebration of home-grown provender prepared with allegiance to our culinary heritage. O.K., maybe the Pilgrims didn't garnish salmon steaks with juniper berries and lemon mayonnaise, but why be persnickety and spoil the party?
LEAD: YOU wouldn't guess it from her offstage manner, but Sandra Chinn feels more comfortable as a cockroach than as a butterfly.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: IN an equity market that seems lately to have lost its sense of direction, several shoe stocks -considered a ''niche'' industry by most Wall Street standards - have moved ahead briskly.

LEAD: The newly formed American National Opera Company is to present Mozart's ''Magic Flute,'' in English, conducted by James Kay, tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3 P.M., and again June 12 through 14 at the same times, at the Brooklyn Conservatory, 58 Seventh Avenue, near Flatbush Avenue, in the Park Slope section.

LEAD: At least four laboratories are now reporting tests in which synthetic materials show signs of losing all resistance to electrical current at close to room temperature of about 70 degrees Fahrenheit. The findings have further encouraged hope that the components with total loss of resistance can be isolated and used for a multitude of revolutionary applications.
LEAD: Fallon McElligott of Minneapolis and Chiat/Day of Los Angeles, San Francisco and New York were the big winners at the One Show last night at the Palladium.

LEAD: No matter how many ways they phrased the questions, reporters could not lure the two prosecutors, Rudolph W. Giuliani or Mario Merola, to make broad comments on greed and corruption in the Wedtech case.

LEAD: The Iraqi missile attack on the United States frigate Stark last month has complicated Washington's military relationship with Saudi Arabia, whose pilots declined to intercept the Iraqi plane after its strike.

LEAD: After being offered a job at the New York City Planning Department last August, Tucker Ashworth told his prospective employer there was something he ought to know: he had AIDS. The offer, director of public affairs, stood; he accepted.
LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY
LEAD: Edwin Moses' 122-race winning streak, the longest in the history of track, ended today when Danny Harris, another American, beat him in the 400-meter hurdles at an international meet here.

LEAD: Former Federal District Judge Noel P. Fox, whose career included a controversial ruling allowing Indian tribes to fish commercially in the Great Lakes without Government interference, died Wednesday at the Villa Elizabeth Nursing Home, where he had lived since February 1986, Mary Ann Greenhoe, director of nursing, said today.

LEAD: A top Federal expert, in an effort to calm some of the increasing anxiety over AIDS, emphasized here today that surveys had found no sign that a major spread of the AIDS virus had begun among heterosexual Americans.

LEAD: As allied support grows for an accord to reduce medium- and short-range nuclear forces in Europe, I am reminded of a brief conversation I had at the Reykjavik summit meeting with Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, chief of staff of the Soviet armed forces.
LEAD: The head of New York State's prisons said today that he would recommend the purchase of a decommissioned British troop barge for use as a 700-bed minimum-security prison.
LEAD: A House subcommittee refused today to block the sale of 12 F-5 jet fighters to Honduras, a decision that legislators said would effectively end Congressional attempts to halt the deal.

LEAD: More than 30 films by artists and film makers from the East Village are to be shown this weekend at the New Theater, 62 East Fourth Street. The films are part of the Late Show Film Series, which will be offered at the theater for the next four weekends. Screenings this weekend are at 8 and 10 P.M.

LEAD: The Gerber Products Company said the management of CWT Inc., its trucking subsidiary, had offered to purchase the business. Gerber had declared its interest in selling the unit two months ago. It said acceptance of the deal depended on CWT management's obtaining financing for its leveraged buyout offer.

LEAD: The main agency that accredits hospitals in the United States said today that it would require them to have formal policies specifying when doctors and nurses may refrain from trying to resuscitate patients who are terminally ill.
LEAD: The most up-and-down team in baseball, the Milwaukee Brewers, was up tonight and sent the Yankees down to defeat, 9-3.

LEAD: THE J. Walter Thompson Company, whose people could certainly use the boost in morale, took five gold prizes last night as the most effective advertising of 1986 was honored at the 19th annual Effie Awards at the New York Hilton.
LEAD: The vectors of two seemingly unrelated scandals intersected this week at an East Bronx church, appropriately named the Cross Road Tabernacle.

LEAD: A divided Federal appeals court yesterday affirmed a lower-court decision that imposed a $100,000-a-day fine against the two principal organizations of Roman Catholic Church bishops in this country.

LEAD: Several companies and investors, including some well-known corporate raiders, are considering buying major stakes in Texaco Inc., the chairman and chief executive of the Pennzoil Company said today.
LEAD: House Budget Committee members today rejected a compromise on the 1988 budget that would have given the Defense Department $8 billion more than the House approved.

LEAD: Former Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada and the McClatchy newspaper chain announced an agreement yesterday to dismiss competing lawsuits that have been seen as a barrier to Mr. Laxalt's plans to run for President.

LEAD: An ambitious redevelopment program for Coney Island, including new amusement and shopping malls, a new boardwalk and stages for concerts and festivals, is recommended in a new study conducted for New York City parks officials.
LEAD: A group of 23 corporations and financial institutions was asked today to join in a study of the feasibility of opening a 24-hour-a-day stock exchange in Atlanta.

LEAD: Phyllis Halliday collapsing yesterday in Nanticoke, Pa., near Wilkes-Barre, after learning that her son, Robert, had shot to death his former girlfriend, Kimberly Kruczek, and then killed himself. With her were her sister, Audrey Hummel, and a police detective, Frank Requlski. (AP)

LEAD: Mention the slums of Lambeth and the average English voter might only smile and hum the show-stopping tune ''Lambeth Walk,'' envisioning this city's doughty Cockneys happy with a meager lot in life as they coarsely needle their social betters.

LEAD: Senators John W. Warner, left, Republican of Virginia, and John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, meeting Wednesday with Sheik Zayed bin Siltan al-Nahyan, President of the United Arab Emirates, in Abu Dhabi. The Senators concluded a five-nation tour in search of ways to preserve free navigation in the Gulf.
LEAD: In this self-proclaimed ''colony of the arts'' - and one of America's most famous small towns - the scent of history hangs on almost everything.

LEAD: If NBC moves to Secaucus, its news crews should be warned they won't get the kind of footage from the big developer here - Eugene Heller - that they now get by going around the corner and talking to Donald Trump.

LEAD: A picture of a young woman striding with a baby in her arms down a deserted corridor was released last night by the police, who said it was taken by a security camera at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx Wednesday night as the woman kidnapped the child.
LEAD: Elizabeth Morgan, a veteran actress and longtime officer and board member of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, died of a stroke on Sunday at her Manhattan home.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THIS is a time when many young artists feel compelled to stress the commodity status of the work they produce. They let us know they know that their art is in part made to be bought, installed and viewed, that it may bring its maker fame and fortune and its owner pleasure and status. Few artists make this knowledge evident with as much chutzpah and technical finesse as Ashley Bickerton, who has dedicated his second one-person exhibition at International With Monument (111 East Seventh Street, near First Avenue, through Sunday) to Robin Leach.

LEAD: HARDLY had Nazi Germany died in 1945 than Berlin's theaters began to come to life. The need for diversion seemed almost as great as any of the other many needs of the residents of a destroyed and conquered city. People lined up at box offices, much as they lined up for water or fuel, some having walked for two or three hours to see a production of ''The Gay Parisienne.

LEAD: Milk has become a symbol of triumph for New York City consumers. Since a Federal judge ordered the state to allow Farmland Dairy of New Jersey to sell milk in the city, the price has fallen 41 cents a gallon. But victory is not yet assured. As the Attorney General and consumer protection chief warn, low milk prices depend entirely on a single dairy that defies the local milk cartel.

LEAD: On the desolate block of East Sixth Street between Avenues C and D -where homeless families have built a fragile shantytown and where countless windows of an unfinished city-sponsored housing project have been lost to vandals - No. 742 is on its way to becoming a neighborhood shrine.

LEAD: It's double-take time at the newsstands once again. This time, it's not similar covers on Time and Newsweek, but it's Forbes aping the cover format of Business Week with its June 15 issue. And it's really an inside joke. William Donald Garson, public relations director of Forbes, said it was the magazine's way of retaliating for what he called Business Week's copying of Forbes's idea for an issue on chief executives.
LEAD: McNab Leaving
LEAD: The City of Detroit has lined up Japanese investors to finance the early stages of a $1.2 billion economic development project that includes a new assembly plant for the Chrysler Corporation.

LEAD: Frank Chiapperno of A&M Auto Wreckers, left, and Robert Monaco, a supervisor in the Sanitation Department Derelict Vehicles Operation, examining the car that had been left abandoned and unlocked at 104th Street and Broadway on the West Side. It was finally towed away Wednesday. After eluding theft and vandalism, with key in the ignition, for nine days on the street, the compact car was made even more so in preparation for its final journey -to a crusher in Newark.

LEAD: When Pope John Paul II returns on his third papal visit to his native land this month, no group will be more eager to see him than Poland's 300,000 Ukrainian Catholics, whose church has affirmed papal dominion for nearly 400 years, often with piety, risk and sacrifice.

LEAD: More than 25 dance, theater, music and film programs from 16 nations have been engaged for the first New York International Festival of the Arts next June, Martin E. Segal, chairman of the festival, announced yesterday. Negotiations are under way for some 60 more.
LEAD: ''There aren't many of us left,'' observed Clark M. Clifford, the silver-gray eminence who has served as a counselor to Presidents for more than 40 years.

LEAD: Joseph Licitra, managing partner of the Garden City, L.I., law firm of Shaw, Goldman, Licitra, Levine & Weinberg, died Wednesday at Winthrop-University Hospital in Mineola, L.I., after a long illness. He was 57 years old and lived in Garden City.

LEAD: Flute Force, a quartet of flutists, is to perform works by Bach, Roger Reynolds, Jeremy Beck, A. Leroy and David Jones on Sunday at 4 P.M. at 100 Grand Street. Tickets are $8, $6 for students and the elderly. Information: 866-3594.

LEAD: PRECIOUS objects and architectural relics - a rare gold box awash with jewels by Tiffany & Company, sections of a cast-iron staircase by Louis Sullivan, a silver-plated clock by Josef Hoffmann of Vienna and a gold musical automaton watch by Carrisol of Geneva - are among the highlights in auctions taking place tomorrow and next week at Sotheby's and Christie's.

LEAD: WILL there be an anti-British - or, rather, an anti-French - backlash this year? Would August Wilson's play have a better chance to win as best play if it were called ''Les Fences,'' or would ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses'' have a better chance if theatergoers could pronounce the title properly and also spell it?

LEAD: At one point in his testimony, Albert Hakim described a tour of the White House that he and Lieut. Col. Oliver North gave to a contact in the Iranian Government who came to be known as the ''second channel.''

LEAD: Big Time Sarah, a blues singer, is to perform tonight and tomorrow at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (212-777-5077), with sets at 9:30 P.M. and midnight. There is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.
LEAD: The Coast Guard is backing off from a policy of intensive boardings of pleasure boats on the Great Lakes that grew out of a mandate to become involved in the campaign against drug trafficking.
LEAD: The night will belong to a couple of superheroes, one found in the funny pages, the other a young pitcher known as Dr. K, both attempting to overcome the pitfalls of the real world.

LEAD: Calvin Klein Industries has lost its second high-ranking executive this week. Edward M. Jones 3d has resigned as president and director of international licensing at the company's Classics division, the fashion designer Calvin Klein said yesterday.

LEAD: Albert Hakim, an Iranian-born businessman, testified today that he thought Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North must have been aware that a secret $200,000 Swiss bank account had been set up for him and that Mr. Hakim had made him a beneficiary in his will for $2 million.

LEAD: ESPN's coverage of the seventh game of the Stanley Cup championship series between the Edmonton Oilers and the Philadelphia Flyers on Sunday received a 5.0 rating from the A. C. Nielsen company and attracted the fourth largest viewing audience - 2,140,000 million homes - in ESPN's eight-year history.
LEAD: Firefighters searching for a missing victim after an explosion and fire ripped through a car dealership in Essington, south of Philadelphia. At least six people were reported injured. (AP)

LEAD: ''Anyone who desires to survive into vigorous old age,'' Donal Henahan, the Times music critic, wrote last year, ''can improve his chance dramatically by arranging to be born with extraordinary talent as a musical performer.'' The master guitarist Andres Segovia, like Pablo Casals and Arthur Rubinstein, made such an arrangement.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch yesterday about legislation on airline safety misstated the reason for a surplus in the airport trust fund. A surplus has been created by revenues that were higher than expected; since Sept. 30, $1.25 billion has been spent from the fund.
LEAD: The New York City Department of Transportation has listed these trouble spots for weekend traffic:
LEAD: Bond prices were stable to slightly higher yesterday as many market participants waited for fresh economic data and next week's economic summit meeting.

LEAD: John B. Fraser, the president of Morgan Grenfell Inc., the New York-based subsidiary of the British merchant bank, has left to become a managing director in the mergers and acquisitions department of the Citicorp Investment Bank.

LEAD: Private homes, a church, a concert hall and a park can be visited on Sunday during a tour of the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn. The tour, sponsored by the Fort Greene Landmarks Preservation Committee, begins at noon at the Williamsburg Savings Bank, 1 Hanson Place, off Flatbush Avenue. Admission is $6 (advance tickets) or $7 on the day of the tour ($5 for the elderly.)

LEAD: Israel Chorberg, a violinist, and Harold Coletta, a violist, are to perform works by Mozart, Paul Chihara, Villa-Lobos and others, Sunday at 3 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. Tickets are $7. Information: (212) 362-8719.
LEAD: Several of the nation's largest insurance companies are planning drastic reductions in the amount of life insurance they will offer to anyone who refuses to take blood tests for the AIDS virus.

LEAD: A few weeks ago, in her Villanova dormitory, Vicki Huber spotted a copy of Track and Field News. As she thumbed through the magazine, she noticed a list of athletes in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championships.

LEAD: Two journalists who disclosed information that embarrassed the South Korean Government have been found guilty by a judge in Seoul. But the judge released a third defendant and gave the other two light sentences.
LEAD: One of the ironies of Mikhail Gorbachev's ''openness'' and ''restructuring'' program is the impact on the Soviet bloc.

LEAD: It's a true piece of fortune that Edward Koch is Mayor of New York and not, say, Secretary of State. Consider his suggestion that all foreign tourists to New York be barred if they test positive for the AIDS virus. Consider how ill considered this idea turns out to be.
LEAD: A Growing Empire

LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi won opposition support for India's air drop of relief supplies for the Tamils in northern Sri Lanka Thursday night and moved to explain and defend the Indian action to leaders of other nations.
LEAD: Retail sales in New York City rose an average 8.2 percent in May over the year before, a spot-check found yesterday, while sales in the metropolitan area were up an average of 7.7 percent.

LEAD: Name: David M. Lewis Age: 40 Position: Partner in the Washington law firm of Finkelstein, Thompson, Levinson & Lewis, practicing primarily securities law. Role: Mr. Lewis was approached by Willard I. Zucker, an American lawyer who, in effect, ran one of the Swiss companies involved in the secret transfers of funds from the Iranian arms sales to the Nicaraguan rebels, to help design a fund for Lieut.
LEAD: The Jardine Matheson group, one of the oldest and biggest trading companies in Asia, yesterday named an American lawyer as its managing director.

LEAD: George Stubbs's ''Baron de Robeck Riding a Bay Cob'' (1791), which depicts an aristocrat on a rearing horse, was sold yesterday at Sotheby's for $2.42 million, a record at auction for a sporting picture and for a painting by the British artist. The buyer, who was not identified, bid over the telephone.

LEAD: Cedar Walton on piano, Ron Carter on bass and Billy Higgins on drums play trios tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (212-242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

LEAD: A 74-year-old Irish prelate, Msgr. John Patrick Carroll-Abbing, who founded Boys Town and Girls Town of Italy 40 years ago, was made an honorary citizen of Rome this evening, the third non-Italian in modern history to be so honored. The others were Presidents Woodrow Wilson and Franklin D. Roosevelt.

LEAD: Lieut. Gen. Alfred M. Gray Jr. has been recommended by Navy Secretary James H. Webb as the next Commandant of the Marine Corps, replacing Gen. P. X. Kelley when he retires this month, according to Pentagon officials.

LEAD: Reid Nagle, an investment banker formerly employed by Ivan F. Boesky & Company, filed suit yesterday in New York State Supreme Court against Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., charging that it failed to honor an employment agreement.

LEAD: Hundreds of homeless people abandoned their makeshift shelters as a line of about 40 police officers swept through Skid Row Thursday night, tossing belongings into the street and threatening to arrest those who refused to move.

LEAD: The House of Deputies gave final approval early today to a bill that would end prosecution of most military officers accused of rights abuses in the ''dirty war'' against leftists in the 1970's.

LEAD: The Playland Amusement Park here has been designated a national landmark by the United States Department of the Interior, the Westchester County Executive, Andrew O'Rourke, said today. The 279-acre park, opened in 1928 and built in an Art Deco style, was the first totally planned amusement park in the country, according to county officials.

LEAD: In a rare display of independence that caught Mayor Koch's office by surprise, a City Council committee yesterday disapproved nine of Mr. Koch's nominations to city boards and postponed action on two others, refusing even to hear testimony from the stunned candidates and their supporters.

LEAD: Public television's ''WonderWorks,'' a family entertainment series, continues to import quality British and Australian series to flesh out its schedule. Beginning tonight at 8 on WNET, and concluding next Saturday, there is a two-hour production of ''The December Rose,'' a co-production of the BBC/Friday Productions in association with Alpine Pictures Ltd.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Minstar Inc., the Minneapolis-based leisure products and energy services concern, said today that it would take a special charge of $15.8 million against its second-quarter earnings for the costs of a plan to reduce its debt.
LEAD: Ivan Lendl softened up a counterpuncher while Mats Wilander knocked out a heavyweight today in the semifinal round of the French Open.

LEAD: When 20 teams assemble this weekend in Quebec for the finals of the Canadian Grand National Team Championship, one of the pairs involved will be thinking back to an earlier stage of the event. Irving Litvack of Willowdale, Ontario, and Joe Silver of Montreal solved a bidding problem that would be likely to defeat the best players in the world.
LEAD: The Pirates were not looking forward to playing a supporting role in the Dwight Gooden story last night. He entered the game with a 6-0 career record against them and improved upon it.

LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday declined to rule in advance on whether a radio broadcast of part of James Joyce's ''Ulysses'' would violate the indecency standards adopted by the commission in April.

LEAD: After 20 years of argument, Canada's quarreling parliamentarians joined in a prolonged ovation when Prime Minister Brian Mulroney announced on May 1: ''What we now have is a whole country.'' Quebec had finally compromised and signed a new Constitution in return for recognition of its status as a ''distinct society'' among Canada's 10 provinces.

LEAD: Mayor Koch in Washington as he testified before a House Energy subcommittee. ''If Congress sets limits that can't be met, no one will build any facilities,'' he warned of bills that would require Environmental Protection Agency to regulate air emissions and ash produced by municipal incinerators. Under one bill, ash would have to be tested for hazardous content.
LEAD: President Reagan urged today that his counterparts at a seven-nation economic summit meeting set a goal of eliminating agriculture subsidies by 2000.

LEAD: A 75-foot cross put up in a busy intersection for the visit of Pope John Paul II has set off a national debate that recalls Uruguay's historically stormy relationship with the Roman Catholic Church.

LEAD: James Thurber, who died in 1961, gave vent to his very special humor, in word and drawing, in the pages of The New Yorker magazine, on 44th Street east of Avenue of the Americas. Thurber is gone, but his humor lives on, fleshed out two blocks north, and west of the avenue, in the American Place Theater.

LEAD: Golf Morse Ahead by 1: Cathy Morse retained a one-shot lead in the $500,000 L.P.G.A. McDonald's Championship with a round of 70 in the second round yesterday in Wilmington, Del. Morse was at six-under 136, one shot ahead of Sherri Steinhauer. Sherri Turner, was at 138 after a 71. (AP)

LEAD: Generally, when a hitting streak in baseball ends on a questionable call, the controversy goes on. Not so for Robin Ventura of Oklahoma State University. LEAD: In the dusty courtyard of a Hindu temple, 1,200 women, children and old men stood quietly in line today for rations of rice and flour. Their homes had been bombed, and they told stories of hunger, terror and helplessness.

LEAD: Antony Tudor's ''Dark Elegies,'' one of our century's most unusual ballets, received its first performance this season by American Ballet Theater on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. ''Dark Elegies'' is totally plotless yet emotionally rich. And, though its choreography derives from ballet technique, it looks like modern dance.

LEAD: Lucas Industries of Troy, Mich., said it had purchased the Western Gear Corporation from Becor Western Inc. for $88.8 million in cash. Western Gear of Milwaukee makes equipment for airplanes and helicopters and had sales of $154 million in 1986. Lucas, a subsidiary of Lucas Industries P.L.C., a British corporation, said the purchase would expand its annual sales to about $500 million, half of it in the aerospace business.

LEAD: According to the Hollywood experts, ''River's Edge'' was a movie that would never appeal to audiences. The tale of a teen-age boy who kills his girlfriend, the movie was considered so bleak that not even the small distributors would touch it.

LEAD: Advocates of eating outdoors have won a victory in Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J. By a 5-to-2 vote, the zoning board Thursday granted a variance to allow an outdoor cafe at Claude's Ho-Ho-Kus Inn. Borough law prohibits lunch wagons, diners, road stands or ''any eating place rendering service other than inside the premises.

LEAD: India proposed talks with Sri Lanka here next week to resolve their bitter dispute over Indian assistance to the Tamil population in Northern Province in Sri Lanka, where the Government is fighting Tamil separatist guerrillas.
LEAD: President Reagan warmed up for a taping of his weekly radio address today by telling an Italian-Irish joke, unaware that his remarks were being picked up on broadcast monitors.

LEAD: ''THE JOY OR THE HORRI-ble - the extremes -'' the director Joseph Chaikin gropes for words to explain what lies beneath the wild non sequiturs in ''The Bald Soprano.'' Navigating in rehearsal through Eugene Ionesco's comic ''anti-play'' of charged, disconnected phrases, the actors pick out signposts from the director's own charged, disconnected phrases.

LEAD: Hotels, resorts and even cruise ships advertise that they have places for the younger kids to stay and play while the parents partake of a little adult-quality time. Sometimes the facilities are merely supervised reading rooms or playgrounds but some are full-fledged day camps; some may come with the room rate and for others there is an extra charge.

LEAD: Dance Celebration June 8 - The exuberant Jacques d'Amboise, the Pied Piper of dance, returns to the Felt Forum for the 11th annual Event of the Year with 1,000 youngsters from his National Dance Institute. The institute conducts yearlong dance classes for 3,000 students at more than 75 public schools across the nation.

LEAD: Residents of Greenwich, Conn., with physical handicaps have for years driven out of their way to catch trains at other stations to avoid mounting the tall flight of 40 steps at the main Greenwich train station. ''Even the elderly lose their breath struggling up those stairs,'' said Louis Palomba, president of Provide Access to the Handicapped Inc., a Greenwich lobbying group.

LEAD: Bet Twice, a narrow runner-up in both the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, reversed those decisions with a vengeance in the 119th running of the Belmont Stakes yesterday to deprive Alysheba of racing's Triple Crown.

LEAD: TALL perennials become floppy, if not staked, particularly peonies, delphiniums, babysbreath, foxgloves and some rudbeckias. Wise pruners save some of the tallest canes and twigs for this purpose; when poked into the ground, these supports hold up floppy herbaceous stems and in time become invisibile.
LEAD: WHEN Eleonora Gardini and Giuseppe Cipriani announced their engagement in Venice recently, Italian newspapers hardly knew whether to print the news on the social or the financial page.

LEAD: There was encouragement even for teen-agers in the employment report on the New York region issued last week by the Labor Department. Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, called it a ''picture of an economy in strength,'' with unemployment rates below 6 percent and record numbers of job-holders.

LEAD: THE OPENING ON APRIL 23 OF the London Theater Museum in Covent Garden was a happy day not only for London but for the numberless foreign visitors (above all, those from the United States) who would never dream of coming to London without going to the theater.

LEAD: CALL IT THE LIKABILITY Factor. It's as good a yardstick as any for measuring TV entertainment. Certain forms, notably situation comedies, are almost aggressively likable. ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' wasn't just nice; it was adorable. That's how sitcoms are built. Even Archie Bunker had to be a ''lovable'' bigot.

LEAD: THE CONCEPT OF FIDEL-ity, passionately pursued by audio fans, is treated more casually in video. Music listeners are meticulous about tone color and shun stereo equipment that falsifies subtle nuances of timbre. By contrast, video watchers tend to be complacent about the color of images. In fact, they are usually unaware that the colors seen on home video sets are usually quite different from the colors actually televised.

LEAD: THE Game Plan study served some sobering statistics to the Tennis Industry Council. Of the country's 10.5 million to 11 million players, only 1.6 million -about 15 percent - are serious players and active consumers of tennis goods and services. Sixty-three percent of all players are playing less. And the report predicted that unless the industry took action, the total number of players would continue to drop significantly.

LEAD: Thirty-three people protesting the construction of a pumping station were arrested Friday when they defied a court order barring them from blocking access to the site on the Delaware River. About 75 other demonstrators cheered and chanted, ''Dump the pump, save the river.'' The pump is designed to draw 95 million gallons of water daily from the river for use in nearby Lansdale and North Wales and by the Philadelphia Electric Company to cool reactors at a nuclear plant.

This year black has arrived early. Why? Well, the French designer Jean-Paul Gaultier, known for his eye-catching and often exaggerated clothes, has come up with a winner in his architecturally cut black suit.

LEAD: ONE OF THE SUREST paths to literary renown these days is confession, coming out of the closet, baring the soul. Were you a Communist at Oxford? An undercover man for the F.B.I.? A morose parent? A Mondale supporter? Did you once float junk bonds? Get it down on paper. Don't leave out a thing. Riches and talk shows lie ahead.

LEAD: FORMULA for an instant musical hit: gather a cornucopia of random, rare songs by the premier composer of contemporary theater music, Stephen Sondheim. Create a visual, unspoken context, involving two lonely characters, so that a story line emerges through the lyrics. Then get a couple of expert performers (Robert Yacko and Nancy Opel) and a director who has been acclaimed for his way with Sondheim shows (Fran Soeder).

LEAD: NOT all parts of the tennis business are suffering. Attendance at tournaments is up significantly and so is corporate sponsorship. LEAD: UNDER THE LAKE. By Stuart Woods. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Authors, journalists, greeting-card versifiers and anyone else who writes on deadline might have problems relaxing into this slick supernatural mystery. The hero's writing block would surely give that tribe more anxiety than the apparitions that haunt the lakeside cabin in rural Georgia where he has gone to work on a book.

LEAD: IN VISIBLE LIGHT: Photography and the American Writer: 1840-1940. By Carol Shloss. (Oxford University, $24.95.) Like John Berger and Susan Sontag, Carol Shloss views an artist's approach to his subject as an exercise of power. ''In Visible Light,'' an extended meditation about the politics of seeing, examines the complex, often uneasy exchange that takes place between photographers and writers and their sources.

LEAD: To the Editor: In reference to Stephanie Griffith's article ''Encounters of Another Color'' (Travel, April 12): exactly the opposite happened to me!

LEAD: ORDINARILY, UPON ENTERING a movie theater, you check your baggage at the door. That baggage consists of whatever nonessential information you may have picked up concerning the fiscal, professional or amorous peculiarities of those who made the film, or miscellaneous tidbits that are even more marginal.

LEAD: Officials at New York Hospital said yesterday that they were still at a loss to explain the exact cause of a 22-minute power failure early Friday that led to the death of a critically ill 40-day-old boy on a respirator.

LEAD: The tiny marine organisms that made up the ''brown tide,'' blamed for destroying most of the native scallops in the bays of Eastern Long Island, have all but disappeared, a marine biologist said today.
LEAD: The town has approved a $626,000 settlement with a black who was falsely arrested seven years ago while sitting in his car in a white neighborhood.
LEAD: A YELLOW RAFT IN BLUE WATER By Michael Dorris. 343 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $16.95.

LEAD: THE United Nations Postal Administration and the World Federation of United Nations Associations (Wfuna) will issue six postage stamps and a first day cover on Friday as part of a new United Nations program to combat drug abuse. The set of six stamps and the Wfuna first day cover will spread the message ''Yes to Life - No to Drugs.

LEAD: A LONG struggle to renovate a shelter for the homeless in Washington reached yet another climax in March 1986 when the Federal Government agreed to turn the building over to the District of Columbia, along with $5 million to help fix it up.

LEAD: Barbara Ann Woike, a picture editor for The Associated Press in New York, and Jerome Quincy Yulsman, a novelist, were married yesterday at their home in Brooklyn. The Rev. Barbara Hebner, a Unitarian minister, officiated.

LEAD: A CONFIDENT County Republican Party endorsed candidates for 15 of the 17 seats on the Board of Legislators at a convention in White Plains last week, hoping to widen the party's nearly two-to-one margin in the lawmaking body.

LEAD: AS the day drew near when enforcement of the new United States immigration law was to begin, protests from factory owners, farmers, ranchers, hotel owners and restaurateurs natiowide rose to such a pitch that the Senate voted to delay it. But nowhere is there more apprehension than along the United States-Mexico border, whose residents fear the law may disrupt a remarkable process of economic and social integration.

LEAD: Tom Seaver, winner of 198 games for the Mets, the last one in 1983, arrived at Shea Stadium yesterday morning as if he had never left. He greeted members of the Mets and other acquaintances, walked over to his old locker in the clubhouse and donned the familiar No. 41 uniform.

LEAD: THE Concordia chamber orchestra (or, as the group bills itself, ''Concordia: A Chamber Symphony'') is dedicated to that problematic American proposition, the oneness of music. As a nation that values the European musical tradition but has done only a little to extend it, while fostering a non-European popular tradition recognized the world round as valuable, we are bound to experiment with the possibility of cross-fertilization.
LEAD: In an effort to collect more than $70 million in overdue taxes and water bills, the city is going after tax delinquents through newspaper advertisements.

LEAD: The words ''radical'' and ''anarchic'' are used repeatedly in Frances FitzGerald's article to describe Oliver North and the contragate scammers. As a member of America's oldest anarchist organization, I protest this sloppy use of language. The corruption of Government officials who are willing and eager to break the law for their own ends, and for the purpose of violent oppression, should not be linguistically confused with the goal of freedom from all government and oppression, which is the goal of anarchism.

LEAD: South American drug trafficking rings, attracted by the availability of vital chemicals and by good airline connections to the north, are increasingly using Brazil as a processing and distribution point for cocaine, Brazilian and foreign narcotics experts say.

LEAD: THE arrest last week of Nancy Capurso, described by the police as the ''crack queen of Washington Square,'' illustrates both the successes and the failures of the New York City Police Department's efforts to wipe out open street sales of crack, heroin and other illegal drugs.

LEAD: Under the so-called Sullivan Principles, American companies could do business with South Africa if they widened opportunities for blacks and worked to end race segregation. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton, dean of the cathedral, performed the ceremony in the great choir.

LEAD: When Bethesda Terrace in Central Park opened last month, it had been restored to its 19th century glory save for one crowning detail: the ornate and vibrant ceramic tiles that had lined the arcade's vaulted ceiling since 1864.

LEAD: Yesterday was one of the rare afternoons in recent years that D. Wayne Lukas has not had a starter in a Triple Crown race, but the nation's leading trainer won two other stakes races on a glittering undercard at Belmont Park.

LEAD: THE WORLD OF CHIL-dren's audio cassettes has evolved into a market that corresponds roughly to the developmental stages of children themselves. There are soothing tunes and simple songs for the very young, book and cassette packages for those learning to read, and complex stories and novels for older children.

LEAD: FOR 20 YEARS, CHARLES Ludlam made a marvelous career out of being Ridiculous. As the comic genius behind the Ridiculous Theatrical Company, he was a grand recycler of popular culture, an entertainment ecologist, taking old tales and old movies and recharging them with his own extravagant imagination.

LEAD: ONCE upon a time there was a steep, rocky hill in a town called Pelham. Weeds grew on the hill, and it wasn't pretty to look at. Then one day a woman named June Slotkin had an idea. ''Let's clear the hill and put sculpture on it,'' she said. ''Then it will become a thing of beauty the town can be proud of.
LEAD: A police emergency services truck responding to a fatal shooting in Brooklyn, struck and critically injured a pedestrian early yesterday.

LEAD: SUDDENLY last week, shortly before his departure for the economic summit conference in Venice, President Reagan announced that Paul A. Volcker had resigned as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. His successor, Mr. Reagan said, would be Alan Greenspan, a business consultant who served as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under Presidents Nixon and Ford.

LEAD: The Boston Globe has begun publishing on Sundays a thick section dedicated to New Hampshire, part of a direct challenge to The Manchester Union Leader and a test of the growing economic and psychological integration of New Hampshire and Massachusetts.

LEAD: CHESS in a nightclub with pounding disco music, miniskirted cocktail waitresses and glitter galore? Yes, that is how a quick-play match between the world champion, Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union, and Nigel Short, a British grandmaster, was staged.

LEAD: New Yorkers are justifiably skeptical about store signs shouting, ''Going Out of Business - Building Coming Down.'' Many sales later, the structures often are still standing. But the office building at 565 Fifth Avenue, where an electronics shop has hung a colossal banner with those very words in its window, may indeed come tumbling down, though not immediately.

LEAD: If Edwin Moses had forgotten what it felt like to lose a race, he has now had his memory refreshed. When he came in second to Danny Harris in the 400-meter hurdles in a meet in Madrid last week, it was the first time Moses had lost since Aug. 26, 1977, when Harald Schmid beat him at a meet in West Germany.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II praying yesterday at St. Mary Major Basilica in Rome. The ceremony, in which the Pope led congregations on five continents in saying the rosary, was carried worldwide by satellite. (AP)

LEAD: Sixty-seven opposition legislators today ended a three-day hunger strike protesting the Government's refusal to investigate the torture death of a dissident student further, a spokesman for the lawmakers said.

LEAD: AS the AIDS epidemic spreads through the nation's consciousness, rising public alarm is forcing the issue to the top of the legislative agenda. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome has become not only a devastating medical problem but an increasingly political one as well. LEAD: A VANISHING part of Americana, the big top, will return to the state tomorrow. The Clyde Beatty-Cole Brothers Circus will be setting up stakes at the James P. Casey Field in Bristol shortly after dawn for a two-day run after overcoming major insurance problems.

LEAD: It is a staggering scene, seeming to belong in a time in which slaves built monumental works for pharaohs and kings. The ancient, frenzied dream of gold has drawn 400,000 people across the wilderness of Brazil. Digging in the Amazon forests, diving into rivers and gnawing at mountainsides, they move with the rainy season and rumors of new sites.
LEAD: The shores of Lake Minnewaska in New York's Shawangunk Mountains will teem with campers rather than corporate conferees, and sprout tents instead of condominiums.

LEAD: When Dickens saw Cobourg in 1842, he thought it a ''cheerful, thriving little town.'' To a visitor in 1987, this town of 15,000 on the northern shore of Lake Ontario still looks cheerful, if not exactly thriving. It has no significant tourist attractions or memories of national prominence, although since Dickens's day it has had two brushes with power and affluence.

LEAD: THE British have long nurtured a passion for things Italian. A long line of monarchs have collected Italian art, notably paintings by Canaletto and drawings by Leonardo; writers from Keats to Jan Morris have come to see and rhapsodize over landscape and architecture, and so many Anglo-Saxon tourists have filled the quarter around the Spanish Steps in Rome that as early as the 18th century it was known locally as ''the English ghetto.

LEAD: THAT OLD INAUDIBLE ECHO, LOVE While some people travel to forget, for others it has just the opposite effect. In ''Staring at the Sun'' (Knopf), Julian Barnes describes a middle-aged woman ruminating over her life at an echo wall in Beijing.

LEAD: Six Kuwaiti Shiite Moslems, two of them still at large, were sentenced to hang today for setting fires in this emirate's oilfields in support of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Islamic revolution.

LEAD: Every week of the New York season is packed with concerts given at halls large and small by artists who names mean little to people outside the musical profession. The concerts often feature new or out-of-the-way music; they rarely feature performers destined to become superstars. Some of the music would just as well be left buried, and some turns out to be enormously rewarding.

LEAD: St. Martin's Episcopal Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Ramona Leanora Grey to Eric Lamar Harris. The Rev. David Johnson performed the ceremony.

LEAD: LAST July 4, world renowned flutist Jean-Pierre Rampal flew to Boston from Montreal for a Glorious Fourth clambake near the ocean. Why Boston? To see his old friend and flute maker of 30 years, Lewis Deveau.

LEAD: MINISTERING TO THE INDIANS There haven't been many who have ruled both church and state. Michael F. Smith, a Shinnecock Indian, may be considered one of the few. His dual roles are ''time-consuming,'' he said recently, ''but my family and I manage to maintain our sanity.''

LEAD: IT was portrayed by India as a mission of mercy and by Sri Lanka as ''naked act of aggression.'' But diplomats and other experts said the air drop of aid to the ethnic Tamil minority in northern Sri Lanka last week mainly underscored India's growing aspirations to regional power status. The air drop was made after Sri Lankan naval vessels turned back a flotilla of fishing boats carrying the aid.
LEAD: Vigorous police work in southern Thailand has sharply reduced pirate attacks on Vietnamese refugees fleeing their country by boat, diplomats and relief-agency officials say.

Hotchkiss of Bernardsville, was married to Edward Ashton Harvey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ashton Harvey of Skillman, N.J. The Rev. Albert C. Niese performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Israeli soldiers passing a Palestinian woman and her son yesterday as the moved closer to Abu Dis College near Bethlehem where several dozen Palestinian students demonstrated against 20 years of Israeli occupation of the West Bank. Two students were slightly wounded when soldiers fired into the air to disperse the rock-throwing crowd.

LEAD: TRYING to reach someone at Turner-Hall Publishing the other day, I was greeted by one of those now ubiquitous answering machines that parrots a lengthy pre-beep preamble about leaving one's name, telephone number, time of call and brief message. But that wasn't the end of it. This particular machine was tied into a voice mail system, so I was also told that if I really needed to speak to a human being, I could reroute my call by pressing the zero button on my telephone followed by the one for the number sign.

LEAD: LANDLORDS of Manhattan office buildings are ripping out fluorescent tubes, stainless steel elevator doors and every other trace of the 1960's from their lobbies.
LEAD: On the ravaged landscape here, the view from a descending helicopter brings to mind the television pictures of the American astronauts making the first manned landing on the moon.
LEAD: GROUND clearing has begun on Willowbend, a $100 million, 410-acre housing development around an 18-hole golf course on the edge of this Cape Cod community.

LEAD: Something is slowly killing ash trees in the lower Hudson Valley, and Craig R. Hibben thinks he knows what it is.

LEAD: SALLY GROSS might have been a witch or magician in other times. All she has to do to weave a spell, it seems, is walk onto the stage and begin to move in that strangely drowsy but focused way of hers. The elements are simple, with much of the dancing performed in silence. She has gathered around her other women performers who form a kind of understated family group.

LEAD: There was some excitement at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday afternoon when a family lugged in its favorite fossil, excavated from a neighborhood parking lot, for identification by the museum's experts.

LEAD: Broadcasters had hoped that the fairness doctrine, which requires them to present differing views on controversial subjects, would wither away. That seemed possible, as the Federal Communications Commission, enforcer of the policy, had termed it pointless and probably unconstitutional. But Congress disagreed, so much so that it has now voted to turn the fairness doctrine into Federal law.
LEAD: The original falls were washed away more than 100 years ago, but town officials have made an honest city of Wichita Falls with the grand opening of a $400,000 man-made waterfall.

LEAD: Two brothers of a prominent Texas family will go to prison under a plea bargain announced Friday in a case that Justice Department officials have described as one of the largest criminal fraud cases in recent history.

LEAD: The Valais is a region of soaring beauty. Visible from its trails are Switzerland's highest mountains and two of Europe's most formidable peaks, Mont Blanc and the Matterhorn. But for ordinary hikers the lure is the series of north-south valleys forged by the tributaries of the Rhone. These allow access to gentler summits and scenic treks from village to village in a single day.
LEAD: William S. Gaither, president of Drexel University, twice put his hand on the knee of a female subordinate who sat next to him at a business dinner in Toronto six weeks ago.

LEAD: TECHNOLOGY, WITH GODLIKE inscrutability, both giveth and taketh away. Consider how strange it is that even as advances in sound reproduction now allow us to savor utter silence between the notes on a compact disk, strides in portable electronic amplification also make it possible for musicians in New York's subways to outbellow arriving and departing trains.
LEAD: In recent days, aboard a lumbering armored launch that flew the Stars and Stripes, a Venetian pilot instructed an American Navy helmsman in the art of maneuvering in the choppy Venetian waters.

LEAD: Gary Hart withdrew from the Presidential race hours after his press secretary told him about a private detective's detailed report with photographs showing Mr. Hart entering and leaving the house of a Washington woman, the former press aide says.

LEAD: TEMPTING FATE. By Laurie Alberts. (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) The state of Alaska, disconnected from the rest of the country, has much in common with the characters in Laurie Alberts's first novel, ''Tempting Fate.'' Alaska is separate, little explored and cold. So are many of the characters. A disconsolate Russian, a hell-bent Indian and a flaky dropout from New England move about the little island of Vladimir, salmon fishing for a living and getting potted the rest of the time in local saloons.
LEAD: Public understanding of the dangers of alcohol has increased since 1982, according to the latest Gallup Poll.
LEAD: Frances FitzGerald's contention that Frank Carlucci heralds a change to come at the National Security Council is dubious.

LEAD: THE developers who have taken over the former Gimbels building on West 33d Street at Greeley Square have found a way to put a new twist on a not-so-old theme.

LEAD: THE GREAT PRETENDER, by James Atlas. (Penguin, $6.95.) Ben Janis, the young hero of James Atlas's first novel, is a Chicago boy, educated at Harvard and Oxford, who is torn between high and pop culture. The book ''kept me laughing throughout,'' Leslie Fiedler said in The Book Review last year. ''But,'' he said, ''I was never quite sure who the joke was on - and to tell the truth, I was afraid to find out.

The story told of the bitter fight that ensued for custody of their infant son, Philip, a fight between Taylor's parents in Indiana and his deceased wife's sister and brother-in-law, who live in Staten Island, N.Y.

Big man on campus this time is Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. Three programs are devoted entirely to his music, and at least one Mozart work figures in five of the six remaining concerts.

LEAD: THE two-stick Popsicle, a creation of the Great Depression, became mainly a memory a year ago in May. In its place in grocery stores, which accounted for 80 percent of the sales, appeared a one-stick version.

LEAD: Dwight Gooden was clearly not happy. He had just made a scintillating return to pitching for the Mets, winning the game and receiving several standing ovations from the sellout Shea Stadium crowd, but he was not happy.

LEAD: THE leadership of the State Legislature has taken a look at the healthy tax-collection figures reported by the State Treasurer and decided there is no need to raise taxes this year.

LEAD: After five administrations, more than 250 state dinners and 21 years as the executive chef at the White House, Henry Haller will be hanging up his hat Oct. 1 despite efforts to persuade him to stay on until the end of the Reagan Administration.

LEAD: A certain sign that the aborted Presidential campaign of Gary Hart is in financial straits is that the National Bank of Washington plans to dust off a series of 92 lithographs by the American artist Robert Rauschenberg.
LEAD: The noisy world of politics seems very far away from this tranquil university town, but in its spires and dusty bookshops one finds a different way of looking at our present problems.

LEAD: The Rev. Jerry Falwell announced last week that the PTL ministry's ''May Emergency'' had become a ''May Miracle.'' Under Mr. Falwell's stewardship, the debt-ridden evangelical organization had collected $8.5 million in donations, enough to keep it alive, at least temporarily.
LEAD: Victory Garden Recipes By Marian Morash. Produced by Morash Associates. Knopf Video Books. 90 minutes. $29.95.

LEAD: HARDLY A RECORD COM-pany exists that has not been plumbing its back catalogue for treasures to transfer to compact disk. And many of these reissues, from major and minor companies alike, have indeed been treasures, from Furtwangler and Callas to Bernstein and Karajan. Now, Nonesuch finally joins the parade, with nine releases, reflecting the diversity of the label and, in a way, honoring previous overseers of Nonesuch's releases, including Teresa Sterne, who was consultant for the CD reissues.

His father, George Clarke, and stepmother, Melanie Ann Clarke, were charged with first-degree murder by aggravated child abuse. The youth, George Clarke, was comatose and weighed 22 pounds when his father sought medical help for him Thursday, said a spokesman for the Hillsborough County Sheriff's Department.

LEAD: According to a recent survey, there are 80 public toilets in the Eternal City. More than three quarters of them, however, are permanently shut, and the rest are in such a state of disrepair that the word ''ruin'' should no longer be applied to Rome's recently cleansed famous monuments but instead to those few public latrines - dark, dank and without running water - that have earned their reputation as the new catacombs.

LEAD: TWO animal-rights groups have challenged an order by the State Environmental Protection Department to begin shaking the eggs of swans and destroying swans that the department considers a growing nuisance.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II made a new appeal for an end to the arms race today, telling President Reagan in a Vatican meeting that that would liberate ''immense resources that can be used to alleviate misery and feed millions of hungry human beings.''

LEAD: Osaka goes crazy over food - in Japanese, ''kuidaore no Osaka,'' meaning literally, ''Osaka, which collapses from eating its brains out.'' Osakans boast of this passion, noting that they are unlike the people of nearby Kyoto, who discreetly spend their money on luxurious clothes and furnishings. While Osaka shouts out its gluttony unashamed, Kyoto eats in silence, shielding its mouth with a delicately raised hand.

LEAD: LIKE plagues of locusts, student interns descend on corporate America during academia's vacations - summer, Christmas and spring. At best they are a highly visible nuisance; at worst they impede productivity and depress morale.

LEAD: AGRICULTURE in New Jersey has undergone a major transition, especially in the last two years. Huge tracts of farmland have been acquired by developers eager for well-located property, and profitable new sectors of agriculture - horse farming and plant nurseries - have blossomed.

LEAD: Some recent comments by the East German leader, Erich Honecker, have again raised politically charged expectations that he will finally make his often-postponed visit to West Germany.

LEAD: Visitors to Yellowstone National Park may find park roads congested due to construction this fall. Mr. Cleary also said the construction project meant that motorists might need to make detours or go slowly through construction zones.

LEAD: OSCAR WAYNE, 77 years old, still drives from his home in Manhattan to his job at the Kings Electronics Company in Tuckahoe, as he has for 33 years. Indeed, says Mr. Wayne, who has been the company's financial vice president and treasurer since 1963, his routine has changed only slightly over three decades.

LEAD: CONDUCTORS INTENT ON recording the Mozart symphonies face a daunting task - finding new things to say about works that have been amply explored on disk -yet the flow of new releases seems both constant and voluminous. Musicologists, of course, with their frequent reinterpretations and shifts in attitude, have made the task a bit easier by providing a number of alternative approaches for conductors to try.

LEAD: IN the first two months of last season, Dave Righetti registered 12 saves but squandered 7 other save opportunities, not a terrifically good ratio for a relief pitcher. Nearly a year later, on Sept. 13, 1788, following ratification of the Constitution by 11 states, the Continental Congress passed a resolution that put the new Constitution into operation.

I'm certain Oliver North did not have this in mind.

LEAD: It would be against his principles to live there, but President P. W. Botha of South Africa found the bleak township of Sharpeville not a bad place to visit last week. On Mr. Botha's first appearance in a major black area since 1978, Mayor Esau Mahlatsi made him an honorary citizen and about 1,000 children applauded the President and seven Cabinet Ministers before they helicoptered away from the place that has been a symbol of the struggle against apartheid since the police killed 69 black protesters there in 1960.

Baseball is a game where the most obscure player can take the field or come to bat and return home a hero.

LEAD: Sheltered by flowering hedgerows, we felt the June sun beat warmly on our backs. As my husband and I turned and twisted along a narrow path, we could hear bees buzzing among the tangled gorse, dog roses and red campion above our heads. Teased by a tang of salt air, we tried to guess how far ahead lay the open sea, but gaps in the thick hedge only showed us rolling meadows and scattered sheep.

LEAD: On the day after, the Mets still were enjoying themselves so perhaps there was something profound about the return of Dwight Gooden. Then, again, maybe it's because they're playing their favorite team, the Pittsburgh Pirates.

LEAD: There are some nice things about NOWHERE MAN by Jerry Oster (Harper & Row, $15.95). There also are some exasperating things. In many respects this is a virtuoso piece of work, animated by very bright, sophisticated New York dialogue, some of it quite funny. But the author asks us to believe in some remarkable coincidences.

LEAD: Most Florida-bound travelers heading down Interstate 95 usually regard Brunswick, Ga., as nothing more than the last overnight stop before crossing the border into the promised land. Yet, it is considerably more than that. In addition to being the gateway to three of the romantically described ''Golden Isles'' of Georgia,
LEAD: TWO winters ago, Christine DeAngelis unlocked the door of her Hastings-on-Hudson home, but the odor of gasoline was so strong she could not go inside.

LEAD: Cathleen Mary McGuigan and David Bruce Berridge were married yesterday at the bride's summer home in Sag Harbor, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles A. Baldwin, the United Church of Christ chaplain of Brown University.
LEAD: Holiday Starring Cary Grant and Katharine Hepburn. Directed by George Cukor. 1938. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 94 minutes. $69.95.

LEAD: Because of a production error, an article about the opening of a new building for the Carriage Museum at Stony Brook, L.I., was omitted from Page 20 of the Long Island Weekly section today. The article will appear next Sunday.
LEAD: THE Penguin Repertory Company, which can be counted on to present offbeat or strictly new plays, is putting on, of all things, a 1930's-style drawing-room comedy.

LEAD: DONALD BYRD was part of the hard-bop jazz mainstream in the 1950's and 1960's; in the 1970's, he took a lucrative detour into pop. But through this Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, he is playing what he said was his first New York jazz club date in 17 years, working with a quartet led by James Williams on piano.

LEAD: A picture caption on page 24 of the Arts and Leisure section today and a film listing in the Arts and Leisure Guide give an incorrect opening date for ''The Believers.'' It opens Wednesday at the Orpheum, 84th Street Six, 23d Street West Triplex, National, Manhattan Twin and Bay Cinema.
LEAD: Two decades after the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn was rocked by riots, litter-strewn streets, ramshackle tenements and street corners crowded with drug dealers are still common.

LEAD: Of course, says everyone from the President to Mayor Koch. It's obvious: Test people for AIDS. Testing, whether called mandatory or sugared with the term ''routine,'' has suddenly become the politicians' cure for this incurable disease. But testing is no more obvious than it is a cure. The underlying question, lost in all the clamor, is not whether to test but when, and why.

LEAD: BARONS OF LABOR: The San Francisco Building Trades and Union Power in the Progressive Era. By Michael Kazin. (University of Illinois, $24.95.) This welcome labor history covers broad trends in San Francisco in the Progressive Era: building trades union and business interplay, the personalities and careers of the ''labor barons,'' mayors of San Francisco who came out of the labor movement and the decline of labor influence prior to World War I.

LEAD: The Quilted Giraffe, applauded as one of New York's best restaurants, will close June 26 while its owners, Barry and Susan Wine, vacation for three weeks in Japan. But when the restaurant reopens July 20, it will have moved from 955 Second Avenue (at 50th Street) to 550 Madison Avenue (at 55th Street), the present premises of the Wines' less formal cafe-style restaurant, the Casual Quilted

LEAD: Jeanne E. Zavell, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul M. Zavell of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., was married there yesterday to John Christie Archibald Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald of Rumson, N.J. Msgr. Francis X. Canfield performed the ceremony at St. Paul's on the Lake Roman Catholic Church. He was assisted by the Rev.

LEAD: Katha Pollitt, a poet and literary critic, and Randy Cohen, a writer for television, were married yesterday afternoon at the home of a friend, Tina Stiefel, in Manhattan. Judge Emily J. Goodman of City Civil Court performed the ceremony.

LEAD: THE 40TH BIENNIAL EXHIBI-tion of Contemporary American Painting at the Corcoran Gallery of Art is a cogent argument not only for abstract painting but also for the continuing vitality of a late modernist esthetic. It brings together 13 artists between 37 and 51 years old. All live or have lived in New York City.

LEAD: On the surface, there was an air of confidence in the paddock before the race, a byproduct of winning five Belmont Stakes in succession. Minutes before Woody Stephens would attempt to add to his record with a sixth, Gone West stood placidly as Chris Bausch, his groom, fussed with the colt's forelock, and photographers and reporters inched forward for a closer look.
LEAD: AFTER the wedding, what next?

LEAD: Loss of a Laundry Lease Question: I own a coin laundry in Queens and the lease on the space I have for this business expires in a few years. My landlord says he does not want to renew my lease and I believe that it is his intention to take over my business. I have heard that there is a law that would keep him from opening the same business as mine for a period of two years if he refuses to renew my lease.

LEAD: IT is hard to conceive that anyone could be the world's best at two demanding intellectual activities. Such a claim can made for Alexandre Louis Honore Lebreton Deschapelles, a Frenchman born just before his country's Revolution. As a young man he was probably the world's best chessplayer but abandoned the game when outstripped by one of his students.
LEAD: Beth Darling and Dr. Edward Luttrell Maclin were married yesterday at the Wilson Inn in Lambertville, N.J. The Rev. Anderson Clark officiated at the nondenominational ceremony.

LEAD: California State Assemblyman Tom Hayden, who as a campus firebrand two decades ago flung brickbats over the war in Vietnam, chose not to be on the receiving end last week. Mr. Hayden canceled his scheduled commencement speech at San Jose State City College after groups of Vietnamese students threatened to disrupt the proceedings.

LEAD: With four days of campaigning left, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is a solid favorite to lead the Conservatives to a parliamentary majority and become the first Prime Minister in this century to win three consecutive terms.

LEAD: IMAGINE, for a moment, an unlimited budget, an uninterrupted stretch of some 60 hours, no commitments, no responsibilities, a conscience wiped clean of guilt about reckless spending and a memory with no recollection of undone chores. In other words, an ideal weekend, a dream of a weekend, a wish-come-true weekend.
LEAD: ''THE idea,'' said Angelo Jacorossi, the head of Fintermica, Italy's fastest-growing and biggest energy conglomerate, ''was never to get too enamored of our products.''

LEAD: To the Editor: As a Dutchman born, if a long time naturalized, I always derive great satisfaction from articles about my native land. But I feel compelled to make a slight correction in the one about cured new herring.
LEAD: After five years of steady failure, American officials are making a last-ditch effort to create a new Miskito Indian guerrilla organization willing to take on the Sandinista army.

LEAD: WILL Washington succeed in its latest grab for New York's cultural treasures? The target this time is the beleaguered Museum of the American Indian, long in search of a worthy home for its nearly one million tribal artifacts, mostly warehoused in the Bronx for lack of exhibition space.
LEAD: The glory of the race track shone vibrantly yesterday on the morning of the 119th Belmont Stakes, in which Alysheba would be going for the Triple Crown.

LEAD: THEY battled the bugs, balanced themselves on rocks in the streams and cleared away the branches of trees - all to get accurate readings on the elevations of the land for their topographic maps.
LEAD: Harry Lee (Butch) Reynolds Jr. is for real.

LEAD: Unite, ridden by Walter Swinburn, won the $400,000 Gold Seal Oaks for fillies today as Scimitarra, the favorite, was pulled up with an injured fetlock less than an eighth of a mile from the finish of the mile-and-a-half race. Scimitarra was ridden by Steve Cauthen, the American jockey.

LEAD: India calls it ''humanitarian aid'' to beleaguered Tamils threatened with massacre. Sri Lanka vehemently denies atrocity charges and denounces India's air drop of supplies as ''a naked violation of our independence.'' India's Rajiv Gandhi has become as much field marshal as Prime Minister, while armies mass on all the subcontinent's fault lines.

LEAD: NO longer do sloops laden with oysters ply the waters of Long Island Sound. But William Ciaurro of Bridgeport and a few others can still remember how they once earned their living by oystering under sail, and Philip Teuscher of Weston is recording those memories.

LEAD: ROAST duck challenges the cook. As delicious as a succulent, properly roasted Long Island duckling can be, with its moist, rich flesh and crisp skin, achieving this result takes care and patience. And it is no easier for restaurants than it is for home cooks.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: After nearly four years of rumored political candidacies in Michigan, Virginia, Tennessee and New York, Peter M. Dawkins, a much-decorated Vietnam War general who left the army to become an investment banker, announced last week that he would run for office - in New Jersey. Mr. Dawkins said he would seek the Republican nomination to oppose incumbent Democratic Senator Frank R.

LEAD: A chart on May 17 with an article about black baseball fans carried a heading that erroneously characterized statistics about black players and the positions they play. (Because of an editing error, the same characterization appeared in the article.) The heading should have said, ''Of all black players, the percentage for each position.
LEAD: Six hundred protesters, surrounded by police officers, marched through downtown Greensboro today, a day before Ku Klux Klan members are to to hold their first rally here since 1979.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: CONTROVERSY CONTINUES TO rage over the colorization of classic black-and-white movies. At recent Congressional hearings in Washington, major film makers including Woody Allen and Sydney Pollack spoke out against the tinting of films like ''It's a Wonderful Life,'' ''Casablanca'' and ''The Maltese Falcon.

LEAD: Joanna Tucker couldn't make it to French class all year. Claude Brooks missed the entire fall semester of school. And Midori Goto's last day of ninth grade occurred last month -about four weeks before the end of school.

LEAD: WHILE taking my daughter's car pool to school, I noticed that a small white farm house set on a field of veronica, the first house I had lived in as an adult, was no longer standing. A field of apple trees, a grape arbor and a trellis covered with wisteria were also missing. A bulldozer stood over a brown dug-up lot and a sign advertised a future condominium.
LEAD: The City Council has passed, 5 to 4, a bill that would make Rochester the second city in the nation to bar random drug testing of nearly all employees.

LEAD: Even at the seven-nation industrial summit this week AIDS will be on the agenda. In attempting to change both public health practices and private conduct, European governments have begun shaping national policies. Most require reporting of AIDS cases, as in the United States, but not testing. Most have extensive educational campaigns, though they have far fewer cases than the United States.

LEAD: Letitia Octavia Gill, a daughter of Dr. Robert J. Gill of Philadelphia and the late Thelma Eisenhard Gill, was married yesterday to Joseph Andrew Gembala 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gembala Jr., also of Philadelphia. The Rev. James A. Trimble performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Philadelphia.

LEAD: To the Editor: I very much enjoyed ''Cured New Herring of the Netherlands'' (Travel, April 12) because in May 1968 when we were in Amsterdam, the street vendors with their carts were everywhere. I consumed a raw herring in the approved manner and still have a snapshot to prove it.
LEAD: The Investing column last Sunday misidentified the portfolio manager of the Freedom Financial Fund. His name is James K. Schmidt.
LEAD: An Argentine Army captain arrived at a meeting a few days ago wearing a parka and carrying his military jacket over his arm, folded so the insignia and medals could not be seen.

LEAD: A ONCE-SMALL networking group for middle-management women that started seven years ago now has become so successful that more than 60 percent of its 250 members earn more than $50,000 a year and close to one in five tops $90,000.
LEAD: CURRITUCK SOUND, in the far northeastern corner of North Carolina, is a special place for specialists among fishermen and hunters.

LEAD: I have never understood why people are attracted to horror movies that promise to give the viewer nightmares. But Connie Willis's new novel, LINCOLN'S DREAMS (Bantam, $15.95), literally gave me dreams -strange narrative fantasies that left me with a not unpleasant sense of being on the verge of some important revelation.

LEAD: The Soviet Union has no intention of augmenting its force of three small warships in the Persian Gulf despite its apprehension about United States plans to build up its fleet there, according to First Deputy Foreign Minister Yuli M. Vorontsov.

LEAD: A FRIEND of mine, with a summer house on the dunes, once thought it would be a good idea to get his two pre-teen-age daughters started on a seashell collection. This was not only to teach them the fun of collecting and classifying objects (my friend has a fascinating collection of stocks and bonds), but also to teach them the joy of leisurely early morning walks along our Atlantic beaches on the East
LEAD: Steffi Graf of West Germany with her trophy yesterday after she beat Martina Navratilova, 6-4, 4-6, 8-6. Section 5. (AP)

LEAD: ''THERE is a great commitment to the children here and to helping them succeed,'' said Lois Zabriskie, principal of the Columbus Elementary School in New Rochelle. ''What we wanted to convey through our application was that attitude, which we feel is integral to our success. We were concerned whether we could communicate it well enough.

LEAD: A 61-year-old Brooklyn man with a criminal record dating back to 1943, including a conviction for murder, was charged yesterday with the fatal shooting of two merchants and a customer in the robbery of a Queens liquor store last week.
LEAD: Iran ordered today that five British diplomats leave the country in retaliation for the closure by Britain of an Iranian consulate, the official press agency reported.

LEAD: STORIES IN ANOTHER LANGUAGE. By Yannick Murphy. (Knopf, $15.95.) The language of Yannick Murphy's spare, stark vignettes is, for the most part, that of childhood. And while she concentrates on depicting the shadows of violence, the disingenuous flirting with taboos that can make these years distinctly unpleasant, there is also a strain of longing underneath the harsh surfaces of her fiction that usually keeps it just within range of our sympathy and understanding.

LEAD: ''If someone predicted 10 years ago that the church would have gained so much so soon, I would have thought him mad.'' - The Rev. Antoni Pominski, editor of a Roman Catholic newspaper in Woclawek, Poland. [ 1:4. ]

LEAD: Months before the space shuttle disaster in January 1986, engineers knew there were problems with seals on the booster rocket. It was the failure of one of these O rings that caused the explosion that killed the Challenger's seven astronauts.

LEAD: Although more hitting in general is good for fan enjoyment, the disproportionate increase in home run production only lessens its impact and drama. Now, the smaller, less powerful players swing for the fences more often instead of accepting their roles as ''table setters'' for the true home run hitters following in the lineup.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Maurizio Vitale, the Italian entrepreneur who introduced the manufacture of jeans to the Soviet Union, has died in Turin. He was 42 years old.

LEAD: The marriage of Ellen B. Wahl and Daniel S. Parker, 1984 graduates of the New York University Law School, took place last night at the Harrison Conference Center in Glen Cove, L.I. Rabbi Irving C. Lowenheim performed the ceremony.

LEAD: To the Editor: With June 16 nearly upon us, my feelings are hurt by noting that Sean O'Rourke wrote ''What's Doing in Dublin'' (Travel, May 24) without mentioning Bloomsday (June 16), which James Joyce made famous by delineating the wanderings in Dublin on that day of Leopold Bloom and a few other Dubliners.

LEAD: Catherine Shawhan Taylor, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Arthur Taylor Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Gordon Hawkins, a son of Patricia Hawkins of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and David Hawkins of Brookline, Mass. The Rev. John A. Klingelhofer performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church of

LEAD: The level of safety at nuclear reactors around the country is so low that a fatal meltdown in the next 10 to 20 years would not be a surprise, according to James K. Asselstine, a retiring member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

LEAD: IF the skills and attributes of the 1986-87 Lakers were molded into a single player, he would possess the court-vision and awareness of Earvin (Magic) Johnson, the quickness, body-control and confidence of James Worthy and the majestic presence of Kareem Abdul-Jabbar.
LEAD: BUYERS shopping for cooperative apartments often are surprised to learn that some co-op corporations own their buildings, but not the land on which they stand.

LEAD: THE Wedtech affair spread out last week, entangling politicians and civil servants, undermining a Federal program designed to bring minority groups into the mainstream of American capitalism and brushing against two other scandals.

LEAD: Paul S. Willis, a business executive and former president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, died Friday at the Bayberry Nursing Home in New Rochelle. He was 96 years old and a resident of Bronxville, N.Y.

LEAD: Three New York families will be honored tomorrow when the NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund presents its annual Buddy awards at the Plaza Hotel.

LEAD: At the First Presbyterian Church in Moorestown, N.J., yesterday Sarah Louise Langerhans, manager of creative services at the Poppe Tyson advertising agency in New York, was married to Dr. James Mark Armstrong. The Rev. C.David Langerhans, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev.

LEAD: Lauren Jill Rappoport, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley D. Rappoport of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Steven Charles Witkoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Witkoff of Old Westbury and Westhampton Beach, L.I., were married last evening at the St. Regis-Sheraton in New York by Rabbi Amiel Wohl, assisted by Cantor Helene Reps.

LEAD: IN the kingdom of literary animals, where each genre takes the form of an individual species, light verse is probably represented by the Carolina parakeet. This comely bird, which according to Audubon offered a ''welcome intimation that our darkest forests and most sequestered swamps are not destitute of charms,'' was an amicable neighbor to our pioneer forebears not only in the Carolinas but all up and down the East Coast, from New York to Florida.

LEAD: Faced with an unrelenting rise in narcotics arrests, New York City court officials are establishing special courts that will try to dispose of felony drug cases through plea bargains within six days of an arrest.
LEAD: JUST how I decided to attend my 20th college reunion, I'm still not sure.
