LEAD: The pretrial detention for almost two years of two suspects in the $7.6 million Wells Fargo robbery in Connecticut in 1983 has been unanimously upheld by a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

LEAD: Kimberly Ann Tooley, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David John Tooley of San Diego, was married yesterday to Donald James Sutherland Jr., the son of Mr. Sutherland of New York and Glen Head, L.I., and Mrs. Jonathan Ingham of Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. Walter E. Neary performed the ceremony at St. James-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in La Jolla,

LEAD: Thirty paintings, some dating to the ninth century, were stolen from a truck near here on Friday as they were being transported to Palermo for an exhibition, authorities said today. The paintings, estimated to be worth $385,000, belong to private art collectors.
LEAD: IN a city where political conflict and controversy are the norm, people sometimes overlook the significance of a new consensus, like the one on catastrophic health insurance for the elderly.

LEAD: A Puerto Rican drug-rehabilitation agency in the South Bronx has won an award that it hopes will help Hispanic groups overcome the obscurity that has long hampered their search for charity money.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: The marriage of Sarah Jane Wilson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Wilson Jr. of Rock Island, Ill., to Paul Kinnan Strader, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harlan L. Strader of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., took place yesterday at the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club in Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. T.Carleton Lee performed the Episcopal ceremony.

LEAD: Loosely applied, the term Santa Fe charm covers a lot - from rounded adobe walls and crystal-clear mountain air to the distinctive Southwestern atmosphere where Indian, Spanish and Anglo cultures closely intertwine and artistic creativity flourishes like a desert bloom. Until recently, also high on the list of summer charm was a confirmed room reservation in this small city of 50,000 that stretched to the seams in high season.

LEAD: THIS IS A STORY ABOUT A SMALL project, with relatively modest architectural ambitions, that in its own way instills a degree of faith in New York, faith in architecture and faith in the human race that few buildings of greater scope have been able to bring forth. The building is not tall, it is not dazzling, and it is not in Manhattan.

LEAD: RARE indeed is the individual who doesn't realize that life is an experience often characterized by contrariness. Whether one lives in the heart of the city or on the fringe of civilization, it has always been a sure bet that the cuff link or tweezers dropped when time is of the essence will bounce or roll far under the piece of furniture that most closely hugs the floor.
LEAD: Fish Theft Rises In Gloucester

LEAD: Up to a third of Oregon's strawberry crop may rot in the fields because the fruit is ripening early and a new immigration law has discouraged Mexican workers from coming here, officials and workers say.

LEAD: UNMARRIED couples who have lived together for years may feel as if they were married, but in legal terms nothing could be further from the truth. During life, the partners generally do not qualify for such tax-free benefits as employer-sponsored health insurance that spouses routinely receive. And at death, they do not automatically inherit a share of their deceased partner's property.
LEAD: CAN a flourishing Chinese restaurant in Great Neck also flower in Smithtown?

LEAD: Nicaragua's President, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, announced a cutback in fuel supplies today and warned Nicaraguans of the need for more severe economic restrictions because of the growing cost of the civil war.

LEAD: Representative Robert G. Torricelli's courageous proposal to reform land-use decision-making authority in New Jersey [ Opinion Page, April 19 ] is a long-overdue call to action that our legislators in Trenton should not hesitate to endorse.
LEAD: LAST weekend marked a milestone in our lives. We dismantled the swing set, acknowledging that our son was no longer a young child, but a pre-adolescent.

LEAD: As medical advances make it easier to extend the lives of terminally ill patients, doctors have increasingly made use of the do-not-resuscitate order. When patients quit breathing or their hearts stop beating, doctors can often use drugs, electric shocks and mechanical respirators to keep them alive.

LEAD: Four hours upriver from Bangkok on the Chao Phraya River - or perhaps 60 minutes, if you decide to risk your life in one of those pencil-slim, waterborne Concordes currently favored by Thailand's gondoliers - lies a most spectacular ruin, much visited, but very little known. Ayutthaya was the capital of Siam for more than four centuries - from 1350 until 1767, when the Burmese sacked it and trampled everyone to pieces with their elephant cavalry.

LEAD: EVERYONE LIKES TO CELE-brate anniversaries, and the American Dance Festival is no exception. In 1984, the festival staged a wide-ranging international season to celebrate its 50th anniversary, harking back to its pioneering summer sessions at Bennington College in Vermont and, later, at Connecticut College.

LEAD: LAST July, Mikhail S. Gorbachev assembled the officer corps of the Far Eastern Command in Khabarovsk to discuss problems in the military. ''How is discipline?'' the Soviet leader asked the district commander.

LEAD: As a translator and editor of some of Adam Michnik's works in English, I found myself disturbed by Michael T. Kaufman's article ''Poland's Plucky Activist'' (April 26). Adam Michnik is certainly an important political thinker and activist, but Mr. Kaufman insists on turning him into the only oppositionist of historical merit.

LEAD: The marriage of Dr. Laura Schiller, who graduated last month from the Cornell Medical College, and David R. Ratner, a partner in the New York law firm of Hartman, Ule, Rose & Ratner, took place last evening at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park. Judge Margaret Cammer of the City Civil Court in Brooklyn performed the ceremony.
LEAD: Now that Jim and Tammy Faye Bakker have left the PTL ministry and seem unlikely to return any time soon, one not-so-urgent question remains: What about the souvenirs?

LEAD: Instead of making history, the Alysheba contingent made do with a fourth-place finish in the Belmont Stakes yesterday as the colt's rider and trainer chided themselves for the slow, bumpy path that their horse could not gracefully survive.
LEAD: In the Kingdom of the Dolphins Produced by Hardy Jones. Home Vision. 50 minutes. $39.95.

LEAD: West Germany hates to be the odd man out, even when arguing with its allies about becoming just that. Edging away from an increasingly isolated position in NATO and West German domestic politics, Chancellor Helmut Kohl last week abandoned his objections to a proposed Soviet-American agreement on barring so-called shorter-range (300 to 600 miles) nuclear missiles from Central Europe.

LEAD: ''Paul Volcker was the world's greatest financial crisis manager. Greenspan is going to be a rookie at that, so there has to be some uncertainty about how adroit he will be when the next crisis comes.''

LEAD: Jacqueline Ann Victoria Dean, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Geoffrey James Dean of Seattle and Southampton, England, was married yesterday to Malcolm Guy Witter, a son of the late Dean Witter Jr. of San Francisco and the late Faith Atkins Breeden of Boulder, Colo. The Very Rev. Alan Jones, dean of Grace Episcopal Cathedral in San Francisco, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The 13th summit gathering of the major industrial democracies will convene here Monday under the shadow of considerable political and economic uncertainty in the seven participating nations.

LEAD: New York City's Chief Medical Examiner yesterday released the results of an autopsy that he said largely exonerated New York Hospital in the death of a critically ill infant during a power failure last week.

LEAD: IT often pays to take a contrarian view, Bailard, Biehl & Kaiser Inc. of San Mateo, Calif., believes. The investment management firm started buying foreign stocks in 1979 and it concentrated on bonds in the spring of 1982, suddenly emphasizing a sector that had proven a disappointment for years. Both moves turned out to be profitable for clients of the firm, which emphasizes asset allocation.
LEAD: Now that his first victory in seven years has taken some of the pressure off him, Don Pooley wants to erase a label that has been pinned on him.
LEAD: Lee Mazzilli might have bit the hand that feeds him yesterday, but he did it for the team that raised and nurtured him.

LEAD: Boston Garden, where the Boston Celtics seldom lose, and the deafening support of a capacity crowd of 14,890 both figured to be pluses today in the Celtics' attempt to recoup from what Dennis Johnson termed ''two embarrassing losses'' to the Lakers in Los Angeles.

LEAD: ''Les Miserables,'' a musical adaptation of the 1862 Victor Hugo novel, and ''Fences,'' a drama about a black American family on the eve of the civil-rights era, swept the 41st Annual Tony Awards, which were presented last night during a live broadcast from the Mark Hellinger Theater, winning the awards for best musical and best play, respectively.

LEAD: Dr. Ellen Gloskin, a dentist in West Haven, Conn., and Peter Cohen, a woodworker for the Breakfast Woodworks in Branford, Conn., were married yesterday at the Westbury (L.I.) Manor. Rabbi Albert Thaler officiated. The bride, a graduate of Queens College of the City University of New York and the New York University School of Dentistry, is a daughter of Mr.

LEAD: On the fifth floor of a rundown city-owned tenement in Washington Heights, Alisa Del Tufo thought she had found the unattainable commodity - two apartments that could provide safe housing for a group of battered women and their children.
LEAD: Imagine Mr. Whipple, the squeezer of the Charmin, as the star of a full-length movie. Or think of Bartles and Jaymes, the wine cooler pitchmen, in feature films all their own.

LEAD: Product Movers of New York, which says it can never be sure that The Sun will distribute its free-standing inserts, will use direct mail to reach 500,000 Baltimore households beginning Jan. 10. The mailing list has been developed by Harte-Hanks to approximate the demographics of The Sun's readership.

LEAD: WHEN the gavel goes down in the High Court of Justice in London's Old Bailey today, it will mark a new chapter in the war between biotechnology companies over the valuable rights to drugs created by genetic engineering.

LEAD: WHEN John Wallowitch sits down at the piano, everything spills out, including what he refers to as his ''Lithuanian roots,'' his self-proclaimed obsession with Joan Rivers, his glowing admiration for Irving Berlin and Cole Porter and his unstinting joy in making songs out of everything that comes to mind.
LEAD: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. filed a motion in a Federal District Court in Atlanta last week seeking to overturn a $10 million judgment against it awarded in late May.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Morris Tarshis, who resigned abruptly under pressure last month after 21 years as New York City's Franchise Director, kept no logs of appointments, visitors or official telephone calls.

LEAD: AT 9 this evening on Channels 13 and 49, ''American Playhouse'' dips into the popular television genre that has come to be known as ''the disease movie.'' In this instance, an 80-minute drama entitled ''Dottie,'' the disease is agoraphobia, or a fear of being in open or public places. According to a press release for the film, millions of people in the United States never venture outside their homes because of this fear.

LEAD: Three children trapped on the second floor of a row house died in a fire today, and a 35-year-old man who had been barred from the home by his estranged wife was arrested and charged with homicide and arson. The accused, Rodney Ray Robinson, set the fire with a flammable liquid, according to the police.

LEAD: When Ernie Dozier moved into the Y.M.C.A. here, he figured he would stay just a few months. Instead it has been his home for 17 years, a measure of security in a life supported by minimum-wage jobs.

LEAD: Kuwait has asked China to join the United States and the Soviet Union in helping protect Kuwaiti oil shipping from Iranian attacks in the Persian Gulf, a senior Foreign Ministry official said today.

LEAD: Delta Air Lines said it would match the fare increases announced earlier by other airlines to offset rising fuel costs. The increases, ranging from $3 to $7 for one-way domestic trips, would be effective on tickets bought after June 19, a Delta spokesman, Jim Ewing, said. Similar increases have been announced by Trans World, Continental, United, American and Northwest airlines.

LEAD: Asbestos, slathered on years ago like dirty gray icing, insulates the beams in the ceiling of St. Patrick's elementary school here. There is asbestos in the classrooms, the cafeteria, the halls. There is asbestos on the basement pipes.

LEAD: As drug testing in the workplace becomes more prevalent nationwide, employers must decide whether it is worth the ''ill will'' and expense to test the entire work force to find a few drug users, Government and business officials said today.

LEAD: Richard Petty, who suffered two broken ribs in a crash at Dover Del., May 31, will miss the next two races on the stock-car circuit. He is expected to be ready to drive again in time for the June 28 race at Brooklyn, Mich. . . . Arnold Palmer missed qualifying for the United States Open golf championship for the fourth straight year, this time by shooting 71-72-143 Tuesday at Disney World in Lake Buena Vista, Fla.
LEAD: A leveraged-buyout group led by Morgan Stanley Group raised its bid for Burlington Industries yesterday by $2 a share, to $78.

LEAD: A police officer who had been assigned to the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn has been convicted of trying to arrange protection for a drug dealer so he would not be bothered by police narcotics officers.
LEAD: S. E. Copple, who made and lost a fortune in real estate and the Commonweath Saving Company of Lincoln, Neb., died Tuesday. He was 90 years old.

LEAD: There is a peculiar quality about the way our Government talks to the American people about foreign policy problems involving life and death issues. It is an old-fashioned, musty quality, as if it came from another period and way of thinking.

LEAD: The departure of Donald Manes from Queens politics raised hopes for reform of old patronage practices, especially when the acting Queens Democratic Party leader, John Sabini, set up a new system for selecting judges. Now, however, it's back to judicial politics as usual.
LEAD: Leo D. Hochstetter, a public relations consultant and journalist, died yesterday at his home in Bethesda, Md., after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

LEAD: The nation's orange harvest for the 1986-87 crop season is estimated at 183 million boxes, down 4 percent from the May forecast but still 4 percent more than last season, the Agriculture Department said.

LEAD: Nancy Pelosi, a Democratic fund-raiser who never before held elected office, was sworn in Tuesday to represent San Francisco in the House of Representatives. Mrs. Pelosi, 47 years old, won a special election last week to fill the Fifth District seat of the late Sala Burton, also a Democrat.

LEAD: Thousands of well-organized protesters, using bold hit-and-run tactics, fought with riot policemen in street battles that lasted through the night and into today. It was the worst street violence Seoul has seen in years.

LEAD: The financial supermarket chains are coming, if the Reagan Administration has its way. Big commercial banks have long pushed to expand across state lines and into related financial markets. Now the Treasury Under Secretary, George Gould, would go further to encourage mergers between banks and industrial corporations, creating megabanks with enough capital to compete with huge banking conglomerates in Japan and Europe.

LEAD: The Mustang Club, which set out to raise $1.3 million for athletic scholarships at Southern Methodist University this year, has easily surpassed its goal, collecting $1,528,165 during its seven-week fund-raising drive. The fund, which consists of cash, endowments and gifts of goods and services, is used to support almost 200 scholarships for the school's 16 varsity athletic programs.

LEAD: Youngsters watching from the wings at Harbor Junior High School for the Performing Arts on East 109th Street yesterday during graduation performances by students who had taken part in the yearlong circus arts program there. Repeat performances are to be given today. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)

LEAD: The 13th conference of the major non-Communist industrial nations ended today with a sober appraisal of the world economy and a series of generalized proposals to deal with persistent problems like unemployment and protectionism.

LEAD: WITH the playing of the overture, we are reminded of Jule Styne's invaluable contribution to the American musical. One difference between this and other Styne overtures is that there is, occasionally, a gentle Hebraic strain to the music. Then the show, ''Bar Mitzvah Boy,'' begins and, within minutes, it is evident that a major American songwriter has once again been diminished by those twin demons, book and lyrics.

LEAD: A new Supreme Court decision wisely shifts the current balance of law on the ticklish conflict between a landowner's right to use land freely and government's need to regulate that use in the public interest. By a 6-to-3 majority, the Court warned local governments they may have to pay private owners for even a temporary restraint on freedom to use property.
LEAD: The Rotunda of the Capitol, a stop on many Washington tours, will be closed for the next two weeks, and the fresco on the dome will be obscured for more than a year.

LEAD: Sweeping changes to the three great traffic circles on the corners of Central Park will be proposed tonight by the New York City Planning Department, in an effort to sort out tangled strands of vehicles and pedestrians and to make more monumental gateways out of jumbled, haphazard intersections.

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Richard J. Ferris lost his job as chairman and chief executive of the Allegis Corporation and his battle to preserve his travel company at a wrenching, seven-hour meeting on Tuesday.

LEAD: True to expectations, there was no progress at the Venice economic summit conference. Despite an intellectual consensus on the grave dangers of standing still, and even on the solutions, nothing happened.

LEAD: Leaders at a seven-nation economic summit meeting today declared AIDS ''one of the biggest potential health problems in the world,'' and they called for international cooperation against it through the World Health Organization.

LEAD: The Allegis Corporation's stunning announcement late Tuesday that it would break up the company and sell off the pieces could bring investors about $3 billion in profits, investment bankers estimated yesterday.

LEAD: Upon taking office two years ago, Brazil's new civilian Government pledged both to punish those involved in past corruption and to put an end to kickbacks, conflicts of interest, nepotism and influence-peddling.

LEAD: A former aide to Bess Myerson said yesterday that she was shocked by allegations that she had been hired to influence her mother improperly. The aide's mother, a judge, had been handling a divorce case involving Ms. Myerson's longtime companion, Carl A. Capasso.
LEAD: Ronald E. Rhody, senior vice president for corporate communications at the BankAmerica Corporation, is resigning to form his own public relations company, the bank said today.

LEAD: The Justice Department is preparing a lawsuit aimed at removing the executive board of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and putting the union under Federal control on the ground that is under the influence of organized crime, department officials said today.

LEAD: THE birth of mortgage-backed securities four years ago was widely regarded in the real estate industry as the beginning of the end for traditional institutional financing of large commercial developments. The projects had grown so large that developers sometimes needed $500 million or more to construct them, and only a few banks, pension funds and insurance companies would participate in these projects, even at a premium interest rate.

LEAD: The Getty Petroleum Corporation, the Long Island-based gasoline marketer, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy nearly all the assets of the Clark Oil and Refinery Corporation in a transaction valued at $447 million.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II called today for the restoration of an outlawed Solidarity union of private farmers.
LEAD: Book publishers were slow to sign up books on AIDS after the disease came to public notice in 1981, but now they are making up for lost time.

LEAD: A major move against international terrorism lies buried deep in the sonorous Venice declaration. The leaders of the seven industrial powers pledged to impose aviation sanctions when a country refuses to extradite or punish hijackers. If the leaders mean what they quietly promise, commercial air flights should cease ''immediately'' to offending states.

LEAD: West Germany will not extradite Mohammed Ali Hamadei to the United States for trial in the June 1985 hijacking of a T.W.A. airliner and the murder of an American passenger, White House officials said late today.

LEAD: WHEN Mayor Koch acted Sunday to resolve a bureaucratic tiff over the tileless ceiling in the restored Bethesda Terrace in Central Park, he scored points with curators, conservationists and architects. They had protested the absence of the vibrant Gothic Revival tiles when the terrace reopened last month.

LEAD: EMILIO AMBASZ'S designs are primal, yet rich -as basic as a child's set of blocks, yet as complex and multilayered as a sonnet. He is a designer who probes architecture's fundamentals, struggling to release the emotion and intensity that lie beneath the surface of everyday experience. His work does not look like the work of any other designer actively practicing today, but it is neither mysterious nor bizarre; indeed, it has a strangely natural quality to it, a startling appropriateness.

LEAD: As the House of Representatives today moved toward passage of a major housing bill, it defeated a key provision that would have given tenants of public housing the right to buy their apartments at 25 percent of market value.

LEAD: At the Harvard commencement 40 years ago Secretary of State George Marshall made his proposal for American aid to the devastated nations of Europe. In a few spare paragraphs, without oratorical flourish, he opened the way for the West's great postwar economic and political achievements.

LEAD: Charles F. Luce, the senior director of the Allegis Corporation who had a pivotal role in the decision to break up the company and force the resignation of Richard J. Ferris as chairman, described yesterday why the board switched its stand this week.

LEAD: When Sachio Kinugasa of the Hiroshima Toyo Carp ran out to third base for last night's game against the Yokohama Taiyo Whales, he matched Lou Gehrig's endurance feat of playing in 2,130 consecutive games. Gehrig took 15 years. Kinugasa needed 17. . . . Will Grimsley, who has covered 35 World Series and 25 Kentucky Derbys for the Associated Press, was given the Red Smith Award for sportswriting last night.

LEAD: Aloha Pacific Cruises has selected Smith Burke & Azzam, Baltimore, as its agency of record after a two-month competition that included two California-based agencies. The account is in the $1.5 million range.

''PREDATOR'' starts out as a second cousin to ''Rambo'' and ''Missing in Action,'' with Arnold Schwarzenegger (as Maj. Dutch Schaefer) leading a covert mission to find military operatives missing in Latin America. After 45 long minutes, he and his cohorts (among them Carl Weathers) find an enemy camp and conduct a raid. ''Knock, knock,'' says Mr. Schwarzenegger, kicking down the door to a hut. ''Stick around,'' he says, running somebody through with a sword. The missing men are found, but they have been brutally butchered, and the camera lingers lovingly on the carnage. Then ''Predator'' turns into a monster movie. It seems that the troops are being stalked by a large thing, played by Kevin Peter Hall, who also plays the large thing in ''Harry and the Hendersons.'' It looks like a man-sized lizard, can disguise itself like a chameleon, contains high-tech computer components and has dreadlocks on its head. Something for everyone.

LEAD: Johann Leprich, a former Nazi soldier who admitted lying about his past to gain entry to the United States after World War II, will be stripped of his citizenship, a Federal district judge has ruled. Mr. Leprich, 61 years old, will be denaturalized, the judge, Barbara Hackett, ruled Monday in granting a request by the Justice Department.

LEAD: The seven leaders left the economic summit conference proclaiming how pleased they were with themselves, and in a way it was true. They had come with thunderous warnings of tough talk, especially from the United States. But no one's arm was twisted, no one's toes were trodden on. They came up with banalities and ambiguities to address the issues before them with the least possible friction, and with the least possible content.

LEAD: Who makes Federal policy on AIDS? Sometimes it is difficult to tell. Education Secretary William J. Bennett, for example, who has urged young people to refrain from sexual activity as a way to avoid the disease, has been more outspoken than have many Government health officials who, with decades of professional training, would ordinarily be expected to make the major policy decisions on such an epidemic.

LEAD: A RARE Frank Lloyd Wright dining room ensemble -eight tall spindle-backed chairs and a squarish table - is to be auctioned June 20 at 2 P.M. at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, in what is described by the house as the largest and most important sale ever held of the architect's early furniture.

LEAD: Millions of computer users, both individuals and businesses, would pay substantially higher fees for telephone hookups to information services under a new Government proposal, industry officials said today.

LEAD: Two of six dissident alumni of Harvard University who ran for the Board of Overseers on a platform urging Harvard to divest itself of South Africa-related stocks have been elected, along with three others sympathetic to divestment. LEAD: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward will meet Monday with the head of the City Health and Hospitals Corporation to discuss the charges of a Harlem Hospital staff physician that he was the victim of police brutality, a police spokesman said yesterday.

LEAD: The days of Brooklyn as a maze of trolley tracks and rail lines are to be explored on a bus tour Sunday sponsored by the Prospect Park Environmental Center. LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it was reducing the flow of air traffic through the nation's busiest airspace sectors when they faced saturation. It said that the program had been adopted to increase safety margins but acknowledged that it was causing added delays.

LEAD: Golf Richard Leads Mayflower by a Shot: Deb Richard, who has never finished in the top 15 in her two years on the L.P.G.A. tour, shot a six-under-par 66 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead after one round of the Mayflower Classic in Indianapolis. Lenore Muraoka, who hasn't finished higher than 37th this year, shot a career-best 67 to share second with Colleen Walker and Cathy Gerring.(AP)

LEAD: Musical crib mobiles made by Woodcrafter Kits Inc. are being recalled because of excess lead in the paint, the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today. The paint on the mobiles contains more lead than is permitted in Federal rules, and paint that flaked off could pose a hazard, the agency said.

LEAD: Markets New stock issues with multiple voting rights would be limited by a proposed S.E.C. rule. The plan, which would bar shares carrying more than one vote each, effectively removes one defense against takeovers; it is aimed at preventing managements from diluting existing shareholders' voting power.

First published in 1852, the novel was an immediate success, selling 300,000 copies within a year. And from the outset, its unflattering depiction of slavery was controversial.

LEAD: In a move to get some semblance of agreement among its 61,000 employees on a $6 billion breakup of the company, the Allegis Corporation has begun looking for a top labor negotiator, insiders said yesterday.

LEAD: Princeton University - Princeton. There are guided tours of Princeton University every day at 10 and 11 A.M and at 1:30 and 3:30 P.M., except Sundays, when there are no morning tours. Orange Key, which conducts the free hourlong tours, also has self-guided tours of the campus trees, sculpture, architecture and, a favorite of many, the dozens of gargoyles.

LEAD: First Jersey Securities Inc. and its Atlanta branch manager have agreed to pay $97,500 in penalties and cost reimbursements, concluding a state investigation into purported securities violations. Georgia's Secretary of State, Max Cleland, said Wednesday that the consent order signed by the branch manager, Matthew Wochele, and the New York-based stock brokerage firm also placed the company under probation for two years in Georgia.

LEAD: An air traffic controller frantically tried to guide Dean Paul Martin's Air National Guard jet through a blizzard just before it crashed, but heavy air traffic hampered communications, according to an Air Force investigation.

In fact, a lot of them don't even want the areas mentioned.

LEAD: Almost from the moment they assumed power more than two years ago, the two Soviet leaders have seemed slightly out of step.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had sold much of its holding in the Intel Corporation, a key supplier of microprocessors for I.B.M. computers, after concluding that the chip maker no longer needed its financial support.

LEAD: Judicial misconduct charges have been brought by a state panel against the judge whom Bess Myerson, the former New York City Cultural Affairs Commissioner, is accused of having improperly influenced, law-enforcement officials disclosed yesterday.
LEAD: The United States and France have reached a tentative agreement on ways for the West to negotiate with the Soviet Union on conventional arms, a senior State Department official said today.

LEAD: Lloyd Daniels, the former schoolboy basketball star from New York City who was recruited then spurned by the University of Nevada-Las Vegas, pleaded guilty yesterday to a misdemeanor charge of attempting to buy rock cocaine at a crack house this year. Daniels must enter a three-month drug rehabilitation program and undergo urinalysis twice a week under terms of a plea bargain.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II today proclaimed the outlawed Solidarity labor movement a model for all human rights struggles, declaring that the world must remember Poland's brief, now dormant experiment with freedom.

LEAD: A former vice president at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company was indicted yesterday on charges of conspiracy and aiding and abetting the illegal activities of Antonio Gebauer, the former Morgan executive who pleaded guilty to defrauding the bank.
LEAD: Jim and Tammy Bakker returned to their home here late Wednesday night, promising to return to television evangelism within 30 days.

LEAD: Warning that the spreading AIDS epidemic among intravenous drug users in New York City had reached a ''state of emergency,'' state and city officials disclosed a new program yesterday that would provide treatment for 3,000 drug addicts.

LEAD: Alexander Iolas, known internationally first as a ballet dancer and later as a leading art dealer who specialized in the Surrealists, died on Monday at New York Hospital. He was 80 years old.
LEAD: Elizabeth Hartman, who was nominated for an Academy Award for best actress in 1966 for her role in ''A Patch of Blue,'' died in a fall from her fifth-floor apartment in Pittsburgh on Wednesday.

LEAD: The unexpected rejection of the Knicks' general-manager job by Jack McCloskey of the Detroit Pistons this week could have other ramifications for the Knicks in their search for a new general manager. David Checketts of the Utah Jazz, who is also under consideration for the position, said yesterday that Richard Evans, the Knicks president, had promised him that if the job were offered to anyone else besides Checketts, he would be called.

Cohen from the movie, which was in turn adapted from the William Goldman novel, tells the story of a Manhattan serial murderer whose victims remind him of his monstrous actress-mother.

LEAD: The Veterans Administration was ordered to pay thousands of dollars in new penalties today because a judge ruled it had illegally withheld internal documents sought by a veterans' group in an increasingly bitter lawsuit.

LEAD: Although a lawyer by profession, George Templeton Strong was also a 19th-century patron of the arts who kept a journal of his cultural activities. ''PREDATOR'' starts out as a second cousin to ''Rambo'' and ''Missing in Action,'' with Arnold Schwarzenegger (as Maj. Dutch Schaefer) leading a covert mission to find military operatives missing in Latin America. After 45 long minutes, he and his cohorts (among them Carl Weathers) find an enemy camp and conduct a raid. ''Knock, knock,'' says Mr. Schwarzenegger, kicking down the door to a hut. ''Stick around,'' he says, running somebody through with a sword. The missing men are found, but they have been brutally butchered, and the camera lingers lovingly on the carnage. Then ''Predator'' turns into a monster movie. It seems that the troops are being stalked by a large thing, played by Kevin Peter Hall, who also plays the large thing in ''Harry and the Hendersons.'' It looks like a man-sized lizard, can disguise itself like a chameleon, contains high-tech computer components and has dreadlocks on its head. Something for everyone.

LEAD: Charles Garside Jr., a history professor at Rice University, died yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital in Houston of complications after a stroke. He was 59 years old.

LEAD: New York is going to have a museum of broadcast advertising, thanks to a $375,000 grant from the Advertising Educational Foundation. But to make it a success, it must receive copies of advertising as donations.

LEAD: As their days dwindle, these are things AIDS patients say they want most: cool sheets; a hand to hold; a promise that they will not have to bear too great a suffering, and that they will not have to die alone.

LEAD: In a step that could remove a key defense against hostile takeovers, the Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed a rule that would forbid corporate managements from diluting the voting rights of their existing shareholders by issuing new classes of stock with multiple voting powers.

LEAD: Cameras caught more than one Western leader with drooping eyelids in the closing moments of their summit conference in Venice. Sadly, there wasn't much reason to stay awake. To avoid embarrassing each other, or exposing their own political weaknesses, none of the seven leaders had pressed for tough decisions on any of the world's burning issues.

LEAD: Bruce Babbitt, a Democratic Presidential hopeful, began his campaign in Iowa nearly a year ago with what he describes as ''a terrible anonymity.''

LEAD: Several thousand anti-Government student radicals fought with the police in the heart of the capital Friday and early today, hurling bricks and gasoline bombs and chanting, ''Down with the military dictatorship!''
LEAD: Three of Panama's six morning newspapers failed to appear today after editors refused to submit articles for censorship.
LEAD: Louise Vyent smiled from the cover of the February issue of Vogue. Two months earlier, Karen Alexander, another black model, appeared in profile on the cover of Elle magazine.

LEAD: The Pennzoil Company said it was considering spinning off one or more subsidiaries if its protracted $10.3 billion legal dispute with Texaco Inc. was not resolved in the coming months.

LEAD: The flowers covering the front of the Sheridan Square Playhouse, bleached from two weeks of late spring sun, have begun to wither; the notes from the bereaved - some hastily scrawled on cards, others printed out by computer on yellow telegram paper - are fading; the impromptu crowds of mourners have slowly dwindled to a trickle of passersby, curious about this funny-sad street shrine.

LEAD: Dizzy Gillespie's current engagement at Michael's Pub, his first appearance at the club at 211 East 55th Street, is titled ''Dizzy Goes Broadway.'' But not to worry. As he approaches his 70th birthday in October, the celebrated jazz trumpeter still goes no way except his own.

LEAD: The Philadelphia 76ers' center, Jeff Ruland, the key in one of the franchise's most controversial trades, has retired from professional basketball because of a chronic knee injury. ''We have concluded that Jeff can no longer pass physical requirements to play professional basketball,'' said John Nash, the Sixers' general manager.

LEAD: Maybe, after these eight years, mine were lying eyes after all.

LEAD: An uneasy truce settled over the Mets today, but the bitter feelings continued between Manager Dave Johnson and Darryl Strawberry, who said: ''I don't know why Davey is always trying to bury me.''

LEAD: Yields on Treasury bonds fell to around 8 1/2 percent yesterday for the first time since late April, in response to a slight decline in the trade deficit and slower than expected inflation.
LEAD: A selection committee has made Churchill Downs - the home of the Kentucky Derby - its unanimous choice as the site for the fifth annual Breeders' Cup Day next year.

LEAD: The prosecution in the trial of Justice Francis X. Smith of Queens described him yesterday as a willing participant in a scheme to bribe a cable television operator seeking a franchise in the borough.

LEAD: Madge Kennedy, a stage and silent film star in the early part of the century, died of respiratory failure Monday at the Motion Picture and Television Country Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. She was 96 years old and lived in Hollywood.
LEAD: The new Parliament that sits on June 25 will include the first nonwhites elected to the House of Commons since the 1920's, but it will be missing some veteran politicians from past Parliaments.

LEAD: Leading black journalists have hailed the plaintiffs' success in a long and bitter racial discrimination trial against The Daily News as a significant development that will encourage the promotion and hiring of blacks in the nation's newsrooms.
LEAD: A Federal researcher who pleaded guilty in Federal court last month to falsifying chemical analysis reports in accident investigations has resigned from the Federal Aviation Administration.

LEAD: Adults with braces, a rarity 10 years ago, are almost commonplace nowadays, and orthodontists say that while their adult patients are more cooperative and responsible than younger ones, the adults complain more about discomfort and are more self-conscious about their appearance.

LEAD: An alleged gang member should stand trial in the 1984 slaying of a Chinese-American writer who was a critic of the Taiwanese government, a judge has ruled.

LEAD: Five students were beaten with baseball bats and 13 youths were arrested yesterday as a roving band of beer-drinking toughs snatched gold chains and attacked victims at random outside a high school in Brooklyn in what the police called an outbreak of racial violence.

LEAD: Marianne Savare, the daughter of Mrs. Leo Dugar Savare of Memphis and the late Mr. Savare, was married there yesterday to Ronald Anderson Walter, a son of Norris Walter of Memphis and the late Estelle Anderson Walter. The Rev. Donald Mowery, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Orpheum, a restored landmark theater.

LEAD: When all else fails for the Mets, when Darryl Strawberry stops talking to Davey Johnson, when Tom Seaver struggles and Bob Ojeda ails and Wally Backman hurts, there are always the bats and Sid Fernandez. And the combination exploded again tonight.

Cromartie, after being hit by a pitch, punched Masami Miyashita of the Chunichi Dragons, who is expected to miss about 10 days while recovering from a cut in his mouth.

LEAD: Investigators looking into mysterious reports that Bess Myerson sent large amounts of cash to a Third Avenue address have subpoenaed financial records from at least three companies in the building.

LEAD: The midtown office district is spilling west across Seventh Avenue and Broadway, transforming a neighborhood of theaters, movie houses and related businesses into a workplace for investment bankers, lawyers and accountants.
LEAD: Paul D. O'Brien, a New York lawyer who had many famous clients from the entertainment industry, died after a long illness on May 29 at his home in Longboat Key, Fla. He was 82 years old.

LEAD: Tuvia Bielsky, the leader of an armed band of Jewish partisans in Nazi-occupied Byelorussia that was known as Bielsky's Brigade, died yesterday in Brookdale Hospital in Brooklyn. A resident of Brooklyn, where he used the surname Bell, he was 81 years old.

LEAD: Nearly three months after the PTL scandal broke, Jessica Hahn, the Pentecostal church secretary who was briefly at the center of it, says she spends her days in her Long Island apartment, bewildered, anguished and alone.

LEAD: Joe Gonzales, Texas state trooper, being rescued by a television station helicopter after his car was stranded outside San Antonio. The last six months have been the wettest in the city since 1935. The body of 12-year-old girl, who, along with a cousin, was lost in a rain-swollen creek Thursday, was recovered yesterday.
LEAD: In a hurry as always, Jeanette Best did not bother to use a glass yesterday, but swigged straight from the bottle.

LEAD: The Federal judge in the fraud and bribery trial of Representative Mario Biaggi told lawyers yesterday that a woman who accompanied the Congressman on two vacation trips to Florida should not be asked about their relationship when she testifies.

LEAD: It was a damp, dreary day, definitely not a beach day, but for Glenn Radermacher, a lifeguard at Far Rockaway, it was business as usual even though there was no one to guard. Showers are likely again today. (NYT/ Larry C. Morris)

LEAD: The Defense Deprtment's inspector general has concluded that the Navy, through gross mismanagement, wasted $10.7 million trying to build the first of a new class of attack boats for its Seal commandos.

LEAD: A Minneapolis-based investment group said that it was considering reviving an attempt at a takeover of the beleaguered Zondervan Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, a Minneapolis broker, Jeffrey P. Wendel, and an investment partnership, DVC-JPW Investors, said that they ''are seeking to enter into arrangements with other persons who may be interested in acquiring control'' of the Bible publisher.
LEAD: MARVIN TOMPKINS, a retired food company sales manager now living in Clearwater, Fla., signed a prenuptial agreement before remarrying 18 months ago.

LEAD: Pvt. Douglas G. Beane, who spent the last 17 years living in Australia after deserting from the Marine Corps in Vietnam, has been ordered held in jail until his case was settled, the Corps announced today. The 39-year-old marine, who returned to the United States voluntarily to visit his ill father, will be confined to the brig at the Quantico, Va., Marine Base pending a possible court-martial, a Marine Corps statement said.

LEAD: Like the Grover's Corners of Thornton Wilder's ''Our Town,'' Lake Wobegon, Minn., is situated on a stretch of the imagination, at the crossroads of what we are and what we wanted to be. Millions acquired the habit of tuning in to that mythical place Garrison Keillor created wherever public radio might be received.
LEAD: Raya Dunayevskaya, an author who was secretary to Leon Trotsky, died Tuesday in Sheridan Road Hospital, Chicago. A resident of Evanston, Ill., she was 77 years old.
LEAD: The PTL ministry, struggling to survive in the face of a mountain of debt, filed for court protection from its creditors today under Federal bankruptcy laws.

LEAD: At St. James's Episcopal Church in New York yesterday, Sheila Driggs Hultkrans and William Feick Jr. were married by Bishop Robert C. Witcher of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, who was assisted by the Rev. Susan C. Harris.

LEAD: A landmark document on Christian-Jewish relations ran into sharp, unexpected opposition today at the annual meeting of the nation's largest Presbyterian denomination and appeared headed for defeat.

LEAD: The New York Philharmonic has presented three concerts this week at Avery Fisher Hall intended primarily for the visiting delegates of the American Symphony Orchestra League's annual convocation. On Tuesday, Zubin Mehta broke his year-long sabbatical to lead a snippet by Elliott Carter and Bruckner's massive Eighth Symphony.

LEAD: A three-judge Appellate Court panel today delayed a court hearing scheduled for Monday in Toms River on the suitability of a site in Ocean County as a temporary repository for 15,000 barrels of radium-contaminated soil. The panel made its ruling pending a decision, expected next week, on a request by the State Department of Environmental Protection that the case be heard directly by the Appellate Division rather than by lower courts.
LEAD: Asher B. Edelman and Dominion Textile Inc. hinted yesterday in a letter written to Burlington Industries that they might raise their joint bid for the company from $77 a share.

LEAD: Representative Patricia Schroeder of Colorado met with top Democrats in her former home state today, testing the waters for a potential run for the party's Presidential nomination. She said her one-day swing in Iowa, where the Democrats' first caucuses will be held next Feb. 6, would be followed by a trip to New Hampshire.
LEAD: New York City must stop leaving babies in hospitals for months at a time while foster homes are sought for them, according to a court agreement announced yesterday.

LEAD: A Washington dispatch yesterday about testimony critical of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission before a House Interior subcommittee misidentified a subcommittee member who questioned the commission's believability. He was Representative George Miller, Democrat of California.
LEAD: A 37-year-old fireworks expert pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that he bombed an abortion clinic in Manhattan and tried to bomb another one in Queens.

LEAD: By seeking to sell Maverick air-to-ground missiles to Saudi Arabia and then abruptly withdrawing the proposal Thursday, the Reagan Administration appears to have erected a new hurdle in its efforts to restore American credibility in the Persian Gulf.

LEAD: Shares in JWT Group Inc. climbed $1.625 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, to $50.625, amid widespread rumors that MCA Inc. might rescue the big advertising and public relations organization from an unwanted $45-a-share British takeover bid.
LEAD: A swaggering inmate who said he would ''rather be fishing'' was executed in the electric chair early today for the shooting deaths of a bound and gagged couple in 1982.

LEAD: The historical antagonism between this city by the sea and its longtime rival, Madrid, is on the decline. In recent years, the two have found less that divides them and more that binds them, and reasons to pull together rather than continue to fight.
LEAD: Presbyterians and Judaism A sweeping document on Christian-Jewish relations appeared headed for defeat at a meeting of the largest Presbyterian denomination. Page 6.
LEAD: Workers and security forces clashed briefly tonight in an incident that marred Pope John Paul II's visit to the birthplace of the Solidarity labor movement.

LEAD: Charles Gatewood is a photographer and anthropologist who specializes in ''subcultures.'' On the evidence of ''Dances Sacred and Profane,'' Mark and Dan Jury's documentary about Mr. Gatewood, he is drawn particularly to Mardi Gras revels, gatherings of nudists and sex clubs. Bare breasts, elaborately tattooed bodies and bizarre behavior are featured in his work, and in the movie.

LEAD: An article in some editions of Sports Pages yesterday incompletely described the new position for Harry Edwards at the baseball commisioner's office. He will act as a part-time consultant to the commissioner and will not have a formal title with major league baseball. Further developments are reported today on page 45.

LEAD: The subject of blueberry muffins has come up periodically ever since this column carried a recipe two years ago for the blueberry muffins served at the Ritz-Carlton in Boston. The hotel had adapted the muffin recipe used by Gilchrist's, once one of Boston's best-known department stores.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has called for a methodical loosening of central controls over the Soviet economy, but he stopped short of endorsing more far-reaching measures urged by some economists and party officials, according to party documents published today.

LEAD: Ted Owens, who had a 21-36 record in two seasons as basketball coach at Oral Roberts University, resigned Thursday night after three months of pressure from the university. In March, Owens was removed from his post as athletic director, and Ken Trickey, a former head coach at Oral Roberts, was hired as his assistant.
LEAD: Daniel Mandell, a film editor who won three Oscars and was nominated for five others during a lengthy Hollywood career, died Monday in Huntington Beach, Calif., at the age of 92.

LEAD: The Koch administration has responded to the rash of corporate departures by announcing new tax incentive programs to attract and retain business. The administration may give the impression that it is ''doing something,'' but its program, awaiting approval by the City Council and State Legislature, seems hastily drawn and suffers from basic flaws.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: When the game was over, Dennis Rasmussen slumped into a chair in front of his locker and insisted once, twice, three times that he was not aware he might have been pitching last night to save his job with the Yankees.
LEAD: The Government said today that it had released 1,000 detainees held under the state of emergency.

He called Monday night's nationally televised 11-0 loss to the Toronto Blue Jays ''embarrassing.

LEAD: David S. Solomon, a 35-year-old developer who resembles Groucho Marx (he is taller and does not wear glasses), hates the lights of Broadway. He wants to replace them with trees.

LEAD: Milton F. Tingling, a New York City Civil Court judge, died of respiratory failure Tuesday in St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center. He lived in Manhattan and was 66 years old.

LEAD: John Niekro of Lilburn, Ga., whose father, Phil, and uncle Joe are both veteran major league pitchers, has been drafted by the Atlanta Braves, with whom Phil pitched 18 seasons and Joe part of two seasons. At Shiloh High School, Niekro was mainly an outfielder, but won his first six pitching decisions.

LEAD: Telling the same story twice may be profitable for a panhandler or a stand-up comedian but it is a great mistake for a bridge player. North made this error on the diagramed deal played recently in California.

LEAD: When the marble floors of railroad stations become beds . . . when 6-year-olds play games like snatch-the-purse in welfare hotel lobbies . . . when lack of housing for middle-income executives threatens business expansion . . . when old people cannot afford to heat the houses from which they cannot afford to move, America's urban housing problems send alarms that cannot be tuned out.

LEAD: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that ''it would be hard'' not to endorse Senator Sam Nunn for the Democratic Presidential nomination if Mr. Nunn, a fellow Georgian, decided to enter the race.

LEAD: The settlement of a suit by former Senator Paul Laxalt against the McClatchy newspaper chain leaves in its wake serious questions about the good sense and propriety of libel suits by Presidential candidates and high public officials. In Mr. Laxalt's case, both sides proclaimed victory after an ambiguous settlement.

LEAD: Every once in a while a crime comes along that couldn't have occurred even 50 years ago - simply because the weapon didn't exist. Such is the alleged crime of Karl W. Hall, who lives in Brookville, Va. He is charged with trying to kill his wife with their waterbed.

LEAD: A top health official admitted today that the state had erred by having a 14-year-old boy locked up in a mental ward in an effort to keep him from spreading AIDS. The official said he would ask a judge to lift the quarantine order.

LEAD: The unevenness of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's campaign clouded a political message that was delivered with unmistakable clarity by Britain's voters once the ballots were tallied this morning. Come thick or thin, an unshakable bloc of voters support Mrs. Thatcher on pocketbook and military issues.

LEAD: The stock market moved ahead smartly yesterday, capping a week when its blue-chip indicator, the Dow Jones industrial average, never had a down session. Indeed, it has now moved higher in seven of the last eight trading days.
LEAD: A picture caption on the Style page yesterday with an article about the costumes of the New York City Ballet misidentified a man inspecting an Edwardian jacket. He was Leslie Copeland.
LEAD: The galleries swelled around Jack Nicklaus as the intermittent rain fell, but he could not satisfy his fans, who have been spoiled by his remarkable success in the past.

LEAD: Snow Chief, the fourth-leading money-winner in thoroughbred racing history, has an injured tendon in his left front leg that will probably cause him to be retired to stud, his trainer, Mel Stute, said today.

LEAD: The Alpine Ski World Cup Committee announced today that the men's calendar will be cut from 30 to 28 races next season while the women's schedule will go from 28 to 27.

LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation today announced scores of arrests of people accused of running major narcotics money-laundering rings, among them seven Colombians. Undercover agents processed sums totaling $175 million in the three-year operation.

LEAD: Michael Sergio, the parachutist who landed afoul of the law when he jumped into Shea Stadium during the sixth game of the World Series last fall, was released yesterday from the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan, three weeks after he began a six-month term for civil contempt of court.
LEAD: President Reagan sought today to undercut Europe's perception of Mikhail S. Gorbachev as a leader of peace, bluntly challenging the Soviet leader to tear down the Berlin wall.
LEAD: President Jose Sarney ordered drastic measures today to give what he called a ''shock to the economy'' in order to ''pull Brazil from its crisis.''

LEAD: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration is expanding its investigation into allegations of unreported job injuries among workers at the nation's largest meatpacking company, according to Labor Department officials.
LEAD: Here among the wooded hills and green fields of Dutchess County some very angry people are mounting an assault against an enemy 354 miles long.

LEAD: Bloke here claims he can throw the knuckleball.

The driver, identified as Eduardo Cardenas-Ventura, faced alien-smuggling charges.

LEAD: DURING ANTON CHEKHOV'S lifetime, the one-act play ''The Bear'' was one of his most popular and financially rewarding works. As he acknowledged, ''I live off the labors of my bear.'' With a few exceptions, dramatists today have had no such comparable experience with one-acts. Short plays are generally regarded as curtain raisers or afterthoughts, perhaps stageworthy but not commercially viable.

LEAD: Jacob Rabinow is right, ''You gotta make things,'' but to get from the invention to the successful manufacturing and use of products, you've gotta have innovation (''One Man's Mousetraps,'' by Robert Kanigel, May 17). Invention is often the solution to a technical problem. To take an invention and translate it into a commercially successful product requires the fusion of marketing requirements, manufacturing and assembly, and ergonomics, all translated by design into useful ''things'' that meet user needs and arrive on the market ahead of the competition.

LEAD: BREAD AND CIRCUS. By Morris Renek. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $18.95.) This historical novel is like New York City itself. So many characters do so much so fast that one is seldom entirely sure of what is going on. Historic fact suggests that the hero, William M. (Boss) Tweed, must come a cropper at the end, but in the meantime one is carried along by the energy of this tale of 19th-century power and lust and by the enchantment of the author's gift for the metaphor juste.

LEAD: FOR THE FIRST TIME, TO bacco - a symbol of America for more than 400 years, a subject of national debate and a source of inspiration to folk artists for most of that time - is the subject of a major museum exhibition. On sunny days, which alternate with spells of storm and fog in the summer, the sky maintains a blue stillness, and on the hills sheep graze almost without moving.

LEAD: THE construction tragedy in Bridgeport dramatizes once again the fallibility of men and their machines. There is something in the human condition that demands, especially in situations like this, the definition of a ''cause'' that brought about the ''effect.'' This must be approached on a rational level, setting aside preconceptions and prejudices, looking dispassionately for the true essence of the problem, with the resolve to correct, not simply to blame.

LEAD: New York City jurors receive $12 a day, while Nassau County residents get only $7. In Rockland County, the per diem is $6. Legislation pending in Albany would set a uniform jury fee statewide and increase compensation to a more presentable $15.

LEAD: Between the end of August and mid-October, visitors to Cape Cod who travel the back roads near the ocean or the bay are likely to come upon residents toting white plastic Cape Cod Potato Chips pails and staring like bird watchers at the shrubbery.

LEAD: A bipartisan consensus appears to be growing on Capitol Hill that the Government should be doing more to solve what many experts describe as a crisis in child care. But there is little agreement yet on what needs to be done.

LEAD: TWO EXHIBITIONS OF considerable interest have recently opened at the IBM Gallery of Science and Art (through July 11) - ''Pre-Modern Art of Vienna 1848-98'' and ''Building a National Image: Architectural Drawings for the American Democracy, 1789-1912.'' They have no formal connection with each other, though taken together they may prompt a few thoughts about contrasting national styles.

LEAD: One thing that sets Dallas apart from major cities on both coasts is the prominent role of its mainstream Protestant churches. In a social sense, as well as a moral one, church is the place to be on Sunday morning. Members of the establishment, and those aspiring to it, mingle on the steps after worshipping inside.

LEAD: NEARLY a year to the day after unknown arsonists destroyed the venerable Hitchcock Presbyterian Church on Walworth Avenue in Scarsdale, the church's governing body has approved the design for a new exterior in a rebuilding that will cost considerably more than the $3 million budgeted for the new structure.
LEAD: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters is so corrupt that the Government is preparing a lawsuit aimed at taking control of the union, the Justice Department said last week.

LEAD: Dr. Laurie Horowitz, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Horowitz of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., was married last evening to Dr. Bruce Segal, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Segal of Weston, Mass. Rabbi Joel Y. Zion performed the ceremony at the Sign of the Dove in Manhattan. The bride, who will retain her name, is a resident in pathology at the New York University Medical Center.
LEAD: FIELDS OF FRIENDLY STRIFE By John Janovy Jr. 130 pp. New York: Viking. $14.95.

LEAD: In the accompanying article, the authors suggest that the subcontracting of production now so popular among major corporations might provide the basis of an industrial revival. In the following discussion, Hannah Roditi, a research analyst with the Massachusetts Machine Action Project, in Springfield, assesses their theory from her perspective on the factory floor.

LEAD: Because of a transcription error, a story last week on earth sciences weekends for Pleasantville High School students incorrectly quoted Dorna Schroeter, director of the Madden Outdoor Education Center in Kent Cliffs, Putnam County. Miss Schroeter said: ''The reason we may not have as much of a problem with acid rain here as compared to the Adironacks is because we have a lot of limestone deposits in the Taconic region, and limestone acts as a neutralizer, bringing down the level of acidity.

LEAD: Now let's see . . . On one hand, David Robinson could put up bombs, and on the other hand he could launch them. He could overthrow a pass or a government. He could shoot hoops or people. He could follow the rules of the basketball court, or ignore the rules of the World Court. Hmmm . . . tough call.

LEAD: ONCE UPON A TIME, or in 1942 if you prefer, high schools graduated their sweaty produce in June. Now the car-crash roundups in the press suggest they favor May, and why not? LEAD: The marriage of Maura Del Gaudio, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Del Gaudio of Greenwich, Conn., to Peter James Marcon Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marcon of Larchmont, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Carsten Martinson performed the ceremony.

LEAD: A COMMUNITY theater, it is presumed, puts on lightweight, ephemeral and escapist fare for hometown audiences. One hardly expects such a local amateur group to tackle a topical play on a controversial subject, win prizes for it and wind up as a candidate for international honors.

LEAD: A delegation of senior Communist Party officials sped to Poland's holiest shrine early this morning to tell Vatican officials they were distressed by the Pope's speeches praising Solidarity, according to a member of the Pope's entourage.
LEAD: Thieves prefer imported automobiles to domestic ones, according to the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

LEAD: Leigh Foster Watkins, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frank Moore Watkins of Royal Oak, Md., was married yesterday to Brent Michael Taylor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Keith I. A. Taylor of Wellington and Otaki, New Zealand. The Rev. Donald Etherton performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in St. Michaels, Md.

The Rev. Frederick Boswell performed the ceremony at St.

LEAD: Last summer when my husband and I drove through the stone gates of Arles, the Provencal city immortalized by Van Gogh, we could hardly believe our eyes. There, striding proudly down the narrow street, were two Arles women attired in the dress seen in Van Gogh's pictures. Farther down the street, another.

LEAD: The jury in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz asked to have the judge's instructions about the law of self-defense read back to them yesterday, but they were given a slightly different version - more favorable to Mr. Goetz - than the one they heard when deliberations began Friday.
LEAD: To the Editor: ''A Seafaring Past Preserved'' by Malabar Hornblower (Travel, May 17), overlooked a unique and exciting museum - the Museum of Yachting - at Fort Adams State Park in Newport.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: RETAILERS' memories might be called ''longuette.'' That term was coined to describe the mid-calf (and longer) skirts that designers and retailers banked on almost exclusively in the fall of 1970. At the time, the fashion was described as the most heavily promoted in history; it was hard to find anything else.

LEAD: The engagement of Alison Vincent Smith to Robert John Marcinek has been announced by her parents, Kathleen M. Hodgsdon of Fairfield, Conn., and Peter B. Smith of New York and Sharon, Conn. The future bridegroom is a son of Martin S. Marcinek of Windsor Locks, Conn., and the late Mrs. Marcinek. An October wedding is planned.

LEAD: IN AN AGE IN WHICH MUSEUMS HAVE become grandiose, expressionistic, highly personal works of architecture, the first impulse is to say that the new Menil Collection in Houston represents an opposite trend: it is matter of fact, understated, utterly deferential to the art it contains. Yet in its way, this 402-foot-long, two-story-high box of steel, wood and glass, which seems so plain, is as expressive of personal style as any museum in America.

LEAD: Finding your hotel does not have your room when you have paid for it in advance or guaranteed your reservation with a credit card number is an utterly dismaying experience. Most motels and hotels, knowing that the name of the game is indeed hospitality, will try to place you promptly in a comparable room nearby and will try to get matters right, with an apology at least and sometimes a basket of fruit or a voucher for a cocktail.

LEAD: The newest addition to Governor Cuomo's out-of-state itinerary is Indianapolis, where he will depart from his usual practice and participate in an outright political event - a fund-raising dinner for the Indiana Democratic Party.

LEAD: IT is strange that in the current epoch, when so many diverse strategic and tactical ideas are pursued by a veritable army of hungry tournament players, one can still find a stone of critical importance unturned. Yet it does happen.

LEAD: THE OBITUARIES FOR THE ''REAGAN revolution'' are already being published. A Time magazine cover story reports that ''there are signs of a fundamental change in the nation's political weather . . .'' Even Mikhail Gorbachev has casually referred to Ronald Reagan as a lame-duck President, though why the Soviet leader should be so eager to make unprecedented concessions in order to negotiate an arms-control agreement with such a President is left unclear.

LEAD: AN OYSTER, LEFT TO ITS own devices, sits in its bed under water and carries on the happy-go-lucky bivalve life. Yet slip that oyster the tiniest bit of grit, or some other well-chosen irritant, and the result might just be a pearl.
LEAD: Vietnamese street signs are popping up all over Bangkok these days as two American film companies follow each other around town, part of a new wave of movies set during the Vietnam War.

LEAD: Suzanne Elizabeth Durrell, an assistant Attorney General for the Commonwealth of Massachusetts in Boston, and Ian Scott McIsaac, a Boston real-estate executive, were married yesterday at the Cochran Chapel on the campus of the Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass.

LEAD: At Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Centerport, L.I., Sharon Anne Maguire, an account executive at DDB Needham Worldwide, an advertising agency in New York, was married yesterday to Bryan J. Buckley, an art director at Chiat/Day Advertising in New York. The Rev. Thomas Fusco officiated.
LEAD: Although the New Jersey Legislature considers thousands of bills each year, and passes hundreds, there is only one bill it is required to act on - the state budget.

LEAD: IN the beds and borders of a garden, men and women meet as equals. Eager for blooms and merciless on bugs, both appreciate the efforts of the other. But a few aspects of the art appear to be rooted to gender.
LEAD: Ninety days into an investigation that is supposed to last a year, Governor Cuomo's Task Force on Bias-Related Violence has issued two modest but useful recommendations.

LEAD: Col. Roberto Diaz Herrera, a self-described sinner and until recently the No. 2 man in the Panama Defense Forces, said fear that God would punish him if he remained silent had led him accuse the No. 1 man, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, of complicity in murder and electoral fraud. Colonel Diaz's statements touched off a week of political violence that paralyzed Panama City, the capital.

LEAD: Amanda Bayer, who is studying for a Ph.D. degree in economics at Yale University, was married in the Marquand Chapel at the Yale Divinity School in New Haven yesterday to Andrejs Penikis, a budget analyst for the Department of Education in Washington. The Rev. Dean Ahlberg performed the Protestant ceremony.

LEAD: By publicizing her mother's Memory Book, Joan Gage does a disservice to her mother's memory. The reader, with all due respect to piety, will find this woman neither mysterious nor interesting, despite the many pretty photographs. If she is memorable, then it is for her apparent inability, all her life, to cease being a spoiled little girl.

LEAD: ''FINE Italian hand'' may have a negative connotation, politically speaking, implying Machiavellian intrigue, but when it comes to cooking, that's the kind of hand required - fine, as in dextrous, keen, sharp, precise, skillful. In Italian cooking, that mother of all European culinary finesse, it is essential.
LEAD: * To M. M. Dostoyevsky Dec. 22, 1849

LEAD: A DISPLAY OF WYETHS A. N. Wyeth, the 38-year-old nephew of the painter Andrew Wyeth, will attend the opening reception for his exhibition of watercolors from 2 to 5 P.M. today at the Lyman Allyn Museum in New London. Mr. Wyeth's work will be on display until July 12, accompanied by one painting from each of his artist-relatives.

LEAD: Massachusetts has opened a new clinic for alcoholic women in an effort to correct a glaring deficiency in services that had resulted in the state housing such women in a prison without treatment.

LEAD: To the Editor: I was surprised that Edward J. Sullivan didn't mention the Museum of the Royal Academy of Fine Arts of San Fernando in ''Madrid's Other Museums'' (Travel, March 22). LEAD: TIME'S ARROW, TIME'S CYCLE Myth and Metaphor in the Discovery of Geological Time. By Stephen Jay Gould. Illustrated. 222 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $17.50.

LEAD: ONE of Connecticut's largest collections of castoff pens lies in the center drawer of the teacher's desk in the computer room at Westport's Coleytown Middle School. There must be about 200 there now, most in good working order. Since Westport is an affluent town, some of the pens cost $2.79 at the local stationery store.

LEAD: ''My idea was to paint a picture verbally of what a successful principal did on a daily basis, what her roles and responsibilities were, how she interacted with people and how she led her school,'' said Dr. Barbara Morris, referring to the research she conducted while working as an administrative intern at the Springhurst Elementary School in Dobbs

LEAD: WARREN CROMARTIE, the former Montreal Expo star who has been playing for the Yomiuri Giants in Japan, was suspended by the league for seven games after he charged out to the mound and punched a pitcher who had hit him with a ball in a game on Thursday. . .. Tatu, the Brazilian-born Dallas Sidekick forward who tosses his shirt into the stands every time he scores a goal, was named the Major Indoor Soccer League's most valuable player for the 1986-87 season after he led the league with 111 points on 38 assists and 73 lost shirts.

LEAD: The marriage of Holley Ann Linscott, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Linscott Jr. of Concord, Mass., to Howard I. Cannon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Cannon of Paramus, N.J., took place last evening at Castle Hill in Ipswich, Mass. Rabbi Allan Press and the Rev. Edward French, an Episcopal minister, officiated.
LEAD: To our children . . . in the hope that they will grow up as we could not . . . equal . . . and understanding.

LEAD: Darryl Strawberry's week of travail ended with more travail tonight when he was struck by a pitched ball, charged the mound, wrestled with Bob Kipper and touched off a tussle between the Mets and Pittsburgh Pirates. And, after all that, he was branded the aggressor and was ejected from the game by the umpires.
LEAD: Political violence began to subside in Panama today, but many stores remained closed and policemen in riot gear were prepared for new outbreaks of protest.

LEAD: The old Royalton Hotel, with its dingy facade, had never commanded much attention on 44th Street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas, a block noted for its illustrious institutions. LEAD: If movies and modeling ever go sour on her, Brooke Shields will have something to fall back on - a degree in Romance languages from Princeton University. Miss Shields, one of the 1,050 members of the class of '87, was graduated from Princeton with honors last week. ''I did it in four years and I worked hard,'' the actress said.
LEAD: It's not often there's a new travel story to be written about the chateaus of the Loire. But then it's not often there's a new chateau to be visited there.
LEAD: Some old friends are back on the home screen this week after a long absence.

LEAD: THE scandals that have plagued the Koch administration and New York City's Democratic Party for the last 18 months have come closer than ever to the Mayor's office at the west end of City Hall.

LEAD: Soviet high school students are more serious, do more homework and have a stronger national pride than their American counterparts, according to members of the first group of American high school students to study in Soviet secondary schools.
